Posts.Content: Hi Bids24  Are you saying your original surgeon didn't even oversee the surgical procedure? I would say this is definite cause to complain. All he had to do was ask if you minded beforehand. What happened to mean that your surgeon couldn't operate? Unless he was ill he needs a flippin good excuse! I guess it depends on how far you want to take it. Are you happy with the end result? Would the end result have been different with the original surgeon? It might be too early to tell.  I waited 10 days for path results. Three weeks seems awhile but he may have been preempting a backlog at the path lab and erring on the side of caution?  As you are discussed weekly at MDT meetings it could be anyone involved with them to give you results. I was fortunate it was my surgeon who gave me mine.  Your care doesn't sound consistent and that's not fair Nor helpful to you. Make it known that's how you feel.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Finding it hard to trust my consultant

Posts.Content: Hello Clare  I was only thinking of you the other day as I had noticed you hadn't been on here for a while.  I do understand the 'the one thing after another' as only yesterday I had to have a bone scan of which I am awaiting results for. I'm 5 months post treatment.  The things I can say that are positive are that they are checking this suspect area out thoroughly. Were any words of comfort given to you after the MRI or any possible reasons for the suspect area? The not knowing really is torture.  To be honest I got so down and fed up with not being me I had to start counselling after treatment and have had 15 sessions which has completely got me back on track. I'm of the opinion that unless I am told I have something that's incurable I will plod on and not worry. The worry and angst quite often is worse than the physical side. I'd had enough of feeling like cr@p but needed psychological help to move on. It may be worth exploring for you.  Anyway, it's good to hear from you again but I'm sorry it's for these reasons.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Cannot move forward

Posts.Content: Are the antibiotics kicking in yet Ali and the symptoms getting any better? This might help the anxiety if you see the anti Bs start to work. Xxx
Posts.Title: re occurance

Posts.Content: Hi mightymouse  See how your belly button continues to heal as I think it's very early days to see the finished article. If you are not happy with it do make it known to your surgeon. Don't accept an appearce you aren't comfortable with. it isn't fickle at all. why shouldn't you feel and look fab in your bikini again because you've had BC. Theres no way on earth I would wear a swimsuit.... mainly due to being just under 6ft and never finding a costume long enough haha.  I was lucky in that my scars made me cry with relief when I saw them and I remember making the very sexist comment that I couldn't believe a man could be so precise with nipples and boobs. he said to me if I wasn't happy then he would relook at more surgery but it didn't go way.  Apparently surgery sites will take up to 12 months to settle.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Navel gazing

Posts.Content: Morning ladies  I would imagine blogging is very cathartic and as you say Liz, you wanted real experiences before starting chemo. As Maggie says though, the problem with this is that chemo is given a bad name most of the time. Good experiences aren't normally documented , it's mainly the bad. I am always reading how ladies and men are dreading chemo and have even declined treatment due to the 'what ifs'. Chemo is such a personal thing that no one can predict how your body will react. A good example is docetaxel. To date I've never read any good experiences. This made me so frightened yet for me it turned out better than FEC. X
Posts.Title: Blogging

Posts.Content: Hi Gaynor  it's still early days after chemo for it to be sepsis. If your chemo was Thursday, take more notice of your temp from Tuesday.  A low temperature can be a sign something is wrong. The only way your mind will be put at rest is if you give the chemo unit a ring. Do you feel shivery and achy?  Taking your temperature can become an addiction so try and limit it. As this is your first cycle this is all new. Next time you will have something to compare.
Posts.Title: Temperature worry

Posts.Content: Hi jj The chemo won't help an already weak back but I would imagine that it isn't helping being sedentary. I know you've said previously you've been in bed after chemo. This won't help a back problem as tight backs like to be moved.  This is a catch 22 as you need to move that back but you may not be feeling well enough after chemo to be active.  I've had lower back problems in the past and found the most helpful treatment is regular (4 times a day) ice pack on the area. I use a frozen gel pack wrapped in a towel.
Posts.Title: FEC and back pain

Posts.Content: Hi Jen  Youve been diagnosed at an early age. I feel for you. I also feel for you in waiting 11 weeks in getting a diagnosis. It's mad.  From seeing your GP you should see a breast consultant within 2 weeks then start treatment around 4 weeks after a diagnosis. however it's only a guideline Which is used as an arguement.  Waiting for an MRI hasn't helped either. I had to have three body scans before I started treatment so it was 6 weeks before I started. Was the MRI because you have lobular cancer?  When you go on 16th March do make your anxiety known. On the basis you've waited many weeks already they should be offering surgery soon. dont think your cancer is growing uncontrollably (we all did it) because it doesn't and the fact you've had an MRI is good because they are making sure they are dealing with just one primary.  All the best  Julia x
Posts.Title: waiting and more waiting :(

Posts.Content: Oksana, I'm sorry to read how I'll informed you were about lymphoedema. I find it quite harsh that your surgeon has asked you to sign a consent form for axilla clearance (assuming you did sign an agreement) and didn't go through the risk of lymphoedema with you. It's one of the most risky side effects from that sort of surgery and in honesty why some ladies are against having clearance. I would raise it as an issue as you can't be signing consent forms without being properly informed. After the event is too late.  love Julia x
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Loolyboo, take some pain relief before the mammo and do tell them you are sore. Ouchy, I feel for you. A good scanographer will only take a minute or so to take the X-ray so fingers crossed you get a good one. love Julia xX
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Hi Loolyboo  I had lymphoedema in the breast. It does present as warm and pink and orange peel skin and will be much bigger than your good breast. It tends to be worse at the end of the day though after you are upright all day and defying gravity. It looks better in the morning. Massage daily towards the good breast - not the axilla site. It is possible this is lymphedema but It can be hard work getting a referral. Click, just to say  that I had odema in the breast and it was successfully treated. I had it for 4 months and have been ok for 18months. The only thing that worked for me is KINESIO taping which I had to get done privately. Odema clinics tend to start with compression bras and bits of bobbly fabric that you wear inside your bra. Neither did anything for me. I am a big advocate of taping and manual drainage. I had very good results. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Loolyboo, take some pain relief before the mammo and do tell them you are sore. Ouchy, I feel for you. A good scanographer will only take a minute or so to take the X-ray so fingers crossed you get a good one. love Julia xX
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Yay Loolyboo  Get in.... get into the paddock and let us welcome you :) what great news. Do the massage every night before sleep with any oil or good moisturiser. I still do this two years on (Without sounding weird!)  If you know anyone that does kinesio taping then go see them as I can highly recommend it for odema in the breast. Worked a treat for me. Ive also found a brilliant multi purpose herbal oil  that smells so good by Lanolips. You can get it in Waitrose. Go celebrate your good news. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Hi Jackie  Another TNBC girlie here too, or rather I was. Diagnosed June 14. Now 5 months post treatment. There has to be a point in which you stop worrying over the what ifs. That can happen consciously or subconsciously.  I had a pathological complete resonse (PCR) to chemo. If your tumour can't be felt at this point there is every chance come lumpectomy that you will have no cancer cells left whatsoever. You won't know that however until after sugery. That is the best outcome you can hope for and you are on the way to achieving this! That HAS to be a good sign and a good indication of prognosis. Please take it as a good sign. Also as JJ says, you don't need a MX. If there are no cancer cells left in your body at this moment.... It can't spread. Chemo has worked on you as the tumour has gone.  Dontread the negative stuff about TNBC if it makes you feel worse during this time. Read the positive things ( research what the prognosis is if you have a PCR from chemo. That will definitely lift you) from all those TN survivors out there. Trust me, when treatment finishes you will learn to live again. It doesn't happen overnight but I do not have the fear I did have. I had the best possible outcome and I now look after myself, the rest is down to my immune system.  Mention your veins in your pre op assessment. If it is a problem it can be overcome with warning.  Take the time between now and 2nd sept to enjoy life, make the most of your days before you feel sore from the operation.  It gets better Jackie x
Posts.Title: Any Triple Negative survivors willing to calm me down!!??

Posts.Content: Can you not use an old passport photo? Do you have a wig that's close to your normal look?  I agree, to have it as a reminder isn't good but I would use my previous photo.
Posts.Title: here's a weird question

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4  Are you planning your end of treatment party already ;)  This really will depend on how you respond to chemo. I had a 10 week gap between chemo and surgery (over Christmas) but it was known after chemo it looked like I had had a pcr so surgery wasn't time critical. If you don't get a good response then surgery will happen sooner. i had a 8 week gap between surgery and radiotherapy. The wait had no detrimental affect it also meant my recovery in between treatment was very good love Julia x
Posts.Title: Gap between chemo and surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Morning Jojo4  Youve written these words down for the world to see now so it's time to act on them. I too, really hope you can act on what you say because Christmas is a time for family and feeling content. You are still here and you are being treated. That's what matters at the moment. As worried2016 says so rightly, don't give yourself the opportunity to look back on this Christmas and say that was a shite time. Make it count.  Instead of feeling sorry you missed the out on the school celebrations make celebrations with your children and husband at home. These are the people that will get you through treatment. School will still be there when you are ready to return. Yes people have survived grade 3, multiple tumours and people are also still surviving worse diagnosis.  You yourself have said how well your body responded to the first chemo. I'd say you were very fortunate as I've never known nausea like I had on FEC. It was dibilitating. So do focus on how much worse it could be if only to make you feel like you are doing pretty darn good.  You are the one that's stopping yourself from living at the moment.  Concentrate on chemo and having a memorable Christmas for the right reasons.  Time is very precious, trust me. love Julia x
Posts.Title: New day, new attitude

Posts.Content: Hi Oksana  I don't think Lymphoedema is taboo as we are made aware of these risks very well. I even had to attend a lymphoedema workshop after surgery. Almost to the point it panicked me!  The difficulty is that swelling is expected after surgery. Where tissue is removed in a WLE and axilla clearance you are left with vacuums. These fill with fluid .... the reasons why some people still have drains after clearance. That's a normal process of the body dealing with these Vacuums. seromas are common where and how you describe.  lymphoedema presents in a slightly different way. I had lymphoedema in the breast which was treated successfully but it wasn't diagnosed until 6 months post surgery. Are you massaging your breast daily? Light massage towards the good breast is good to get the fluid draining again. Your body has to adjust now you have fewer nodes.  It takes time. Rest assured if you are diagnosed with lymphoedema then you will get a referral to a clinic.  Love Julia x

Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: I had surgery 20 months ago and the GA was a concern for me. It needn't have been though. You will meet you anaesthetist before surgery and they can put your mind at rest with the types of GA they use and why most nowadays don't cause sickness. I was very sick on chemo but not after the GA. I did eat quite soon after though (toast) as was flippin starving after not eating for so long. Having an empty tum can make sickness worse. So have something to eat and for me a cup of tea always does the trick!  I was pleasantly surprised how good I felt after surgery.  All the best with it. Julia X

Posts.Content: I finished Rt in March and have the same symptoms too.  I assumed it was from surgery and RT but was recently told it was lymphoedema. It's only in the breast not the arm. They can then refer to a lymphoedema specialist. It could be a number of things so best get it checked and err on the side of caution.
Posts.Title: question

Posts.Content: Hi Judith Thanks for the info in the Lymphoedema website. I was wondering if you had already received the fact sheet as it looks like you have to order and pay for them? Even though my consultant said I had lymphoedema in the breast he also said it was too early to get referred to our local lympo clinic. I am 7 months post sugery, 3 months post RT. I have been doing self massage which has helped a lot but I am going on holiday to hotter climes in August and have read that temperature can make the swelling worse. Thank you julia

Posts.Content: Thanks Judith and Kate I am going to go back and say I want to be referred. Im struggling with my consultant/surgeon at the mo as he is not helpful at all now treatment is over. The lymphoedema clinic is also at our local Hospice which also doesn't help as I hate going there!! Thanks Ladies xx
Posts.Title: question

Posts.Content: Hi naziai  I can understamd why you find  it hard to be looking and feeling at the mx sites as its a lot to get use to however without regular checking you aren't able to determine what normal feels like for you. I had a WLE but check myself every week. I know what Normal feels like for me.  What you are feeling could indeed be perfectly normal for you. Are you due a follow up appointment with your surgeon/onc soon? You could ask then or make an appointment with your GP so they can check it out. You need peace of mind. UnderstandablY.  Your BC nurse can advise on how you can do physical examinations. We were given a training session on physical examination and it helped me take control hugely.  All the best. Julia X
Posts.Title: Is it back ?

Posts.Content: If you mean me Denzil ? ............................... Number 11 'You will be fine. Its not like breast cancer is real cancer is it'
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Hi helsbels18  Survival is measured from when you are first diagnosed.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Question about survival stats

Posts.Content: I can totally relate to the cliches you have been on the reveicing end of.  I have met and talked to many people who have had a cancer diagnosis and it's a common theme, how they are put out by what people say to them.  Pre cancer use to be me. I never knew what to say to people in my life who had cancer. I even went out of my way to not speak about it for fear of not knowing what to say. And I didn't want to talk about it. I wonder how many of us were like that or have we always been totally empathetic. It's only now due to our experiences we can relate.  Now, through no fault of our own, we have experience of cancer and we should now know how to communicate with others who have gone through the same thing. Everyone is different though so what might be acceptable to one won't be to the other.  I truely believe that people don't know what or how to say things to you but they want to speak to you so mouth engages before brain. It's not they purposely want to make you feel crap.
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Karen and Ali your posts made me smile and smile hard I did.  We are alive and can write to tell the tale.  Whether we have endured treatment after treatment or are on hormonal therapies which make us feel crap, we are still here.  Its a question of what is the lesser of the evils?  There is light Lorraine, hang on in there X
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Hello berren  welcome to the club. That is good news on the liver. Waiting for those results are horrendous. I've been there.  We do have lymph nodes around the breast bone at the base of the neck. If it's glands that raise when you have a sore throat it maybe just a sore throat? Mention it to your consultant. Your treatment must be due to start soon? we imagine every ailment is cancer spreading on diagnosis and for a lot longer after but it's much more not the case than is the case. Cancer doesn't reproduce at the lighting speed we imagine.  Your consultant will assure you.
Posts.Title: Liver scan

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy d  I don't have acrylics done but I do have manicures And I am at risk of odema. The trick is to choose a reputable salon where you can see good hygiene and the staff are trained. I took a risk once and went to a particular cheaper quick and easy place and it was a big mistake. When they did my cuticles they did so until they bled. That's the risk. I never went back. I would have them done Especially for hols. Just take some emergency anti biotics with you on hols just in case. To be honest I do regardless on holiday anyway. Have a fantastic time Julia x
Posts.Title: Lymphodema and acrylic nails

Posts.Content: O ronstar, I feel for you and I also LOVE your little disclaimer at the bottom of your post. Holding still in that tight position is difficult at the best of times. I've used diclofenic before and it works a treat. Keep the shoulders moving and I really hope tomorrow is easier for you. Hugs Julia x
Posts.Title: Just some letting off steam after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Dash  George has recently used this as an aide memoire http://dudleygroup.nhs.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Food-safety-advice-for-patients-having-chemotherapy-V3.pdf If you feel you do need refreshing on information please do ask your chemo nurses as they can give another blue book (some use other colours). I did find mine very useful at times.  Will be thinking of you next week. julia X
Posts.Title: Best food to eat and food to avoid

Posts.Content: Hi Ange  when you say you had a CT scan do you mean the breast ct scan to plan your measurements for RT? This is the planning scan? In which case your bones may not have influenced the change in drug as the scan wouldn't specifically looked at your bones.   You do need to know why the booster sessions have been added but to be fair I don't think it would have been to do with todays ct scan. 15 or 20 sessions is the norm but 24 seems a lot. You haven't enrolled in a trial? I'm guessing you will only receive peace of mind when you get your BCN/oncologist to explain. We have all been there. Got home and thought why didn't I ask that. Phone tomorrow. Don't dwell over the weekend.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: change of treatment plan after ct scan. what do you think?

Posts.Content: Hi Jackie  If you are ready to wear it again then I would go ahead. Personally I have changed what deodorant I use now I'm post BC and use only natural products. The less chemicals in a product the kinder it is too skin and post surgery that may make a difference to you.  julia
Posts.Title: Deodorant

Posts.Content: Hi Fairyelephant   Welcome to the site. You may get a better response starting a new thread with this but I'll answer anyway to try and help.  im sorry you find yourself in this situation But it's good things are being checked. It's important. There are a few stages to the breast unit referral. You will get physically examined, then a mammogram then possibly an US and biopsy. They don't always do a biopsy if they can rule the worst out but if you do get to that stage do be asking questions if you need to. I had an US as well as mammogram As they can look at lymph nodes via this method if needed. You will get the mammo for sure Though. some clinics don't give results the same day. I waited 10 days. You will need to ask if you can record any conversation. It's good to always take someone with you and do ask to be copied into any correspondence written about you.  This is a crap time For you. Your mum will be a great support to you. You will feel like it's wait wait wait.  Im heading towards two years post diagnosis and was successfully treated. BC is very treatable but let's not jump the gun.  Please do come back and let us know how you get on and I send you all Good wishes love.  Julia X  ps take some pain relief before you go to the appointment just incase as the biopsy can hurt. X
Posts.Title: First appointment Tomorrow

Posts.Content: The feeling of it being worse at night Apoole72 is a classic oedema symptom. Gravity has meant the swelling is worse because youve been upright all day. in the morning after lying down it will feel better.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer and operation

Posts.Content: Hello Pat Could it be to do with any other rmedication you may have started taking? Ive just had a liver function test as I have started taking statins. I know some other meds effect liver function -  a bit like when  were tested before each chemo session. Did your Doctor offer any possible reasons or futher tests required? Congrats on your 1st birthday. Mine is this weekend. Any reason to eat cake :)
Posts.Title: liver function tests.

Posts.Content: Hi smitten  As your surgeon has said as its your good breast it shouldn't be RT side effects unless the measurements were way way out which is highly unlikely.  I might have said this before but lymphoedema in the breast causes pinkness swelling, hotness and orange peel skin. It also gets worse by the end of the day due to gravity working its magic. I had odema in the breast and by night time the breast was so firm and pink and bigger than the opposite one.  Is your breast much better in the morning?  it is unusual for it to happen in your good side but I just wanted to say that lymphoedema can cause symptoms very similar to IBC. Julia
Posts.Title: Any one got experience of inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Ed Yourhead must be all over the place. Have the bowel consultants discussed the possibility of cancer or are you preempting the reason for the test? To have twoprimary cancers (breast and bowel) must be very rare? I had a colonoscopy 12 months pre BC diagnosis which was totally unconnected. It turned out I had piles caused by long distance running. This In turn caused blood. understandably you don't want to worry family at this stage because you don't know what your dealing with. Try and look at the positives. It's good that the consultants are being thorough. the other positive thing, unlike bC, you should know the results of the test whilst they do it. Mine talked through what he was seeing, you can even watch it all on the big screen although I'm not recommending it! All the best for Tuesday.
Posts.Title: Feeling down

Posts.Content: Hi Apoole72  Swelling is normal after surgery especially when nodes are taken. Your body has to learn to work with fewer lymph nodes and that readjustment takes time. Odema is normal. Sometimes it becomes persistent and can develop into lymphoedema. Doing your exercises is key and gently massage the skin towards the good boob if you can bare to touch it yet. you should still be seeing your surgeon/bc nurse? So they can say what's normal or not. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Breast cancer and operation

Posts.Content: Hi Fluff99  I was tested too. It was a negative.  After I sent the forms off I had to wait until they offered an appointment which was around 2 months. The appointment was then a counselling session first then the blood test only if you are happy to go ahead. The results do take an age and are posted to you. Mine took three months. It's a shame testing isn't done earlier to avoid multipe surgeries, where it's needed. i find the nurse who did mine very informative and kind. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Brca 1 ... the journey .... chemotherapy and more !

Posts.Content: Hi Trojan50  This is certainly a dilemma. ive had lobular triple neg BC which I had chemo, surgery and RT for. My brca result was negative. (41 yrs old on diagnosis). My own opinion is that preventative surgery is still the optimum for brca positive. I would be happier with a bilateral mx.  As Lynn says, there are options regarding reconstruction but be guided sensibly by your surgeon.  i would be asking more questions about chemo if you are ER+ only. Ask what benefit it would give over and above hormonal therapies. The hormonal therapies are key but do come with side effects due to suppressing oestrogen. They are given over 5 years but some now over 10 so do check what length of time you would need to take them. On the basis that even with no ovaries to produce oestrogen, you developed BC, so need those hormonal therapies.  Rt in comparison to chemo isn't bad just very time consuming and you can only be zapped in one area once so you wouldn't be able to have more in the future.  All the best with your decision making. I took weeks to decide on surgery with many visits to my surgeon. don't feel rushed making it. love  Julia x ps life post bc for me...... much more fullfing than pre
Posts.Title: Brca 1 ... the journey .... chemotherapy and more !

Posts.Content: Hello Fluff99  Having gone through the Brca testing myself i dont think your husband can be critised for what he is saying. Saying that, having things sprung on you is never easy so i appreciate this is a complete U turn in your treatment. I always knew i needed to be tested as was deemed at risk.  The genetics nurse would have explained both outcomes of the test to you and you have to consent to the blood being taken. I am at risk from a heredity brain disorder that killed my father and his twin sister. I decided i do not want to know if I carry that gene mutation (notch3) as there is no cure or preventative treatment for it. If i have the mutation i will get the disease andI can't live waiting to die.   With the brca1/2 mutation test there is preventative treatment available but only if you consent to it. But thats a positive.... there is preventative treatment just like hormonal therapies but unfortuntely it includes more surgery.   you have already got two different professional opinions on your risk of carrying the gene mutatuon so already its not stacking up In the genes favour. I tested negative and waited three months fpr results. It was a huge releif but i tried to think of a positive result as a continuation of the treatment. I also needed to know if i carried the gene mutation so i could draw a line under it either way. i really will keep my fingers crossed for a negative result for you. If you think negatively about this test then 8 weeks is a long time to be holding onto those feelings. sending hugs Julia x
Posts.Title: Brca 1 ... the journey .... chemotherapy and more !

Posts.Content: Hi H Sorry to read of your Mums diagnosis and good on you for getting stuck into the advice. I had TNBC too and had chemo first. I waited just over 10 weeks between chemo and surgery and it had no detrimental affect however it turned out I had had a pathological complete response to chemo so all cancer cells had gone after chemo. I don't think 7 weeks and 4 days will be detrimental at all. The good news is that after 7 weeks your Mum will have recovered better from chemo than she would have at 4-6 weeks so will be in better shape for surgery. So many of us on diagnosis think we will be better off having a bilateral MX. I was one. Having a healthy breast removed reduces another primary BC but will have no affect on whether a secondary cancer happens or not. Its harsh but I was told by my surgeon having both breasts removed did not mean I would not die of BC. I rethought my decision and had a WLE and have no regrets. I am left with both breasts without much sign of surgery. It is very difficult to listen to others when you are going through BC. I completely understand that you and other family members would say have a bilateral but when you have to make the decision yourself its very tough. The surgery itself is more complex and more things can go wrong. You also have to figure out how it will feel to no longer have your breasts. It may sound easy to say take them away but its not. I would go with what the surgeon is suggesting. I was told that RT does come with a slight risk of causing another cancer so its always possible that your Mums first round of RT was an aggravating factor but something you can never prove unfortunately. All the best for surgery. I hope it all goes to plan whatever the decision. Julia x
Posts.Title: Never posted before - Mum has TNBC advice needed pls asap

Posts.Content: Hi Ruby  The wait for results is horrible but as has recently been said on here, whilst you are waiting for tomorrow's rain you are missing todays sunshine. The worry and anxiety will otherwise End up presenting itself in other ways. If it is BC, as Pat says, it sounds very early stages. Until you are given the results try and fool your brain that nothing has changed. You will have been waiting a long time for the results, does your breast care unit not provide cover for consultants? It doesn't seem very fair. I have seen many locums when my consultant has been away.  all the best for the 28th x
Posts.Title: mammo found clusters of microcalcifications. Very scared!

Posts.Content: My view is the same unfortunately. Swimming was definitely off for me as I had a PICC line so couldn't get it wet. As Vonnie says, pools aren't the cleanest of places and as it's advisable to avoid close contact with the public whilst on chemo, swimming in water shared by others is a risk.  Have a lovely time. It's great you are holidaying during chemo. Just what you need x
Posts.Title: swimmimg whilst having chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Judy  Sorry to read you are having to go through more tests. Preventative bilateral Mxs are normally carried out for Brca gene mutation carriers on the basis it reduces the risk of having primary BC. However as we already have or have had BC specialists will argue that mx is often over treatment  and will make no difference to wether the BC comes back elsewhere in our bodies. Do check with your specialist if they are saying it doesn't help recurrence in the breast or secondary recurrence elsewhere in the body.  Mxs are given where there are large tumours or multiple cancer sites. I was going to have a mx but neoadjuvant chemo meant my tumour disappeared by the time I came to have surgery so I opted for a WLE. Clear margins were obtained so I knew the rest of my breast tissue was cancer free.  I am very comfortable with the decision I made as my breast looks like it did pre BC and they are both still equal.  You always have a choice but the results from the next biopsie will dictate surgery to a large extent. If the tests reveal nothing suspicious then in my experience do trust the WLE if that's all they are suggesting.
Posts.Title: Smells and tastes

Posts.Content: Both my relatives who had BC and ovarian had died. Tests on other family members  don't have to have been carried out To establish a brca fault. The team confirm via death records that the relatives did die of what you say they died of. with living relatives they don't test them. As long as they establish a good link and identify a risk of it being genetic you will get tested.  J xx
Posts.Title: Brca 1 ... the journey .... chemotherapy and more !

Posts.Content: Hi Chris1962  Once you have the NHS prescription for the wig you are free to choose where to go. I used the  House of Fraser wig concession. I liked the hot hair styles.  Your local cancer support centre may offer fitting services but I found the choice of wigs limited.  Do ask at your chemo unit where local options are as they should be more than familiar. Failing that Google wig services in your area, just double check they take NHS prescriptions.   One word of caution though... don't get sucked in to buying shampoos, conditioners, sprays etc etc as they aren't covered and I ended up with about 6 bottles of stuff I 'apparently' needed that coat a small fortune. Funnily enough two years on I've just chucked them out unused!!! love Julia x
Posts.Title: Wig advice

Posts.Content: I never asked the radiographer doing the scans/biopsie what he was seeing despite it turning really serious in the room and getting to the biopsie stage. I knew that indicated the worse but knew if It was confirmed then I would worry even more before I was officially told and had the way forward described. Try turning things on their head. If you were told during the biopsie it was BC but no further information was given about treatment etc or any how would you now feel.  As for being prepared for cancer...... It's not human instinct to be prepared for this kind of cr&£. There are protocols about giving diagnosis so it's likely the doctor doing the tests wasn't trained to do that or even make that judgement on whether it was definitely BC or not.  BC has taken a year of my life but if that gives me many more years on this planet (I was 41 when diagnosed) then it was so worth it.  X
Posts.Title: mammo found clusters of microcalcifications. Very scared!

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy  I am not taking any hormone or biological therapies (triple neg). I put on a stone during treatment, most of it after chemo. I Absolutely hated it. Even Refused to buy any bigger clothes as I only saw it as temporary. I finished treatment in March and have almost lost the weight and back to my normal weight. Mainly cause I am going on holiday next week!  I do the 5:2 which I feel great on cause I only have to be good for 2 days a week. I do high impact exercise daily which was what I did pre cancer. For me the hardest side effects of BC was hair loss and weight gain but I am slowly feeling in control of that now.  I've just found out that I am going through the menopause at 42years which is chemo related and makes me even more conscious about my size.
Posts.Title: Weight loss after chemo radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy  I am not taking any hormone or biological therapies (triple neg). I put on a stone during treatment, most of it after chemo. I Absolutely hated it. Even Refused to buy any bigger clothes as I only saw it as temporary. I finished treatment in March and have almost lost the weight and back to my normal weight. Mainly cause I am going on holiday next week!  I do the 5:2 which I feel great on cause I only have to be good for 2 days a week. I do high impact exercise daily which was what I did pre cancer. For me the hardest side effects of BC was hair loss and weight gain but I am slowly feeling in control of that now.  I've just found out that I am going through the menopause at 42years which is chemo related and makes me even more conscious about my size.
Posts.Title: Weight loss after chemo radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi weeble  I'm with Maggie, I think if it looks like it's turning nasty that's the time to go to the GP. I personally don't think taking antibiotics 'just in case' is good for you as your body may just be one immune to them. Give the scratches a good wash like we would have done pre BC and whack on some antiseptic x
Posts.Title: Cuts and scratches

Posts.Content: Hi Shaz The proposed treatment will depend on the type of BC you have. What ER, PR and HER2 status are you? Are you having neo adjuvant chemo to try and shrink the tumour so that you can have breast conservation surgery? There will be reasons, it's probably just that you haven't had all the answers from your oncologist yet.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy and Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Pauline  im 15 months post chemo and my eyebrows are not nearly as full as they were pre chemo.  I've used Marvala eyelash (always for brows) Double lash. its helped but nothing has worked Completely.  do check out eyebrow tattoo images before you decide as they are quite severe but also very effective.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Eye brow regrowth.

Posts.Content: Hi Cocopops1  Yes this sounds like a receptionist who thinks they are a medic too. You could at least be offered a telephone consultation with your doctor. I email my GP. She was excellent at isduting notes. I didnt see her personally once it was all done via email and phone. julia x
Posts.Title: Angry over sick note

Posts.Content: Hi Maggie  It's worth getting it checked clinically. It could be lymphoedema/odema. I have it in my breast and it's sore and sensitive but it's also swollen compared to my other breast.
Posts.Title: Pain a while after op

Posts.Content: Yay JMC04, what fantastic and o so positive news.  Keep going girl. Love julia xx
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: Morning Elaine  i had lymphoedema in my breast of which made the skin feel thicker and tighter. It was also swollen.  Your appointment today will put your mind at rest. There are many things after RT surgery and chemo that change the breast.  Julia
Posts.Title: thickening of skin on breast, bc side.

Posts.Content: Hi QuietRose  This negative association is is quite common. I would speak to your chemo nurses as they will be very familiar with it and no doubt have tips to help. I had a problem with the epruibicin. It's red and so red that I associated it with danger and if I saw it in the syringe, would get sick. I had a soap at home I had to chuck  out as I developed an association with sickness and this soap. if I could smell it I would be sick. The smell of the chemo unit would also do it. Even the smell of my kitchen made me sick it was weird.  You need some help to turn it into disassociation and that will be by mental processes and distraction . You need a thought strategy to concentrate on whilst you have the drugs. But not being able to see the drugs might help. Not looking at what's going on helps. You could try headphones and eyes closed or a eye mask on.  good luck with it. It's a common thing so the unit will be able to help no doubt. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Psychological revulsion towards intravenous drugs

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline  i can relate to what to you are saying about the first follow up oncologist appointment. I had high expectations that weren't meet so now I have no idea expectations and I feel much better about appointments. I'm being seen every three months so it helps with any anxietys. You are in the best place whilst having counselling.  Regarding the scans, these are only undertaken if there is an ongoing problem that needs checking out or you take drugs that could affect the heart or bones.  If you think rationally about having a scan though, if you had one and a week later got a all clear result, for how long would that clear result appease your anxiety? A couple of months I am guessing before you would want another. It would be a vicious cycle. Ultimately you could pay privately for a scan but how much help would it be in the long term. Learning to trust your body again is the key. As life moves on and you get more involved in life again the less the anxieties get.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Seeing Oncologist - what will it involve?

Posts.Content: Wishing you a very happy birthday. Birthdays for me are very cherished. Birthdays mean you are getting older and that means you are living. You will be here next birthday. Don't fear. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Birthday

Posts.Content: Wishing you a very happy birthday. Birthdays for me are very cherished. Birthdays mean you are getting older and that means you are living. You will be here next birthday. Don't fear. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Birthday

Posts.Content: JJ you have been through so much. Give the bc unit a ring in the morning amd take it from there. it maybe normal after surgery but new to you as you are feeling it for the first time.  Hugs  julia
Posts.Title: Panicking another lump

Posts.Content: Hi peaches  I think if you were on a taxane you could attribute the pain to that. I have a long term back problem which docetaxol made worse. I found chemo made my joints more spongy and susceptible to pain. The pain in your calf is probably secondary to the problem in the hip as its all connected. Is your lower back ok? Is it a sports injury? Keeping sedentary isn't good for muscles and joints as they need to be keep free by moving but can appreciate that the pain isn't allowing you to do this. Have you tried hip flexor stretches? U tube is full of stretches for hips. Foam rollers are a godsend also as they home in on problem areas. Do you have a good massage therapist that can help? If it continues then it is worth seeing a physiotherapist as they can assess if its major or minor damage. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Leg pain, advice needed

Posts.Content: Hi Fluff99  You are right, this is still very early days for you and when you are still in pain this will do nothing to lift your emotional state. If you remember it's at least three weeks post last chemo when your body is picking up again (the length of time between each cycle). How were you feeling 11 days on after the previous chemo sessions? I did access counselling 3 months post treatment finish because my everyday life was being affected. I had no problems whatsoever about going or asking for help. I knew I needed it.  At the moment I would suggest you are still feeling rubbish due to chemo not due to not being able to move on. The healing process takes time.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Moving on, counselling?

Posts.Content: I was 41 on diagnosis. My NHS trust only screen every two years for bc patients. I fought hard against this and asked for a mammogram every year which was accepted. you don't need to turn up for the appointment but having had bc once I would think twice. Early detection is key. im really not sure if there is any hard and fast data out there that does support the statement that to much radiation causes other cancers. What's too much? I've been led to believe that mammo machines nowadays expose you to very low levels of radiation. not much more than that of the surrounding environment We live in. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Mammograms are they needed every year

Posts.Content: Personally I think she has spoken to soon and as already implied on here, sooner or later she will find that its not so 'doable'. Maybe in her opinion the MX was 'doable' but I would challenge her to come back after chemotherapy and RT and tell the rest of the world its doable so get over it! You would also question why you would almost 'brag' about a MX being ok. Does she think she is such a role model that we will all follow in her footsteps and go into such an operation with a smile on our faces because VD says its all ok? She will no doubt at some stage eat her words but then again I trust nothing that is reported. PS I would not wish chemo on anyone but it will be interesting to see if her hair loss is as well documented as her MX
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: Hi jojomomo  I can understand your apprehensions based upon the healing issues you have had. I too found RT the most uncomplicated treatment out of the three. With you I would imaging they will keep a close eye on you and you must show the radiographers any signs of damage as it happens. For me it was a bad sunburn but not until a week post it finishing. For the first couple of weeks I didn't feel much apart from the odd twinge. All the best Julia x
Posts.Title: 1st Radiotherapy session tomorrow...really scared

Posts.Content: Morning peachesxxx  I can totally see why you are thinking flippin heck what next. Thank goodness you had the opticians appointment though. I don't know much about diabeties. I'm sure you know of ways to reduce your BP and blood sugar though? Were the chemo unit not bothered about the high BP? You need to check next Wednesday that they are happy to commence with the bleed risk.    is there room for one small one more in the caravan hehe? It sounds lovely and as you say, just what you need. Speak to hubby on the phone and get it all out and let him listen. I bet he feels bad about being away from you at this time. Hugs and love to you Jo julia X
Posts.Title: So fed up

Posts.Content: Hi GMc  I can't pretend I wasn't hard on my partner of 9 years during treatment because I was. I was scared and I couldn't cope with him showing any signs of being scared Or emotional. He also came and lived with me and looked after my 9 year old with me which caused friction too. I look back now and feel embarrassed by how I was at times. However we got through treatment In one piece.  It didn't end happily ever after though because we did end up splitting up 6 months after treatment finished. I was of the opinion that as we had got through cancer we could get through anything and I felt closer to my man. He didn't feel the same. It took a lot out of him and he walked away. Listen to your wife vent, tell her you understand and you are always in sickness and in health. See how you both feel when treatment ends. It will either all be brushed under the carpet and you move on together or it maybe a time when as George says, you take stock of what you have and what you haven't got In the relationship.  its true when they say we hurt those close to us the most. I would be more worried if your wife stops communicating all together. Never a good sign. All the best. I know from experience how tough it can be. Julia
Posts.Title: Emotions

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly  This topic comes up a lot on this forum, understandably, as if like me, look forward to a glass of wine, it would be hard to ban it. If we put BC aside for a moment and look at The recommended weekly units of alcohol for both men and women, they have been put in place for a reason. The more we drink the more we put our health at risk.  I have always been very health and exercise conscious but did drink around 20 units of wine per week. I now only drink a bottle (10 units). I've even made more changes to my diet since diagnosis but for me it's always been a big part of my life so they aren't drastic changes for me. I made these changes even though I was triple neg and there is no evidence that alcohol affects triple neg bc.  I have met many ladies who carry on smoking after BC and are overweight and never exercise but are happy that way and there is a lot to be said for self happiness. Others I've met have changed lifestyles completely as it's been a wake up call and have felt and looked the better for it.  If you gave up alcohol completely would it make you miserable? If so consider sticking within the recommended limits for other health benefits as well as lowering your chance of recurrence.  There is much more evidence that says being physically active after BC lowers your chance of recurrence and for me it's much more achievable than giving up the wine!  As sister snail says, you do what makes you the most happy  x
Posts.Title: Measures to prevent breast cancer recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi Crystal kitty  Good to see you pop in again and see us it's just a shame it's worrying circumstances for you. I am having an ultrasound on 22 no for the same reason only i have a lump low down in my neck and no cold however the GP thought it more than likely to be a lipoma. That's good enough for me! I can't bear worrying anymore so I tend to switch off. The best you can do is getting it checked out which you are doing. Nodes at the back of the ears are less worrying than those lower in the neck/along the collar bone. I know it's hard not to think the worse but I really do send you positive vibes as there is nothing worse than persistent anxiety and when you get the all clear you will say to yourself what a waste of emotion worrying over nothing. It's a good thing we are in tune with our bodies I'm certainly more in tune with mine than pre BC.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Painful neck after bad cold ....

Posts.Content: Hello Ck A warm welcome to this friendly forum.  Deginately a slip up here as you should have verbally had the results given by your consultant first. However as you received a cc letter your have probably asked to be copied in to all correspondence written about you? I did and it helped as the letters where more comprehensive than what the consultant told me face to face.  It's always shocking seeing a result written down though.  Get on to you breast care unit and ask that you receive results verbally and get more info on your diagnosis. Invasive BC means its not longer 'in situ' but broken out into either the milk ducts it lobules. The results also indicate the cancer cells have travelled to your lymph nodes. Don't view this as a negative as the lymph nodes are like sieves they drain out the good and bad so the cancer cells have been caught. That's the reason you have had body scans, just to check your treatment will he for primary BC only.  The MRI on the other breast maybe because you have invasive lobular BC? Has that been mentioned?  This is one hell of a learning curve and a awful time. Keep posting. We will support you and answer any questions you have.  All the best X  Ps grade 2 is the intermediate level. Grade 3 being the high grade, grade 1 the low grade.
Posts.Title: New to the site after being diagnosed with breast cancer a week a...

Posts.Content: Full clearance doesn't always mean every node is removed....only those surrounding the affected node/s. I had 11 removed 20 months ago and never had a problem. If you are fit and active and a healthy weight then your chances of Lymphoedema are reduced. You can have RT to the Axilla. Having immediate results can be good but it also means you could wake up finding they have removed more nodes than you have hoped. It's a gamble But you need to weigh up which risk is greater to you... The risk of lymphoedema or the possibility of cancer cells being left in the nodes. Do ask about rt to the Axilla though. Julia X
Posts.Title: I dont want a Total Axial Node Clearance - what are my options?

Posts.Content: Hi Mildred  As you are anxious about secondaries even before you treatment has ended you need to nip it in the bud as it will get out of hand.  At the moment you are sensitive to every ache and pain but you need your brain to put perspective on it. Tamoxifen causes all sorts of bone and joint pain along with a whole host of other side affects. It's bound to be the drug.  It's unlikely you will be offered a ct scan although it's worth mentioning the back pain. You won't be able to sustain scan after scan after every ailment. Anxiety has to be learnt to be managed.  Trusting your body is he hardest but best thing you can do.  Your cancer was grade 1 and I'm assuming no nodes were affected due to you not mentioning chemo? Grab hold of the positives. Secondaries in your case are statistically not going to happen.  It won't help if you aren't getting out and about having 'you' time. Do try and squeeze this in. Most BC units run a moving in course. I would recommend this. You will then see we ALL have the same worries. How long we let them affect us is the key thing.  I'm 9 months post treatment now and time is a great healer. Your anxiety will lessen but at the moment you have another hurdle. That hurdle will be finishing treatment. That's the hard bit... Being let lose back into the wilderness.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Cant stop worrying about secondaries

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass  im sorry to hear you have this level of pain. is the pain a SE of hormonal therapies? Or chemo? i think you need to decice what you want fixed First. The pain or the way you are feeling? (I know they are closely linked) It is tricky for a GP because most of the time drugs are trial and error. You have to find one your body likes.  Could you switch brands of hormonal therapy? can you ask for help to get you sleeping better? can you ask for something to give your mood a lift? can she signpost you for counselling or through Your BC nurse? Have you found exercise helpful in managing pain?  Have you access to a moving on course? They deal with this topic amongst other helpful ones. semding hugs Julia x
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Hi Mand  If you do a search on cold cap on this forum you will get loads of previous discussions.  I would say more don't than do but those that have have managed not to lose all their hair  it just 'thins'. By all accounts it is uncomfortable.  I never considered the cold cap even though my hair was my pride and joy. It felt like I would be messing with the chemotherapys journey around my body if I wore the cap and I didn't want that. I was only bald for 6 months.  Worth trying if you really want to keep your hair but do be prepared for it not to work despite perseverance.  all the best on your chemo journey. julia X
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Morning Mand Of course, ask away. It was my oncologist that said to me that in his opinion the chemo should be aloud to go around the whole body and not to interfere with that process around the head. I was triple neg so would take no chances. I always knew chemo was my best defence. There's no evidence to back up what he was saying it was just his opinion which was enough for me. Hair loss is the biggest thing for us ladies because it strips us of identity but as I said it is only temporary and nowadays you see it so often it's not such a effort to be out in public.  Julia X
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: I can't disagree with that Little Wombat. You must be drained. What a flippin long wait.  Fingers crossed the biopsies comes back with nothing sinister. great they've got you back tomorrow. Any indication on when the results can be back Next week?  Im not sure what machine they are referring to in London but would imagine some hitec piece of kit that isn't used countrywide.  Its better to get it all checked out now rather than get nasty surprises during surgery. When the surgeon knows exactly what he's dealing with he can advise the best course of surgery. a WLE could still be on the cards due to the size of the lesions.  Its back to that awful waiting game again.  Fingers crossed for tomorrow X
Posts.Title: WHAT QUESTIONS SHOULD I BE ASKING

Posts.Content: We will always listen Little Wombat. I have been on the path you are beating your way through now. I had to have MRi's, bone scan and a CT scan before my treatment started because there was a risk of secondary's on diagnosis. I used to feel physically sick whilst waiting for these results.  Turns out I had one solitary tumor with one affected node. That didn't stop my head from telling me I was dying. What I will say is that BC is so very treatable. It sounds so flippant but its true. I am two years post diagnosis. I had an 9 year girl to take care of. It was just me and her at home. The best advice I was given was 'this will take up to 12 months out of your life'. I remember thinking ' you are flipping joking'. They weren't wrong. I didn't work for 11 months. I had chemo, surgery and radiotherapy then months of counseling. Its a tough time. I would say its unrealistic that you will be joining the school at the start of Autumn term in September. Coping in the holidays is a very valid worry. This is time to call on friends and family to help out. You wont be able to maintain a good and consistent level of care for four kids. (Respect to you for doing this now). Hubby will have to take on being the strong one whilst you get this done. You never know he might actually enjoy the challenge. You have to be honest about what you need though and men like lists of things they can do to help. You are very right in that this will be a time when you see people for what they really mean to you. I was lucky in that I had a couple of close friends who carried me through treatment. For that I am always grateful. Keep someone close because you will need to talk and be allowed to talk. Don't keep those anxieties rattling around in your head. Julia x_
Posts.Title: WHAT QUESTIONS SHOULD I BE ASKING

Posts.Content: It really is a personal choice based upon what our consultants are telling us and our gut feelings. As I said, being triple neg I wouldnt take any chances. Triple neg secondaries Are more likely in the soft organs and brain rather than bones. Taking hormonal therapies after treatment is different because it gives continued protection.  It's really worth trying the cap and if you don't get on with it then you can stop.  J X
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Hello Little Wombat  The waiting is the pits. this will be the worst waiting however, getting to know exactly What's what. You have two more days to fill until you will know. Keep as busy as you can And try not to fret about what you don't yet know. I appreciate its hard but the whole cancer journey can be worry after worry. Managing it is key.  I hope your consultant can change your opionion of him next time. I did find some abrupt but some folk appreciate the less flowery approach. There is however no excuse for rudeness. He may have being speaking about a mx and chemo to give you the most onerous end of the spectrum to make sure you know what the perameters are. Nothing worse than having something sprung onto you When treatment is already in place.  Until you get those results that tell you you are only dealing with a solitary tumour, the treatment plan cant be put into place. I don't think for one minute the consultant is hiding anything from you. I do know on diagnosis  we become very volnurable making us mistrusting. It's a defence mechanism.  Questions you could ask ....  What surgery do they recommend and why  Are they doing anything with the axilla what are the chances of having chemo/what does that hinge on will they recommend radiotherapy  Two days to go now. You are nearly there. Once you are you will find everything moves very quickly so it will be one extreme to the other. Find a good box set you've been meaning to watch to take your mind away from what's to come. Julia X
Posts.Title: WHAT QUESTIONS SHOULD I BE ASKING

Posts.Content: The scan mirrors mine so rest assured it's normal.  breaking bad was the box set I watched on diagnosIs. I loved it and have fond memories of sharing my journey with Walt.  Tags are when you tag people in posts like this Little Wombat.  Julia X
Posts.Title: WHAT QUESTIONS SHOULD I BE ASKING

Posts.Content: Hi Nikki  I didn't have any relapses from chemo as I continued to get better after my last T. However there are loads of bugs going round at this time of year so it's probably not chemo related it just feels similar to chemo SE. Your immune system will still be struggling to get back ontop of things. See how you are Tuesday and if you aren't well enough to start RT can be delayed. Don't worry about that bit.  Hope you feel brighter soon X
Posts.Title: Do the side effects of 'T' return after last round?

Posts.Content: Hello and Welcome to the site and congratulations on getting over half way through chemo. I am 4 months post all treament and doing really well physically. The mental state has been more challenging. Absolutely no amount of 'preparing' can ever prepare you for chemo. For starters nobody can tell you how you will react to it it literally is  a case of lets see what happens. I had neoadjuvant chemo too and by the end was a wreck. Bear in mind that they effects can get harsher as the chemo accumulates. But you sound as though you have done the research to find ways in which to give your body the best chance of recovery. I had melt downs every cycle. I would shout scream and say that was it I wasnt going to have any more. I really did throw my dollies out of the pram. I literally survived each day at a time and had no expectations beyond that. In hindsight I can say that chemo was the worse out of the three stages but they all come with challenges in itself. Chemo messes with your head big time, but remember its the chemicals, not you. Allow yourself to feel whatever emotion gets you through the day. Tomorrow will be a new day and may bring strength and positivity. Just think of that nasty 'swamp juice' (chemo) killing all those cancer cells and making you better long term. This sounds like I am blowing my own trumpet but I had a pathological complete response to chemo so it can happen. Nothing will be the same again for you after treatment but that just means finding the new you (without cancer). You dont need to face that yet. My biggest tip, literally take each day as it comes and allow yourself to feel or do whatever you want. Its just about survival. Its absolutely ok to be needy, emotional and feel hopleless. Get a big calendar and mark off every day that you get through until that finish line is in sight..... which isnt far away for you. You will do it.
Posts.Title: No amount of preparation can ready you for this emotional journey

Posts.Content: Lovely post Yvonne and good on you for the decision making. You made me chuckle reading about the wedding plans. I hope you have run it by your hubby first he he. In a strange way I have found that post cancer (mainly post chemo which changes everything about you) I have learned to like myself more. I look back and think I was very harsh on myself pre cancer. Now I am not so harsh. If anything it showed me what I should have appreciated before but I didn't. There will be so much much more to you to love over an above your hair. Julia x
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: I feel for you wombat.23.  Relationships aren't my strong point.... cancer brings out both the best and worse. I never appreciated what my partner went through taking care of me (although I'd like to think I didn't need taking care of!). He did have enough and binned me after treatment and 8 happy Years. I was so very bitter.  Yes do put it on the back burner for now. Let him sound off just like you need too. Cancer tests relationships to the max. just like we needed it huh! Time will tell if he's just letting off steam or he means business. When we are in pain we have no tolerance to relationship bollocks and we will be much more volatile.  Bite your lip and concentrate on getting you through the rough. Has your husband a mate you could ask to speak to him to check in with him? No doubt he's scared but can't express this without being angry. Sometimes men just don't know what to say or do to make us feel better. I remember the eye rolling my partner did if I mentioned cancer more than once in a day!  Go gently and mention the back at the unit tomorrow. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: upper back pain

Posts.Content: Hi Flopsyuk  To be on the safe side, when you come to sign the surgery agreement I think you need to write on this explicitly what you don't want to happen During the testing. Julia X
Posts.Title: I dont want a Total Axial Node Clearance - what are my options?

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly  This topic comes up a lot on this forum, understandably, as if like me, look forward to a glass of wine, it would be hard to ban it. If we put BC aside for a moment and look at The recommended weekly units of alcohol for both men and women, they have been put in place for a reason. The more we drink the more we put our health at risk.  I have always been very health and exercise conscious but did drink around 20 units of wine per week. I now only drink a bottle (10 units). I've even made more changes to my diet since diagnosis but for me it's always been a big part of my life so they aren't drastic changes for me. I made these changes even though I was triple neg and there is no evidence that alcohol affects triple neg bc.  I have met many ladies who carry on smoking after BC and are overweight and never exercise but are happy that way and there is a lot to be said for self happiness. Others I've met have changed lifestyles completely as it's been a wake up call and have felt and looked the better for it.  If you gave up alcohol completely would it make you miserable? If so consider sticking within the recommended limits for other health benefits as well as lowering your chance of recurrence.  There is much more evidence that says being physically active after BC lowers your chance of recurrence and for me it's much more achievable than giving up the wine!  As sister snail says, you do what makes you the most happy  x
Posts.Title: Measures to prevent breast cancer recurrence

Posts.Content: HI Kim45  Having gone through chemo myself I would say a definite no.  I suffered severe nausea  on FEC which was always made worse on an empty stomach. The thought of adding chemo drugs to am empty stomach is not good. Most meds you are advised to take with food. I know chemo is taken through the blood but it will affect digestion big time. The trick is to eat little but often and avoid foods high in fat before chemo. The other thing you will find out is that chemo affects your taste and ability to eat foods without feeling sick so there will be lots of foods you can't stomach. I lived on chips and humous as it was the only thing I could stomach. Diet and nutrition go totally out of the window for at least a week after chemo. approach comparing other people's chemo experiences with caution. There are so many chemo drugs and all have different side effects. To compare is impossible. Do join our monthly chemo club where you can chat to others going through it at the same time. All the best love  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Fasting along side Chemo - Advice/Thoughts

Posts.Content: Hi wombat.23  Im sorry you are still in so much pain.  I didn't have a MX but have seen you had your surgery only 4 weeks ago? Do you think it could still be the pressure of surgery. We don't realise how much force is used by surgeons and this wil make our bodies ache. Has the pain been there since surgery or it is it new?  When are you seeing your surgeon? A call to your BC unit will help as if they think it needs investigating they will get you in. Are there any signs of infection? Skin warm? Pink?  Love julia x
Posts.Title: upper back pain

Posts.Content: Hi Anna  There are ladies on here that didn't finish the full course due to being poorly but I haven't heard it being stopped for this reason. To be honest it sounds pretty lame. The staffing issues at your unit should not have an impact on your planned treatment. Are you having chemo adjuvantly?  Docextacel (it that's what you now having) is also very powerful so don't think this is the lesser of the evils.  You need to be told the reason why your oncologist has ditched one cycle and I would be inclined to be asking now. Phone the onc reception and explain why you need to see the onc or at least have a telephone conversation.  All the best x
Posts.Title: Not having full FEC moved into T

Posts.Content: Hi Pookie33  Welcome to the Macmillan community. What a worry for you. I've been there to so can understand how you are feeling.  However what I would suggest is that you break this down into steps. Your mind had galloped off into the future and by the sounds of it you've convinced yourself you are on your way out. Rein that back If you can by being distracted. Even if it means spring cleaning your house! Wednesday is two days away and you will be told then what the biopsies have thrown up. It will either be non sinister in which case you will kick yourself over the level of worry you have put yourself through. if it's a cancer diagnosis there will be a treatment plan put into place. Bc has the highest rate of  successful treatment. I'm three years post diagnosis and was successfully treated. Please don't assume because your mum had BC that you will too especially as it was bowel cancer that took your mum. Was the bowel cancer a new cancer or connected to the breast cancer? being 40 is a major birthday. I was 41 on diagnosis But boy did I celebrate being 40. Dont right your birthday celebrations off. It's to early. I send all good wishes for Wednesday. Do come back to us Wednesday even if it's just to say phew and say what fantastic news it's nothing sinister. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Awaiting breast biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hello Ann  All of us go into chemo with complete fear. You read so much about how crap chemo is and you imagine the worse for yourself. However after the first session it no longer becomes the unknown and the fear is taken away, you get your head down and get stuck into getting through the ordeal. You will do it and you may do without mamy SE at all, you just don't know yet.  With EC you will more than likely feel sick. My sickness would come on 5/6 hours after and I found sleeping as soon as I got home helped. Eat small meals regularly both before and after and avoid anything too sweet and stodgy. Think healthy and light. It helps in a queasy tummy. You will be given all the medication to combat SE.  You probably could drive home but I would suggest if you can take someone for support it would be much better.  Drink lots of fluid before you go in and continue to do this for at least 3 days after a session. Over 2 litres per day. Have small snacks in the house, crackers, ginger biscuits, ice lollies, squash, bottled water. I developed a craving for humous I lived on the stuff throughout FEC. seeing the oncology unit and being given the low down from the professionals will ease your fear. They deal with this day in day out and in my experience are very kind caring nurses.  chemo is a means to an end to cancer and you will get through it. Sending hugs  Julia X    Ps I had 3 Fec and 3 docetaxel and was scanned have way through and on completion. The results of Fec were immediate for me but I was triple negative.
Posts.Title: CHEMO TO START

Posts.Content: Great to hear from you LondonLass. Sleep well and sweet dreams xx
Posts.Title: THANKYOU SO MUCH

Posts.Content: Hi Bunty-ann Chemo is the treatment feared the most. Mainly due to the horror stories. However there aren't enough positive posts about chemo. You are in the mind set that you are going to get every possible side effect going and thats not helpful.  Any grade 3 bc or a her2+ or triple negative cancer has a higher recurrence rate so you are not alone. I had Tnbc and was genetically tested. The results were negative.  i had a complete pathological response to chemo so ultimitely it was my lifesaver. Anything so powerful at killing cancer will make itself none so you will experience some side effects. You need to develop a positive approach however. I needed chemo, no question so I just got my head down and got through it however I could. Fec made me very sick and I found eating regularly and small amounts helped. Fasting before chemo can cause problems with the drugs you take before chemo start so do check with your Onco nurse if you go down that route.  Keep positive, eat well and excercise regularly Between now and when you start. Take each day as it comes. When you start, sleep as much as it off as you can and don't expect to much. Be informed, know the risks of sepsis and don't take risks.  Im 18 months post chemo and have no lasting side effects. You mention 'the side effects you are all having trouble with' in you post...... That might be generalising somewhat as we don't all have all of the side effects.  All the best julia X
Posts.Title: Chemo consult

Posts.Content: Hello Lizzy Paranoia comes with the package unfortunately but you are very self aware by the sounds of it and do know deep down that this highly unlikely to be what you fear the most based on your surgery results and the fact you are currently on anti cancer drugs. I had neoadjuvant chemo so my tumour was still in my breast whilst I was having it. It caused discomfort and pains very similar to PMT. (I am pre menopausal). Chemo affects our  hormones amongst lots and lots of other things. Lets face it chemo affects our entire bodies so it should nt be a suprise that its causing the surgery site (a weakness) to be sore. I am 6 months post all treatment and still get discomfort in my affected breast. It can seem never ending at times but it does lessen in time. All the best with the check up. Julia
Posts.Title: Breast pains during chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Helsbels  The surgeon will prep you for surgery. He may use a guide wire inserted into your breast pre op using ultrasound so he knows exactly where he's going in and he will mark up your breast with a pen. It's very precise.  im sure your surgeon will say to you that there is always the risk that once the breast has been opened they find more than what was seen on the scan. It's a warning we all get But one they have to give.  once the cancer has been removed along with a margin of surrounding tissue it will get sent to a path lab to make sure clear margins have been achieved. That's the measure used to say they got all the cancer out. Again there is a risk they don't and you need further surgery.  Remember this is all still very new to you but your surgeon will be very experienced at this. My WLE experience was a good one. Clear margins achieved and a scar that follows my aerola. I was very surprised at the neatness of Everything. So surprised I cried with relief when the dressings came off.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Terrified..MX on Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi Kat  Clear lymph nodes is a good thing.  The cancer cells hadn't  travelled from the tumour up to the axilla so your cancer was dectected early or so it sounds.  I'm also guessing you don't need chemo based on clear nodes? You may like to ask if you had vascular invasion but if you did the consultant would have said by now.  Have you any radiotherapy planned?  I had one node affected but no longer worry as it was removed and I had chemo. I would say you are in a very good position not to worry. There could have been a worse outcome.
Posts.Title: Lympth nodes

Posts.Content: Hi sacred heart  This is a very scary time for you. The million and 1 questions is normal and just your minds way of trying to make sense of being out of control.  As already said, the tumour size isn't always an indicator that cells have travelled to your lymph nodes. Only scans can confirm the size of the tumour and give an indication of how you lymph nodes are. With regard to you insurance policy, you need to check the terms as some policies only cover certain types of BC. When you took the policy out you would have had to declare if you were a smoker or non smoker. If you claim on that policy there is a lot of paperwork that your GP and your consultants fill out. One of the questions to your GP asks if you are a smoker. If you have declared this to your GP it will have been recorded on your records and will have to be reported to the insurance claim. The process only took around 4-6 weeks for me and it was a fairly straight forward process.  All the best.  Julia
Posts.Title: Im scared

Posts.Content: Blood is constantly being pumped around the body. Whether you are running, doing head stands, jumping up and down in aerobics or asleep. I don't think a vibration plate would increase your chances of recurrence. Moving is good for your body and mind. Xx
Posts.Title: Vibration Plate

Posts.Content: Hi Suse  I'm two months post treatment, a year since diagnosis. My anxiety levels are at there worst since treatment began. No amount of scanning will help that. The mental effects of cancer is much underestimated by those not having experienced it (professionals).  You haven't completed chemo yet but are trying to 'move on', worrying about work, worrying about holiday and it's all too much. Break things down. Keep an eye on that chemo finish post, then see how you feel about a holiday then work. I've just returned to work but don't really want to be there as I would rather be doing things that make me happy. If I'm honest, work isn't one of them even though it indicates 'normality', and I use that term loosely.  I was adamant that due to my anxiety levels I was having a mastectomy. My surgeon told me his worry was that I would have life changing surgery unnecessarily then find at the end of it I was still anxious. He was right. Everyone of us feel this anxiety. Some days it's more prevailent than others. Many breast care units offer moving on courses to support the transition. Counselling helps me to control anxiety levels, it's an option.  One step at a time, then it won't feel so overwhelming.  I would guess we don't hear from Survivors on this forum often because they have moved on which is a good thing. You do reach a point where you decide that you no longer need the support of this forum. It works differently for everyone though xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer Nov 14'. Lumpectomy no spread in lymph...

Posts.Content: Hi Jane As you are a nearly a year post surgery your poor boob will let you know if you've rammed it into a tight sports bra and jumped up and down. Haha. No sports bra will give you 100% support so you will feel it when that bra comes off.  I started running through RT and I had to run through the soreness until I was fine again. Do watch out for lymphoedema in the breast. Massaging it regularly (I do every night) with a good moisturiser will help. I think it's fab you are back doing the cardio. You'll find the benefits to your mental health priceless. Good on you. Julia X
Posts.Title: Exercising after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Jeanette  Its common to have the dosage reduced, mine was.  Is this your first check up appointment with your oncologist since starting chemo? Your onc will see how you are coping physically/mentally and make suggestions based upon that.
Posts.Title: Can I change the frequency of my Chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi JackiRuss  I think you may have set your expectations very high. Having little expectation allows you movement. For you to be going back to work 2 days after chemo is gold medal territory. I remained in bed for at least three days after FEC with awful sickness and thought there was no way I could make the end of chemo. After 7 days I was back feeling myself again and enjoyed 2 good weeks out of three.  Dont be worrying about the last three che is yet. I assume you mean a taxane? One step at a time.
