Think about the here and now. I lived through chemo literally one day at a time.... I also never set foot into work. This was the case for 11 months. Drink over 2 litres per day. Don't get dehydrated as it makes SE worse.  You are doing great. Go with what you feel and it's really ok to hide under the duvet and cry. Julia X
Posts.Title: First chemo was on 17th August

Posts.Content: Hi deedee if you are fit for starting exercise then I'm guessing a vibration plate could be used. As with any impact exercise, get a well fitting decent sports bra first. Preferably zero impact.  Studies have shown that having moderate aerobic exercise for at least 2.5 hours per week reduces BC recurrence rates. I am a big fan of exercise and will always promote the real thing. For me, a vibration plate wouldn't cut it but if you are looking at it as a step back into exercise then it's a positive thing.  All the best.
Posts.Title: Vibration Plate

Posts.Content: I'm glad I've made you laugh. That makes me smile. i was guilty of it to. Planning my funeral service and thinking maybe I should make a video saying goodbye. Embarrassing now looking back as I'm very much alive and kicking.  Turn you mums bc into something positive..... it wasn't the type of cancer she died of and so that means she was a BC survivior.  Get you kids from school and give them lots of cuddles. Kids have a great way of making you feel better. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Awaiting breast biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hello Zanib  I had a 25mm tumour with one node affected but was triple negative So I didnt take herceptin or hormonal therapies.  I had FEC t chemo which won't mean much to you. You are yet to learn what treatment plan is being offered. I had 6 Cycles. chemo is most often given every three weeks. It's the treatmemt we all fear the most. There are many side effects you can get. How you will be affected  is totally unknown. Most common effects are nausea, sickness, hair loss, fatigue, mouth problems, nerve problems and so on. I am 15 months post chemo and was lucky to have no lasting side effects. I was pretty fit going into chemo and I am back to that level of fitness....  i am running a half marathon in April. You will be assessed before you commence chemo to make sure you have no underlying problems that could be made worse from chemo.  Chemo is a means to an end. An end to cancer. It's not nice at all but it's manageable.  See what your consultant has for you. You still have lots of information to come.  There is a great monthly chemo thread on here so you can join in on that conversation and be supported whilst you are going through it.
Posts.Title: lump is cancerous but blood report is clean

Posts.Content: Hi Sal44  I don't think you are selfish at all to plan a family. It is something you need to talk to your oncologist about however if you want children before age 35 years. It may be that you wait until after 35. Or stop tamoxifen early but I guess the longercyou take the drug the less chance of carrying a child.  I don't take hormonal therapies so have no experience. However if it were me I would be asking how my risk would increase. Stopping the tamoxifen will put you at risk but also getting pregnant will also add to this due to the levels of oestrogen your body will need to carry a child. there may also be an optimum time to wait before your body is ready for a pregnancy. It took my body a good year for my periods to return and hormonal levels to get back to some sort of normal. Even with TNBC I was advised not to have children post treatment.  There will be blood tests you can have to see what your hormones are doing. you could "ask a nurse" on this forum. I know they are very helpful.  Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Taking a break from tamoxifen for children

Posts.Content: I could advise you that from what you are describing you have had the best outcome from treatment so there is no need to worry but I don't think that Alone will stop you worrying.   I am 16 months post diagnosis and no longer worry. I don't worry because for a while I did worry and it affected my life to the extent I wasn't functioning. I realised not only was that not fun but not helpful to my daughter or my family. Life was crap.  All of us have the potential of anxiety because we have had cancer once already. In time that anxiety fades as life returns to its fullness. We want to be alive and live well so we can't afford to worry. What do we gain from worrying about the what ifs? Statistics are on our side.
Posts.Title: Lympth nodes

Posts.Content: Don't wait until you feel sick before you start taking the anti sickness. I was always hit with nausea around 5 hours post administration. Try and sleep as much as you can which helps.  Do keep that Picc line in the back of your mind. I had one and it was a godsend.  Rest as much as you can. Those SE will come and find you so be ready.  I was breathless but not until after my second dose. It made going up the stairs difficult. It got worse after each session. Four months earlier I was running half marathons! But you will find everyone's experience is different.  All the best.
Posts.Title: 1st chemo, how soon for side effects to show

Posts.Content: I hope those SE are being kind Bandele xx
Posts.Title: 1st chemo, how soon for side effects to show

Posts.Content: Hi Zanib  A warm welcome to this friendly site. i do hope you find it a help. Many of us do.  You don't have vascular invasion. That means although the cancer cells have reached the lymph nodes (the tumour is likely to have been there for some time) it hasn't got into your blood stream and therefore less chance of it circulating around your body.  the bone scan maybe to just make sure it hasn't gone anywhere else. It's very routine so don't think the worst. I had three scans before treatment commenced.  I had neoadjuvant chemo (chemo first). It means your consultant is hopeful  that chemo will shrink the tumour enough for you to have breast conservation surgery. Which means they cut away the remains of the tumour and surrounding tissue and you will be left with your own Breast. If you have surgery first as the tumour is sizeable you will be left with very different breasts. chemo first is good as you get to see it working on that tumour.  so many of us had no symptoms whatsoever when diagnosed. Scary stuff. The weird thing is that treatment will make you feel pants but you have to remember it's short term and for the much greater good.  Do ask your consultant  these questions too as its their job to keep you informed.  julia
Posts.Title: lump is cancerous but blood report is clean

Posts.Content: Hi Bijou  I think we do or say whatever we need to get through and try and get through the least unscathed. not being able to be honest with at least one listening ear is very hard for you though. That may have repercussions because you aren't able to say how and what you really feel. Almost like in a counselling session. I had many months of conselling and I've never felt better but gosh it took months post treatment. We are polite to friends because really who wants to be a conversation stopper by being vocal about how we are really feeling. You may also not be prepared for sympathy/shite comments or them not knowing what to say. In our eyes saying nothing is best. I was always honest with my partner and one best friend. To be honest she really dig deep when asking about how I felt so I never felt I wanted to hide and it helped having her listen.  We can't keep a lid on emotions though not forever. It's bad for mental health. Carolyn28, it sounds a bit like avoidance tactics. Avoiding Not being part of everyday 'normal'(mundane) bits of life. You are right, it could be that you are waiting rather than engaging with life again. I had the opposite trouble... I was so overwhelmed by everyone saying I was to 'move on' my poor swede got overloaded with what to chanhe first.. My body, my job, my house, my friends, my partner and even my hair colour! I was totally manic. Counselling was my only option.   love julia X
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlercrab  I was 41 on diagnosis. I never bonded with my BC nurse as there was no common groUnd. She was much older. I always felt like I was treated as an older lady.  The one thing that did help was my unit offering a 'mentor' . It ended up being a lady of similar age and had gone through the same thing. I was given her contact details and I text as phoned her when I needed. Never met her until 2 years later. It was immense support for me. Triple negative bc is more likely in younger women and I found my BC nurse could tell me nothing regarding TNBC. It was almost as if the less said the better. That's not helpful when you know you have a potentially nasty BC with no preventative therapies.  I asked for a reading material to support me telling my 9 year old and it took her an age to find a aged dog eared booklet that she had to blow the dust off. It was soooout of date I was horrified and binned it. It was called mummy's lump and the pictures were something from the 80's.  I still think the younger lady is treated as the minority as therefore we miss out on a lot of support.  The only BC nurse I bonded with was the head one as she was my age and I could talk as a younger person. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Feedback for BCN

Posts.Content: Hi Little Wombat  I do get saddened to read how little support is giving within families.  The problem with expectations... they are seldom met. That post it note, those flowers or a little 'I love you'. The problem with feeling "let down" is you turn it into anger And resentment.  Your daughter no doubt thinks you kept her in the dark and to her that's a sign of not being open and close enough for you to confide. I can relate to that as my mum hid  the severity of my dads illness. Then Suddenly he died. I was angry. What I appreciate though (I'm 43) is that my mum did what she felt was best.. you did what you felt was best. You need to have a frank and open conversation with your daughter why you took time in telling her and how cancer has made you feel. No its not nice to talk about cancer with your kids but it's also good to get comfort and support from your close ones. Bear in mind your daughter will also be as scared as you are. It won't hurt to let her know that. Say to your family when they glaze over when you talk treatment that you need to talk and it's helpful to you if they listen.  Dispite cancer affecting more of us than not people are still in the dark when talking about it. This is your chance to educate family and friends If you think you don't get the support you would or have shown them. Failing that... spoil yourself. Indulge. I never gave up on buting shoes and bags through treatment. I may have lost my identity but still loved to spoil me.  Love  Julia x
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Hi Macrad This was exactly the line I was given by my Radiographer who I thought at the time wasn't being very helpful. She told me to continue moisturizing as I previously did. I've always been a big fan of Vitamin E cream so continued to use that. I do agree that maintaining a well hydrated skin is important regardless of RT. It may be that clinical trials are not planned for this cream although it makes me nervous that GP's are giving out this cream. Personally I think that creams that are given by the a RT unit can act as a placebo. I wasn't given any cream which made me feel my SE were worse than they should have been. They weren't. Whose to say they would have been any different with a product specifically given to me. Julia
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Cathy  This is quite a bombshell and it would have been better to have stuck with your old post as you did your phased return to gently ease you back.  Cancer aside, would you still be anxious starting a new role? Many of us would.  I am the only female in an office of ten men and have been for 15 years. I had eleven months of treatment and I only tell them what I feel comfortable telling them. They never ask about my treatment so I don't think your 20 something colleague will need to know anything about the side effects you are having. As long as your line manager is aware and supports you that's all that matters.  If I were you I would ask that you do your old role until you are ready to move on or spend one day per week in the new role to get you settled in slowly. There is no harm in asking. I've been back to work 8 months now and my BC is not mentioned unless I raise it. To be honest I find working with men so much more straight forward than women.  All the best. Julia X
Posts.Title: Return to work - advice please

Posts.Content: Gosh Jacster, that sounds nasty. Drains are normally left in for upto 7 days so it's not very common for them to be in longer . Drains are there to collect fluid more than blood. If the drain is just collecting blood wouldn't it be better for the drain hole to be closed?  The loss of blood is no doubt making you anaemic which you might need some help with.  medical advice is really the best here so I hope you can get answers soon. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Still Bleeding .....

Posts.Content: I wouldn't recommend using anything else with the steroid cream but then again the steroid cream doesn't sound great In my eyes.  On the basis there is absolutely no consistency across the NHS trusts in terms of creams that are given, this is a good indicator. My team in Torbay wouldnt give any cream out it was left to me to carry on moisturising as I normally did, even when I did get very pink a couple of weeks after RT finished.  if you've managed to get K1 and 2 ftom your GP that means it's a product your GP can get their hands on and has deemed it suitable for you. saying that I would use it on its own and not  with the steroid cream. julia X
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Lillian So glad you are being used to make things better. It must feel good knowing you can make a difference in future. We have had photos on here previously of boobs to show reconstruction. Just bear in mind that the photo will be viewable by any member of the Macmillan Community and that's quite a wide audience! One way to share would be to 'friend' people and send it via the private message tool. All the best Julia x
Posts.Title: Lymphangitis

Posts.Content: We can't take a healthy future for granted but in hindsight we never could.  but maybe chose to think it would never happen to us. Longevity is guaranteed to no one.  My smile is real because 2.5 years ago I thought i was dying and now im not.... in the near future anyway.  that makes me happy julia x
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info Liz. Please bear in mind it won't be certain that you will develop these side effects. I had 3 cycles of docetaxel and didn't have peripheral neuropathy. I actually had worse effects from FEC. My saving grace was Drinking over 2litres of water per day. My worst side effect from taxol was a bird cage mouth. I couldn't have followed a diet with any will in the world as nothing tasted as it should. My chemo nurse always said to me don't worry about food just make sure you drink lots.  All the best for a good 12 weeks. Please let us know how following the diet has helped xx
Posts.Title: Taxol & Peripheral Neuropathy - check this out!

Posts.Content: Hi pink  There is not one of us here that hasn't been anxious about a recurrence. Your question is so very valid, how do you get a balance?  The biggest influence is the amount of time that passes when your treatment ends. You aren't completed yet so take the impending RT as another belt and braces attack.  I had a major wobble when treatment ended and had four months of counselling which has brought my psychological wellbeing to its most healthy.  Time really is a great healer and you must trust your body. Cancer aside we all get ill, aches and pains and let's face we grow older. As we have had cancer our minds automatically jumps to the wrong conclusions. If you reason with yourself and think that the pains you have are short lived and the fact your cancer has been removed there is very little chance it's back so why does your brain say it's back.  Life will return for you and actually takes over again quite quickly post treatment. I am 10 months post treatment and it's a distant memory and I live very happily and very content but it's taken me a good 6 months to get there. Trust your body not your mind.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Everything spells cancer

Posts.Content: Hi WORRIED2016  I can tell from your post you are frantic. As said above you need to stop and take things one step at a time. Your thinking about things that you don't need to be thinking about at this time.  Break treatment down into bits. First is surgery so concentrate only on that. Nodes will be removed during surgery if the dye shows that some/one are affected. You need to be clear however how many they will remove if say just one or two nodes are affected. If none are affected then nothing will be removed.  Call in favours and get more help in for your dad. You cannot go through surgery and maintain the same level of care you are giving your dad at the moment. It's only Temporary.  Phone your BC nurse and get answers to your questions. You can't maintain this level of emotion you will end up in a bad mental state. Ask your GP for help to get you calmer.  The best you can do is take this one step and a time.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: WORRIED2016, yes the dye will have worked by the time you have surgery and so they will know what's going on/not going on with your nodes.  After surgery your tumour along with clear margins of tissue gets sent to a path lab to be tested. It's then that they confirm what you already know about you type of BC . It will definitely tell you your her2 result. That's why it takes two weeks to get results. it will also confirm that clear margins have been obtained.  you are having a WLE (lumpectomy)? In which case there is no reconstruction surgery done. Your affected breast will be smaller than the other After surgery. you will meet with your surgeon before surgery. Please make sure you fully understa what will happen. Do you have a companion going with you to act as a second pair of ears? J xx
Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: Huge waves from me too Heather.  Lovely to see your name pop up. glad to know your healing well. The fatigue is an issue but small steps as Kate says. I find I have weeks of feeling so alert then suddenly I'm hit with a week of tiredness. We forget lovely lady that we are getting older too. Or in my case complete denial!!!  lots of love to you.  Julia X
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: morming Bijou  It did get easier for me after 4 months of counselling. My diagnosis was stage 2b and I've no lasting side effects. Even so I needed a lot of pyschological assistance so you could say I didn't fight like a good girl either come the end. Honestly, I was exhausted. I would have a chat with your GP about feeling down and see where that leads. Pretending you are ok isn't doing you any good despite you thinking you are protecting others. no one looks after you better than you look after yourself. Love Julia X
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Try this link: https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/464395/fit-note-patients-employees-guidance-sept-2015.pdf Your GP can give you a fit note but say on it you can return to work with adjustments. It is then down to you and your employer to agree what adjustments are going to be necessary. This means talking. Small employers have little of know knowledge about cancer patients. If you work for a larger employer and they have an occupational health unit then you can be referred to OH who will then assess you and make recommendations on what your phased return will look like. You do need to be open with your employer about your needs, otherwise they will assume you can go straight back into the workplace which will be detrimental to your health. I work in a very challenged environment so I asked not to answer a phone for a good 6 weeks when I returned as I feared that I would just flake if someone got stroppy with me. It was more about confidence than anything else. I didn't even know if I had retained any information (I work with legislation) after 11 months so equally wanted to be sure that I was still competent. Rome, you need to be speaking with your GP before Monday to make arrangements otherwise you will be going in at the deep end. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Return to work - advice please

Posts.Content: Hello sr23  I'm very sorry to read it's back and reared it's ugly head after having all that primary treatment. I do know that secondaries in the bone are very manageable. The oncologist just need to plan what drugs they will throw at it next. Sometimes it can be trial and error.  Wondering why it's come back so soon will tie you up in knots. No treatment or preventative drug is 100% guaranteed to stop a recurrence/secondaries but they reduce that risk. That does leave a % of us that will face secondaries. It can happen to any of us at any point.  im sure you will have seen the Breast, Secondary Cancer Group - Discussion Forum  which will give you access to other ladies with secondaries and the names of drugs involved in that treatment.  Im hoping your oncologist will be able to rest your mind soon because secondaries in the bone is manageable and if they are considering surgery then it sound like they are on the ball. all the best  Hugs  Julia X
Posts.Title: Cancer in spine

Posts.Content: Hi Kat40  It sounds like you could be long sighted. Have you had an eye test in the last 12 months? i would make an appointment to be checked out. i do have very dry eyes caused by chemo and previous corrective eye surgery but my eyesight was never affected. i don't take hormonal therapies so don't know off it's a SE of these. Does it mention anything on the patient leaflet? love julia x
Posts.Title: Tired eyes

Posts.Content: I always think when they pass the decision back that's the hardest. Hold out for the results of the Oncotype test. There's plenty of time. 2% is a very low percentage but I personally would want the evidence behind that and the test results will show that. You've hit the nail on the head. How can you make a decision without the test results. After all that is what the test has been designed for to tell you if the risks of recurrence are high enough to say chemo will be of benefit. Without the results you could find yourself thinking round in circles. Julia X
Posts.Title: Scared about today

Posts.Content: morning Papa Smurf  Today is a big day for you but you do need to know the way forward. I always knew I'd have chemo so I had plenty of time to sort it in my head.  If the tests come back low risk then you can breathe a sigh of relief. If they come back high scoring then you know that chemo is tough but it's not as scary as having cancer itself. So many of us on here have had chemo and we are still here to tell the tale. If the score comes back intermediate then that's the hard decision as the oncologist may hand over the decision to you.  its good you have had the oncotype dx test, not everyone does so at least you have the maths behind the chemo decision.  whatever the outcome we are always here to support you.  I will be thinking of you today.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Scared about today

Posts.Content: That sounds good. Im all done and dusted with treatment.  Infact today i celebrated it being exactly two years since i had my last chemo session. Today you would know no different. Onwards and upwards ladies xxxx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - week 3 of 3

Posts.Content: Hi WORRIED2016  I can tell from your post you are frantic. As said above you need to stop and take things one step at a time. Your thinking about things that you don't need to be thinking about at this time.  Break treatment down into bits. First is surgery so concentrate only on that. Nodes will be removed during surgery if the dye shows that some/one are affected. You need to be clear however how many they will remove if say just one or two nodes are affected. If none are affected then nothing will be removed.  Call in favours and get more help in for your dad. You cannot go through surgery and maintain the same level of care you are giving your dad at the moment. It's only Temporary.  Phone your BC nurse and get answers to your questions. You can't maintain this level of emotion you will end up in a bad mental state. Ask your GP for help to get you calmer.  The best you can do is take this one step and a time.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: Changes I have made : I eat at least 5 a day if not more I have an organic fruit and veg box delivered weekly Increased my protein intake Drink two/three cups of green tea per day I eat more fish than meat and never eat processed meat I try and limit alcohol to 14units per week (don't quote me on this!!) The key is a varied diet that is more fruit and veg than anything else. I totally agree with Carolyn..... avoid food in boxes You know when you have got your balance bang on when you are content with how you look and how you feel :) Julia xx
Posts.Title: Changes to diet

Posts.Content: Hi candytop  i had neo adjuvant chemo and do drive. However i dont think it makes any difference between having adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemo. I could have driven after chemo sessions but my partner choose to drive me. Im only  5 miles from the hospital. i was very nauseous after fec but from 3 hours post administration. after docetaxol i was fine to drive after. the point being you dont know how you are going to feel after your first session so maybe make other arrangements for the first session like a friend collecting you? Just in case. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - week 3 of 3

Posts.Content: Hi susie  Take all the compliments you can lovely!  I know how hard it is. I got through 9 months of treatment then had to have 5 months of conselling to get me back on track but I'm there. This time last year I had no hair on my body, no fingernails a stone heavier and didn't recognise myself. I sit here now with a head full of chemo curls and think to myself life is pretty darn good.  Others compliment you because they want to make you feel nice. It's far better to be told your looking good than looking shi£e.  Inside you are in turmoil but I don't think there is anything to gain for spreading that turmoil amongst those you mix with. On here its good but to those who haven't had similar experiences it's hard for them to emphasise. Give it time.... This time next year you will feel completely different. Trust me.  Happy Christmas Julia X
Posts.Title: The Miseries

Posts.Content: Hi JeanieB  Cording can go on it's own with some help from you. I sorted mine without needing physio. Stretching the arm is the key. Stretching it above your head or even grabbing the top of a door then pulling down gently at first. Keep doing it and it will pop back. julia x
Posts.Title: How do I get rid of cording?

Posts.Content: WORRIED2016, yes the dye will have worked by the time you have surgery and so they will know what's going on/not going on with your nodes.  After surgery your tumour along with clear margins of tissue gets sent to a path lab to be tested. It's then that they confirm what you already know about you type of BC . It will definitely tell you your her2 result. That's why it takes two weeks to get results. it will also confirm that clear margins have been obtained.  you are having a WLE (lumpectomy)? In which case there is no reconstruction surgery done. Your affected breast will be smaller than the other After surgery. you will meet with your surgeon before surgery. Please make sure you fully understa what will happen. Do you have a companion going with you to act as a second pair of ears? J xx
Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: Hugs JJ im so sorry to read this  xxx
Posts.Title: What is it with cancer?

Posts.Content: Good for you mistyblue. Sounds like a perfect day to me. im busting a gut trying to get an assignment done that ive had a month to do , started it only yesterday and needs to be in on Thursday.  Im also ploughing my way through a huge box of continental chocolates Whilst I do it. It will be wine next!!  Happy Sunday everyone xxx
Posts.Title: Happy Sunday.

Posts.Content: Hi iwannaliveforever  Secondary cancer is still treated with chemotherapy Regardless of it already being given. There are so many different types the possibilities are endless and many take what treatment is offered.  The point being as you are now no evidence of disease you will have no way of knowing how your forthcoming chemo will affect any cancer cells that may or may not be hiding out in your body. There are no measures So without that you have no way of knowing what it's doing. At least with neo adjuvant chemo you can see it working.  Recurring cancer can become resistant to chemo but that's not a reason to not have it now. You have chemo now to reduce your chances of ever having another episode.  The Onco type test is a very good test which provides statistical evidence based upon your tumour. It's tailor made and was designed so that it takes the guess work out of whether you will benefit from chemo.  Try not to delve to deeply as you run the risk of talking yourself out of it. Trust the test.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Chemo - long term implications for treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Sleepy Mushroom I'm not familiar with the type of cancer you were diagnosed with but I did have Axilla clearance after neo adjuvant chemo. The problem is that although it looks like on the scans that the lymph nodes have shrunk you don't know if there are still cancer cells in them. Only after testing them once removed will you know. I had a pathological complete response to chemo but this was only confirmed once I had had surgery And they were sent to the path lab.  Even though the procedure is called Axilla clearance it doesn't mean they will remove all your lymph nodes. Lymph nodes cluster together so they will remove those surround the affected nodes. I had 11 removed. 1 had been affected. We have a varying amount of lymph nodes in this area but most common is around early 20.    Personally I wanted nodes removed even though it was looking like I had had a pcr to chemo. Lymph nodes are in the lymphatic system and its risky to leave possible cells in this system to circulate around the body. I had surgery 15 months ago and have no lymphoedema in the arm but did get it in the breast. That was due More to the wide local excision I had done.  My Axilla scar is not very visible on me.  All the best  Julia X
Posts.Title: Advice on Axillary Lymph Nodes Dissection / Lymph Nodes Removal

Posts.Content: Hi Redkite26  Sorry to hear you are suffering with the dreaded nausea. I had it bad too after FEC and tried all sorts. A few things I did learn....  take anti sickness regularly- don't wait until you feel sick Eat small portions regularly. If you don't eat, it makes nausea worse! Suck Ice lollies just sip from a drink nearly regularly. I found juice mixed with carbonated water good. Sleeping it off worked for me. I spent three days post Fec in bed lying very still.  it does wear off so hang in there. Do make an effort to drink though as I learnt the hard way and ended up in hospital. there are different brands of anti sickness so tell your chemo nurse and you may find its trial and error. Love  Julia X
Posts.Title: Struggling to drink recommended fluids after chemotherapy!

Posts.Content: Hi Pfom  When you have neo adjuvant chemo those choices can't be made as you wouldn't have the results of the brca mutation test in.  I would imagine cost to the NHS has a lot to do with it. Docetaxol does seem to be the most common taxane used. I don't think there is much difference between them both. Studies have shown taxotere (docetaxol) given as less infrequent doses as Taxol is equally as affective.  Confusing huh. i guess it's one to ask you oncologist Jojo4 next Thursday. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4  I know which post your talking about as I looked twice. Either taxane is common practice (more so docetaxol in the U.K.) for TNBC where there is either node negative, node positive OR larger tumours.  Dont take it that you aren't getting the correct chemo drug. These are "first line" drugs. There are a few others used in trickier situations Such as platinum agents.  your Patricia Prijatel book will explain all.  Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: Thanks for explaining Pfom.  Can I ask where you are being treated. if this is based on latest research it's a good thing as we often wait over three months for brca results. That's no help at all when having neoadjuvamt chemo. A 6 week turnover is great but is this in the uk? my appointment didn't happen until 6 months after diagnosis.  love Julia x
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: hi Helsbels  It's worth talking to your gym and explaining as many will offer a free month or so to get you back after treatment or you might be able to pay as you go through treatment.  Insanity might be a tad optimistic but there may be some more body conditions cycles in insanity? I do T25 and some are cardio and some are body conditioning so I pick the one most suitable. You can pick up second hand t25 sets quite reasonably. I jump around in the living room much to my daughters amusement! I know how you feel when people say there are more important things than a good weight and healthy body image but when it's happening to you it affects your mental wellbeing.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Weight gain on chemo

Posts.Content: Hello peachesxxx The pyschology of cancer is interesting. I read your post and thought, kids at school, hubby at work..... Ahhhh relax. Bearing in mind though I'm two and a half years down the road from diagnosis and life has definitely caught me up. I remember too being bored. Then within weeks of being back at work, wished I was off. It seemed like there was no pleasing me.  It's so difficult for our heads to accept rest and waiting when it's forced upon us.  I would have suggested preoccupy yourself with friends but you have done that. The sleeping is a problem. Have you thought about sleeping in the day (it's allowed even when your a grown up!) or taking herbal sleeping remedies at night or sleeping tabs from the GP? We can only sustain limited sleep up to a point.  Wednesday was only 2 working days ago and there are another 5 working days to wait. Try and kid yourself you are on holiday. Having gone through chemo myself I know you will be preoccupied feeling quite poo for a lot of the time so feeling ok now is good in comparison.  I watched the entire box set of breaking bad and fell in love with Wentworth Miller in Prison break. He was a great distraction.  I found planning really helpful.... Decorating schemes/christmas presents/ holidays and Pinterest is fab. Hugs Julia xx
Posts.Title: Feeling frustrated

Posts.Content: Good morning ladies This has popped up on my FB feed. I find this site very encouraging when it comes to studies. I think we all knew the increased risk of BC whilst taken HRT but this is interesting reading... New HRT study results Julia X
Posts.Title: HRT study results

Posts.Content: So lovely to see you use the word brave, and of course the other lovely words Fiona. You have learnt so much.  Leaving treatment behind is hard but from reading your posts I get the feeling you will be ok. Like you, my life is much much richer now than before. Id call it a wake up call. Chemo does become a thing of the past but the scars will always remain.  I hope the last chemo is good to you. I was ready for anything come the last but it went out with a whimper more than a bang!  Julia x
Posts.Title: Farewell to Chemo!

Posts.Content: Losing nails is very normal and common after Docetaxol. No need to see your GP. It is a documented side effect which you should have been informed of. Keep the nail bed clean and dry. They will be sore for a few weeks and especially when the nail first comes away. Julia x
Posts.Title: Nail problem from chemo - urgent advice please?

Posts.Content: Having Chemotherapy before surgery is being done more and more in this country. I had neoadjuvant chemo and glad I did. It's a good way to measure how the chemo is working For you. The better the response the better your prognosis is. However it's only given to those that are definite candidates for chemo I.e triple neg and her2+ patients. The idea is to shrink or obliterate the tumour so that a good WLE can be performed. I had a 25mm tumour which if had been removed from my breast from the start would have Meant a very wonky and misshaped boob! As it turned out I had to have minimal tissue removed and I'm left with equal sized breasts And I had a complete response to chemo which is my golden nugget that I cling to when I have those moments of panic over recurrence.  Ann you are right, many ladies that are ER+ don't know until after surgery if they would benefit from chemo.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Advice on Axillary Lymph Nodes Dissection / Lymph Nodes Removal

Posts.Content: Hi Bev  I feel where you are coming from. Weight gain and hair loss where the things that upset my mental wellbeing the most.  I was a size 10 going into cancer and have been for the last ten years. I love food but am a big exercise bunny. That's how I keep in shape.  I found through chemo you are lucky to be able to eat some days through nausea then on other days you crave bizarre foods you wouldn't normally eat. I had to go with the flow. I really would suggest you don't try and follow any meal replacement plan diet whilst your body will be at an all time low. It's too risky.  You can however keep active throughout (if you are already active). I had to stop running as my lungs just couldn't cope but I did indoor cycling throughout and I did fitness classes. Chemo alone didn't cause my weight gain. You could say it's steroids but it's normally much more simple than that .......Throughout treatment we are forced to become less active and our eating habits so change do we put on weight. Treatment also causes pyschological issues which tend to manifest themselves in what we choose to eat and when.  I put on a stone over a 8 month period due to not being able to run. It took 6 months to shift but I'm now back to my pre cancer body shape and running a half marathon in three weeks.  I am a huge advocate of excercise and have been all my adult life. There are so many reasons why we should do it.  Do mention the shake diet to the chemo nurses, I think they will say no but do check.  It's a tough time, one of the many many things beyond our control at this time but you can excercise when you feel like it. Take back some control. Put together a little excercise plan for weeks 2 and 3.  But you never know you might not gain anything you may lose it. Remember it's not just chemo alone that causes it.  If you are going to be taking hormonal therapies that will bring separate issues.  All the best with the Fec . Julia X
Posts.Title: Weight gain on chemo

Posts.Content: No problem Bev.  That treadmill your using as a clothes horse he he sounds ideal to me. I would have loved a treadmill at home. You can get on it not caring how you look or who sees you. When you feel up to get on and start gently and build up every time you go on it. It's amazing how pleased with yourself you feel after. I got such a sense of putting up my two fingers to BC when I excercised during chemo.  I know the hardest thing is doing it. I'm still the same. I'm due a long training run today and I'll sit here for a good two hours or so procrastinating about when or why I shouldn't go. Even when I'm doing it I swear, I'm grimacing and thinking what the hell. Not fun at all but I can't describe that feeling of satisfaction when I've done it. I never thought I would be back to being able to run 13 miles, never.  Anything is better than nothing Bev.  Concentrate on getting through chemo and get on that treadmill when you can and try and eat well. That's the best you can do and I am sure you will do it well.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Weight gain on chemo

Posts.Content: Ahhhh Blue - I find myself here to. My ex after 4 months apart decides he made the wrong decision and wants me back in his life. What a head mess!!! Like you all I think is when the shite hit the fan he left. Id  never trust him again and that wouldn't work. Men really are from Mars. Keep you pecker up Blue and you are so right............. only Jen knows how much she can forgive and forget. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Husband remark to cancer

Posts.Content: Ha ha I know my bloke had his head  up his Uranus most of the time  :) I often wonder if it had been different should we have been married. It shouldn't have made any difference of course. Ill enjoy seeking that man that can step up to the mark. High five to you George :) Julia x
Posts.Title: Husband remark to cancer

Posts.Content: Hello JMC04  I remember this stage well. I think I used to tug my hair every morning for about 4 weeks wondering when it would go South. Mine started coming out after the second chemo. I left it as long as I could as I have very thick hair then when it turned into a mullet and my daughter disowned me I got my friend round with a pair of clippers and we said goodbye to it. If you have fine hair then it may be noticeable sooner for you. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hi Jen I wrote a reply last night after reading this but lost it so Ill try again. Your post was so familiar to me I had to reply. A cancer diagnosis really does open your eyes to a whole host of stuff you didn't see before. Your husbands remark is likely to be down to one or two things. Men (please bear with me as I am generalizing here based upon my experience. George I don't count you in this he he) generally tick along nicely until something upsets the apple cart. If that something involves emotions then they go into panic mode and cant/wont/don't know how to deal with it. In this case they try and get you to shut up about your diagnosis because he cant or doesn't want to do the touchy feely stuff. Women are much better at that, as we all know. Either that or he really is just plain scared and doesn't know how to protect you and his defense is trying to get you to think that its all done and dusted now and you can go quickly back to life ticking along nicely again. My partner of 8 years supported me through 11 months of treatment but very early on in the diagnosis he would 'get that look' on his face when I talked cancer. It was like, here we go again. I did stop talking to him about BC and used my girlfriends instead. Come the end of treatment my partner changed dramatically towards me ending up with him finishing the relationship. He said he was angry that he hadn't been thanked enough for looking after me. He was also struggling with the fact the past 11 months had been all about me! The end of treatment is a very difficult time. I think you may have to admit that he isn't going t be great at giving you the support you need at the moment but do try and seek that support elsewhere whether its on her or with another close body to you. You could try and discuss how you are feeling with him. You could also try and get him to read the paper below: www.cancercounselling.org.uk/After the Treatment - Peter Harvey.pdf Its a worthwhile read for anyone moving on. All the best. Julia x
Posts.Title: Husband remark to cancer

Posts.Content: Hi LJB234  breast cancers are tested to see if they have receptors for three things. Oestrogen, progesterone and her2. The majority of bc are ER+ which means hormonal therapies after treatment are given over 5/10 years to prevent recurrence. if you are also or only her2 positive it means you have herceptin which is given in conjunction with chemo. if you test negative for all three you have triple negative BC which there are no preventative drugs for just chemo. Some diagnosis can be triple positive too.  So depending on your type you will get a different preventative drug or not as in the case of TNBC.  Are you er+? If you were her 2 positive you would be having chemo. With ER+ the oncotype dx test is more frequently carried out to see scientifically how likely you would gain a benefit from chemo. It can bring grey areas however and that's a tough call. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4  Its good you can tick off the dentist from your list now though. The clip insertion is really ok. I found it less uncomfortable than the biopsy. The US is used to guide the clip to the tumour site to get accuracy that's all. The clip is tiny and is placed in like a punch biopsy tool and is inserted then the clip pushed in. My advice would be don't watch what's going on as it can make you feel worse..  or it did me.  I would take pain relief before you go. You have a local but take the pain relief too.  it's ok honestly. love Julia x
Posts.Title: What a day...Marker Clip Insertion

Posts.Content: Hi Becs  This depends upon where you are in the country.  We have a very good specialist oncoplastic breast surgeon in South Devon called Michael Green. You can google him. He does private work and NHS.  He wasn't my WLE surgeon but I have seen his work and he has a good reputation.
Posts.Title: Lumpy Boobs Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Hi wombat.23 You have answered your own queries in that whatever has gone before makes no difference because it can't be changed. there will be so many of if not all of us on here that have a different experience  to tell on how they were diagnosed. The point being ...  we were diagnosed in early stages. The treatable stage.  I found a hefty lump purely by accident. If I'd Not found it by accident I probably would never have made it to the age of breast screening. I too have a dodgy "good" side by I know what dodgy feels like to me. I also am reassured by three monthly check ups and yearly mammograms .... until someone else comes along and says screening didn't help them at all. I have to believe there is always hope. Theres no one size fits all and no way of looking into our bodies to know exactly what's going on. There is a lot to be said for living for the here and now.  I know if I have a recurrence in the next 2.5 years I'm done for. I can't live by that because it's waiting to die. I lived blissfully unaware I had cancer for probably more than a year. How ironic is that! The hard but was finding out It was cancer. Moving on is very bloody hard and it doesn't come quickly.  I had 5 months of counselling and as Carolyn is doing, do grab all the moving on support you can get. its the best thing I did. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Was this the start?

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah Do you mean a seratoma/seroma? As in its fluid? A haematoma is different than fluid. I had one that was exactly how you described and I had it drained. It did come back but not as big but they would only drain it once.  I went into my BC unit and they drained it there and then. It was around 8 days after surgery. I would phone your BC unit and explain and they will see you as soon as possible if its that uncomfortable. It is a horrible sensation. A water bed under the armpit. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Haematoma

Posts.Content: Most definitely. Within 6/8 weeks mine had all reappeared. the whole nail doesn't fall off just the top section.
Posts.Title: Nail problem from chemo - urgent advice please?

Posts.Content: This is just one of millions of chemotherapy experiences. Written for a national newspaper. It's her take on things just as we all have our take on chemo.  A  close friend of mine bought a real hair wig whilst she was bald. It cost thousands of pounds. What was wrong with a freebie from the NHS? For her it was what she needed to cope with hair loss better. Let's face it hair loss is one of our biggest worries. Public figures I'm sure think about this more.  im 20 months post chemo and it Is a very distant memory. for me chemo was my life saver and I never hesitated over having it. it was a crap time but my life since being told I'm in remission totally over rides what chemo temporarily did to me.  Do what ever you have to do to get through it. Sod everyone else's experience.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Decca Aitkenhead in the Guardian

Posts.Content: Hello ladies  There are different types of ear problems that cause vertigo. You don't need the ringing or tinnitus. Years ago I had benign positional vertigo which was debilitating. I had an operation 6 years ago to cure it which worked. Saying that I am 3 months post all treatment and not on any meds but have the dizziness episodes have started again. Mainly at work using my computer on the swivel chair but it's also bad when I'm up and down the Isles in the supermarket too. I'm taking it as an old symptom (I can't cope with any new ones!!) Julia x
Posts.Title: Vertigo after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi candytop  The oncotype test really will help here then we can help put the % uplift chemo will give you into perspective. Example....  chemo may give you a 4% uplift over 5 Years. (That's a pure guess)  meaning 4 in 100 women/men will receive the benefit and survive 5 years With chemo. Do you want to be that 1 in 4 or are you happy to be the 96 that won't get a benefit and therefore more unlikely to survive 5 years? benefits of chemo are never high anyway. so you need perspective and the predict test gives that. julia x
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi mattyg  Its hard moving on being triple negative but I think that's the same no matter what type of BC you have had. Every ache and pain is magnified in our heads. Not to be the bearer of doom and gloom but TNBC tends to come back as secondary in other organs rather than bones unlike ER+ BC.  I had a sore rib after treatment that had lasted for some months. I mentioned it to my oncologist...  More than once until he referred me for a bone scan. It came back fine. apparently the GCSF injections can cause this niggle. There could be a million and one reasons for back pain. I'm a long distance runner so aches and pains are normal to me and I sort that out with regular physio/massage.  Ice packs on the site site 3/4 times a day can help. having a massage can help. Specific stretching exercises can help but I do suggest if this continues for another month then you go back to her oncologist or GP. First though I would try and get your wife to self help with the back pain. I have a very dodgy back that goes around every 3 months but I can get it better in around 4 days after through Ice and exercise. All the best..... It's great to hear your wife is through treatment. Julia X
Posts.Title: Back Pain Post Radio?

Posts.Content: Hi Isingbass No specific diet will keep you cancer free. The reason why there is so much conflicting information out there is quite simply as nothing is 100% proven. Cancer books sell and anyone can write a book claiming to have the key to staying cancer free.  I don't believe there are any adults out there that don't know what a 'healthy' diet looks like. The trick is being strong enough to make changes and stick by them. Ultimately  you need to find your own way And find what is realistic for you. As you have found out with the vegan diet, if it doesn't suit your lifestyle then you are more likely to quit.  Excercise is key because with a minimum of 2.5 hours per week you have leeway with your diet. Protein is essential for weight loss and so are good fats (Avocado, nuts etc) Low fat diets are the worse because you end up substituting with high sugar and very manufactured products. Eating over 5 portions of fruit and veg per day is key. Protein at every meal is essential (chicken being one of the best sources) and small carb portions after exercise. I drink green tea at least twice per day, eat oily fish at least twice per week and take glucosamine daily as I excercise a lot.  I alternative between non dairy and dairy. Again I eat dairy because of the protein.  You will know when you've got the right balance when you are happy with your dress size, and feel like you are doing all you can to keep 'healthy' without feeling guilty when you have the odd treat! Tackling comfort eating is tricky because the underlying cause needs treating first. Get that nailed then there's no stopping you.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Vitamin supplements & diet advice ?

Posts.Content: Hi Ruthie63  I needed chemo as I was triple negative. I didn't think twice about having it. I was very fortunate in that I had neoadjuvant chemo and had a pathological complete response so I can say it was worth every sodding ache and pain! And there were many. However I'm two years post chemo and have no lasting side effects.  Ive seen what an amazing job chemo can do but it doesn't happen all the time. With or without chemo you aren't guaranteed to never develop secondary BC but by having chemo you are less likely to. You are monitored closely on chemo so I'd like to think there would be less chance of long term SE such as neuropathy. But it is a risk.  Im 2.5 years away from diagnosis and took all the treatment I was offered to satisfy my mind that being TNBC I needed to move on from this knowing I've done all I can to help prevent this thing coming back.  This is a hard decision to make but unique to you. There are many many of us here who have lived through chemo to tell the tales.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Mounica   I'm very sorry to hear about your mum.  Is the hand swelling on the affected side? Lymphoedema in the arm often presents first as a swelling in the hand. Rings should be removed and any watches. It's advisable a specialist takes a look as if it lymphoedema then your mum will need access to a clinic. Getting help early is key before it affects the whole arm. Massage helps but you need to know how to massage. It's towards the good side and very gently.  Either this or the chemotherapy is causing fluid tetwntion but that's normally in the feet and ankles.   All the best love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Hand swollen..

Posts.Content: It's important you get to know your breasts and how they change during your menstrual cycle. You will then know what lumps and bumps are normal for you and what's not. Dont take risks with lumps and bumps. The only persons time you will end up wasting is your own.  Lying down gives a better position for self checking With an arm up. Chevk under the underarm too for lumps.  Xx
Posts.Title: finding lumps - some advice please

Posts.Content: Next years birthday will make up for it JJ. Do keep yourself really well hydrated (over 2 litres per day).  You may not feel like sipping but your symptoms will lessen especially the UTI. I had one after my first tax due to dehydration so I never made that mistake again.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Narrow escape

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzy It may be that it is a delayed reaction due to the cold cap. I didn't use the cold cap but my hair didn't start regrowing until around 6 weeks post the last chemo. Your iron levels will be low as chemo sees to that. I ended up having transfusions due to anemia. Only in time will  these levels start returning to normal - 4 weeks isn't long enough to be back to 'normal' levels. Skin, hair and nail supplements are worth trying. I used these until my nails grew back. I also had regular head massages with oil. My chemo regime finished with 3 taxol which doesn't cause hair loss like an all FEC regime would.  If you had all FEC? then this is a big dose of the stuff that makes your hair fall out. Julia
Posts.Title: Hair still falling out 4 weeks after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Skye01  Nothing like a cancer diagnosis to bring out the worst  in people. I don think it would be helpful for me to say how unsupportive/unhelpful your family sound as they are still family at the end of the day and a cancer diagnosis shakes things up. I almost get the impression you are being blamed for this diagnosis as its upsetting your Mum's day to day life. Your Mum sounds like she has a lot of control over everyone.... a little too much. I would take the rearranging of the party to a date not suitable for you (her child) as an insult. You are only 70 years old once after all. Two options : Go to the meeting and be hard and fast with what help you require. Go with the list (as long as your bleedin arm if need be) and leave it to them to provide the support you need. Say that you will only accept the help when it is given UNCONDITIONALLY and without a second thought. If they need to think twice then forget it. Or Keep your distance during this time. Leave it until treatment is done and dusted. Being in hospital gives you too much time to think... which isn't great. The realty is you may never need be admitted again so you wont need help for that scenario. You may find if you withdraw then they will realise they have gone to far. Are they use to you doing what they want you to do? Stand firm. I had a similar problem with my mum, as you know, but I found my support from other sources until I didn't need it. Then I felt I couldn't be bothered to revisit it and it was all  brushed under the carpet. Incidentally I am now closely then ever to my Mum. Cancer is Cr%) Hugs Julia xx PS If all else fails..... print out this thread and post it too your family :)
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah  use the previous 3 sessions of chemo as an indication of what SE your mum is having. After chemo number two I had a good idea of what I would feel on what day and when I would start to feel better.  On the basis your mum hasn't had any cycles delayed or postponed it means her body has recovered enough to go into another cycle. If something nasty was up it would show in her blood test results.  I am in my early 40's yet would be in bed for three-four days post each FEC. With taxol I become poorly from day 3/4. As long as she is monitoring her temperature and reports any high temp which indicates sepsis then that's the best you can do.  Chemo is incredibly hard going. If mum is at the end of her tether or it looks like her long term health is being affected, as chloecat says, discuss this with oncology but if they are saying what's she experiencing is 'normal', that's what you go on.
Posts.Title: my mum is struggling with chemo

Posts.Content: Hi pipsters  It was with my tumour. Very obvious. I only found it by fluke. It was 2.5cm when found. However it's not the only symptom of breast cancer. Can you feel something in  your breast? If you can, the best course of action is to make a GP appointment. They wil gauge if it needs a referral to the Breast care unit. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: finding lumps - some advice please

Posts.Content: To be honest no amount of iron rich foods will undo a low iron level due to chemotherapy. It will return in time. Your blood cells have been suppressed for months, it takes time. If your iron levels were too low whilst you were having chemo you would have been told as it would have shown up in your blood test results. Mine went too low  and that was why I ended up with a transfusion. I used a normal massage oil (base oil) and coconut oil. Superdrug do a very good one in a tub which is a good price. You have to rub it in your hands to soften it before use. I think if you had had FEC first your hair would be starting to grow very soon. Its the red chemical in FEC that makes you hair fall out.
Posts.Title: Hair still falling out 4 weeks after chemo

Posts.Content: That was the opinion of my oncologist too Kacang. I'm in south Devon, U.K.  Once he said that I didn't think twice about not trying the cold cap.  No doubt there will be no hard evidence to suggest that the caps increase chances of a secondary cancer but it made sense to me.
Posts.Title: Hair still falling out 4 weeks after chemo

Posts.Content: Hello Suzyjane  i can't share experience of a MX but I read your comments about your husband and it struck a cord.  Im sorry to read you are facing another round of treatment and I think that In itself is permission for you not to be strong and hold it together. Lean on the other men in your life. It sounds like you need to be having words first. As George says, in sickness and in health. I hate being stereotypical but men do need things spelt out sometimes.  I'm not married but have a partner of 8 years. At the end of treatment he expected me in sexy lingerie and the whole works. Jeez that was the last thing on my mind. I had zero confidence and the thought of sex made me panic. I was giving off bad vibes which in turn my partner took as me not fancying him anymore. It was a vicious circle which ended up with no sex and us both feeling unattractive. He took to watching porn which added to insult. I took all the blame until counselling made me realise there are two people in a relationship so a problem with one is a problem with both and both of you should be working at it to get back on track.  You may not feel strong enough now to deal with the relationship side or you may feel to get the most out of those close to you you need to be heard before your surgery.  some breast care units run support groups for partners. all the best julia
Posts.Title: Bi lateral masectomy with immediate construction - I'm terrified

Posts.Content: Hi October2017  Sorry to hear of your Grandmother's diagnosis. I was diagnosed with TNBC but was 41 years old at the time. The key thing here is that the Grade of cancer. TNBC isn't always Grade 3. I had Grade 2 cancer which is slower growing. The trouble with TNBC is that Googling it will give you a grim picture. Its not always that way. I am 3.5 years post diagnosis and its looking good. One positive with TNBC is that is that if you manage 5 years without it coming back, after that, statistically your survival rates are better than that of ER positive BC. Your Grand mother could well see 100 years old :) All the best for surgery. Chemo is grueling - the risks at 94 will more than likely outweigh the positives. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Triple negative breast cancer in elderly

Posts.Content: I can appreciate that was a hard conversation LondonLass. But so very lovely of your niece.  I have to be honest, as an adult I still fear cancer even after having it. Its probably one of the most common illnesses. 1 in 2 of us. Must of us will have had grandparents that died of cancer if not parents. I lost a grandparent to throat cancer and can honestly say it was horrible so my opinion of cancer was influenced by what had gone on before. My 9 year old daughter got loads of support from her school. One of her classmates had gone through treatment for leukaemia so her school was very proactive. They took part in Wig Wednesday to raise awareness and raise money they also invited kids to speak in assembly to share their experiences. My daughter was praised for the way she outwardly coped with my cancer. I couldn't fault the school for supporting her.  As a child it's as scary as hell when an adult who you are close too gets ill.  It really would be great if you could share your experience of cancer with your nieces peers. But only you will know when the times right.  love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Today......

Posts.Content: Hi Barbara On the basis this has got worse over a short period of time you need to get it checked out soon. Breast tissue covers a wider area than I ever imagined but I can't say if this breast tissue. It could be a side effect from surgery. All the best Julia x
Posts.Title: Red mark - should I be concerned?

Posts.Content: Hello  No need to feel a fraud here.  Sorry to read about your gran and mum. It's unusual due to your grans age on diagnosis that she was tested for the Brca gene mutation. Was there family history further back than your gran or a reason why she was tested?  I was tested as diagnosed at 41 years with BC with a family history but it was negative.  It's down to you whether you seek to get tested. You don't have to do it. The opera guide is the first step then if your GP/specialist feels it needs to be taken further you then need to fill out paperwork which asks all about family history of cancer types and other illnesses. It would be at this point the info you supply is checked against databases and in your case would confirm you gran has the Brca gene mutation. You do get counselling before the test as you need to be fully aware of what a positive result would mean for you.  As already stated you have a 50% chance of a positive result but even a positive result doesn't automatically mean you will definately get BC due to the gene mutation.  If you feel you need to do it then seek assistance but maybe it's not something your mum needs to know your doing or it may not be worth persuing testing for your mum at this time. She might be worried that if she was tested and positive then that would affect you. Ontop of all she is going through its another hurdle for her. It's a complex situation.  Whatever you decide, I hope it's a positive outcome.
Posts.Title: Talking to family

Posts.Content: Dear Skye01  I'm very sorry to read this and in truth concerned. I also think this is the time to close the lid on this family. You run the risk of it affecting your mental state big time and dealing with cancer is enough in its itself.  you knew from diagnosis this was going to be s challenge getting support. You've been vocal about what you need but they can't come up trumps for you. Don't put yourself in any more situations that will lead you to question what you are doing wrong. You aren't, the family just aren't getting it. Time to walk. Protect yourself. Even if it's until the end of treatment. While they affect you you will question everyone around you because you are volnurable. Folk will stare at bald heads the same they stare at disabilities, obese prople and so on. It's not a personal thing (unless your family have gossiped to them). hair loss is temporary. It doesn't feel like it and I'm not saying it will feel any less temporary tomorrow but in a year it will be in the past.  Clear your head and that I think means clearing the family.  Failing that, voodoo dolls??!!! sending hugs and all the best for chemo. Take a deep breath as you go in and vow to not think about family. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: I'm 12 months post chemo and stil have chemo curls. It was such a shock it coming back curly. But less than a shock than losing it I guess! I am able to straighten it now but as soon as I go outside into weather it frizzes back into a tight perm look! It's worse at the gym when I get hot. I can feel it growing outwards on my head as I get hot!  I was holding out for it returning back to normal now I'm one year on. A guy I work with did ask why had I spent money on getting it permed after it had only just started regrowing. Jeez I wouldn't have paid for this look.  I sound ungrateful but my hair is the thing I still struggle with X  Ps Maggie your hand grenade comment cracked me up
Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: Hope the chest gets better soon Tray41.  Huge congratulations and respect for getting to the end of treatment. The next bit is a challenge too, finding your new normal but as you so rightly say, one day at a time does it. Before you know it you'll be looking back on this all . take good care. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Another box ticked

Posts.Content: Hello Ctrigg i finished chemo last Nov. 3 FEC, 3 docetaxel. You have two more cycles to go, that's over half way. What an achievement. I counted every single day off the calendar through chemo it felt like I was literally living to get to the end of chemo treatment, that in itself made me feel bad because I was wishing time away.  For me chemo was the most 'challenging' shall we say. Your appearance changes drastically , your head gets mashed and your body fries from the inside.  I have to say however, 5 months down the road I feel great and look back and think It really wasn't that bad. I know deep down it was but it's amazing when you get through stuff how your mind tells you it was all ok in the end.  Be proud of how you are getting through this. Have faith in your body and you mustnt feel guilty about how you are feeling reflecting on others. I have a 10 year old and I started by hiding a lot from her. Then I found I couldn't but we carried on. She knew what was going on and she loved and cared for me in her own way.  Chemo is literally a means to an end to breast cancer. Without a doubt the hardest thing I have done . Be proud. Two more sessions Wooooppppeeeee. The finish post is in sight xxx
Posts.Title: Hit a brick wall

Posts.Content: Hi fiddlesticks  There are no time constraints but it's also not open ended as you should be able to show you are progressing. My phased return took 6 months and was over seen by occupational health who assessed me during this period and made recommendations on increasing hours after each appointment. I would say your Head is being reasonable but ultimately if you can't achieve your contract by the end of the year you could be asked to see OH. That's not a bad thing.  You may need to get you Gp involved to write a fit note based upon needing adjustments If you need it next year. I don't take hormonal therapies so haven't had that to cope with and have been back at work for 18 months now without one day off sick yay. I am so glad I had that 6 months to ease back into things gently.  I empathise as returning to work is tough. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: How long can I stay on a phased return/reduced duties?

Posts.Content: Hello This really does vary. On the whole most women I have met, hair growth has been normal after chemo but some I've met its taking a lot longer.  mine grew through tax but was still shedding at the bum fluff stage! I finished chemo in Nov 14 and by March 15 I was going out without scarves or wigs on, so four months. It was however a very short 'crew cut'. Mine has grown back very curly but the same lovely thickness And same rate of growth (if not quicker!) One year on I have shoulder length locks and you would never know I was bald only a year earlier. The curls however look like they are here to stay. Personally  I don't think if you have it trimmed regularly or not makes any difference. I only had mine cut twice over about an 8 month period.  Julia  Ps I don't take hormonal drugs and I didn't have herceptin. I don't know if these would make a difference to the strength and fullness of hair regrowth
Posts.Title: Question about hair growth

Posts.Content: Hi Sammy2017  I'm sorry to read you are facing biopsy results. There are two ways of dealing with this. I was in your position albeit I was too scared to view the ultrasound screen. My way of dealing with waiting for results was not down playing cancer but by burying my head in the sand until I was given facts. I'm a big fan of not worrying until you have something concrete to worry about!  The alternative is to think you have bc and that i itself will cause no end of problems. With that will come worry, anxiety, no sleep, no concentration, loss of appetite, anger and so on.  For a professional to give you a 95% opinion that it's not sinister would be good enough for me. No consultant likes to be wrong and to be fair it was helpful of him to tell you that.  I had nothing but silence And worried faces. let us know how you get on. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Karen I feel for you. I was assigned a volunteer through my BC unit that I woukld speak to in times when I was having to make a decision. It helps talking on the phone. Is that something that your unit could arrange? The volunteers are ladies that have been through a similar diagnosis to yourself. I would still consider the risk of stroke higher than any good chemo will do you. Is there any chance you could have RT first then see that it has zapped those cells in the node before making a decision to have chemo? I know how you are feeling. It feels like a life or death decision and you are so afraid of making the wrong decision. WIll you have RT to the nodes in the underarm? (I only had it to the breast) If you are and along with the the hormone supressors you will take, those alone will give more protection than chemo will chemo brings the risk of making you so poorly. Do you feel you are being swayed a particular way by your oncologist? You arent pathetic and you arent crazy (unless theres something you arent sharing he he) you are dealing with the sh@@e that is breast cancer. Julia xxx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy with W L E with one node positive

Posts.Content: With one positive out of 19 taken and with such a small benefit I would ( knowing what chemo is like) trust the RT and letrozole.  I had one positive node out of 11 taken but being triple neg knew I had to have it. It was 5 months of pure existence for me. Couple this with your risk of stroke it's not worth that risk. There's also the risk of neotrophenic sepsis which was included in my treatment plan as a possible cause of me dying if I got it. You lose hair, nails, confidence and feel crap. The bottom line is that even if you had chemo you can never be certain that it will prevent recurrence. There are no guarantees.  I think they can still zap your axilla with RT as well as the breast so it may be worth exploring. All the prediction tools I have seen give higher benefits to RT than they do to chemo.  Julia xxx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy with W L E with one node positive

Posts.Content: ps I too found massage helped all through and at the end of chemo I started acupuncture and still go now. Can't recommend it enough
Posts.Title: Hit a brick wall

Posts.Content: Hi Denise1962  Hair loss after hormonal therapies is common. The difficulty with hair that's always been chemically lightened is that the chemicals in these products are a lot harsher than say browns.. Have a look at the following website. I found it fab. The way forward maybe is to  find a hairdresser that has been specifically trained by Trevor Sorbie's 'My new hair' initiative rather than take risks with a hairdresser looking for a safe limit of peroxide. http://www.mynewhair.org/support-advice/ Spray in root control colours are ideal. I use these for the pesky greys that pop through. Ultimately you could think about going darker but its going to take some planning. Julia x
Posts.Title: Hair lightening products

Posts.Content: Thank you for the update mamasatch. Do ask the lymphoedema clinic about manual drainage and kinesio taping as they tend just to stick to more old fashioned methods In my experience. Im sure the antibiotics will do some good real soon and you feel better. What did the GP think of the swelling on your neck?  I do hope you feel brighter soon. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Lymphedema 2yrs on and possible recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi elaineo2  I would suggest give your BC unit a ring and ask them the quickest route. I suspect they will say it's quicker to go via your GP. hope it gets sorted soon.  love Julia x
Posts.Title: Breast and arm pain

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou1007  Anyone having chemo is at risk of neutropenic sepsis. Chemo reduces white cell counts to a dangerous level and during that time you are at risk if you become septic. Saying that there are very good emergency procedures for this to ensure anti biotics are administered fast. white cell boosters are also given after every chemo (GCSF) to try and stop this from happening. I got septic twice. I'm not diabetic. Chemo is still recommended with some ER+ diagnosis. It's more frequent for the oncotype dx test to be offered nowadays to give you a score based upon path results of how likely you will benefit from chemo. From the number of nodes involved with you though I would suspect chemo would be of benefit.  Im sure all will be discussed tomorrow but try not to be too dispondant yet as you may find chemo, radiotherapy and hormonal drugs are still on the table. Julia x
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona72  Im sorry things aren't working out for you. I had lobular bc and am wondering why you want to have the bilateral MX because of this alone? lobular is more likely to appear in more than one place on diagnosis but if thats not the case with you then it's treated as any other BC. I don't think lobular is a strong enough argument for a MX alone In a healthy breast. I had a WLE.  Surgeons and more importantly anaesthetists won't take risks. By saying it's too risky to operate they are saying you are at risk of dying If you have this type of surgery. It's a hard one to argue. Are you willing to take that risk if you had the opportunity? Surgeons are also very reluctant to remove good breasts.  You could seek another surgeons opinion but again if you were to find one who would operate would you take the risk? Being told we can't have what we would like is hard but in a few days/weeks when you have had time to process this information you may feel differently.  Ask how much you would need to lower your BMI before they would consider recon as you may think that's doable? I would say take time to really consider the professional opinion. love Julia x
Posts.Title: I'm not allowed reconstructive surgery because my BMI is to high

Posts.Content: This won't be what you want to hear but I found I was good for around 3 days after docetaxel and would get rubbish around day 4/5. You really won't know until you've had your first cycle.  BUT  it was a different kind of rubbish. I never once felt sick on tax whereas FEC was awful for me in that sense.  The worse SE on tax for me was a terrible mouth, it was sore and furry and I had no taste and everything that went in my mouth tasted  bad. I had a bit of joint pain too. 6 weeks after my last cycle I lost all finger nails too.  To be honest JJ you may find tax is much kinder and easier to manage. You are half way there and that's a reason to be cheerful xx
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects info please

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou1007  welcome to the Macmillan Community. You are omongst those who have had a BC diagnosis so we will support where we can. I too would be very peed of with the Nurse. being told your cancer free and then being told you have your chest wall affected are at different ends of the spectrum. How can those two conclusions come from the same set of patient notes. I think to be safe you need to find out where the nurse was coming from, just in case someone is wrong here. Surgery always comes with a warning that they may find more than first suspected. that's why surgery is still the best course of action. This is especially the case with finding out how many nodes are affected.  The cells tested would have been grade 2 and 3. The stage of your BC, does it remain at stage 2 or has it been changed following the chest wall involvement?  There are ladies on here that are diabetic and have had chemo.
