I'm hoping they will come along soon. The bottom line I guess though is what your oncologist feels is right for you? Is your BC ER+? You will be offered hormonal therapies so there are more options out there along with radiotherapy.  Hopefully the PET scan will happen soon and you won't be kept waiting for results. The waiting is awful, I know.   Sending love and best wishes and maybe the strength to have a conversation with the BC unit.  julia x
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Make sure you are using the 'desktop' version of the site.  When you compose a message on the top of the message page you will see icons.(where bold and italic is) Click on the one that looks like a photo then it will ask you if you want to upload and will take you to where your photo is saved on your pc. Click on the photo and press upload.  Uploading photos on this site is tricky.
Posts.Title: What am I on?

Posts.Content: Hi mamasatch  The swelling in the right side really does sound like lymphoedema however as will happen on 23rd, that left hand side needs exploring. No doubt they will want to do an ultrasound.  I had an enlarged node in the neck (which was checked with US quickly) but was told it wasn't sinister as it was below 10mm in size. A node bigger than 10mm becomes more suspect.  have you checked your nodes higher up in the neck and by the ears?  All the best for 23rd and do let us no how you get on. Julia x
Posts.Title: Lymphedema 2yrs on and possible recurrence

Posts.Content: Welcome jobiejo Here you are at the end of treatment. Good on you for getting through and it's good to have you with us.  My finger nails fell off after docetaxel around 2 months after my last one. If this is a chemo side effect there's little you can do too stop the nail from coming off. Keep them short and painted to make them stronger.  Solar oil is good for keeping them moisturised. I did use boots own hair nail and skin supplements for a short period. Some will say you should be getting all your vitamins and minerals from a healthy diet but cracked nails are a sign nails aren't happy. Mine do this in winter. If your nails do come off keep them clean as your risk of infection will increase.
Posts.Title: Toenails and Nails

Posts.Content: I'm sorry to read it's reared its ugly head again Carole. It is very very small and sounds like you are under good surveillance. Let's hope it can be whipped out quickly and be the end of it.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Another Lump Update

Posts.Content: Morning everyone George , can BC ladies/gents get Lympheodema in any part of the body? I was understanding it would only be the effected arm where nodes had been taken?  Hope the scan goes ok today I will beat this x
Posts.Title: Lymnphedema

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne Deciding on chemo is a tough decision but the oncotype test  is a great indicator of how useful chemo will be to your specific circumstances.  With some types of BC (triple neg and her2 +) chemo is almost always guarenteed as its one of the best forms of treatment. Triple neg and her2 also respond very well to chemo. Not all BC respond well to chemo and if you have adjuvant chemo there are will be no indicators that chemotherapy is working or not working.  I had chemo purely as I was triple negative and without it my prognosis was not good. Now Knowing what chemo does to you,  if I was given statistical info based on my specific set of circumstances that gave a very low benefit of chemo I would not go through it again.  Trust the oncotype test and be guided by the oncologist. Chemo isn't something to take without any assurance it will be of benefit to you because the SE will far outweigh this.  All the best X
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX

Posts.Content: Hi caz The  pressure is already being put on you and it's not good.  I went back to work 6 weeks after finishing RT. I was off for eleven months. seriously think about getting another sick note.  You won't be able to give 100% so don't commit and don't let her dictate that. As you work for a bank I'm assuming you have occupational health support? Ask that you see them and with their guidance create a return to work plan. Your manager doesn't sound like she will be sympathetic to your needs.  My phased return lasted 6 months but under the guidance of OH.  gettng this right is very important because you don't want any set backs And returning is very challenging.  all the best  Julia X
Posts.Title: Confused need some advice please

Posts.Content: Hello angebow65  Itching is a sign of healing however you are along way from surgery so will have healed By now. Are you using anything different on your skin? I ignored a very persistent itchy boob for over a year. I then felt a lump which turned out to be cancer. The itching was directly over the tumour site. Itchyness isnt documented as a sign of BC for obvious reasons but I'm convinced the itching was an indication something was happening under the skin. You might feel better if you get it checked out before July? love Julia xx
Posts.Title: itchy nipple !

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4  You do have a valid point but it's way to early for theses sorts of decisions. Looking on the bright side, chemo will do its magic and you will have a WLE.  half way through chemo, you will know what's going on properly and it's then you can have these conversations with your team. Regardless of how active you are, a high BMI puts you at risk. Lowering that will give multiply  benefits but now isn't really a good time to be actively dieting or exercising.  Any surgeon worth their salts will do their upmost to get a good cosmetic appearance. They will look at your body in proportion and tell you what's realistic.  Think positive for the time being and go with the WLE. Don't doubt chemo when you haven't given it chance yet. love Julia x
Posts.Title: I'm not allowed reconstructive surgery because my BMI is to high

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou1007  welcome to the Macmillan Community. You are omongst those who have had a BC diagnosis so we will support where we can. I too would be very peed of with the Nurse. being told your cancer free and then being told you have your chest wall affected are at different ends of the spectrum. How can those two conclusions come from the same set of patient notes. I think to be safe you need to find out where the nurse was coming from, just in case someone is wrong here. Surgery always comes with a warning that they may find more than first suspected. that's why surgery is still the best course of action. This is especially the case with finding out how many nodes are affected.  The cells tested would have been grade 2 and 3. The stage of your BC, does it remain at stage 2 or has it been changed following the chest wall involvement?  There are ladies on here that are diabetic and have had chemo. I'm hoping they will come along soon. The bottom line I guess though is what your oncologist feels is right for you? Is your BC ER+? You will be offered hormonal therapies so there are more options out there along with radiotherapy.  Hopefully the PET scan will happen soon and you won't be kept waiting for results. The waiting is awful, I know.   Sending love and best wishes and maybe the strength to have a conversation with the BC unit.  julia x
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou1007  Anyone having chemo is at risk of neutropenic sepsis. Chemo reduces white cell counts to a dangerous level and during that time you are at risk if you become septic. Saying that there are very good emergency procedures for this to ensure anti biotics are administered fast. white cell boosters are also given after every chemo (GCSF) to try and stop this from happening. I got septic twice. I'm not diabetic. Chemo is still recommended with some ER+ diagnosis. It's more frequent for the oncotype dx test to be offered nowadays to give you a score based upon path results of how likely you will benefit from chemo. From the number of nodes involved with you though I would suspect chemo would be of benefit.  Im sure all will be discussed tomorrow but try not to be too dispondant yet as you may find chemo, radiotherapy and hormonal drugs are still on the table. Julia x
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: If your manager would have you back a work when you are covered by a sick statement then the companies insurance provider would have something to say! What an idiot.  You do need to communicate with him/her. Not all managers have experience of cancer so unless you tell him what you can't do he won't know.  Some do work during chemo. I did but only from home. But at the end of the day if your GP is saying you aren't fit for work, you are not fit for work.
Posts.Title: Unsympathetic manager

Posts.Content: angebow65 Thanks crystaljuju. Once again you ve come to my rescue!  You helped keep my head above water while I was going through chemo , july 2015 to november 2015, put me in my place occasionally to get my head back in gear. You were and still are a knight in shining armour. Bless you!  No i ve not used anything different and yes, i ve healed so well now so, it can't be healing process. Its just driving me crazy!   I will get in touch with doctor or bcn tomorrow and see what they say.  Whats this Pagets disease thing?  Do you think it could be this or is brain in overdrive - again? Thankyou for advice hun. I hope you are doing well. Lots of love and hugs Ange xx Thank you so much :) Its always a pleasure to help and always a bonus to get a thank you and to see ladies reappear over the years. It feels like a little reunion. I don't know much about Pagets but I think coloring of the skin and texture comes into it to with this. Don't let you brain go there. Phoning the BC unit is good enough and they will tell you the way forward if its needed. Glad you've healed well Ange. Let us know how you get on. Lots of love J xx
Posts.Title: itchy nipple !

Posts.Content: I think this may be a local thing with oncologists. Are you being treated at the R D and E? I was treated at Torbay but I know the oncologists work between the two hospitals. My onc is Dr Bliss and he advised it was best not to 'interfere' with how the chemo worked especially around the head.  I didn't try the cap as I took the opinion It was inevitable I would lose my hair. The cold cap can be very effective but I think you need to be prepared for the disappointment should it not working. Worth a try though x
Posts.Title: fec-t and cold cap

Posts.Content: Hi Helen A worrying time for you and especially when its time you hoped to be moving on. I too went back to work in May after being diagnosed last June. Take the initial opinion of the medics as what has gone on...... you have had infections. You have been extra unlucky that you have had a few. Your immune system wont be working at full capacity since all the treatment for BC, couple that with you returning to work and being in close contact with germs your body has picked things up that it would normally fight off without you knowing about. The infection in your breast could be something to do with the surgical site. The scan has been suggested to rule out a recurrence dont think of it as being sought to confirm a recurrence. I dont take hormonal suppressors so cant say whether the infections are common with herceptin and tamofixen but other ladies might be able to share similar experiences. Its good you are being seen next week and you can be guided by the radiographers/consultants on what they see in the scans. All the best next week x
Posts.Title: worried its come back

Posts.Content: Yay yay yay. We all love good news stories. Keep em coming. Hugs Julia xx
Posts.Title: Gene test result :-)

Posts.Content: Hi QuietRose  im sorry to read about the soreness. Sometimes chemo can leak from the veins. Do you have a port/picc line or are you cannulated? Its worth exploring to see if it's a leakage. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Upper body skin sensitivity

Posts.Content: hi Lilt80  Weclone to the Community. if the lump in the breast is benign I'm wondering why a MX is being suggested? the lymph nodes are dealt with separately. I had one node affected and what the call axilla clearance so 11 in total were removed. That puts me at risk of lymphoedema. Hahe you been given an indication as to wither you will have axilla clearance?  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Metastatic Lymph Nodes

Posts.Content: Hello Andrew  What a truly amazing husband you sound. Six years and six recurrences ontop of working. Here you are still by your wife's side.  I know from speaking to my partner how hard it was looking after me for 9 months let alone 6 years. He would never show it but he was scared. Very scared. I am so sorry to read about what your wife is going through. When you say she had non hormonal BC do you mean she is triple negative or her2 positive? She must have had so much treatment.  I can totally understand why you feel you cope better at work. Have you spoken to Macmillan or your local cancer support service as it may be time you ask for some outside help? You need to be supported as much as you support your wife.
Posts.Title: Its getting tough

Posts.Content: Hi Galarussett Welcome to the Macmillan community. I am guessing you are thinking you have breast cancer, which is the reason you are joining us. Please bear in mind that we have all had a breast cancer diagnosis so may speak as if you have already had a  diagnosis. However, we are jumping the gun as you haven't been given the results yet. Its not a done deal that its cancer. Saying that, it will be very tough for you tomorrow if you decide to go it alone. Do you have a close friend you can take. My mind went after I heard the words cancer. I cant tell you what happened after that but my partner was there taking on board all the info. I don't even know what to say to you regarding questions as you may find you don't want to know anything initially. We also run the risk of overloading you causing even more anxiety at this stage. My advice is see what tomorrow brings. Take someone supportive and do come back to us when you know what is what. If it is cancer, its very very treatable and has one of the highest treatment success rates. You wont believe this at first but you learn to accept this. I was 41 on diagnosis that was almost 2 years ago. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Waiting is nearly over

Posts.Content: Hi boneyem1  To be living with this level of fear/anxiety three years on is a indication you will benefit from psychological help such as counselling. A surgeons knive isn't the solution for curing anxiety. As Helen says, as harsh as it sounds, removing breasts has no bearing on not developing secondary BC. What would happen if you had a bilateral mastectomy then hated the cosmetic results afterwards and found your anxiety was still there?  Speak with your GP as it sounds like you aren't able to live a normal life because of this fear. I'm 2.5 years post diagnosis and love and value life but I needed 5 months of counselling to get me where I am now. love  Julia x
Posts.Title: Thinking of breast removal

Posts.Content: welcome Sally-Lou. Hopefully the combination of both, tapping away and these replies will start to support you.  I was diagnosed over 2 years ago. Successfully treated and back living lots of lovely life. Breast cancer is very treatable without sounding flippant.  however, that doesn't lessen the shock and your world crashing around your ears temporarily. You feel bad for the hurt your causing and I can guarantee your family feel ten times worse in that this is happening to you.  Every twinge, cough, sneeze, twitch you will associate it to the cancer. In your head it's everywhere. It's really not the case. BC more often than not grows over a long period of time. I had to have three body scans before starting treatment and they were the worse results to wait for. Getting the clear results made me think phew only primary BC to deal with. Perverse but t needed all the positives I could get.  At the moment until you get all the results from scans and the type of BC you have you cant start treatment. When you do start treatment it's head down and off you go. Throughout my dianosis I always used a mental pair of scales in my head. One side negatives, one positives and the positive side was always heaviest. That got me through. All the best for the scans. So let us know how you get on and when you can start treatment and remember its very treatable. Julia X
Posts.Title: Diagnosed this week - helpless

Posts.Content: Hi WORRIED2016  It does look like a pretty straight forward DX. Doesn't mean you will be any less anxious or fearful.  Remember back to pre cancer..... no dubt you had off days then to so they are still going to happen post cancer. Having your dad so poorly is a lot to cope with on top of getting you through to the end of RT. But of course you need to see him.  Are you able to say to your sister when you are feeling volnurable that you can't listen to her just at that moment And maybe the conversation can be postponed until another time.  learning to live after cancer is actually quite if not very hard and it won't be smooth going. Be gentle and concentrate on the here and now. Looking back or too far in the future isn't good.  You've done so great since your DX. You've come in to us with a marriage break up, a sick father, dependant kids and had a nasty infection on top of it all. I think you've been amazing.  Allow an afternoon of crap. Tomorrow they say is another day.  Lots of love Julia x
Posts.Title: Silly worries? How do you sort your head out

Posts.Content: Hi Kezzacare  A warm Welcome to the community from us all. Ive had a read of your profile. That's some reading.  Are you waiting for a referral appointment to a breast care unit? There are five different signs that could indicate breast cancer. 1 sign in isolation doesn't mean it definitely is cancer yet some people have no symptoms at all. Fluid leaking from the nipple does need to be checked out. If you haven't seen your GP then do make an appointment. Early detection is always key. Love Julia
Posts.Title: Discharge from nipple

Posts.Content: Hello Folks I've received a letter from Torbay health care trust (where I was treated) to tell me that the guidance on avoiding injections/blood tests/BP tests on an arm that has had nodes taken from the axilla has been changed. The information in the leaflet given says that there is no evidence to suggest that having bloods etc taken from an affected side makes your risk of lymphedema any higher. However the caveat is when they are done 'IN A HOSPITAL ENVIRONMENT'. I have questioned this as to be honest , I get most of my bloods taken/BP done at my GP surgery by a nurse. That technically isn't a hospital environment so I am not sure where they are coming from on that basis. Do they consider surgeries less aseptic than hospitals? This isn't me saying we should all adhere to this advice but I was interested to know if its a national thing or local thing? To be honest its difficult to know what advice to trust? Or is it just me? It is good news however for people that have had clearance on both sides etc. Incidentally the leaflet that I was sent had the web link to the Macmillan fact sheet about lymphoedema. I looked at this and couldn't see any advice saying avoid bloods/injections etc from an affected arm. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Change in preventative advice for lymphoedema

Posts.Content: Wendy, don't feel pressured to keep to the operation date on Monday. If  it  feels like you will be rushed into a decision. You need time to have a proper discussion with your surgeon then to go away and think it over. As I say, I took weeks to make a decision. I'm fearful your BCN won't be able to talk through the surgery with you like the surgeon does.
Posts.Title: NO DISCUSSION

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline  i have returned to work this week after 11 months away from the office. I too had to visit OH before they agreed I was fit to return. Physically I am ok but mentally I struggle. We agreed on a 6-8 week phased return which started with a few morning per week and gradually increased as the weeks went on. It will be reviewed however. They did refer me for counselling which was fab as I had no joy with the NHS with pyschological support.  We talked about what I didn't feel I could do, in my case I am not to be public facing (my job involves meeting the public) for the first 6 weeks and I won't be answering our telephone helpline. I was a line manager but those duties are on hold until I'm ready. I take regular breaks and have had another workplace assessment as I was told that lots of keyboard work can increase lymphoedema risk.  I like you felt brilliant at home but am shattered after three mornings back at work , have problems concentrating and even getting up on time. It all takes time.  On my first day back I was so confident driving in, going into the building, I opened the office door and burst into tears! All the best x ps I went back to work 5 weeks after finishing RT
Posts.Title: Back to work

Posts.Content: Hi terri f  with the first one under your belt you'll have more of an idea what to expect next cycle. I was actually very sick with fec so it sounds like your doing well.  dont worry about sleep patterns but accept you may need to sleep in the day. I stayed in bed for theee days post every fec and tried to sleep it all off as I felt so yuck. Your body does the majority of its repair when we are asleep. Sleep whenever you can.  I wouldn't say the itchy scalp is a sign of hair loss. Even without the cap three days into chemo is too quick for hair to be shedding. I didn't cap and it wasn't until after chemo 2 it fell out.  i hope you've managed some zzzzzz 's today. ..... and never fell guilty for staying in bed if that's what you need.  Love julia x
Posts.Title: A quiet hello from me!

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass  on the basis your BCN knew the reasons why you needed the results tomorrow, phone the lead BCN tomorrow and explain/complain. She will at least confirm that what you are now being told about timescales is correct. You've said its not the first time it's happened so you'll only resolve issues of you raise them formally. All of this may totally be out of you BCN control its just she is the deliverer of the news you don't want to hear. That's never easy.  Im sure you prospective employer will understand that you will have results Monday rather than tomorrow especially as this is through no fault of your own. I do feel you need to raise this tomorrow or you will be thinking about this all weekend. Julia X
Posts.Title: So now my BCN is lying to my face...............

Posts.Content: Hi Poohbear44  Congratulations on getting the finishing post in sight. It's a tough one Isnt it. i don't have experience of hormonal therapies as I'm triple negative so there's nothing I can take to prevent recurrence. Taking a drug that has side effects (as all drugs do) to prevent recurrence  in my eyes is worth a shot. Try it at least. I do know many ladies that take hormonal therapies and can say this. Those that were a healthy weight and fairly active before bc dont put on weight as they maintain their healthy lifestyle. Those that were overweight and have tended to be up until their BC diagnosis do put on more weight.  The pills themselves aren't calorie loaded but it's how they make you feel when suppressing oestrogen. You might not feel like being active, you might feel a bit achy so you make bad choices with food to feel better. Then it becomes a viscous cycle.  Any diets work with 100% willpower. That's the hard bit. Being good all the time is flipping hard! Dieting alone won't give you the results that diet and excercise will give. If you are content with how you look now I would say give the tamoxifen a go.  im a healthy weight and very active but do the 5:2 diet as it suits my lifestyle and I like having two days per week where I control calorie intake.  Your BC unit will have access to diet advice. I was also given advice e by a dietitian at a moving on session. To be honest though it's pretty generic advice. We all know what are healthy choices. There is lots of evidence that says being overweight increases your risk with ER+ BC.  Exercise makes you feel great after and you continue to burn calories well after the session.  I'm a big advocate of exercise because if you get that right you will find you don't have to worry about dieting. i do appreciate its daunting but please do take on board other ladies experience of weight loss such as Kacang. It's an truely inspirational example. Good luck and all the best Julia x
Posts.Title: Weight gain with Tamixifen

Posts.Content: Hi Annie I am assuming your dressing have been removed and you are good to go in the bath now. The advice given about non perfumed etc is too reduce the chance of irritation. It will be the same with anything you put on your skin around the surgery site. Try and use non perfumed or organic products that have less chemicals in them. Maybe a bath oil? I never stopped using shower gel - but then I always use organic products. Holland and Barrett have a good range as do Waitrose.
Posts.Title: Bathing

Posts.Content: Hello  congratulations on getting through chemo and good on you for seeking help when you need it.  Your husband leaving his job to take good care of you speaks volumes. I'm sorry to hear you think your diagnosis will affect a 30 year marriage ( I'm in awe of thirty years!).  My 8 year relationship with my partner went downhill during and after treatment but is now on its way back on track. I had 5 months of counselling. My partner is also someone who thinks counselling is a waste of time. It angers me because he's never tried it even though he fought in the Falklands and has major baggage. Some men are just to stubborn and short sighted. However that's not a reason why you should not have counselling. Counselling is to help you back on track. Part of that counselling will be talking about your relationship and youll get help with coping strategies. Do this for you. You can always try and come back from counselling and drip feed to your husband what happens at counselling, he might become more receptive when he sees the benefit you are getting. A happy wife is worth their weight in gold or so I am told!  All the best with it. My counselling was a life saver .  Julia
Posts.Title: Feeling so angry tired and weak

Posts.Content: Hi Under Par  Yay, the first hurdle is ticked off. Good on you. How long you are left between chemo and surgery will depend upon a number of things. What response have you had to chemo? or what response do they think you have had? If it looks like you have had a complete response then time isn't critical. I waited 10 weeks between chemo and surgery but it was confirmed I had  a PCr. The other point is as you say, when you are fit for surgery. Bearing in mind though that there was only three weeks between chemo cycles, your body could be ready for surgery in 4 weeks or so. I would say, don't be in a rush if your consultant isn't as the long recovery in between is ideal. I coped with surgery really well as I had 10 weeks to get fighting fit again. It is a little concerning however that you haven't talked to your surgeon to go through surgery options. You need to be guided by him. Do you have an appointment with him soon? Assuming you have finished chemo now? Love Julia x
Posts.Title: How long after chemo will I have surgery?

Posts.Content: Phew. So glad it's sorted for you Wendy. I wish you more than luck on Monday. Here's to a speedy recovery x
Posts.Title: NO DISCUSSION

Posts.Content: Work can't just 'get Rid' of you after being on long term sick. Or rather it's a very silly employer that thinks they can not adhere to legislation. You are protected.  Is it policy for yourHR to make contact with whilst you are sick? I work for a very large employer and to be honest HR were the last people I would have wanted to speak to whilst going through treatment. I did however have almost monthly contact with my line manager and he fed back. I find most people in HR have the least empathy!  I'm sorry that you don't feel supported by work colleagues. Do you think it's because they don't know how to support you? I had to spell a lot of stuff out as everyone assumed as I looked well I was back to normal. Maybe these are people you don't need support from then you wouldn't feel so angry towards them. One thing cancer does and that is make you realise who you want in your life. If they don't help you don't let them in.
Posts.Title: Feeling so angry tired and weak

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy  My pre-op was done at outpatients and literally was height, weight, bp and bloods and I was given my pre op drinks. Nothing was checked regarding the BC side.  You do need to find out what surgery your surgeon is performing on Monday as if you are undecided then he obviously doesn't know that and the type needs agreeing now. It will be too last minute Monday. You will see your surgeon pre op but that shouldn't be the time to agree what type of surgery you are having. You will also be required to sign to say what op it is and agree to the risks involved. My surgery was agreed weeks before I had it. I met with my surgeon three times before I agreed on surgery.  Have you actually met your surgeon yet? I agree with you totally this seems too last minute. I hope it gets sorted tomorrow x
Posts.Title: NO DISCUSSION

Posts.Content: Hi Doglady  This is a good example of why the endopredict is useful. It's more scientific than the 'opinion' of the oncologist. I would take it as a good thing in your situation because the test proved u you benefit. Not having chemo would have put you at more risk. there are bad side affects and there are bad side effects! If your oncologist thought the effects you were having we're life threatening or changing he would stop it. Whilst they feel awful se to you and indeed did  to me they are 'normal'. I had fECT and was hospitalised twice after becoming septic and had UTIs and recurring thrush amongst a whole host of effects. All of which I recovered very well from.  chemo is horrid but it has to be more powerful than cancer hence the effects. Hang on in there it will come to an end. Do remember to have over two litres of water/liquid per day. That will help with the UTI. Julia X
Posts.Title: oncoDX result

Posts.Content: Hi Anne  you will stil get yearly mammograms with the breast care unit? It's just oncology who are discharging you.  To be fair when I see my oncologist (I'm still on my first 12 months post diagnosis) all he does is manually check my breast which I do regularly so I can understand why that comment was made to you. You probably check your breasts very regularly now so it is realistic you would pick something up? ive read similar comments on here regarding this so its not unique to Bucks.  Please do check on those annual mammograms though.
Posts.Title: Annual checks

Posts.Content: Hi boneyem1  I'm sorry things haven't eased for you. Do get the lump in the armpit checked out if nothing else but to appease the anxiety. Can you revisit the counselling sessions? How long did you have them for? My counsellor was only happy to wrap the sessions up when I was in a good place. It sounds like you may have stopped to soon. Do you think more would be useful?  The emotional fallout of a cancer diagnosis is quite often referred to as similar to PTSD that's why your quick fix counselling may not have been enough especially as you are so far on from your diagnosis now.  Have you tried the Macmillan helpLine? I think you would benefit from calling. Do consider calling if you haven't already.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Thinking of breast removal

Posts.Content: You make a very valid point Fiona. You don't feel comfortable in your own skin. Your own skin isn't your old skin. Cancer takes so much from us. You won't look feel or behave like you did before. The trick is learning to do these things again. Learning to be comfortable in your own skin.  Cry when you need too. That level of emotion can't do any good being held inside. It is worth getting upset about because this is a really big deal. A huge deal.  You are now grieving for the post BC you. That doesn't mean to say the new you isn't better than the last. Temporarily she make have a few extra pounds but that will come off.... Long term in not tomorrow or next week or next month.  julia X
Posts.Title: A bit of a ramble....and a thank you!

Posts.Content: Hi iwannaliveforever  i guess ultimately you need to decide if you disclose the cancer to your employer. That then gives you the opportunity to wear the scarf. They can't say no to you.  My employer knew my diagnosis from the start and in turn my colleagues. I was overwhelmed by love and support from them despite me not going into work for 11 months.  There might be times when you can't go into work so you need to be prepared. You may of course be lucky and not need any time off At all but you can never tell.  Having a word with the Principal but expressing that you want your diagnosis kept quiet I'm sure will be enough for that to happen.  I didn't find I was treated any differently just with more compassion which actually helped me get through.  I do appreciate however it's a hard thing to do. Julia X
Posts.Title: Women in France - scarves in schools

Posts.Content: Hi Dolina  This is very common and is a form of PTSD. It's recognised as a clinical post cancer condition. I fell apart after keeping 'my stiff upper British lip' when treatment finished. For me it was more about thinking I had to completely change my life in order to move on and I didn't know where to start. I ended up having months of counselling as my everyday life was being affected. Have a read of the following. If nothing else it's affirmation of why and what you are feeling. http://www.cancercounselling.org.uk/Peter%20Harvey%20-%20After%20the%20Treatment%20Finishes%20then%20What.pdf?openElement Ask your BC unit for any moving on support they offer. It really helps. Now is the time to be asking for help but be assured it's common to be feeling this way. Sending hugs.... This will pass. Julia X
Posts.Title: Now the treatment is over

Posts.Content: Hi smb1970  An 8% decrease in risk is not to be sniffed at. i was triple negative so there were no question marks over whether I'd have chemo. However the oncotype test is a good test and the theory behind it is to give some scientific evidence behind what chemo can do for you. Ultimately you have to make the decision based upon how you feel, not how your husband feels. He's probably scared for you because chemo does affect you dramatically, albeit temporarily And he's probably unsure on how you will cope. I was so scared having Tnbc that I would have done anything to not go through a recurrence. At 41 years I was not planning on leaving a 9 year old child. You could say it was easier for me as I had little choice however with an 8% decrease in risk i would take it. If you decide not to take it it's a decision you have to be at peace with in the future.  I am 20 months post chemo and dont have any long term side effects. I did go into chemo however very fit. I have managed to get back to that level of fitness but it all takes time.  i think you need to say to your husband he should just say he will support you either way. Anyone not faced with a decision like this can't possibly offer an informed opinion because it's your cancer, your body and your future and chemo is very powerful.  All the best Julia X
Posts.Title: oncoDX result

Posts.Content: Hi ali73 I just wanted to say that from what I know about lobular bc (my type) it doesn't influence whether you have chemo or not. On diagnosis, lobular cancer means there is a higher risk of it being in both breasts simultaneously or elsewhere in the body. If after investigations you have just one solitary tumour its treated the same as ductal. I would question whether the lobular aspect of the diagnos really affects the Onco tyoe score.  julia X
Posts.Title: oncoDX result

Posts.Content: Dear Heather  It was lovely to read your post. I have been wondering how you were. Sorry to read that rt wasn't kind to you especially after the flap surgery.  It sounds like you have taken good control of the letrozole decision. It did its job pre surgery but as you say, the SE now aren't worth it. Good on you.  I too have found I will never be the same but realise as the months roll by that I actually like what I have changed into. Yes I'm rough around the edges but there are many things I have learnt about myself that are positives. This applies to you too Heather. You have shown courage and patience, such patience with the letrozole. I can say from your posts you are a very gentle and compassionate human being and I do really wish you all the very best.  For me, counselling was equally if not more important than the conventional treatment. I had sessions over 5 months starting 6 weeks after I finished RT and it helped so much. My head is in the space it needs to be in to enjoy life again. And enjoy life I do.  Take care Heather. We are always here if you need us.  Much love julia X
Posts.Title: Four weeks post radiation and my thoughts

Posts.Content: Hi Jammyfiona  i can totally relate to how you are feeling. My feelings got the better of me and I needed help moving on As we've discussed before. if you dwell on the negatives (or areas you aren't happy with) it will soon become all too overwhelming. It was for me. I had no idea where and how to start. You have all the time in the world now to 'move on'. This process is even more important than treatment itself. It's important to get it balanced. Trust me, in a years time you will look back and think phew. You will also be looking like you and feeling like you. It doesn't have to happen oVery night.  keep the negatives on the back burner. You still have RT to go yet.  Julia X
Posts.Title: A bit of a ramble....and a thank you!

Posts.Content: Hi Clump (Lucy) For me kinesio taping was an alternative to compression and the only thing to work for me. I had odema in the breast only and just like you, found wearing compression vests made me feel worse than the odema itself and did absolutely nothing to help. I didn't find my lymphoedema clinic very helpful. After using kinesio tape after 6 weeks I saw results. This was last August. The tape stays good for up to 5 days before it needs reapplying depending upon how sticky it stays. I use Rocktape. I used a cheap alternative but it made me itch like crazy.  im now discharged from the lymphoedema clinic now as the odema has gone. I get occasional 'flare' ups where I use tape for 3-5 days then it goes. I massage/moisturise each night wich takes minutes.  I run upto  15 miles a week and it's ok with a decent sports bra.  My experience with clinics is that they tend to let the odema get worse before they move on to taping!  In my opinion I would look at having it now before it gets worse. I'm certainly glad mine was nipped in the bud so to speak. Julia X
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: Morning WORRIED2016  Remember we had a conversation about being ready to drive a few weeks back? The more you are doing the more you are working against the healing process. Be kind to your booby :) if you can bear to touch the boob then gently massage it daily. Any moisturiser will do. I mean really gently though. It will help with the fluid too. Massage towards the good boob.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Tell me about your scars

Posts.Content: For those that haven't yet tried kinesio taping, do seriously consider it. I had lymphoedema in the breast and nothing worked until I had kinesio taping. I had to pay for it privately as my lymphoedema clinic was so slow to treat. lymphoedema really is best treated at very first signs and straight in with manual drainage (voder) and taping. In my experience compression garments aren't enough.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: Hi Hobbs (Jan)  i was lucky in the respect that I found a very good Dutch lady who I started using for massage during chemo. She also happened to be trained in manual drainage and taping. In Holland taping is done very early on. To be honest once you know how the tape needs to be applied you can do it yourself  With the help of a partner. I buy Rocktape. The tape is cut into tails and placed into certain positions. The idea being it lifts the skin to allow better drainage. I did self massage daily and used the tape for around 2/3 Months. I no longer need it. Some lymphoedema clinics do offer it but they tend to wait until symptoms are servere before they offer it. Some sports therapists are used to kinesio taping but you need to check they can use it for oedema. Google vodder specialists in your area because they are also often trained in taping.  Try searching images on kinesio taping for odema in the arm and that will give you an idea of what it looks like.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: Hi T smith  Courses of chemo are standard. You won't get more or less than standard unless of course you have such a dangerous reaction it has to be stopped. This applies whether you have chemo adjuvantly or neoadjuvantly.  Having chemo first gives the benefit of seeing it work on the tumour. As already described here, if you have a pCR (pathological complete response) then your prognosis is better than if you still have residual cells. However there is also the worry that you don't get such a good result. Triple neg and her2 BC responds better to chemo. I was TNBC and had a pcr. In my case it was chemo that worked the best.  If you have surgery first and your nodes are affected or you have vascular invasion or a large tumour/multiple sites you would be recommended for chemo. There are no good measures to see if chemo taken adjuvantly has done anything. You only hope that any cells that may be hiding out somewhere in your body are found and destroyed but you can't measure that. In which case you would have the prescribed amount of sessions ( norm is 6). Courses are normally broken into two as you switch drugs half way through. Different drugs work in different ways. So you would need everything to complete the process.  Some people have weekly sessions rather than 3 weekly due to pre existing medical conditions that could be made worse by chemo.  It is common however for doses to be lowered if you have severe side effects. That happened to me.  I wish you all the best with it if you end up going down that route.  Julia X
Posts.Title: My apologies as I am not sure if my question crosses all groups

Posts.Content: Sounds good Hobbs (Jan). I was very happy with taping and I occasionally need to do it but its well under control now. Have a wonderful holiday - I went on holiday after being taped up last August and ended up looking like a Zebra ha ha. My fingers are crossed for you x
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: Hello Rebeccboo  your man and your family sound lovely.  Your diagnosis is still so recent. The further you get away from it the less fearful you become.  My diagnosis (TNBC) was 17 months ago. I had neoadjuvant  chemo, WLE axilla clearance and 15 RT sessions. Got through it all pretty unscathed although initially there were many dark moments however it all fell apart when the treatment finished. I had 11 months away from the office. ive just finished 5 months of counselling and a 6 week 'moving on' course. Both have been lifesavers and I feel fantastic now. I really do. Life is back on track and better in some ways. I always wonder if triple neg ladies are hit harder by the psychological effects purely as we have had the Unknown breast cancer. And to be honest you generally find people talk about triple neg very negatively! I no longer fear TNBC . I can't change it and actually we have positive things about TNBC.  If you find your pyschological state stops you functioning day to day, do seek help. Your BC unit can arrange it.  This time last year I was having my last chemo. I remember watching my 9 year old in a carnival and openly wept the whole way through. Every time I looked at her it was overwhelming. Those feelings are no longer a year on.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Hello fiddlesticks    i hope sleep did come to you. It's one of many things on a long long list of things that can happen when you have a cancer diagnosis.  If you do find yourself staring up at the ceiling and finding your mind in dark places, distract it. Get up and distract it until you are calm again. There are some good ideas on here already.   As humans we like to make sense of things of things and at the moment nothing is making sense hence the feeling of no control. We all like structure and to be in control. You have to accept that just for a while you will be told what you have to do and you follow instructions and you will have to do whatever you body needs to do just to get through treatment. It's a short price to pay if it gives you many many years left on this earth. At 41years I willing said it would be 12 months out of my life and I gave it. Now I'm well out of of the tunnel and life is very bright again.  I had 11 months away from the office and kept thinking during treatment I want to get back. I have now been back at work for five months and guess what..........I now realise that I enjoyed my time whilst not working, even though I felt rubbish for some of it, I spent more time with family, friends and my daughter and doing things that made me happy. Work doesn't always Make me happy! Use this time wisely and do things that make you happy. It's well worth it.  The 'what ifs' is a hard one but you will get ontop of it as time moves on. Again I say this in hindsight, but when you are in the midst of treatment you are doing everything possible to get cancer free. The what ifs therefore won't affect treatment and the outcome. You are doing all you can. The hardest part is when treatment stops and you have to trust that body of yours to behave. Let the what ifs go during this time.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Hi maggiemnou  My rib soreness came on after the first chemo two years ago. I have since put it down to the GCSF injections. I had a bone scan  last year and nothing appeared so it was put down to one of those things.  It doesn't cause me any trouble it's just a soreness under the bottom rib on my unaffected side. It is worse after heavy exercise but it's not so painful I need pain relief. Apparently rib pain is quite common after treatment. It's good you have a name for the diagnosis although but it does sound it causes issues with you.  Sorry I cant be of more help but I would imagine other ladies on here have had rib problems after treatment So you may find more help to follow. Julia X
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Jan  the tape is placed so it should lift the skin. Wearing a compression garment ontop will compress the tape and you will restrict drainage X.
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: A warm welcome Loulou99 . What a Christmas present your oncologist has given you ;)  6 lots of chemo every three weeks is pretty standard.  We have an brill 'chemo club'. If you follow this link you will find a great blog on handy and helpful tips.  community.macmillan.org.uk/.../118955 My advice is eat little but often tomorrow and don't eat lots of heavy sweet things. Drink lots and I mean lots of water before and then every day after chemo until you feel better. Be prepared for nausea but it's important to keep eating little and often. Take the anti sickness tabs even if you don't feel sick.  The first chemo is scary but you will be well looked after.  Be gentle on yourself when you get home and sleep as much as you can. Walk daily if you can too. Fresh air is a great healer. All the best for tomorrow. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Fidst chemo session tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Jammyfiona  Dont write yourself off yet in terms of being peri menopausal as its too early to be sure. My periods returned 5 months after chemo for a few months then went haywire again. I had a blood test and it came back I was peri menopausal. However a month later and ever since i have had very regular periods so am no where near the menopause I'm pleased to say.  as you say, periods returning are a good thing.  Your GP should do a blood test if you want it but they may say it's still early days to see if you are entering into the menopause. You aren't officially through menopause until 12 months of no periods.  Ive had a bone scan since finishing treatment but that was to check out a rib problem. If you have an ailment that needs checking you should get support from your oncologist. Mine is fantastic. I mention a niggle and he deals with it To reassure me. To be honest I rarely see my GP as I'm still seeing surgeon and oncologist 2 years on from diagnosis.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: Pin interest is amazing. I made all my Christmas cards last year and even personalised Christmas presents which bought tears to my families eyes. I loved looking through getting ideas then making things. I had just finished chemo so was starting to feel better. Can highly recommend it.
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Hello Jenny  i don't get to take any hormonal suppressors as I was triple negative but I can tell that you are at the end of your tether.  Ultimately you can choose to have a break from the herceptin or stop it completely.  I can't imagine anyone blaming you should the cancer dare to return if you choose to stop the drugs. If you could live with that risk and feel better in the short term then would that be better for you? If you can live with that decision that's all that matters.  Speak with your oncologist and be guided into a decision whether the the current side effects outweigh the risk of recurrence.  It is now 7 months since you spoke to your BCN and you say you are still waiting? On no level is that acceptable. Try the oncologist or if you can face a battle, start shouting more loudly at your BC unit or you will carry on suffering.  All the best.  Julia
Posts.Title: feed up

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea I found that moving in bed caused me to wake and be nauseous. I did in time learn sub consciously not to move around in bed but its hard to do. You could put pillows around you to help keep you still. Are you eating small amounts regularly? Nausea can be worse when you have an empty tummy. It maybe that you need a little snack before bed. Taking tablets on an empty stomach isn't great either. You should find that the nausea is getting better from now on. Julia x
Posts.Title: Controlling nausea overnight

Posts.Content: Hi Kirsteen78  It is something you need to clarify with your surgeon but it is common to take the surrounding nodes from the ones that were positive. To achieve clear margins if you like. I do know that more surgeons are reluctant to do this now due to the risk of lymphoedema but you need to be sure the remaining nodes have in no way been affected. I had one node affected and 11 removed At the same time as my WLE.  Give your BC nurse a buzz after the weekend. You do need to know what hormonal status you are and what grade. They might be leaving that to the oncologist to tell you. It would have been part of the pathology results so it sounds like your being drip fed information to be honest.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Pathology results

Posts.Content: Hi Cocopops1  Sounds like this was sprung on you. Genetic testing for BC only relates to the brca gene mutation so that was always on the cards. im surprised with only you with a BC diagnosis they are testing you. Is there ovarian and prostate cancer in the family?  I was TNBC and was tested for the brca mutation. It was negative. Are you able to wait until April for the results before making a decision regarding RT? (Not sure where you are in treatment)  love Julia x
Posts.Title: Genetics

Posts.Content: I was Brca tested but my appointment didn't even come through until after I had surgery either. I then waited 3 months for the results. Luckily it was a negative.  Hold out until Monday when you get your surgery results. I was dreading mine too but was told there was no evidence of any cancer cells left after chemo so you never know.  keep distracted until Monday if you can. Monday will give you a way forward X
Posts.Title: Not coping/coping with the wait for results.

Posts.Content: Hi Maria You do need to be able to discuss this situation in a controlled environment so do pursue the counseling route. Too me it sounds like you have tried very hard to resolve these issues but they remain unresolved due to your Mum. You in turn now need to decide to move on from this and leave it all behind. You cannot second guess or even give reasons why she is being like this. To be honest I am not sure it would be helpful even if you did know the reasons. I learnt that parents can act in the strangest way when a child has cancer. I had the same with my mum although now my mum and I never talk about 'things' because I was very angered by her actions when I was going through treatment. I don't blame her now but I just know that she isn't my 'crutch' if and when I need to talk about things. If your mum is damaging your mental state you need to take her out of the picture at present until you get proper help . If you can talk to others about your diagnosis then you don't need to talk to your mum. It feels natural that as children, we go to our parents when we are in trouble. Not all parents find they deal with that pressure 'naturally'. I am guessing she just wants 'things to get back normal' and wishes you would too but ironically she cant see that she is the barrier to you doing this. Due to the length of time that has passed since you have finished treatment It is a good thing you are seeking help. Don't have any expectations from your Mum any more. Talk to your husband and in turn she wont get between you and your husband. Its obvious that your mum is stopping you form 'moving on' and that cant go on. All the best - I wen through 4 months of counseling post treatment. Julia x
Posts.Title: Extended family have turned their back on me

Posts.Content: I made my own covers out of some old patterned tights (like the black lace effect only not fish net ha ha ) . I did get use to it though. I had mine from July til November. To be honest I was more distracted by managing my hair loss! I did make all my picc cleaning appointments at hospital (they said I could have a home visit) and it was good going in every week especially 4 days after I had chemo as it forced me to get up and about. I enjoyed the contact with the chemo nurses too. X
Posts.Title: picc line's any tips on management,

Posts.Content: Hi Apple This can be a worrying time and I know your mind can take over rational thinking and give nothing but negative thoughts, however you need your body to heal after surgery. To do this you need a positive frame of mind. I had counselling between chemo and surgery as my head got totally scrambled over deciding what operation to have. (In hind site it seems ridiculous!) t helped massively. It taught me to look at the positives and negatives and see which outweighs each other. There were always more positives than negatives and that's how I continue to view treatment and moving on.  If you do have some nodes tested as positive how will it have changed your treatment? It probably wouldn't have. If they were positive they are now out of your body along with the cancer cells in your breast. Gone. Radiotherapy/chemo (if u have it) will also be giving added protection.  If you have triple neg Bc you have a higher chance of lymph node involvement. That's how TNBC behaves.  I had two nodes affected but was told this from original biopsie so I always knew from the start.  Your brain is probably telling you that if the nodes have been affected it's more serious.... But that's not the reality.  Here's to a speedy recovery. All the best. Julia.
Posts.Title: anxiety between mastectomy and lymph results

Posts.Content: None of us realise how strong we can be until we have no choice. It does take it's toll eventually though. You will mean everything to your mum at this time. I am very grateful for the amazing support I have,  even from my ten year old daughter! I am a fire safety officer with The local fire & rescue service. I have been doing it for 14 years and my employer has been very supportive. Have a good day mags and mag's mum xx
Posts.Title: Invasive carcinoma&never no stage given?

Posts.Content: Hello  I'm now approaching 6 months post chemo. Whilst going through it I felt the same. Each day was a challenge. I counted every day down. Chemo not only messes with the body, ithink others underestimate how it messes with your head. Saying that, 6 months on I have no lasting side effects (apart from short hair of course!). I had regular massage throughout chemo, slept in the day, walked daily and literally just existed. Don't put pressure on yourself. Try the app mind space for meditation. It takes a while to get into but helped me. Keep going, please, it gets better. I know it feels like a big black hole at the moment but it's the chemo. Xx
Posts.Title: Today has been a blurrrr

Posts.Content: Hi Barbiebee  You may have found yourself in a bit of a vicious circle. The aim of the exercises is encourage movement to return. They do hurt when you do them but the idea s to slowly build up over time. Doing a couple more each day and increasing the range of movement each time. You do have to push yourself. Have you had a post op check yet? Do you have a seroma and/or odema which is causing a problem? Have you got any cording? Really stretching the arm can help.  You could try having a break of a couple of days then get back on it but in my experience the less mobile you become the worse it gets. Take pain relief at optimum times before you exercise. Does that help? Julia X
Posts.Title: Post op arm exercises

Posts.Content: Hello Ann I haven't managed to see what hormonal status your BC is? This does make a difference with what reaction you get from chemo. It's important for anyone having neoadjuvant chemo to know how different types of BC react to chemo. To compare with others isn't a good thing. Er+ tends not to respond as well as TNBC but the playing field equals out as TNBC doesn't respond to hormonal therapies and er+ responds very well as a preventative drug.  Different chemotherapies work in different ways so not being affected by Doctaxol doesn't mean EC/FEC won't have any affect.  The outcomes of chemo are so broad from complete pathological response, partial response to no response.  If you had chemo after surgery you will never know what affect its had on you so some consider neo adjuvant chemo a better prognosis outcome.  I would definitely say don't be despondent as EC could be the game changer.  Don't feel you've wasted treatment with T because without having it you would have never known what response you could have.  Definately Don't lose hope. Julia X
Posts.Title: lump is got bigger

Posts.Content: Hello Carole I am sorry to read you are finding yourself dealing with cancer again. The waiting is awful isn't it. There are ladies on here that are affected by secondary cancer, some for many years now. I do know secondary cancer in the bone can be effectively managed. You may find that these ladies have moved over to the 'secondary breast cancer' forum and You get a quicker response from that side. All the best. Julia x
Posts.Title: Breast to bone?

Posts.Content: It's often the case with TNBC (or rather more so than Er+) that nodes are effected by the time of diagnosis. The majority of TNBC are grade 3 but saying that, I was a grade 2 as I said.  Im doing ok thank you Mags. I'm back at work now after 11 months off. I'm not saying I'm great as the psychological effects of the last 11 months are taking effect now but physically I am well. i have recently read lots of good news about TNBC in that scientists are making good progress with finding a preventative drug and learning much more about TNBC. Keep up the positivity, you are doing fab x
Posts.Title: Invasive carcinoma&never no stage given?

Posts.Content: I only do large glasses and I did drink during RT. If you make sure you rehydrate the next morning I would say that's ok. As you say, it's not like you are gonna get smashed every night. If it brings a smile to your face then go for it.  Cheers x
Posts.Title: Drinking alcohol while undergoing radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I'm 5ft 11 and 11 stone but would still have reacted in the same way!  Don't be in a hurry to invite that friend into your house again.  I think I would have had to shove her out of the door pretty quickly. Chin up lovely. Clearly your friend has little empathy and zilch experience of cancer. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Really bloody angry !!!

Posts.Content: LondonLass  Happy birthday xx
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: Hi mags  carcinoma is the term for cancer used by professionals. The proper name if you like when the tumour has grown out and away from the milk ducts (invasive) and free to move around the body. Invasive is the type of  breast cancer. The types are invasive lobular or invasive ductal. The other types are ductal carcinoma in Situ (non invasive).   I am surprised your mum hasn't  been given a grade of cancer. My experience was that at the time I had my biopsie they tested the grade (2 in my case) along with hormone receptor status. The grade measures the abnormality of the cells. Grade 3 cells grow more quickly than 2. I was also told during the original ultrasound it looked like 2 lymph nodes were effected. Did they look at your mums nodes when they did an ultrasound when she was first tested? As for stage, if your mum had MRI/bone scan/ct scan before starting chemo they would have known that they were only treating the cancer in her breast. The question is whether they knew at the start if lymph nodes may of been effected. They would also know the approx size of the tumour from an MRI.   Even if you have chemo first, when surgery happens and they look at the lymph nodes (dissection) they can still tell if a node had previously been affected by cancer as it looks diffferent. Also the tissue and nodes removed after surgery are tested to see if there are cancer cells present and if 'clear margins' have been achieved. I didn't get to see my stage until I started radiotherapy but I worked it out to be T2 (stage 2). Hope that helps xx
Posts.Title: Invasive carcinoma&never no stage given?

Posts.Content: fluorouracil (5FU) can cause changes to the heart. I think if there is an pre existing condition with a patients heart then it's not given. The other two are epirubicin and cyclophosphamide. Not sure what they G is unless that's a typo?
Posts.Title: Fec

Posts.Content: Hi Claire If it is something that has happened after you have had your first chemo then its more than likely that your immune system is just still not recovered enough yet to be able to prevent the thrush. Two months post chemo isn't long in terms of your immune system being back on top. If you however mention to your oncologist that it happened before chemo he will probably say chemo isn't the cause. Its very common whilst going through chemo especially docetaxol. Julia x
Posts.Title: 2 months after chemo

Posts.Content: The little things Jan. Makes all the difference.  I'm still brushing out chemo curls 15 months on!
Posts.Title: Tangles

Posts.Content: Ask for and take Emend anti sickness and get another packet of anti sickness such as metroclopramide. Drink lots of water and at least 2 litres post chemo.  Dont eat a massive meal before hand and avoid sweet sickly foods. Eat small amounts regularly.  My advice too.... please enjoy today and forget what comes tomorrow.  Xx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: I'm with you wsarahw.  You have lost part of you. Having those feelings doesnt  make you vain. I didn't consider myself vain. I like myself with hair how I want it. I hated (yes hated) having no hair and then short hair. I look back at photos and cringe. It wasn't me at all no matter how well I embraced the slap head.  im two years post chemo and my hair length is now where I feel most comfortable. Its weird though seeing the shape of your head isn't it. Something we would not normarily  have to do.  You may find it chilly in bed too.  in fact it's just plain weird without hair BUT keep in the back of your mind that this baldness indicates you saying good bloody riddance to cancer. Hugs Julia x
Posts.Title: Braved the Shave

Posts.Content: Hi Helsbels  Dreamthief has recently answered a very similar question and pointed us in the direction of the Allred scoring system  medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Allred scoring system According to this system a 6/8 has a 50% success rate compared to 75% with a 8/8. I had a 3/8 score which was deemed negative so the term 'weak' may mean it's not the top score but also not to be dismissed. You are still going to get a lot of benefit. Speak with your oncologist but I wouldn't be dismissive of this result as you only get a max of 75% of benefit and you aren't far behind this. Julia X
Posts.Title: Weak er +?

Posts.Content: Have you not been booked in for a mammogram/ultrasound? it is us usual you have one half way through chemo then at the end.  I know it's hard to not stop feeling yourself to check on progress but your mind can play tricks. Mind did until I had my scans. speak to your oncologist/Bc nurse and ask why you haven't been scanned.  All the very best xx
Posts.Title: Can't tell if its growing or shrinking

Posts.Content: The docetaxel made my breast feel different at different times through the chemo cycle. It also looked like it would swell at some points. Even though my periods stopped after one docetaxel I still get hardending around my period due date. These made me worry. let your oncologist examine you and guide you on what is happening xx
Posts.Title: Can't tell if its growing or shrinking

Posts.Content: JJsailor im so happy to read this.  I too will keep an eye on your blog. It's been lovely to meet you virtually albeit on rubbish circumstances. Your new adventures sound just perfect and I have to admit to being very envious of.  May your life be full of many more adventures. Be safe out there. You are a very courageous lady.  All the best Julia X
Posts.Title: Nearly there

Posts.Content: hi Soups  The 6 months full pay is familiar so they are in their right to stop paying you now however you might like to check how they have put you on SSP against what the companies policy is. It's unusual not to give warning you are being moved off full pay and they should have given you chance to plan and put forward a return to work plan before SSP commenced.  It sounds too me like they are trying to be sneaky but you need to catch them out on abusing process if you can. All of your meetings (even coffee) should be documented so it sounds easy to prove if they haven't followed procedure. Your immediate line manager will be st fault if the end of full pay wasn't communicated before it happened. Julia X
Posts.Title: Worried sick

Posts.Content: Hi  I'm sorry to read of your diagnosis and your husbands.  I've had BC. Diagnosed 17 months ago but I have no experience of being a carer. Were you looking support for the BC? We can provide lots of that as this is a very active forum. I'm sorry you have found the site disappointing. I hope you don't get that impression form the BC forum. I find invaluable support here. Feel free to ask any questions. When were you diagnosed?
Posts.Title: All about face!

Posts.Content: Hi Matt Glad to hear the chemo end is in sight. I was also triple negative and had neo adjuvant chemo too. When you say treatment is coming to an end, if I've read things correctly she has surgery and possible RT to go yet? therefore she's only1/3 of the way through so still lots to be done to get rid of anything that may be left. Its very difficult for an oncologist to predict how a tumour will react to chemo. I am a big advocate of having chemo first but there is always the risk that you expect better results than what actually happens. However, I will say this. At the end of chemo I couldn't feel my tumour but was told to expect when they did the WLE that there was every possibility they could discover more tumour that was hiding. This panicked me.  It wasn't until after I had a very good WLE (my breast has very little scaring and is still very similar to the other) I had the pathological results to say that I had had a complete response to chemo. There were no cells left in either my breast or the one affected lymph node. You are right, previous cancer in lymph nodes causes scaring but it may be that the cancer cells are gone. You wont know until after surgery. I went into a complete state of panic after chemo as I waited 10 weeks for surgery. In the end it made no difference to the outcome but at the time I automatically thought the worse. Its perfectly normal to be feeling these negative thoughts again but do stress to your wife, chemo has worked but until after surgery you wont know how well, surgery will be good in terms of minimal tissue being removed meaning your wife will hopefully be left with a decent breast shape still. and then you have RT which is belt and braces treatment. Hopefully you will get a date for surgery soon which will help the anxiety. Julia x
Posts.Title: Purgatory between chemo and surgery....

Posts.Content: Ask for and take Emend anti sickness and get another packet of anti sickness such as metroclopramide. Drink lots of water and at least 2 litres post chemo.  Dont eat a massive meal before hand and avoid sweet sickly foods. Eat small amounts regularly.  My advice too.... please enjoy today and forget what comes tomorrow.  Xx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: hi Hally12  You do already know the drill but it sounds like its no comfort. I know many ladies that have had a recall after post BC mammograms. mammograms are designed to pick things up early stages that's why they are important. Keep that in your mind... Early stages. Many of the women I know have gone on to have biopsys that have turned out to be nothing sinister. Because something has been seen it has to be acted upon. You've had BC once so are more at risk of a recurrence agsinst someone who hasn't had a diagnosis. We have to View the follow up we get as a positive. I'd never had a mammogram on diagnosis which meant my tumour was quite large before  felt it. How I wish the screening age was lowered.  Hormonal therapies do reduce your risk of recurrence that's why you get to take them. They are better than not taking anything to prevent recurrence.  Everything can still be lovely today, tomorrow and until the next tests. You are preempting something you have no way of knowing yet.  It has every reason to turn out to be nothing but if it isnt, remember early diagnosis is good. You will know what's what in the week. weekends are precious with children. Make the most of them.  My fingers are crossed for you. julia X
Posts.Title: 2 years - mammogram - received letter for tests

Posts.Content: It can take months and months. Put it this way, nearer 6 months than two months. Your oncologist will be able to say if 4 months of thrush is unusual. I had it all through docetacol and I had three 3 cycles so 9 weeks
Posts.Title: 2 months after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi susie  This is a common question and if we are led by 'breast care professionals' we would never colour our hair again!  Go for it. You can dye it anytime as long as you do a patch test and that goes ok. I had my hair dyed at the hairdressers 5 months post chemo which went really well and in hindsight I wish I had done it much earlier as my grey hair really got to me. Just bear in mind that hair is more fragile after chemo. It can take months and months to get back to how it was.  What type Of dye you use again is personal choice. Hair colours have not been linked to BC (see CRuk site) but natural dyes have less harshness in them. I use Paul Mitchell colour, done by a hairdresser.  Personally , I needed my hairdressers advice on how to manage my new crop of tight curls!  It made so much difference to me having my hair coloured and styled (I say styled loosely as there wasn't much styling to be done!).  Julia
Posts.Title: When can I colour my hair after chemo and do I need to use a vegetable...

Posts.Content: I remember you Baki And I'm very sorry to read you have a recurrence.  you don't  know yet what you are dealing with so you can't give in yet. You've given one big reason why not to give up. It's still early days. That survival instinct will kick in just as it did before. Give it time Lovely.  Allow yourself the outcome of the PET scan and the guidance of your specialists before you make decisions. It may be less involved than your mind is telling you now.  Do call the Macmillan helpline in the morning as it sounds like you could do with being heard. Please come back to us with the results if you need further support. We are always here. sending you hugs Julia X
Posts.Title: Devastated breast cancer recurrence

Posts.Content: It makes me angry when I read how employers treat staff. I was very very fortunate with my employer. I even find it weird that no one has been communicating with you whilst you were off. My line manage would speak to me at least every few weeks. I was very supported. OH is the way to go. My phased return lasted nearly six months.  I really do empathize. No one needs work bothers during or after treatmeby for cancer.  Go get em Mistia Grrrrrrerr :)  Julia X
Posts.Title: Worried sick

Posts.Content: See how you feel tomorrow after going to the private hospital. I think you will find its a lot of money In comparison to the NHS For the same thing. I looked into having a MX privately and it cost over £3,000. Many private hospitals wont/can't do Axilla clearance. The reality is the surgeon will be the one who would have treated you via the NHS.  I saved my money and did all the things I needed to do on my house. We all have visions of our BC taking over our bodies within days but it doesn't happen like this. Waiting 31 days for treatment to start isn't detrimental.  I can't fault the treatment/care I received through the NHS. You need to be sure that going down the private route will give you a better outcome than the NHS route and proving that will be very hard.  All the best for tomorrow Julia
Posts.Title: Private or NHS care/treatment decision

Posts.Content: I have seen them in Sainsburys today x
Posts.Title: Adult colouring books

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou1007  On the basis your elevated (and I would say they aren't worrying figures) results haven't caused any concern with your medical professionals then I wouldn't let it worry you to the point where it's causing more anxiety. It will turn into a chicken and egg situation. Youve had good BP results pre chemo so that's your norm.I don't think there is much in our bodies that remain 'normal' during chemo.  Your bp is taken regularly so it will be kept an eye on. your oncolgist will get involved if there's a perceived problem. To be honest I never really took much notice of my BP results whilst going through chemo. A raised bp may be a frequent side effect? Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Blood Pressure

Posts.Content: Hello Anne  congratulations on reaching the year post treatment mark. Like you, I would be anxious over what you have been told. Are they saying you won't have annual screening too?  I too had lobular BC and was told this isn't always picked up successfully on a mammogram which is why I had an MRI also. I can understand the little value in a 'check up' with a consultant in future years but would question no screening especially with a past lobular diagnosis.
Posts.Title: One year check - discharged!

Posts.Content: Hi SpicedTea (nicky) Are you auditioning for the festive period hehe. Rest assured i had 'bum fluff' on my face which disappeared just as quickly as it arrived and never to be seen since. Phew. I really wouldnt advise doing anything with it now. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Bearded lady

Posts.Content: Fantastic news congratulations. Your hair colour is fab too. Xx
Posts.Title: Another Neddy passes the finish post!

Posts.Content: I only had a WLE and node clearance so was only in overnight. I couldn't have survived without my iPhone headphones and iTunes and eye mask! Hospitals aren't conducive to sleep. Alk the best for your surgery  Julia xx
Posts.Title: What to take to hospital?

Posts.Content: Hi June_H  Congratulations on the 5 year mark. That's quite an achievement. I had a WLE two years ago and it's still all pretty neat so I won't have more surgery however I was always offered more if I wasn't happy. It may help asking for a consultation with your surgeon to be clear what exactly what he can offer You.  Sometimes it's more balancing things out by changing the other breast .  if after speaking you your surgeon you might think it sounds like something you would do or you might feel it's not worth it. All the best love Julia X
Posts.Title: Reconstructive work 5 years after original lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Carrie  sorry to read of your struggles.  On the basis you are feeling worse and not better as time goes on I would suggest you get checked out at your BC unit. You should be able to ring them direct, explain your symptoms then they will see you or advise the next steps.
Posts.Title: When do I feel better?

Posts.Content: I hope it all works out ok Hulahoop xx
Posts.Title: 2 years - mammogram - received letter for tests

Posts.Content: Hi Dulcie the BRCA genetic tests are provided on the NHS if you are entitled to free treatment? You don't pay for it. Your family breast/ovarian/prostrate history is considered and if you are considered at risk you can apply for testing. The downside is that it takes  months which is why you should ask now about it.  If you are found positive for the Brca gene mutation a bilateral mastectomy is normally recommended for risk reduction reasons.  Talk it over with your consultant .
Posts.Title: DCIS - hospital /surgeon choice / advice please ?

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear of your diagnosis. Having gone through BC I totally understand your fear.  im sorry you have found the consultants so far to be matter of fact. To be honest that is my preferred way to be dealt with because I can't do wishy washy touchy-feely but like u say you need to find someone you are comfortable with. Give it a while longer just to see when the shock does lessen a bit to see if you start warming to the consultant. Ultimately you can choose your surgeon. Our unit had two surgeons. Where are you in the country?  Because of your family history I really would suggest you talk to someone regarding a Brca mutation gene test as ultimately that could determine the type of surgery you have. This needs to be discussed soon.  All the best x
Posts.Title: DCIS - hospital /surgeon choice / advice please ?

Posts.Content: A lovely feathery cut and the lighter brown looks fab.
