(I'm guessing the avatar is you pre BC?)Don't stress to much about the length of the fringe (says me stressing over tight curls that have appeared gulp) as it shows those lovely worldly wise peepers off. Wear your new hairstyle with much pride xx
Posts.Title: Took the plunge and went to hairdressers today ...

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona Im not going to be much help to you as I had clearance at the same time as a WLE and that was after chemo.  When you say they removed 8, 2 of which were cancerous why are they saying you need more surgery if 6 removed weren't cancerous? I had 1 node affected and 11 removed as that was the cluster around the one affected. I think RT to the lymph area would be after many more nodes were affected Or if nodes are only slightly affected but don't warrant being removed.  If you think we have around 22 lymph nodes ish around this area sometimes they can all be affected In my more advanced Cases. To be honest if I were you I would be asking if the removal of all lymph nodes is necessary as you already had a safety net of 6 Clear. Having all nodes removed means you have the lymphoedema risk.  I had RT 8 weeks post surgery and it made my lymphoedema in the breast worse. Bearing in mind I had surgery to the breast also. RT to the lymph area heightens the risk of lymphoedema in the arm But then you are already at risk with nodes having been removed.  lit might be a case of swings and roundabouts but do ask if more surgery is absolutely necessary. Node clearance doesn't always mean they have to remove every single node.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: Fab news x
Posts.Title: NEDdy

Posts.Content: Yvonne what a day you have had. One you could do without at this time. One thing I know is as mothers we make it a priority to make our families happy, often at the detriment of ourselves. Your daughter wanted to shelter you from her news but she needed her mums shoulder to cry on. That's what mums do. Your husband probably had no intention of telling anyone about your lump until he had a few drinks. He probably needed that release but it wasn't the best environment to do it in. Here you are on Mother's Day feeling like you are picking up the pieces. I feel for you as I've found myself doing this lately with my own mother and it's making me resentful.    Even though u are a mum your all adults in your family and adults make their own choices, there sometimes is nothing you can do to change the choices they make. Put this down to lots of anxiousness for Tuesday. Tomorrow your husband will be sorry and you can hope he has a sore head! Do any of those things that make you get the steam out and look to tomorrow for bringing a calmer day. You need calm at the moment. Tell your husband how u feel tomorrow when he's open to discussion xx
Posts.Title: I just feel so angry with my self & everyone else

Posts.Content: Hi Jen72  Interviews are stressful at the best of times............. what will make you more at ease? This is the potential for a new start. Would you foresee yourself continuing to wear the scarf if/when you get the job? I would embrace this new start and go without the scarf. Your credentials and performance in the interview should overshadow what your head looks like! Very best of luck. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Job interview

Posts.Content: Hi Londongal  Sorry to read the wound isn't healing well. It doesn't often happen but complications can get in the way.  Your team will need you to be as fit as possible with a immune system raring to go for chemo. If your body is fighting infection still it's not ready. Chemo cant be taken lightly and if you start too soon you risk bigger side effects. Instead of asking when you can start, ask your oncologist how long you can be left before chemo can start and still be of benefit. I think you'll be surprised And find you still have a good window. I had chemo first and waited over ten weeks for surgery after. 5 weeks Post op is still recent. Try and eat for boosting your immune system and gentle walks where you can. Every little helps as they say. Julia X
Posts.Title: It worries me that my chemo is delayed because of Diep flap infec...

Posts.Content: Hello Sarah  I've just caught up on your progress. Glad the bone scan came back all ok. It's usual for scans to occur when nodes are affected. It really is just too double check you are only needing treatment for a primary cancer before you embark on chemo, if it's the route you are taken down. It is a shame you can't have a scientific approach to chemo Especially as you were Very early stages And low grade.  i do hope you can dodge this bullet. I'll keep my fingers crossed for you. julia XX
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: Hello Baki  Why would you give in to this disease. Ive not met you but I do know you are a good person whose been able to help others by sharing your experiences And you do it well.  You deal with this how the flipping heck you so wish. No one  will judge on here or in your virtual world.  Whether it works or doesn't work doesn't matter.... if you need to try, you need to try. If I put myself in your shoes I think I would be following the same path myself.  Treasure your family. Treasure your brother that's done this for you. That's love. Sending love your way  Julia xxx
Posts.Title: Guilt and Self loathing

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah The K status is asking if your pathology results said your BC expressed this protein. It's not often given to us and I'm not even sure if it's routinely checked for. It can mean a poorer prognosis.  The chemo regime asks if you had a second and third generation chemo. Third generation is usually a Taxane. If you were to have Fec t for example that's second and third generation. As you say though it's making little difference.  the stats are showing chemo and hormonal therapies will give little benefit. I would imagine because you are grade 1. Your survival stats without chemo and hormonal treatment are good.  Definitely a discussion point when your oncologists give their opinion on both hormonal treatments and chemo. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: Hi Gaynor This hasn't happened to me but I wonder if the heat has something to do with the swelling too. To be flying and into heat ater 3 weeks of chemo is quick and to be honest its fab that you feel well enough to be in Cyprus. I personally would however get it checked out to rule out anything sinister especially if the swelling is painful and hot. Julia x
Posts.Title: Swollen legs/feet

Posts.Content: It is a worrying time Yvonne but even with lymph node involvement it won't change any of your treatment plan. The positive is that whatever was left has now been removed and you still have RT to come. Try and think of it as a  short term setback in that you needed two lots of surgery instead of one. I knew from the start I had lymph node involvement so there were no surprises along the way but I appreciate it must be hard when things still unfold as treatment progresses.  I do hope you come away tomorrow with positive news. Let us know how you get on.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Isingbass  62 is only 5 years before retirement age and to be fair working until 62 is pretty flipping good. im 43 and want to retire! I always think you should live a large proportion of your life retired. Too many of us have to work to live and it's not a healthy state. I work with firefighters and the majority are retiring around me in their early 50's. I am envious. Don't get me wrong I love my job but I also love my life.  since having my child 12 years ago I haven't worked full time since. Having maternity and actually taking 11 months off for BC treatment always made me fully aware that I can fill my life without work. I just can't fund my life without work! Hey ho maybe the new year will bring a rich man :) i think this time next year you will be thinking retiring was the best decision you ever made.  i wish you well :) love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Retiring but scared...

Posts.Content: Keep drinking water JJ. I didn't get out of bed for three days after I had Fec so you are doing well with just a headache. My whole body use to throb. Your only 24 hours in so just take it as it comes. You won't become neutrophenic until around day 5 so your temp will be more important then. Take it easy.
Posts.Title: Is headache after FEC normal?

Posts.Content: Hello Heidi  You are right, as much as you want to, step away from that search engine. The periods of high anxiety always happen over a weekend don't they.  I would suggest you need to talk to your oncologist to put things into perspective and to give a prognosis due to having had chemo and still having cancer cells in your body now. You haven't said what receptor status you are? As you've had chemo already I'm guessing you are her2+ or triple neg?  if the oncologist thinks it necessary you my get body scans again. We all envisage cancer cells growing at the speed of notts but it's not the case . realistically the rest of your body won't have been affected between the original scans and now.  Only going back to your onc will really answer the questions in your head.  Try to box these thoughts up until Monday and seek advice then. do all the things you had planned this weekend in the meantime.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Lymph node involvement

Posts.Content: Hi Irish girl  unusual that your surgeon hasn't at least given you one follow up appointment. Regardless of what came back from pathology he has to communicate the results to you.  My treatment finished in March and I am seen every three months by breast surgeon and oncologist alternatively. I had chemo. This will be until January when i have my first mammogram 12 months post surgery.  You need a follow up plan so start shouting or taking it higher.  Do however check yourself regularly. Don't leave the checking to the consultants. You know your boobs better than them.  Julia
Posts.Title: Feeling list

Posts.Content: The flushes are all part of the effect chemo has on hormones. My flushes stopped two months post chemo. My periods returned 5 months post chemo. Bear in mind though, if you take hormonal therapies after chemo then this will continue suppressing hormones and the flushes will more than likely continue. At each follow up session with your oncologist he will ask if your periods have returned. They do however like to wait around 12 months post chemo before checking via a blood test you aren't in peri menopause. Julia x
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and cold at night

Posts.Content: Hi masquerade2010  its nice to have you join in the posts. I'm glad you feel comfortable to do that now. I'm sorry to read about your husband. Cancer is cruel.  Im not going to be a great help as I did get a BC diagnosis. I was told from the start I would only get my results in person. I knew no different. However please be mindful that whatever is in your breast will need treatment or a course of action and they generally like to give that face to face rather than on the phone or via letter.  In my opinion you aren't necessarily looking at a breast cancer diagnosis.  I hope the time goes quickly for you. Keep your mind occupied as best you can until the 2nd. love  Julia x
Posts.Title: biopsy results on Wednesday 2nd nov 2016

Posts.Content: Hello Everybody A quick question..... I am awaiting surgery after finishing chemo. I'm already being given conflicting advice on how long is safe to wait until surgery.  How long have those that have had chemo before surgery had to wait before they have been operated on? Man thanks Julia
Posts.Title: How long have you waited to have surgery after chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Mary  You have done the right thing in getting it checked. We have all been there once before we know what to look out for. With regrad to feeling like you are wasting people's time, please don't. It needs to be checked out and don't think people will think you have wasted their time if it's nothing sinister.  Whether you tell anyone apart from us at this stage is a personal thing. I would at least say it would be good for you to confide in at least one close somebody because no doubt this is an anxious time and you need to talk out loud.  I've been back since BC and had a second biopsy on a suspicious lump which was nothing sinister. But boy was I glad I did.  All the best.  Julia X
Posts.Title: A bit of reassurance please

Posts.Content: Hi Vic chef  What sort of contract are you on?  what are the consequences of you only doing 3 hours per day?  Its unusual for an employer to dictate the hours if you haven't been clinical assessed by occupational health. I'm assuming you don't have a OH unit? What were the reasons your boss gave for starting you back on 3 hours per day? To be honest I would jump on it if it's not affecting pay. I had a six month phased return after 11 months off and started back on 3 hours per day. I needed it. its unusual for employees to be asking to do more hours than less after cancer treatment.  Could  your boss be thinking about your welfare more than anything else? Love julia x
Posts.Title: Is this ok? Only given 9 hours at work!

Posts.Content: Just keep in your mind then Heidi, that surgery will remove the cells, you then get belt and braces with Rt then you get years of hormonal treatment so there is still lots on the table to prevent recurrence.  I had 11 nodes removed when I had clearance (clearance doesn't necessary mean all nodes go, just the clusters of nodes around the affected ones). The scar 9 months on is bearly visible. Surgery will bring lots of weird sensations but that does lessen with exercise and movement.
Posts.Title: Lymph node involvement

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic  Great that your BCN arranged the scan so swiftly. That's got to help with the anxiety. No cancer consultant can guarantee any of your treatment is a forever cure. it's the risk we have to live with unfortunately. It's not just chemo but applies to surgery and RT too. However I was one of the fortunate ones who had a complete response to chemo. Therefore I am led to believe that puts me in good stead and I consider chemo for me was a complete success. That doesn't mean I will never get secondary bc. I've had 2.5 years to accept this. Life is full of risks. Yes we are more likely to be affected by cancer again because we have already been affected but it doesn't mean it WILL happen to us. its true what Macmillan say..  many more people are living with cancer and surviving. compared to ten years ago I'm glad I got treated recently.  With regard to the wait between surgery and chemo it will depend on if you are recovered enough. it can be anything from 4 to 8 weeks Or longer.  Have you spoken to your Gp about how this is mentally affecting you as you may benefit from some help such as medication.  Take care Julia x
Posts.Title: Any advice

Posts.Content: Hi cancer bat  I agree it doesn't add up. The stage one rings truer with your rHS.  i had a  25mm tumour with one node affected. I was stage 2.  Is everyone sure how many nodes are affected at this stage? That may make a difference.  I asked to be copied into all correspondence that was written about me and that was where I learnt the most about my diagnosis.  To be honest I learnt as time went on and treatment happened, the stage became less relevant. The grade for me was more prevailant.  Julia x
Posts.Title: stage/ tiering system confusion

Posts.Content: Hi silvercloud  I personally would not be worrying about sepsis 13 days after chemo. I got septic twice but it was always at the most volnurable stage ..... Day 5/6 after chemo. Be extra cautious however with your hand washing. The very thought of 35 kids in my house puts me in a spin. Saying that if it's no hassle having it at your mums then let her take some pressure off. If that helps you?  i think you need to be asking why the treatment plan looks like it's changing regarding rt. It's probably nothing sinister but often you find consultants have a differing opionIon. A radiologist will always want you to have rt. The decision to have/not have RT however shouldn't influence the here and now with the party.  Have  a wonderful party, whatever you decide. Julia X
Posts.Title: Am I mad?

Posts.Content: Have you checked your chemo info pack?  I would say normal yoghurt is fine but Live I'm not sure. The advice is normally if you can't eat it whilst pregnant then it's not good for whilst you are on chemo. I can't remember live yoghurt being a food to avoid. The chemo pack will confirm x
Posts.Title: Dietary advice

Posts.Content: Hi Baki  I can't show full empathy because purely I don't know how it feels to be in your shoes with a secondary diagnosis however I really get where your mind is at. looking to far into the future brings anxiety. Dwelling in the past brings depression. The here and now is the most stable place for your mind to be. Dont even set any parameters. Literately see what a few months brings of these drugs. Then assess. Are they doing anything? Side effects? In turn will they give you hope? If so you can then decide what the next step is. Dont look to far forward or else it will bring dispare.  Love and hugs Julia xX
Posts.Title: Guilt and Self loathing

Posts.Content: Diazepam is prescribed for pain relief. I have experience of this with back pain. Beware though it can turn you into a zombie. x
Posts.Title: Hello can anyone help?

Posts.Content: I too would have put a negative for the ki67 score being 5%. That's a good low score it's also good  they tested it as I don't think it's done in the UK as routine. I hope the meeting goes well tomorrow and you are happy with the outcome X
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: Helen, I know the re scaning was just the straw that broke the camels back so to speak but just to reassure you that this does happen and happened to me. My boob had swelled up due to odema between the planning scan and me starting RT which I wasnt aware of at the time so I had to have a re scan. I arrived all ready to start then had it deferred for a week. I too went through the worse posibilities in my head. Julia x
Posts.Title: Burning boob

Posts.Content: Hi loopylu  many congrats on the end treatment and positive news. Fantastic.  I too had invasive lobular (triple neg). I had numorous mris before my treatment began to check we were only dealing with one site. I was never told I would have mris as follow ups but I'll ask as it does seem more sensible. I do find my BCN talks so generically about treatment that it's never about the type of cancer I have. I'll ask soon and post the outcome so you can compare. I'm being treated in Devon.
Posts.Title: follow up for lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Nic - After every session of chemo I would have a wobble, throw my dollies out of the pram, shout and scream that was it I was giving up but then after around day 5 I would pick up and wind my neck in!  After FEC I would be in bed solidly for 3/4 days. I use to think I could feel the chemo rushing through my body it felt like waves and it was awful. You should be due to see your oncologist? My doses were changed after the first FEC (I was hospitalized) and first Docetaxel. It will be your oncologists call on whether the side effects you are having are 'normal' or not. If they are too severe then a reduced dose would be the way to go. Despite me feeling absolutely awful my oncologist would praise me all the time on how well I coped! Hang on in there. Its a few months of crap but its so worth it. I am 13 months on from chemo and it really is a distant memory. Julia x
Posts.Title: Anxiety/restlessness

Posts.Content: Hello Barb This is my situation too. I was TN and finished treatment in March. I have to wait three months before I see my onc and breast consultant again. Neither to date will give any prognosis. I understand the difficulties of them being able to do this but in turn this makes it very difficult to 'move on'. I phoned my breast care team yesterday to ask when my moving on course would be..... It might be in September if I'm lucky. If I'm still struggling to move on by then I'm in trouble. So very dissappointing. I totally get that we live each day preciously as none of us know what is around the corner but when I was first diagnosed with TNBC it was such a 'bigie' now treatment is finished I can't get any consultant to talk about it. It feels like they like to keep you waiting to see of anything reappears in the meantime. All the best x
Posts.Title: Has treatment worked fears?!

Posts.Content: Diazepam is prescribed for pain relief. I have experience of this with back pain. Beware though it can turn you into a zombie. x
Posts.Title: Hello can anyone help?

Posts.Content: Hi mumof3abitlost  Im not sure what this could mean but I don't think it's another cancer. you say your post menopausal  then had a period so I'm wondering if they need to check that out. To see why after menopause your bleeding again? This doesn't mean is camcer related but could be do do with oestrogen levels. love  Julia x
Posts.Title: Worried - Again!

Posts.Content: It's really difficult to predict what will happen to your hair. It might not return to 'normal'. I was hoping but it didn't happen. I'm 20 months post chemo and it grew back curly whereas it was straight before. Don't worry to much about the colour as it can be coloured. Post chemo was the first time I had seen my hair colour 'au naturel' in about 25 years! Quite shocking. My hair is shoulder length now and the regrowth now doesn't look so curly but the ends are. Who knows how long it will stay... You will find that you just morph into style and style with post chemo hair. Try products too tame it and funk it up a bit and experiment with colour. The back does grow quicker than the rest and above the ears which makes it look worse. I'm better with hair though. Would never want to go back there :( Julia X
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: Good news all round and your moving forward.  enjoy the weekend before surgery comes  xx
Posts.Title: WOULD APPRECIATE ADVISE ON HOW TO TELL FAMILY

Posts.Content: When you are still in pain and in recovery you won't feel on top of the world.  I found that there were many times when I had expected to feel great after reaching a milestone or getting a good result  but it never happened. Finishing treatment is a classic example of feeling utterly deflated rather than inflated. It's all connected to what we go through.  I had a simple cold last week, the first since chemo a year ago but it made me very down as it bought back feelings off feeling rubbish during chemo.  Give it time. When you are pain free and healing well you will feel better mentally.  It will get better.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Down

Posts.Content: I am a daughter and I am a mother and I did not think for one minute not to tell my nine year old about my diagnosis but chose what I said very carefully. My mum hid a lot from me regarding my dads illness and I didn't like that. she thought she was being protective but I took the stance that as she didn't tell me the whole story she didn't want my help. In the end when he passed (not from cancer) I felt a bit angry I couldn't share the emotional upheaval with her From the beginning. in the beginning of a diagnosis we think the worst and we don think we will survive. Then we learn that what we have is very treatable  and yes  it's ok to view this as a 'blip' however you need to get that across to your children. They need to know your not dying and they need to know that the cancer you have is very treatable.  if you go down the route of hiding this it will become a slippery slope as you will need RT and chemo is yet to be ruled out? To be honest you will need all the assistance you need so grab it. With four children, the youngest with the active social life can help out after her events. They can take it in turns.  Julia X
Posts.Title: WOULD APPRECIATE ADVISE ON HOW TO TELL FAMILY

Posts.Content: Hello Flowerburn Do talk to your radiographers, I too found them very patient and understanding. To get a burning boob after one sesion is quite harsh so do get them to keep an eye on your skin incase it looks unhappy enough to break. There is no standard advice on what creams to use/not to use so be guided by the staff. As for your meltdown, I can fully understand why it happened. As you say, you have held it together since diagnosis. I went too pieces on diagnosis so to get to RT without  a wobble shows strength. It probably suprised you more than anything. There is always a risk that supressing emptions will bite you on the backside sooner or later. If you dont say how you are feeling to the staff because you think you are moaning you will never get their help and expertise and the only one who will suffer is you. Be selfish- think about what you need to get through these next few weeks. If you hold on to this fear you wil find the end of treatment hard going. Comapring yourself to others isnt helpful either. You do whatever you need to get yourself through treatment. For me RT was the treatement that bought the least side effects and I felt good all the way through. I only started burning a week after RT had finished. Talk to the radiographers. You will be gald you did xx
Posts.Title: Burning boob

Posts.Content: Hello Heather  my affected side was my left and I have a concave chest which didn't help either.  If in the first week when you get into position for RT and after scaning you all match up then they don't Scan after that time. The scanning is belt and braces.  It sounds like you need more reassurance from your oncologist to ease your anxiety over your heart and lungs. My experience of RT wasn't horrible at all and I am back running 10k after 5 months of finishing.  Please do speak to the oncologist and let her explain what they do to avoid your organs getting hit.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Burning boob

Posts.Content: Hi pink squirrel  sorry to read of your diagnosis but a big welcome from us here.  Why has your consultant asked for an MRI? Are they scanning your whole body?  On diagnosis as I had lobular cancer with an affected node I had a Ct and bone scan to check that the cancer wasn't elsewhere. I went on to have an MRI but purely to scan both breasts, again as I was lobular. That wasn't so bad as you go into the scanner feet first, lie tummy side down with boobs placed into baskets! Nice image huh.  I wonder if you could have a Ct scan instead? It is less claustrophobic than the MRI scanner but still may not be great for you? It's worth asking if there is an alternative.
Posts.Title: MRI claustrophobia

Posts.Content: Helen, I know the re scaning was just the straw that broke the camels back so to speak but just to reassure you that this does happen and happened to me. My boob had swelled up due to odema between the planning scan and me starting RT which I wasnt aware of at the time so I had to have a re scan. I arrived all ready to start then had it deferred for a week. I too went through the worse posibilities in my head. Julia x
Posts.Title: Burning boob

Posts.Content: Hello Flowerburn Do talk to your radiographers, I too found them very patient and understanding. To get a burning boob after one sesion is quite harsh so do get them to keep an eye on your skin incase it looks unhappy enough to break. There is no standard advice on what creams to use/not to use so be guided by the staff. As for your meltdown, I can fully understand why it happened. As you say, you have held it together since diagnosis. I went too pieces on diagnosis so to get to RT without  a wobble shows strength. It probably suprised you more than anything. There is always a risk that supressing emptions will bite you on the backside sooner or later. If you dont say how you are feeling to the staff because you think you are moaning you will never get their help and expertise and the only one who will suffer is you. Be selfish- think about what you need to get through these next few weeks. If you hold on to this fear you wil find the end of treatment hard going. Comapring yourself to others isnt helpful either. You do whatever you need to get yourself through treatment. For me RT was the treatement that bought the least side effects and I felt good all the way through. I only started burning a week after RT had finished. Talk to the radiographers. You will be gald you did xx
Posts.Title: Burning boob

Posts.Content: Hello Heather  my affected side was my left and I have a concave chest which didn't help either.  If in the first week when you get into position for RT and after scaning you all match up then they don't Scan after that time. The scanning is belt and braces.  It sounds like you need more reassurance from your oncologist to ease your anxiety over your heart and lungs. My experience of RT wasn't horrible at all and I am back running 10k after 5 months of finishing.  Please do speak to the oncologist and let her explain what they do to avoid your organs getting hit.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Burning boob

Posts.Content: A lovely post Pepys. I won't say I am sorry to hear your relationship ended as it doesn't sound like you need it. My long term partner ditched me back in November, 8 months post treatment and in hindsight it was a good thing. I feel that if he couldn't cope with my 11 month battle after 8 years he could jog on. I have just returned from a holiday in Barbados along with 25 other people attending a wedding. Not once did I mention BC or feel I needed to mention it and wore a bikini without fear or self consciousness. I too enjoyed the Barbadian men coming round to my sunbed each day spraying me with eucalyptus oil to cool me down!   I never dreamed I would feel this good again. Julia xx
Posts.Title: There's light at the end of the tunnel, ladies...

Posts.Content: Hello Joey-sarah  It sounds like you are having to justify your cancer. If they were true friends you wouldn't have to do that or feel you needed to. Any cancer is life threatening if left long enough. Folk have a great way of turning everyone else's experience into their own. To say they wouldn't be tested for the gene mutation is pointless as they REALLY wouldn't know unless they were in the same crap boat. I was tested and the results came back negative.... Phew.   To avoid situations that p&ss you off I would give these 'friends' a wide berth until you are ready to deal with their crappy remarks. I've left friends behind for this reason and I don't regret it.  All the best for a negative result. julia x
Posts.Title: Been a while again but on 6th and final chemo

Posts.Content: Hello Yvonne  its good to hear from you albeit it for sad reasons. I am thinking of you. Xx
Posts.Title: My poor son's inquest tomorrow

Posts.Content: It's really difficult to predict what will happen to your hair. It might not return to 'normal'. I was hoping but it didn't happen. I'm 20 months post chemo and it grew back curly whereas it was straight before. Don't worry to much about the colour as it can be coloured. Post chemo was the first time I had seen my hair colour 'au naturel' in about 25 years! Quite shocking. My hair is shoulder length now and the regrowth now doesn't look so curly but the ends are. Who knows how long it will stay... You will find that you just morph into style and style with post chemo hair. Try products too tame it and funk it up a bit and experiment with colour. The back does grow quicker than the rest and above the ears which makes it look worse. I'm better with hair though. Would never want to go back there :( Julia X
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: Hi Eleanor  I just wanted to say that your thoughts were my thoughts exactly this time last year.  I was bald and we had a family Christmas photo taken like we do every year. It was hard but I also felt overwhelmed to be celebrating Christmas. I didn't think I would get the opportunity again. For your family, you are still you, with or without hair and they are wanting you to know, nothing has changed. With you however, everything has changed.  I'm now 13 months post chemo and my avatar pic is me this Christmas.  Growing your hair back is a journey in itself. Waiting to see what colour and texture it is. I've gone from very long straight to very very curly. But it's still changing every month and it's good to have a different style every month until I am back with hair I feel happy with again.  Don't try to remember who you were. Find the new you. With no will in the world will you be the old you but you never know you could like the new you much more than the old. It does take time though.  Julia X
Posts.Title: I'm not 'me'

Posts.Content: Congratulations Lacomtekp on your Neddy status (no evidence of disease). We welcone this news whenever we can get it. I share your view entirely on gaining your life back. Yipppeeeeee. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: I used a cut up pair of patterned tights/stockings over the tubigrip given by the chemo ward. Especially nice when you want some glamour going out. I found them really comfy and a great fit.
Posts.Title: picc line cover?

Posts.Content: Little Wombat, I hope the lumpectomy went well today. Please let us know if we can help with Any more questions you may have. Xx
Posts.Title: WOULD APPRECIATE ADVISE ON HOW TO TELL FAMILY

Posts.Content: The Papa Smurf reference made me chuckle! The blue will hang around a while. I can understand you not wanting to have to have chemo. Let the family fuss over you in the next few weeks to keep your mind off of the results.  do keep ontop of the exercises as they do help with negating long term issues.  Julia X
Posts.Title: WOULD APPRECIATE ADVISE ON HOW TO TELL FAMILY

Posts.Content: I had bad nausea and it was trial and error regarding anti sickness. I took  emend before, ondansetron during administration , emend the day after and in between metroclopramide or domperidone. I was taking metroclopramide every three hours for up to 5 days post chemo. I did eat small snacks very regularly too which helped even though I didn't feel I needEd too. If you are only having ondansetron it's not much protection, there is more available. Talk to your chemo nurse.
Posts.Title: That awful nausea!

Posts.Content: Hi Grogg  The administrators (Jess and co) are following this thread and are feeding back to the relevant team. My guess is that doing this in house is better than trying to find out who would take/be responsible for listening to your complaints. This site is after all available for anyone to see.  julia X
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Go gently xx
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: I told my mum face to face. I prempted that I needed to talk to her but didn't say what it was and I just explained I had found a lump, it was tested and found to be cancer and I outlined the treatment I was needing. We cried and then said the typical British 'everything will be alright' and then we were able to talk further about it as and when we needed to.  Would you like to tell them all  at once or would one be able to talk to the others To pass it on? Personally I feel face to face is better but that may not be realistic. One thing I felt was relief when I got It out there.
Posts.Title: WOULD APPRECIATE ADVISE ON HOW TO TELL FAMILY

Posts.Content: The admin team read the posts and they get passed on accordingly. A couple of replies have been posted here from the Fundraising team. Your feelings have been noted On this campaign. As they should.  I am 20 months post chemo and have a full head of shoulder length hair. i would not shave my hair off again for all the money in the world. I would consider someone who is willing to shave their head to raise money to help people affected by cancer, including me, brave.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hello Jen  A warm welcome to the Community.  I'm sorry to read you have been diagnosed and diagnosed at such a young age.  Has your consultant discussed having neoadjuvant chemo (chemo first) in the hope of shrinking everything down so that a good WLE can be done? I had it and it worked very well.  Before I had a WLE I was geared up for a mx as I had triple neg lobular cancer. My surgeon due to my age and body frame said he would do a bilateral as body image was very important too me and he wanted to achieve good cosmetic results. However the chemo worked so well I didn't need the mx. Some surgeons have a negative view about removing a healthy breast but if you are clear that you want to have equal breasts and get a good cosmetic result due to your age I think you would be OK. It's worth discussing it soon. You need to talk about types of reconstruction and if you have immediate or delayed recon. Do ask to see photos of the surgeons previous work so you are clear about what the end results could look like.  All the best with the forthcoming weeks. Keep posting when you need help or support.  Julia X
Posts.Title: bilateral mastectomy with one healthy breast??

Posts.Content: Hello Rob  You have answered your own question Which is good. You push loved ones away  because you want to protect them. They are upset for you. They don't like seeing you go through this. It's a steep steep learning curve for all of you. I frequently wished I had no daughter and no partner as it would be easier for me to go through it alone. Then I quickly realised it was those people that dragged me through treatment. And quite often with a laugh and a joke. You don't have to 'cope'. For me I literally just existed through treatment , it was just about surviving. Now I'm through it I'm slowly emerging from that existence and starting to 'live' again. Cancer is Cancer. It can affect many many parts of the body. I use to say I had cancer. I didn't always use the specifics as in breast cancer. We are all proud people, I have lost so much of myself but I'm finding it again a year after diagnosis. you will feel so many crap and scary emotions whilst going through treatment but there is light. Mention to your BC team how you are feeling and you may get into a counselling service. Again something I was also adverse too until I got cancer. All the best x
Posts.Title: I can no longer cope

Posts.Content: I get where you are coming from ladies.  My daughter (year 6) had a 'wig Wednesday' at school to raise money For CLIC. I'm all for raising money to fund research etc but I was really put out having to find some silly wig for my daughter to wear on her head. In protest I send her in with one of my wigs. It turns out that she was called up in assembly and congratulated on being brave whilst her mum went through treatment. She said she was so embarrased By it. A nice thought, but ....
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I too felt uneasy yesterday when we discussed tumours growing whilst on docetaxol.  I wouldn't want anyone to ditch Docetaxol from the regime because of the 'what ifs' or 'because it didn't work for her/him' Any chenotherapy has the potential to cause serious harm but that risk is low.  Cancer cells can become resistant to any type of chemotherapy.  Chemotherapies come with side effects. A drug that powerful isn't going to go into your body and not make itself known. They interfere with our biology.  For me, the overriding fear was the cancer not the treatment.  julia X
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou1007  The oncotype is only offered to node negative diagnosis which explains really why the test is worthwhile. It saves overtreating in some cases by giving a more scientific approach To whether chemo will be of benefit. Ive just seen you had 13 affected nodes so that's why you defaulted straight to chemo without the tests being offered no doubt.  Its such a steep learning curve isn't it. Not that we ever wanted to become bc experts!  Take care julia xx

Posts.Content: Yup that would cure it for me ha ha xx
Posts.Title: Cure for constipation

Posts.Content: Hi pat  how about trying short meditations? You can get apps for you phone for ease of use. I think it's called headspace or mind space. I have acupuncture too which helps relax me and levels me out. I think to have it lowered by Friday will be tough as its more a long term solution. I'm a big advocat of exercise but again that's a lifestyle change that takes time. Reduce salt intake? Walking every day? Good luck with it xx
Posts.Title: Impending op and high BP.

Posts.Content: You are so right Helen.  Whilst going through chemo I was walking through town with a scarf on my head and was stopped by a female motorist and asked for directions. She said to me at the end of the conversation 'I just wanted to say how beautiful you look'. That lump appeared immediately in my throat. She didn't have to say anything but she took the time to make me feel nice even though I had 0 confidence and felt like I could only appear in public sans brown paper bag on my head. I remember that more than the stares.  Hair loss is temporary in most cases. If friends and strangers give compliments until you look and feel more like you pre cancer self then take all you can get.   Julia X
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi Carrie  Your BC type will depend on this decision, as in what hormone status is was. As jj says, some of us will always have to go down the chemo route. Triple neg is an example. In that case it can be used neoadjuvantly so that breast conservation surgery can happen.  It's not a better option but there is the option to have chemo before or after surgery but only if you need chemo in the first place if that makes sense.
Posts.Title: Very confused tonight!

Posts.Content: Fantastic news Pat. xx
Posts.Title: Impending op and high BP.

Posts.Content: The FDA is a good starting point as Marlog has said. Any drug that is used is trialed until it is determined the usefulness outweighs the side effects. You will find most studies research is from the US.  Taxanes (third generation drugs) give benefits to certain types/stages  of BC. Natures review clinical oncology 2009 reviewed 21 trials affecting nearly 36000 women and compared those who took a taxane with those who didn't. The % increase in survival was noticeable.  As with the paracetomol, every drug comes with a patient info leaflet that has a list of possible and reliable side effects. they can't be facts because it's not a fact you will get all if any. Any chemo comes with a risk of death through sepsis. Epirubcin can effect the heart long term and radiotherapy can cause long term damage to heart and lungs for us lefties. Everything comes with a risk but that risk is deemed negligible in most cases against the risk of cancer killing you.  Docetaxol can cause peripheral neuropathy which can be long term but this is monitored And in severe cases the drug is stopped.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Hi elaineo2  To be complaining for a year and a half without action is way too long. Where is the bone pain? Presumably always in the same place? Are you on hormonal therapies? I complained of rib pain once and my onco couldn't get me in the bone scanner quick enough. It turned out clear but I still have pain 2 years on. I can understand you fearing the worse but once the scan is done you will have peace of mind. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Is it bone mets?

Posts.Content: Hi JMC04  sending hope and strength today. With regard to the lumps feeling bigger and nodes in the armpit.... it's common after a invasive biopsy for swelling. My lump felt huge after biopsy and I was so very bruised. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: That's just it, there are no 'facts' when it comes to side effects. We are given a list of things that COULD happen and we literally swallow it and wait and see what happens. With taxanes (Docetaxol) they are generally posted about more frequently than FEC to the point that it be becomes off putting to those yet to enter into that treatment. Some even consider not having the treatment based upon what they are reading. This can be detrimental to a personalised treatment plan. i think this is a very balanced post to what is viewed as 'the Devils work' and has come at a poignant time when folk are questioning their treatment plans based upon others experiences. This post is saying that it's not always the case and to show encouragement and support And to try an alleviate any stigma with Docetaxol.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Because of how cookies work you are more than likely to see the brave to shave ad on your FB Feed Soon. You are right though, any ads can be hidden.  I am not here to defend the fundraising team but do have an understanding of the necessity of fundraising. There are three times as many Macmillan volunteers than there are Macmillan staff which gives an indication of how important the unpaid work is compared to what macmillan can afford to fund.  Losing my hair was very traumatic for me but I'm 2 years on now and find I'm less sensitive now. whilst I agree it's not the best catchphrase I can see why folk would want to show a united front against cancer in shaving their hair to raise money to help people like us get the best possible treatment. Of course, losing your hair is the tip of the shite iceberg that is BC and I wouldn't expect everybody to 'get' what cancer feels like but I bet the people who shave their hair think they are helping and in a way showing empathy/compassion, showing they are trying to relate to what happens when cancer happens.  I personally would feel very awkward telling someone who has just shaved of their hair to raise money that I find it a very insensitive campaign because the thought was there.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi Altolady Thankyou for doing this and raising money. I think it's a very brave thing to do and do appreciate what you are doing. Having lost my hair through chemo, I know I couldn't do it again, so for others to do it to raise money I think is very commendable. It's been said before but yes it's a shame brave and shame rhyme. Of course different wording would mean different things. Thankyou Julia X
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Loulou1007 Hi Crystaljuju,  thank you for the post, would you be able to explain why hormone therapy is enough without chemo?!? I am ER+ 8/8 but also had chemo? I could be reading it wrong but it's interesting, many thanks Lou x  Hi Loulou1007 My post to Jane was in response to her post about Anne's post. It gets confusing but makes sense if you read this thread in its entirety. I know sometimes reading isolated posts can be confusing. Anne had the oncotype DX test and this came back with a result that meant she had chemo. She said her tumour was 8mm I think. Jane came in after and said this was worrying her has her DX appeared to be similar but he oncologist didn't offer the oncotype DX test as it wasn't felt necessary. My comments were to try and alleviate Jane's concerns. Anne had a lower score of oestrogen and no doubt that the oncotype DX test takes this into consideration. Jane however, who wasn't offered oncotype as it was felt chemo wasn't necessary had a 8/8 score which is the best. Meaning that hormonal therapies will have the full % chance of working. The higher your ER score, the more your BC likes ER to grow so by suppressing this with hormonal therapies it works well. If you have a lower score such as 4/8 then hormonal therapies aren't so useful. Or if like me you have a score of 0/8 then hormonal therapies are no use at all. Your 8/8 score is the most optimum score so hormonal therapies are ideal. The question I think you are asking is why did you have chemo as well? Did you have the oncotype DX test that recommended chemo? Or was there another reason with your DX that meant chemo was recommended? Hope that helps Lou :) Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

Posts.Content: Hi Glasgow  Thank you for the information. There are many of us on here that are very familiar with the oncotype DX test and many that have had the test to help make informed decisions about chemo. In my opinion it is a very worthwhile test and takes the 'guess' work out of whether you should have chemo. My advice is that if you are offered the test then take it. If you have a low score - job done. This means you will not benefit from having chemo so there would be little point in having it. An intermediate score its probably the most confusing as the decision is left to you and being borderline is a tough one. A high score is job done too as you have chemo (it you consent). Chemo is not offered lightly nor where it clearly wont give any benefit. The main reason is that chemo can cause death in itself and you need to be fully aware of all risks against the benefits it will give you. The oncotype test wasn't for me as I was triple negative so chemo is standard treatment for this diagnosis. Trust the test. It has been developed for very good reasons. You don't want to be over treated at the expense of your long term health. All the best with your decision making. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

Posts.Content: Hi JMC04  Whatever you are told tomorrow we are here for you and always will be. it will be a sleepless night for you. Will you have your husband with you tomorrow? I know you don't wany to trouble your daughter but it sounds like you really could do with your daughter right now. We think we are protecting our children but they also need to feel wanted and be able to support their parents. my fingers are crossed and thoughts are with you. Remember we are here. Hugs Julia xX
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: Hi EJM60  The score of the oestrogen is a big factor. Anne's er score  was mid range which meant she might not get the full benefit of hormonal therapies Which is the reason chemo was recommended. The higher your score the more benefit you get from hormonal therapies i.e. They work better. Your ER score would have been out of 8. hormonal therapies with a high score would have been enough without chemo. I know it's easy for us to compare diagnosis but there is so much to consider.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

Posts.Content: Hi Sheilarog  In sorry to read about the secondaries. Its a great question and one you could "ask a nurse" on this site. I've found them a great help.  The oncotype test blurb suggests it's for ER positive diagnosis so unless you are ER positive also I don't think it will be relevant for the Her2.  Oncotype is also for early bc, where no lymph nodes are involved so again I'm not sure if it would be useful on a secondary diagnosis.  Are you in contact with your oncologist? They will be able to suggest  other genome tests that may be good for you.  Love and best wishes julia x
Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou1007  No problemo. WhI had post are your referring to that I wrote? Just so I can get some context.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

I'm certainly not up for shaving my hair for charity.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I've skim read the article and it appears she is doing precisely what she is critising others about. Not sure of the point to this at all apart from getting into a national newspaper.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi Kazash56 I had neoadjuvant chemo so know where you are coming from. Congratulations on getting to the chemo finish line. Are there any positives you can draw on between now and Wednesday. Can you feel that the lump has got smaller? Did you not have a scan half way through chemo to see how it was working? There shouldn't be any major suprises next week if they have been keeping an eye on you. As for the tumour growing back inbetween chemo and surgery this is a common thought and common misconception. I worried and worried over this as I had to wait over 10 weeks before surgery. I was always reassured that the tumour would not grow back (i was fortunate in that my tumour had completely dissappeared after chemo) by consultants and I took a lot of convincing. In hindsight the 10 weeks I waited indeed made absolutely no difference. If there was any risk you would be in for surgery quick and if it was still growing whilst you were on chemo then it would have been noticed by now. I lost all nails too and as you say chemo is just one third of treatment. But it is one third that is now behind you and not infront of you. The things you say you need to do may have to be put on hold unless you can get them done for you in the meantime. I found that after surgery, the rest of treatment zoomed by and before I knew it I was back at work. I am now nealry 6 months back at work and thinking why did I wish time away! There is no easy way of getting through treatment. Its a means to an end. An end to cancer. All the best for next week. Please do try and make the most of the good time between chemo and surgery. Grab it while you can. x
Posts.Title: Feeling a bit lost

Posts.Content: Glasgow, even after having chemo there are no guarantees that you wont develop secondary breast cancer. Its all about recognizing risk. I must say, having had that said to you isn't very helpful as it does led you think you always NEED chemo. It could never be certain that even if that one cell did escape it would be killed by chemo. Why try crack a nut with a sledgehammer? The reason secondary's develop is the cancer cells become resistant to drugs. Sneaky suckers.
Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

Posts.Content: Unfortunately loss of confidence comes with the shi** package, or rather it did in my case. I am the only female in a male environment (sounds like heaven but its hard at times!) , couple that with being a line manager and being out of the office for 11 months I had no idea if I could carry on doing the job. I felt like I couldnt as I had lost so much confidence. Thats why I found it useful having weekly meetings with my manager to explain how I was doing/how I felt. With their support, after 5 months I am back to 'me' at work. To be put on a level playing field I would ask your manager to refer you to OH before you retunr. You can then agree on a phased return if they agree thats the best way forward.
Posts.Title: Work issues

Posts.Content: The only person that will look out for you at work is you. The NHS staffing issues are their issues. Managers are put into place to manage such issues so let them do their work. It's time to be selfish. If you go back full on in an unstable state you will come out of it more worse for wear. Trust me, I've seen it. Your doctor can state that you are fit but with restrictions/modifications. That means you need to be assessed to see what parts of the job you can go back to and what parts will have to wait. I didn't answer my telephone for a good couple of weeks when I returned purely because I was scared I would either blub or start shouting! Now I'm sounding like a fruit cake he he xx
Posts.Title: Work issues

Posts.Content: Its a tricky one as hormonal therapies do come with risks of joint/bone pain. Have you got some heavy duty pain relief to help? Crying from pain isn't good. I feel for you. Let us know when the scan is. J xx
Posts.Title: Is it bone mets?

Posts.Content: Hi Julezan It sounds like you work for a large employer. Don't they have a OH?  Seems  strange that you are having to self refer. I was out of the office for 11 months. My job involves driving and a lot of confrontation. The way 'management' would acceot what my imitations were was by OH assessing me and a report being sent to them. I have been on a phased return for the last 5 months so I didnt rush into things by any means. Unfortuantely management wont always seem supportive unless you spell out what your limitatations/needs are. We do assume they would know what we need but I have found I have been able to control my return to work by explaining how I am. It has worked really well. Otherwise as you say, the stress is there before you even set foot in the door. By any will in the world you are unlikely to be able to pick up that job where you left it. For me, it was a massive step and initially it made me regress for a bit which wasn't great but it soon passed.   I hope it goes well for you x
Posts.Title: Work issues

Posts.Content: Hi Purple Fox  In my experience written complaints are beneficial. I made two to my trust and both achieved a satisfactory outcome to me.  The point with formal complaints is that they have to be investigated.  All the best  Julia x
Posts.Title: Still waiting for DIEP reconstruction! Help!

Posts.Content: Hi Julezan It sounds like you work for a large employer. Don't they have a OH?  Seems  strange that you are having to self refer. I was out of the office for 11 months. My job involves driving and a lot of confrontation. The way 'management' would acceot what my imitations were was by OH assessing me and a report being sent to them. I have been on a phased return for the last 5 months so I didnt rush into things by any means. Unfortuantely management wont always seem supportive unless you spell out what your limitatations/needs are. We do assume they would know what we need but I have found I have been able to control my return to work by explaining how I am. It has worked really well. Otherwise as you say, the stress is there before you even set foot in the door. By any will in the world you are unlikely to be able to pick up that job where you left it. For me, it was a massive step and initially it made me regress for a bit which wasn't great but it soon passed.   I hope it goes well for you x
Posts.Title: Work issues

Posts.Content: Unfortunately loss of confidence comes with the shi** package, or rather it did in my case. I am the only female in a male environment (sounds like heaven but its hard at times!) , couple that with being a line manager and being out of the office for 11 months I had no idea if I could carry on doing the job. I felt like I couldnt as I had lost so much confidence. Thats why I found it useful having weekly meetings with my manager to explain how I was doing/how I felt. With their support, after 5 months I am back to 'me' at work. To be put on a level playing field I would ask your manager to refer you to OH before you retunr. You can then agree on a phased return if they agree thats the best way forward.
Posts.Title: Work issues

Posts.Content: The only person that will look out for you at work is you. The NHS staffing issues are their issues. Managers are put into place to manage such issues so let them do their work. It's time to be selfish. If you go back full on in an unstable state you will come out of it more worse for wear. Trust me, I've seen it. Your doctor can state that you are fit but with restrictions/modifications. That means you need to be assessed to see what parts of the job you can go back to and what parts will have to wait. I didn't answer my telephone for a good couple of weeks when I returned purely because I was scared I would either blub or start shouting! Now I'm sounding like a fruit cake he he xx
Posts.Title: Work issues

Posts.Content: The hair blog is a fab idea Emma. It feels good to have contributed x
Posts.Title: I'm growing a hairy,furry face!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Lee  I had found that I'd become much more desensitised about cancer reported in the media since treatment finished but today's 'news' really peed me off. It didn't start my day off well.  Apparently upto 90% of cancers can be prevented. What a load of bull. Then I had to have a word with myself and say that this was an American study (who I believe to be generally   A more obese/unhealthy nation) and it was talking about cancer in general not specifically BC. I was interested in the fact that they also mentioned exposure to 'radiation' was also a factor.  I don't think we need the extra baggage of wondering how we can finely time our lifestyles to prevent recurrence and take the blame for what's happened to us.
Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Hi Geordiebird  You don't have to be on your own dealing with this now. We can be here for you. Its unusual with a stage 1b diagnosis to be needing chemo . Is your consultant recommending chemo due to the family history? Have you had an oncotype dx test?  unless your diagnosis is the same as your relatives that haven't survived BC then please don't think your diagnosis will end the same way. There are differemt types of BC.  There is also a 100% 5 year survival rate with stage 1 BC.  Many don't have/need chemo but the decision not to take tamoxifen however is a big one as that really is your protective measure going forward. What was your oestrogen score out of 8?  Love Julia X
Posts.Title: Natural v Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi invisible me  Screening happens around 12 months post surgery not diagnosis.  im not sure what the 'combined surgeons' is all about. At my mammo the only person I see is the lady performing the scan. There's no consultation.  It may not mean that June is your scan anniversary every year, just this one? in Torbay we only get screened bi annually.... unless you kick off :)  I know the first mammo can be frought but I always think the 2, 3 and 4  is more risky. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Angry! Appointment change

Posts.Content: Jenny, life it does suck. And im sorry its picking on you. I am suprsied the Dr has gone straight into infering its bone cancer. That wont help your anxiety. The positives are that you dont have to wait weeks for the scan. The scan (if you mean a bone scan)itself is ok compared to a CT/MRI. You get injected with a low level dose of radiation and then go back a couple of hours later for the scan which takes 20 mins and isnt uncomfortable at all. The sooner the results are in the better. Wishing you all the best for a false alarm. Julia
Posts.Title: Head working overtime

Posts.Content: Hello sunshine  it's all so scary at the begining and will continue to be scary for a while but the fear does subside as your treatment progresses. This site is great for advice and support.  I had chemo first (6 cycles) before a WLE (lumpectomy). The good thing about chemo before surgery is that you can get to see it working. I felt my tumour get smaller after the first session of chemo. You will be scanned half way through chemo to check on the chemo's progress. I had a great response to chemo. By the time surgery came I had no tumour left and no cancer cells were present in the tissue removed during the WLE. I also found that having chemo first makes the surgery and radiotherapy really do able in comparison.  Chemo is no walk in the park and how your body will react is unknown until you have that first session. I did have at least ten good days out of the three week cycle.  All the best xx
Posts.Title: Which Treatment 1st??

Posts.Content: Hi kusmi i would suggest that a breast care nurse or your mums surgeon checks the redness rather than the radiographer. Is you mum having RT as you mention radio therapists? Is it a side effect of radio therapy? i had lymphoedema in my breast after surgery which made the skin warm to touch and was pink but I didn't have a mastectomy. With lymphoedema you get swelling too.
Posts.Title: Red rash after mastectomy- any advice?

Posts.Content: I have to agree. We have to be mindful that cancer = money and professionals can make lots of money from opinions.  Giving up Dairy should be done very carefully. Ive spoken to a dietitian post bc during a moving on group and it's not recommended.  Dairy  gives so much protein needed for repair and keeping a good weight. If you are ER+ you also should ensure you have enough calcium going in.  Organic milk and dairy products are a good idea though And moderation is the key. A bit of what you fancy now and again is my 92 year old grans mantra.  Diet post bc is a minefield arrggghhhh. julia x
Posts.Title: Natural v Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Katee  i have taken glucosamine for many years as I am a runner. I continued to take it through chemo. I still suffered aches and pains from docetaxel. I don't think taking glucosamine now will help you specifically with chemo related side effects.
Posts.Title: Glucosamine?

Posts.Content: You have made a lovely day even lovelier.  So happy for you both.  Take that Triple negative breast cancer.  Lots of love  Julia x x x
Posts.Title: Good news! Mum got the all clear after surgery!

Posts.Content: The new tool is different from the old version. Do them both to see the difference. for me, the new version puts my prognosis in a very different picture! (Negative).  Its the best prognosis tool out there in the Uk. it all depends if you can work with statistics And are realistic about never getting 100%.  What % did you get too? julia x
Posts.Title: Predict

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass  The think the majority of ladies on here probably won't be 3 years post surgery yet. I'm nearly two years post surgery (WLE) and my breast has been pretty constant since 1.5 years after. I massage and moisturise it daily.  To be honest I think out breast shape changes overtime regardless of BC. I'm wondering if mousturizing the scars will help you though? julia X
Posts.Title: Breast Changes 3 years on!!

Posts.Content: Hi JustLittleMe  That is a great question to ask a nurse in this site or your own oncologist. mine was very helpful over contraception advice. I emailed him.  Most will say the Mirena coil is ok as it doesnt release oestrogen. I however wouldn't do it even with a TNBC diagnosis. i was told the IUD causes heavy periods. As someone who has this I didn't want to have that make it worse. I don't take hormonal therapies however so I'm still pre menopause. It could be different for you on tamoxifen as your periods will stop? Theres the cap and condoms, neither of which are a turn On!!! I think your oncologist will put your mind at rest. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Contraception

Posts.Content: Hi MoMo2626  The1% benefitt is unique to Helens specific diagnosis.  yours may be completely different.  Have a try and see..... http://www.predict.nhs.uk/ You are right though. when you feel the side effects outweigh the benefits that's your cue to question if its worth it. Helen did and decided it wasn't worth it. julia x
Posts.Title: Predict

Posts.Content: Like you I finished treatment in March and I am also seeing my BC consultant next week. I'm actually feeling calmer now I know the appointment is immanent as I've struggled with this whole 'back to normal' and 'moving on' stuff. I'm seeing a counsellor which helps massively. She told me my life will never be the same again and she was right no matter how hard I try to get it back to normal. You know when you take a wrong turning using a sat nav and she shouts at you 'recalculating' .... That's how my brain feels every few days.  The poignant thing about this stage in our journeys is that now the survival period has slackened off you have time to reflect . Reflecting on what's happened and what you have lost. I guess reminders will always be there for us . How we cope with them will be learnt, just as we learnt to cope with the treatment.  All the best for next week xx
Posts.Title: Why am I so scared

Posts.Content: Ultimately, you can ask to see your pathology report Puzzler. They are hard to read without assistance though. Carolyn's specific ++++ diagnosis is the first I've seen on here so it could be that it's not normally given. You get to know your er and PR score out of 8 but I didn't know you had a her2 score also. They just normally tell you you are her2 receptive. Definately worth asking though if it would help you. Julia X
Posts.Title: Natural v Chemo

Posts.Content: You made me laugh Dayityrose with 'DorIs'. It's funny how we give names to things. My tumour was refered to as "Larry the lump". My partner would often shout jog on Larry! Doris sounds just lovely and I hope she does you well xx
Posts.Title: R1 R2 Update after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Oh Jackie you made me smile so much then laugh ......  I wish my oncologist text me. He is lovely. It's a funny vision .... Your oncologist texting you with such news is just fantastic.  Today just gets better and better.  I'm feeling all emotional xxxx
Posts.Title: Good news! Mum got the all clear after surgery!

Posts.Content: hi helsbels18  From reading in between the lines of you post I would say you have made your decision. The only person stopping you saying this decision out loud is you because you think you are being pathetic. I'm wondering what you would have to go through before you thought it was justified to take time out? You aren't pathetic. Actually the complete opposite end of the scale. Your being braver than youve ever been. You know your capabilities. From the day I was diagnosed I never set a foot into the office until 11 months later. It was the best thing I did. I appreciate I was in a position to do this as I still got paid. For weeks two and three of chemo I worked from home. It was agreed through occupational health and I did 3/4 hours per day when I couLd. There was never any pressure.  Nobody will take better care of you than you will. Forget the rumblings at work, they are beyond your control but do be assured that you will have a post to go back to as you can't be discrimated against whilst on sick leave.  There will be no gold medals for slogging through only a detriment to your health.  Your hubby supports you too so it's good to go. julia x
Posts.Title: work or not?

Posts.Content: Hi there Grogg  RT is so site specific that it should have no effect on a bone healing in the foot. Radiation is only directed at the breast. Your body goes into over drive trying to make that harsh sunburn heal. I would imagine from September your immune system is getting well back on track now also.
Posts.Title: Leg in plaster

Posts.Content: Hi Larner  I had this after my first docetaxel. (I had three sessions over 9 weeks) It was very fine baby hair but it did continue to shed a bit too. Don't worry though because it does soon grow. 4 months after my last tax I was able to take the wig off I had enough hair to brave it outside.  I'm now 16months post chemo and have shoulder length chemo curls.  Julia
Posts.Title: Hair growth on Taxol

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass  The think the majority of ladies on here probably won't be 3 years post surgery yet. I'm nearly two years post surgery (WLE) and my breast has been pretty constant since 1.5 years after. I massage and moisturise it daily.  To be honest I think out breast shape changes overtime regardless of BC. I'm wondering if mousturizing the scars will help you though? julia X
Posts.Title: Breast Changes 3 years on!!

Posts.Content: Hi Teresa I was triple neg but I had sugery after chemo. I waited 8 weeks for RT after surgery but it was known at this stage I had had a pathological complete response to chemo so there was no urgency. Ladies wait for RT well over 6 weeks if they are awaiting a sugery wound to heal but thats a medical reason for delaying RT. Having had RT I can say that a hot holiday after it isn't a good idea. The couple of weeks after I completed RT were the worse for me in terms of soreness. Be frank with your oncologist and ask him if you are putting yourself at risk by waiting another few weeks. Julia X ps I think you may find if you cancelled your holiday for reasons connecting to your BC you won't be insured...,,, assuming you declared the diagnosis
Posts.Title: Delaying radiotherapy for a few weeks - could it be detrimental?

Posts.Content: The Epsom salts probably have magnesium in them already? But as Chloecat says you can try oral tablets.  I've always taken high strength cod liver oil as I run and cycle and had Docetaxel during chemo but have no lasting side affects thank goodness. As its shin pain you are getting it might be worth having your feet explored. I
Posts.Title: painful knees and shin's

Posts.Content: Hello  Rt involves lying very still in uncomfortable positions for considerable time. I had mine 10 weeks after surgery and although I had recovered ok I did find the whole process did take it's toll. Can you work on the bad back to get it comfortable again? Acupuncture I found is fab. Is it a long term back problem or one  arisen from chemo? Try a chiropractor. Cooling the area with a ice pack regularly and specific excercises will help.
Posts.Title: ctscan

Posts.Content: All good wishes Pat. Another box will be ticked off xx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy tomorrow, 9-9-15

Posts.Content: Hi Karen Not sure which bit you need help with but ill plod on anyway. For your oncologist 'to put the ball intto your court' they will need to provide evidence/statistics either way for you to make that decision. Have they mentioned the oncotype DX test? this is the maths test done to give you a score to see if you will benefit from chemo. Without them telling you what benefit chemo would be, you cant make a decision. As you are oestrogen and progesterone positive, tamoxifen or suchlike will be of benefit to you and you take this for a number of years so take this into consideration as this in itself reduces your recurrence chances. The clear margins is good as they are saying in the tissue they removed they took not only the tumour but healthy tissue so everything has come out. There is no residual cells which is a good thing. The affected nodes were removed, again leaving no residue. Has anyone mentioned if you had vascual invasion? This can affect if you go for chemo. On the basis that you had no residual cells and you get to take hormonal therapies, chemo may not be a benefit but as I said they need to prove that to you first. Julia
Posts.Title: Meeting with oncology

Posts.Content: Hello Londongal  Its good to have you join us on the Community. Welcome.  I had the same surgery as you are going to have. to be honest I wasted a lot of money on bras that are now redundant. You will need at least one bra that is at least a size bigger around the chest because you don't want anything too tight. I stuck with my normal cupsize. Your dressings won't stay on that long but if you are having a drain that can stay in for upto a week. I went for a plain cotton m and s bra (they have a growing range of post surgery wear). I've heard asda do a very good bra too. Personally I think the key is too have one on preparation then see how well you heal and what your needs are as you are healing.  its great too read you are so active. I'm a huge advocate of keeping active. I was back exercising properly whilst I had RT which was 8 weeks after surgery.  I avoided high impact for a while though. High impact came around three months post surgery however I am in my early forties.  See how you feel after surgery. It is quite dRaining. For weeks you are very restricted to what you can do as you can't lift/drive/push/pull. Do take the advice you are given in that do your arm exercises as directed and don't get to physical too soon. All the best for surgery on 20th And I hope you find us helpful. Julia x
Posts.Title: Post Op bra size?

Posts.Content: Hi Rach1969  Your GP can do a blood test to test FSH levels. But it will depend upon when you finished chemo. My periods returned 4 months post chemo. They like to give you up to 12 months to see if periods return. The FSH (follicle stimulating hormone) test will only indicate that you may be peri menopausal. You aren't classed as having gone through the menopause until 12 months of no periods. But I am guessing if you get put on hormonal therapies then its unlikely your periods will return. That's why a blood test is quite key. When you talk about HRT do you mean hormonal therapies? Oncologists are very reluctant to give HRT to anyone who has had BC. Hormonal therapies are Tamoxifen if you are pre menopause or aromatase drugs such as letrozole for post menopause. Sorry to read about the blood clot. Ouchy I remember the fragmin injections from being in hospital whilst going through chemo. They sting those buggers do. Take it easy. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Menopausal or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Lou I finished chemo last November and by the following March I was just able to go wig free (4 months). Hair at the sides (behind the ears)and the nape grows faster. The fringe was the last too grow. Don't panic about the top just yet - I have a feeling your oncologist would tell you to give it more time if you spoke to him/her now. Try a skin hair and nail supplement and massaging oil (coconut is good) into the scalp. Don't be disheartened just yet. Julia x
Posts.Title: hair growth aftet chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Theresa I developed lymphoedema in the breast after RT. The clinic I was referred too was a bit rubbish but I managed to find someone privately who did Kinesio taping that solved the odema within a couple of months. I still have to massage daily but the swelling is controlled. They do say go straight in with treatment. Don't be fobbed off with them saying wear a compression bra at first to see how it goes. Go straight into lymphatic drainage and taping if you can because it can get worse if its left. Hope it gets sorted soon. I empathize as it is uncomfortable and irritable. Julia
Posts.Title: Breast pain months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: To do proper drainage (Vodder) you need to be qualified but self massage does help. Self massage involves massaging the fluid gently away towards the non affected side - across the chest to the other side. Stimulating all lymph nodes helps before you begin. Kinesio taping uses sports tape (Rock tape is an example) that is cut into like octopus strands and is stuck on from the back then taken up and over the shoulder and fanned out across the breast and underneath the breast depending upon where your swelling is. It stays on for around 3 days before it loses its stick then you can replace it. I was very happy with the way it treated my odema but I went privately for it. My clinic didn't offer it.  If you Google Kinesio taping for breast you can see it in images. Julia x
