Posts.Title: Breast pain months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Sacha  To get "you are cancer free" from a consultant is pretty impressive based on my experience. Mine always erred on the side of caution and the best I got was no evidence of disease.  with this in mind I really really doubt he has got this wrong. do you think it could be a mix up with appointments? Did you explain on the phone you already saw him Friday?  or it really could be to check that you are healed enough to begin radiotherapy ? He may have forgotten to do this last time? for peace of mind I would phone back and double check the reasons. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Now I'm really worried

Posts.Content: Hello Felon Im sorry to read chemo is making itself known. I had the fECT regime and although it was never ending going through it (Hospitalised twice) it did finish and 14 months on I have no lasting SE. Step away from Google. Google isn't your friend whilst going through treatment. The mmost serious risks from chemo will be the ones listed on the consent form you signed. (Neutropenic sepsis) Do see if you can have the White cell stimulator after every session. That will help. I was given 'udderly smooth' cream by my chemo nurse for my skin.  A cancer diagnosis is a real tester of a relationship. You and your husband vowed to be together in sickness and in health. If it were the other way round and you were temporarily looking after hubby I bet you would just get on and care for Him no questions asked. That's what your husband wants to do. Men like to fix things. You may find your feelings of guilt start to manifest themselves in other ways. As the annoying song goes...... Let it go. Focus on getting through chemo. Gran all the help and support you can get with  open arms because it will help you move on from this when the time comes.  Happy Easter weekend  Julia X
Posts.Title: breast cancer, looking for advice,experiences,support

Posts.Content: A very warm welcome YorkA. You will find we can all help immensely to get it through.  What a Crap Christmas present you have had. We have all been there and we initially thought we were dying. It's not the case. BC is the most treatable cancer. Not that I think that we are lucky but it could be different.  I was diagnosed 18 months ago. Treatment was hard, very hard and the emotional baggage of cancer is often underestimated. However treatment worked and I am in a very good place.  Take one day at a time. You will learn lots about BC whether you want to or not.  Grade 2 is better than grade 3. Oestrogen positive means you get to have 5/10 years of hormonal therapy to prevent recurrence so they are both positives.  Have you talked chemotherapy yet?  Telling your children can take some planning. My daughter was 9years when I was diagnosed but honest was my best policy.  Let your hubby take care of you and talk to those who will allow you to talk if you want to.  You will always have an ear on here.  Julia X
Posts.Title: reigning in the fear

Posts.Content: Hi Breastie (made me chuckle)  I was treated in South Devon. I am now half way through a 'moving on course' run by a clinical psychologist and Breast care nurse. It's a 6 week course, 2.5 hours per week. This service is very over subscribed. I waited 6 months post treatment to get on it.  In association with Macmillan cancer survivorship programme a 'workshop' day is held a couple of times a year. Invites are sent to all people diagnosed during the year and includes presentations on diet exercise etc.  Good luck  Julia
Posts.Title: survivorship

Posts.Content: Hi Cjo i had a pink/red face on one side like I had been slapped which lasted pretty much the duration of docetaxel but not as severe as you are describing. The chemo nurses must be able to give some advice as they are experienced in seeing a whole host of side effects. it may be that your skin has just dried out and you need heavy duty moisturiser. My skin was terribly dry throughout chemo. When you go for your pre chemo bloods before next Wednesday check with the chemo nurse. I am assuming your body temp is normal?
Posts.Title: Docetaxel - face and neck red - have you experienced this?

Posts.Content: Hi Pmcd  The best way forward is to discuss with a surgeon what recon is best for your body shape and frame. Size does come into it because if you don't have sufficient excess body tissue then an implant might be the favourable option. It will be down to what the surgeon can do with your body to put it frankly. I was advised implants would have been the better option for me based upon my frame and size when I initially sought a Mx. I don't think it was suggested because it was an easier option.  Have an idea of how you would like your new breasts to look (thing of this as an opportunity) and discuss with a surgeon to see if he can do what you envisage. All the best x
Posts.Title: Reconstruction advice and info please.....

Posts.Content: Hi Theresa I developed lymphoedema in the breast after RT. The clinic I was referred too was a bit rubbish but I managed to find someone privately who did Kinesio taping that solved the odema within a couple of months. I still have to massage daily but the swelling is controlled. They do say go straight in with treatment. Don't be fobbed off with them saying wear a compression bra at first to see how it goes. Go straight into lymphatic drainage and taping if you can because it can get worse if its left. Hope it gets sorted soon. I empathize as it is uncomfortable and irritable. Julia
Posts.Title: Breast pain months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Teresa  I had a WLE and Axilla clearance 11 months ago.   You have got behind the wheel pretty quickly. I tried it too, but only driving a couple of Miles and regretted it.  Stabbing pains are normal and I have to say do last for many months whilst you are healing and knitting back together.  One word of caution.... I didn't take it as easy as I should of and ended up with lymphoedema in the breast.  My skin under my arm is still quite numb in places and it's not completely back to normally a year on.  For the stuff you really 'need' to do try and get help or can it wait.  You need to get the healing process right before it gets worse.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Stabbing, searing pain 1 week after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I think the stress debate and cancer is really interesting.  We create stress in our own heads. Situations don't force stress on us it's how we hold onto negative emotions that's damaging. It takes a lot of practice to walk away And be mindful. its also about self preservation and self worth.  I've spent 16 years being in a working environment as the only female. I was the first female to be employed by my employer doing the job I do. It caused uproar in a uniformed environment and it was not easy to "fit in". The guys tried their upmost to intimate and shock me. However I never allowed the guys to pick on me as they perceived me to be weak. 16 years later Im now managing that office of men and im treated just like any other bloke which suits me.  We know how shite our lives have been by living through BC. Come out of it with the strength you gained whilst going through treatment to say to yourself that arguments aren't worth it, we need to be treated with respect (as should everyone) and we are just as worthy as the next person if not more.  Love julia x
Posts.Title: NPI Scale

Posts.Content: boiled water, left to cool and plenty of cotton balls. Wipe over the eyelid several times per day. Always works a treat for me. Xx
Posts.Title: ...Just when l thought l am sailing thro my 3/5 EC.

Posts.Content: Rest assured WORRIED2016 a  Grade 1 cancer isn't fast growing, the complete opposite. You have a very lazy cancer for want of a better word. Grade 3 is fast growing and this is where the majority of us sit. There is a slight risk after surgery that the Grade is upgraded when tissue has been pathologically tested. Don't worry about the U5/M5 I think that describes the location within the breast. You have a tumor that's 15mm and a suspect area of 5mm. They will look at this during surgery. 15mm is small. Mine was 35mm on diagnosis and I didn't think that was that big. Invasive ductal is the most common type of BC compared to invasive lobular. It means its no longer in situ.... its broken out into ducts. That's when its called a carcinoma (cancer). Its a normal diagnosis. Being 8/8 is the BEST you could have hoped for as you will really gain much benefit from hormonal therapies. No lymph node involvement is the best you could hope for. The cancer hasn't moved from the breast (common with grade 1) If it turns out you are HER positive it means you will have to have chemo. However as you are suspected Grade 1 I would say you are HER2 negative. That's a good outcome. Your Breast care nurse will go through all this with you. Give her a ring it will rest your mind. From reading this diagnosis and as diagnosis's come its not a high risk breast cancer. However any cancer is cancer and having any cancer diagnosis tips your world upside down. Julia x
Posts.Title: A million questions and worries.....anxiety attack ?

Posts.Content: Chemo affects the immune system and mouth and gums. A pre existing mouth problem can be made worse during chemo so it's advisable to go into chemo without underlying problems. Saying that your dental work might be ok to leave until after but you should at least have a check up to get some advice From your dentist. You might not have enough time now to get it done and heal well enough before chemo starts. id get a check up at least. Most dentist provide good advice when going through chemo. Julia X
Posts.Title: Thinking of turning down chemo

Posts.Content: Hi sarah  I had clearance the same time as a WLE but to be honest it was the axilla wound site that was the sorest. It's in such a position that causes discomfort and reduced mobility As your arm will be pressing against it. You will be advised to do exercises. Do these as directed as it's important that you work that arm so it mends ok and don't lift. Do follow advice even though it's tempting to do too much too soon. I felt OK enough to drive after five days but immediately regretted it As was very sore after. I would wait a week but do see how you are after surgery. Over working that wound can cause lymphoedema. I developed it in the breast But there's no guaranteed way of not getting it.  I took brufen and paracetamol which the hospital sent me home with but I wasn't in much pain just discomfort.  Do make sure you are given info on post surgery.  all the best for surgery on Thursday. Julia x .
Posts.Title: Axiallary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi WORRIED2016  You need to stop and breathe in deeply. I do think you will benefit from the Macmillan helpline: 0808 808 00 00, Monday - Friday 9am until 8pm. Its free to call. What you don't know is that behind every inspirational post you read on here, there  was once a lady having the same fears as you are now. Trust me - your cancer isn't growing as we speak. Anxiety brings exhaustion. When you are exhausted you cant deal with anything. Let go of the negative thoughts about your ex at the moment as they wont help. He may be no help to you but he is still the father of your children. If your children don't need their father at he moment then let that ride. If they need him, let them contact him. Please phone the helpline. Sending hugs Julia x
Posts.Title: A million questions and worries.....anxiety attack ?

Posts.Content: Hi Nan Floyd  As this is a new pain and one that's keeping you in bed my advice would be get it checked out.  im 20 months post surgery and I get occasional 'soreness' but never pain. Is it the pain that kept you in bed or your mood because of it? Are you still seeing your surgeon?  It sounds like it's getting you down to spend your birthday in bed. Birthdays after BC are best celebrated. Happy birthday for yesterday. You are going great. Just get this one checked out so you can put it to bed. All the best. Julia X
Posts.Title: Pain one year after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Nan Floyd  It sounds like you could have lymphoedema in the breast. Does it also feel warm to touch? Does it look pink and does your bra leave indents after a day's wear? The inverted nipple may be part of this but it's still needing to be checked out xx
Posts.Title: Pain one year after surgery

Posts.Content: Stoatie I think you would benefit from professional pyschological help. In the first instance try the Macmillan helping but speak you your BC unit. Have you been offered any 'moving on' courses to date? Seek counselling.  I'm 17 months post diagnosis and only just starting to get back into post BC life. I needed 5 months of counselling though to get me here.  The physical and mental things you are feeling are all common. Tamoxifen causes aches and pains, Wont help with weight loss and is playing havoc with your oestrogen levels which your body isn't use too. Couple that with all the treatment you have had you werent going to walk away in one peice.  You seem certain that you are dying and that is why i would suggest seeking proper help. It's also taught me not too live in fear.  i had a phobia of death pre diagnosis so one of the many many things counselling helped with was that fear. I no longer have it.  Whilst you think you are dying you aren't living.  Please feel free to message me as I have been through counselling and cannot recommend it enough.  Julia
Posts.Title: Feeling Morbid

Posts.Content: Hi Chockie  i had lobular cancer but it was triple negative. There are risks on diagnosis with lobular that it will be in more than one place but when it's confirmed where it is and treated the risk of recurrence is the same for ductal cancer.  You could use the NHS predict tool to find out your 5 and 10 year prognosis having had surgery, chemo and now on hormonal therapies. You need to know certain things about your cancer though like size etc.  The good news for you is that letrozole is keeping a recurrence at bay.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass  I would say you sound like you have some pretty decent family and friends who genuinely seem supportive. So many of us put on a brave face and say yes we are fine when things are just not that. It's a load of guff because we don't want to bog folk down. You obviously aren't one of those people and that's a credit to you. But in the other hand you sound like your friends really do care how you are feeling.  your friends and family don't know what a secondary cancer diagnosis feels like. I don't know what it feels like and to be completely honest it is my biggest fear. You however know what it feels like and are in an ok place.  We all want and need to be treated differently when we have cancer. One size doesnt fit all. I need a bucket list and I was successfully treated!!! It's made me realise I am not immortal!  So no you are not wrong in how you feel. simply because there cannot be a right or wrong way of feeling. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Am I missing something???

Posts.Content: Hi rome  Lymphoedema presents like this. Do you find your breast is warm to the touch compared to the other and does it look better first thing in the morning?  Julia
Posts.Title: Pain and skin change

Posts.Content: Hi birty If you had adjuvant chemo then there aren't any tests done routinely to see if you are cancer free. Blood tests can be done to measure certain markers but that's not routinely done for BC in this country from what I gather. You may see your consultants regularly for the first 12 months post treatment who do Physical examinations.  You will have yearly mammograms from 12 months of surgery although some healthcare trusts work differently to this.  Ct scans along with bone scans etc are done if there are ongoing issues that need investigation after treatment has finished.  The best advice is should you have a new pain for more than a couple of weeks, get it checked out. I think as we know are bodies more than anyone else we are more than likely to pick up on something not right long before a consultant does.
Posts.Title: How do we know?

Posts.Content: Hi berren  its advised not to have acupuncture in the arm of the affected side. More a precaution than anything. I don't think it's worth taken the risk as lymphoedema is a life long condition once you get it . Ive had acupuncture (not for flushes) and it was very successful without going near my bad arm. Julia X
Posts.Title: Very bad flushes

Posts.Content: Fantastic news Vonnie.  The celebrations so fab too. Three weeks on Spain is just what the dr order. Room for a few small ones???  I am actually flying to Barbados tomorrow. It's my second trip abroad since finishing treatment. For insurance I went through a price comparison site. Include in your search for one that you want to declare a medical condition it's not that painful. I was pleasantly surprised when I went to Portugal. I do think however that long term hormonal treatments make a difference to the cost as they ask if you are still on any medication for your condition.  The start of your new life awaits.  Enjoy julia x
Posts.Title: I think I am a NEDdy

Posts.Content: That really does sound positive WORRIED2016.  I did a 6 week moving on course and it helped massively. It really is important to invest in some time to sort things in your head after treatment finishes.   It sounds like you've got a good balance going on. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Appointments and courses x

Posts.Content: This is all normal and sorry to be the bearer of bad news but your breasts will take over 12 months to recover from surgery. I'm 13 months post surgery and still have numbness and occasional accasional pain. Do check with your BCN but they really should have prewarned you that this would happen And is part of the Breast healing. i had a burning sensation like an iron had been left on my boob.  what I would say is the appearance will change also. Most surgeons will do as much as they can to give you a look you are happy with but won't do this until around a year after when things have settled. Don't think the breasts you have now won't change or won't be able to be changed. It's very early days for you yet.  Julia
Posts.Title: Pain after op

Posts.Content: Hi Ali  How disappointing for you. I can understand what a set back this is. This really is something that your surgeon should have realised before the bilateral mx. Or has your weight loss been since the surgery?  I was told I would only be able to have implants as I didn't have enough spare skin to do anything but implants. There are different types as already stated.  As misty suggests I would definitely be seeking a second opinion. X
Posts.Title: TUG free flap breast reconstruction

Posts.Content: I'm glad is helping you too Jojo4. It's a great book to get a Perspective. Patricia Prijatel is still alive and well. I read another great book by Dr David shirvan-shrieber but was upset to learn he eventually died.  Xx
Posts.Title: Genetics testing

Posts.Content: This happened to me Joyce ..,, I shed a whole nipple. Found it in my bra one night. Imagine my shock. Makes me laugh now just thinking about it. Sounds like you are healing well lovely xx
Posts.Title: Peeling like a snake!!

Posts.Content: Evening Jojo4  Ive gone through the genetic testing. I had a negative result and was triple negative. Dont worry too much about knowing exactly what relatives died of what and when. The first step in the process is to complete a questionnnaire of first line relatives who have died and what caused their death. It's all checked against databases. I was a bit shocked to learn my great aunt died of ovarian cancer whereby I had no idea It was that.  Its a very lengthy process but if you are seen soon there may be hope for your results to be back in time for surgery. The whole process for me took around 5 months. I had to wait 12 weeks for the results. I had had surgery before I got tested But it worked out all ok. You see a nurse and have a counselling session whereby both a negative and positive result are discussed. I gave permission for my blood to be kept and used for research purposes. It is a simple blood test.  A positive result will mean a bilateral MX is suggested and possibly removal of ovaries as you are pre menopausal?  Positive results aren't common but as already said TNBC is more likely to be connected to a brca gene fault but to be honest that's normally when you are diagnosed before 40years old. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Genetics testing

Posts.Content: Hi Jenells Knowing what i know about BC i would say you cant afford to take risks.  i found a sizeable tumour in my breast then realised at least a year up until the diagnosis i had a very itchy boob. It itched exactly where the tumour was growing. I was oblivious to what was happening under the skin.  The steriod cream might be just masking an underlying cause. i say this not to scare you but to really say please dont take a chance. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Appt on thurs but should I cancel?

Posts.Content: Hello Karen  I'm sorry to read treatment is on hold at the moment. I can understand the worry but it's being checked out so that's the best course of action at this time. I've read on here many ladies that have had lumps and hardening after surgery that were all part of the healing process.  I've had two scares since radiotherapy so I know how they affect you. I started RT late due to swelling so please don't worry it's being held up whilst they check it out.  When do you get the results? Try not to be studying the rest of your body at this time as your mind will be playing tricks on you and it will escalate anxiety.  Julia xx

Posts.Content: Hi Lilythepig  the following link should help .... scroll down to the bottom. https://community.macmillan.org.uk/blogs/b/weblog18/archive/2015/07/31/chemo-aids-shopping-list-gathered-from-breast-group-memebrs I haven't heard specifically about avoiding raspberries or strawberries. I think with any fruit or veg the advice would be to wash it thoroughly Before eating anyway. love julia xx

Posts.Content: A PCr is when you have chemo before surgery and by the Time surgery comes there is no cancer left as chemo has gotten it all. I can't lie. Being on chemo is the worse I have ever felt in my life. it was just a means to an end of BC.  Julia xx

Posts.Content: so lovely to see you pop up Heather77 (Heather). I do think about you and wonder how you are doing. I'll not forget that long slog you had with Letrozole.  Im happy to read you have found changes in yourself that have been for the better. I agree with you. My life has changed for the better. I no longer wish me back to pre cancer Life. Many lessons have been learnt.  My next door neighbour is 100 years old and amazes me every day as I see her getting into a taxi to go to the social club. Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Chloecat  That is very good news on the scan front. Your perseverance really is commendable.  I had TNBC and didn't think about the non conventional route but do see the appeal. It is very difficult though to say categorically what has caused your DCIS too reduce. Your consultants obviously know you are with the alternative methods and I guess you discuss with them what you take? I am also guessing you take quite a lot of supplements? Do the consultants ever offer up an opinion on what you are taking and the results in the shrinkage of the tumour? Do either of them get linked? I do find it very interesting.  Julia X
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi hedgewitch  It takes courage to make any decision whether that conventional/non conventional or half way house. You talk as though you regret your decision to have chemotherapy and RT? Treatment for BC has changed a lot in recent years and continues to do so. One treatment plan does in no way fit all. Scientists have discovered so much and continue to do so that we aren't only having drugs used decades ago. We have hormonal therapies for ER+. We have Herceptin (biological therapy) for HER+ . Scientists are so close to preventative drugs for triple negative BC. We know about the BRCA gene mutation. Radiotherapy has become even more 'targeted' in the breast and risks of heart problems are now minimized. I don't think you can say that the field of BC research is stagnant by any means. Surgery doesn't always come first in treatment. More and more oncologists are using chemo neo adjuvantly. This is a great way of measuring performance and prognosis. I went for conventional because without chemo I most certainly would probably be on my way out now having had TNBC with node involvement.   Conventional treatments do carry risk but where risks are too great a consultant wont be offering it. The trick is to be at peace with whatever method you choose or not to choose. That's why the consultant gets you to sign disclaimers after all. Julia x
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: hi marlog  If you click on chloecats name it will take you to her profile where there is lots of info there.  Julia X
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello Craftyp  Welcome back. So glad you thought of us again to help. I was 41 on diagnosis and was triple negative so I didn't have hormone therapies however I've noted you didn't take tamoxifen for long. I assume you don't take any oestrogen suppressing drugs now? I had FECT too and after 5 months my periods returned. They came back for a couple of cycles normally then went into a weird sync, as you describe above. I was blood tested and it was confirmed I was peri menstrual. This can last years!!! Anyway, after a further couple of months they went back into being as regular as clockwork but a lot heavier. I think this is all part of the peri menopause. I actually celebrated my periods returning as its a good thing in terms of keeping bones and heart healthy. In your case though it means your oestrogen levels are still up which isn't ideal because you were ER positive, albeit weakly. You could go to your GP and ask if they can check the status of your hormones to see if you have entered the peri menopause stage. Either way I think its worth getting it checked with your GP as the advice with irregular bleeding is to get it checked. Your oncologist may be of help too if you are still in contact? I still see mine every 6 months - I am close to 2 years post diagnosis. All the best Julia
Posts.Title: Periods returning after chemo

Posts.Content: Don't you just love a mans sense of humour :) My 9 year old said I looked like a boiled egg! My partner loved the GI Jane stage of hair growth!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Snowys Mum (Helen) Gosh that does sound good. 2a is without node involvement but a sizeable tumour. A very courageous decision to go down the alternative route with TNBC. this is the first natural experience with TNBC I've heard of.  Thanks helen  xx
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I'm gutted for you to chloecat45. I remember the staging scans and that was a scary time. Fingers crossed the node has kept it all there in one place. Don't look back on what you could have done but look forward to what you can do now. Hugs Julia X
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I do find your comments worrying Annie.  I appreciate you are trying to create context but as a triple negative lady i have to say that the use of words as 'highly aggressive' creates panic in itself. TNBC likes to recurr just as much as her2 positive BC. My TNBC was grade 2. It's not always grade 3.  I sound very defensive but there are many tnbc ladies on here and whilst it likes to recurr more so in the first 3 years there are also many positives to TNBC.  Your comment that the majority of invasive breast cancer will kill you sooner or later is over generalising. Do the majority of us die from it? No we don't. Not by a long shot. The stats prove this.  Julia
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello Lisa For ER+ and no node involvement I would have said a straight no. However as this is a recurrence you do have a sneaky cancer and I would be inclined to try more treatment this time to stop another recurrence/secondary diagnosis. Love Julia x

Posts.Content: hi Pepys  Annie could have meant that in which case it makes sense. Otherwise it doesn't.

His words seem harsh but then I'm guessing you are use to his ways. Some men struggle to realise that encouragement and support have a better outcome than being blunt.  Suggest he could start on a healthy regime including exercise with you then you can support each other.  The bottom line is you only need to do what makes you more comfortable and happier.  X

Posts.Content: A PCr is when you have chemo before surgery and by the Time surgery comes there is no cancer left as chemo has gotten it all. Posts.Title: Chemo yes or no?

Posts.Content: Hello Caroline  The best way forward really is the referral your GP has organised.  The only experience I have of calcium levels in blood is that my oncologist ordered a full blood test and bone scan back in August due to rib pain I was getting. The bloods came back with normal calcium levels and the bone scan normal. I know it is something that is measured in cancer patients but it can also be in relation to other things.  I hope I haven't let you down he he.  I hope the tests are arranged soon. Do keep posting for support. I had 5 months of counselling after my treatment and it's just come to an end. I feel like I've been released back into the wild!  Julia x
Posts.Title: High Calcium Levels in Blood

Posts.Content: LJB234, I have had chemo. for me it woukd have been silly not to as I was triple negative. I don't know what it feels like to have a choice so I am bias.  im also biased as I had a pathological complete response to chemo. I do appreciate however that this is rare. i am told that makes my prognosis very good for me. That makes me very positive about my future.  Apart from non serious palpitations I am fitter than I was pre cancer. I was 41 when I had chemo and physically fit Even then. From the sound of your posts I would say you have made up your mind and it would help if you had suppprt for this. In which case I would say go with your gut feeling. You sound like you can live with the decision  to not have chemo.   Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Chemo yes or no?

Posts.Content: CARDBOND What is IDC? Invasive ductal breast cancer. The other type of invasive is invasive lobular cancer. It's to do with where the cancer has grown from within the breast and broken free (become invasive) . julia xx
Posts.Title: Tiredness and aches.....

Posts.Content: I was "lucky" (tongue in cheek) that I was able to cash in my critical illness cover. It's bitter sweet. You have a "critical illness" that's deemed so critical you get your pay out. What would I have preferred? No cancer and to struggle financially or have cancer and have my mortgage paid off?  Its true in that newer CI policies arent covering b cancer in situ. But take that as a good thing as it's not deemed a critical illness.  Macmillan can give loads of financial advice for during a diagnosis so try the helpline once you know what's what.  Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Tiredness and aches.....

Posts.Content: Hi Jo  Don't feel a fraud for thinking that you have breast cancer.  The waiting, blind terror, sheer panic and high anxiety is what we have all encountered and its no fun and it's not pleasant. However at the moment you don't know what your diagnosis is, your brain is telling you the worst outcome.  As Weeble says, take someone close to you with you to the appointment. There are a number of tests that are done starting with a physical examination, a mammogram then ultrasound guided biopsies if needed. Think about what you would like to ask the consultant if you get to the biopsies stage. I couldn't find the balls to ask anything but then I think I didn't want to know until It was official. I did wait two weeks for results but it sounds like you will get these straight away at the one stop clinic. That's a good thing.  My advice is to take painkillers before the appointment or have them in your bag. Take them if you get to the biopsie stage. You will need them.  Come back here when you have the results and let us help you. There are many many experiences on here.  All the best Jo.  Julia x
Posts.Title: breast clinic tomorow im worried sick

Posts.Content: Hi anni69  I am a regular runner and have been for over ten years. It's my salvation! My max distance is half marathon. I'm not built for running as I'm tall but I do it all the same. Chemo was the only time I couldn't run. My lung capacity was rubbish and my heart rate went through the roof very quickly when I exercised. With docetaxol I got anaemic so had blood transfusions. To be honest climbing the stairs without stopping was hard. i switched to using my bike on a turbo trainer indoors and walked a lot. My best advice is don't plan for any thing and you won't get dissapointed.  Chemo is hard going (or was for me) but you can exercise in other ways temporarily. i wish you all the very best for chemo. love julia xx thanks for the tag Snowys Mum x
Posts.Title: Any runners here?

Posts.Content: Hello Faith  Another triple neg lady here.  Its often thought 'node clearance' literally means all nodes are removed. That's not the case. We have around 21 nodes in that area but they aren't all together they are in clusters. I had clearance , 11 removed only 1 of which was positive before chemo.  As your mum had only 2 nodes affected they removed the surrounding nodes around those two. To go on a remove more upstream would be excessive and more importantly increase the risk of lymphoedema which can be lifelong.  Think of the 5 removed around the two as the clear margin.  all the best to your mum.  Julia
Posts.Title: My Mum's treatment - advise needed please

Posts.Content: Hi weeble  They are weird places for acne to appear. Sounds more like a reaction to something so it's worth getting it checked out. i suffered from acne as a teenager and it would be the last straw if I went back there!  Julia x
Posts.Title: Acne!

Posts.Content: Hello jules (I'm a jules too)  A warm welcome. We were all newbies once so have lots of experience to share with you.  I had chemo FEC -T. There is no way of telling what side effects you will encounter until you have it. The best plan is to expect the worst.  I was very nauseous with FEC which use to come on around 3/4 hours after administration but it can happen more quickly.  From my experience of chemo I would not have managed a 3 hour journey at any stage in chemo. If you stay with a friend however you may find as I did that the first 3/5 days after FEC I was in bed. Would you be comfortable staying there feeling poorly? Maybe arrange that for the first cycle then see how you fare. Dont let my experience put you off as many don't get nauseous with FEC but it will affect you on some way.  All the best with it.
Posts.Title: Hi Im new here is there a newbies site? How do you cope with Chemo...

Posts.Content: I do agree Carolina.  No body deserves any life threatening illness but I can't imagine wishing I or anyone else had another type of crap different from the crap we are dealt. It almost feels like it could turn into a comparison game.  By not accepting what has happened to us we don't move on properly.  It is what it is as they say and neither we or nobody else has the power to change our situations.
Posts.Title: Just thinking

Posts.Content: Hi gillie  I too was TN. Finished all treatment 5 months ago. I have uncomfortable pain in the breast from time to time but then I do have lymphodema in it.  As this is affecting the movement in your arm you need to get it checked out. Pain killers will control pain but won't tell you what is going on.  With Rt being only a short time ago it will more than Likely  be after affects xx
