Posts.Title: 1st year mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Rach1969  My hospital has just sent me information saying they no longer consider it necessary for me to avoid injections/BP and bloods on the affected arm. They say there's no evidence to suggest it does increase your lymphoedema risk. No doubt your physio will be practicing good hygiene and sterile conditions so the risk is very very low. I would say though that cortisone isn't known for being great as a one off and it will take many shots to be effective. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Frozen shoulder, Cortisone injection, lymphedema risk.

Posts.Content: I wasn't given an option to not take steriods. With docetaxol especially the chemo nurses weren't prepared to give me the tax until they were 100% sure I had taken the pre med steroids. they reduce your chance of allergic reaction. taking steroids near bed time actually inhibits sleep.  The following link is helpful....  http://www.macmillan.org.uk/information-and-support/treating/supportive-and-other-treatments/supportive-therapies/steroids.html Julia x
Posts.Title: Unable to sleep post chemo.

Posts.Content: I wasn't given an option to not take steriods. With docetaxol especially the chemo nurses weren't prepared to give me the tax until they were 100% sure I had taken the pre med steroids. they reduce your chance of allergic reaction. taking steroids near bed time actually inhibits sleep.  The following link is helpful....  http://www.macmillan.org.uk/information-and-support/treating/supportive-and-other-treatments/supportive-therapies/steroids.html Julia x
Posts.Title: Unable to sleep post chemo.

Posts.Content: The pain, discomfort  and the whole experience of surgery will be catching up with your mind. When our bodies are in pain unfortunately our minds dip into that negative state. Its what we do. All the side effects you are feeling I had too even wth a WLE. The axilla clearance was far the worst pain and troublesome whilst healing. You are trying to kid your mind you dont miss something beacuse it might have killed you but actually this is part of you that has been removed without you wanting it. I found the hardest thing about 'moving on' ( I am 6 months post treatment now) is that sense of loss. I felt bereft. Bereft for my hair, my confidence, my pre cancer breast, my level of fitness and my body image. I kept beating myself up because alI kept thinking was that I should be more grateful I am now cancer free. But again our minds dont work like that. In the following weeks when the pain gets less and you heal your mind will become less hurtful too. You are still in early stages of recovery so dont be hard on yourself and its ok to miss your breast, no matter how much it was trying to hurt you. Take care Julia x
Posts.Title: Tearful

Posts.Content: Gosh I think I would be a tad annoyed too.  I think you need to ask for written confirmation in your case that they delay won't carry any risk. Send an email with your concerns and ask for a reply. If your oncologist thinks the delay wouldn't cause problems get it in writing otherwise she can fit you in sooner.  The thing is a if you don't say anything now, she will assume the heats off.
Posts.Title: Chemo delayed hickman line

Posts.Content: You are so very welcome Gemzy1889. neo adjuvant is a double edged sword but you do have to have trust in it. Any response is better than no response so you hold out for anything with that MRI. No one explained about what response I could hope for so to get the gold standard was my gold nugget. It keeps me strong . I'm three years post diagnosis and have learnt many many things about myself and about life. My life now is better but I've made it better. It was a bloody hard wake up call. All the best for the MRI. Let us know how you get on. love julia xx
Posts.Title: Breast pain whilst on chemo

Posts.Content: Evening Helsbels  I think you are searching for an answer you will never get. It's one we can't answer for you as much as we would like.  It happens. Many ladies on here had tumours not picked up on mammograms or weren't palpable.  Right from diagnosis I was warned that the diagnosed size was likely to change on surgery. Even when it was suspected I had a complete response to chemo I was warned they could find tumour hiding when they opened me up. It felt like I was always prepared for the worse. Consultants never give definitives.  However big it was, it is now out of your body and no longer doing harm.  Ask your oncologist next week why it wasn't detected. Save the anger until then and think of positive things to allow you to enjoy the rest of the weekend.  Julia X
Posts.Title: how can you not detect a 30 mm tumour!

Posts.Content: That's the conversation you need to have with your surgeon. At the moment you are working on the proviso that lymph node involvement is unlikely in your case. With the SNB they often remove the sentinel node anyway so it doesn't always mean even if you do have lymph involvement you need radiotherapy to the Axilla Area, they just remove affected nodes.  Lobular cancer often presents in that web way. I had lobular but was only one solitary tumour. they do MRI scan you though to make sure its not in the other breast too so rest assured youve had good surveillance.  I think you need to be asking your surgeon exactly what they do when the snb is done and if they remove the sentinel node/any other nodes and if there is involvememt would you have the Axilla covered by radiotherapy anyway? Recon will be affected by RT unless its delayed.  things will be one clearer when you meet your surgeon. I would advise staying away from Dr Google until then. Dr Google is no expert.  Julia X
Posts.Title: waiting for mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy - what about reconstruction...

Posts.Content: I am 4 months post treatment and now see BC consultant and oncologist alternatively every three months. I questioned if they ever did blood tests and was told no. Even if markers were present in your blood I don't think that would automatically mean resuming treatment because it doesn't automatically mean secondaries. That's why they rely on symptoms.  I had lobular BC also Triple neg and did have extensive scans before treatment commenced just make sure the treatment was only for primary BC. Having both lobular and being triple neg it was more tricky.  I think we really have to question what good a blood test or ongoing scans would do. The NHS can't Fund that level of tests. Hard for us for sure but as the other ladies have said, we have to start trusting our bodies and especially our immune systems. There are many things we can do too help ourselves too.
Posts.Title: How do you know if you have mets

Posts.Content: Hi London Daisy  I could have been treated at two different hospitals. Sometimes you do get a choice. Are you need needing to decide before the results of the biopsy come back? If you look online at the cancer services for the choice of hospitals you have been given most of them are % rated. This may help you make a more informed decision. To be honest some consultants work across more than one hospital anyway. It also depends on what treatment you need. If you are having chemo then you will be going to hospital frequently, radiotherapy even more frequent so it makes sense to think about how far you will have to travel. I was fortunate in that my hospital (Torbay) was only 4 miles away. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Selecting hospital

Posts.Content: I work in Exeter and have many contacts there so will keep a look out for you.  Julia
Posts.Title: let down again

Posts.Content: Hi Gemzy1889  I had neo adjuvant chemo (FECt) and had pain/soreness in both breasts throughout. I ended up with a pathological complete response to chemo so take the aching/soreness as a very good sign. There probably wasn't a bone/musle/nerve in my body that didn't hurt/ache at some point during chemo. This doesn't mean chemo is attacking cancer. Chemo doesn't know which are cancer cells and which are normal cells it just looks to see which cells are multiplying faster than normal. That's why you lose hair, you get mouth problems, you feel sick etc etc. It affects the whole body. Please rest assured. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Breast pain whilst on chemo

Posts.Content: You've hit the nail on the head. Some things have to be put back without us changing them. It's a hard thing to learn. You are doing just fab.  The dog walking sounds perfect. I've always wanted a dog especially so since cancer but I can't give up work so it's a catch 22. Enjoy the fresh air. I'm mustering enthusiasm for a 9 mile run. I may be sometime!  Have a peaceful day lovely  Xx
Posts.Title: how can you not detect a 30 mm tumour!

Posts.Content: Hi jenny1973  what was the reason you are needing a mX. Is it a large tumour being lobular or in multiple places ? It is possible to know you have lymph node involvememt from first diagnosis. Mine was seen in ultrasound and biopsy tested Right from the start  however I had chemo first. Where you have surgery first they like to wait until then to do the testing. They try to avoid axilla clearance now and the sentinel node biopsy is a good way of doing this. Full clearce adds a big risk of lymphoedema. You don't have to have immediate recon and regardless of whether you have lymph node involvement or not it can all be done at the same time.  Chemo doesn't affect implants but RT does and as Misty says you need to check whether you are needing RT after an implant unless you are having expanders fitted?  To be honest until you meet with the plastics team to see what they are recommending we may be jumping the gun someWhat. They will tell you what is realistic on your body and what can be offered.  Julia X
Posts.Title: waiting for mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy - what about reconstruction...

Posts.Content: hi berren  when we first hear news like this it sets us back. In time you will have processed this and will be less negative.... I hope. Your destination is not already predetermined. If it was, you would have be told you are incurable and you are far from it. You've two more courses of treatment Up your sleeve.  i had lymph node involvement and was triple negative so don't have the benefit of preventative drugs. im coming up to two years post diagnosis. I live with the view that my destination hasn't been predetermined And I live a better life than I did pre cancer.  You will feel better over the coming weeks about this news. hugs  Julia X
Posts.Title: Feel there is no hope

Posts.Content: Hi helsbels18  Im guessing as we've had a DNA fault to start with that affected our breast then as we have two breasts then it could happen again. Im not actually sure though how many develop tumours in the other breast (a new primary). The risk is probably smaller than secondaries? I don't know. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Increaseed risk of cancer in other breast -why?

Posts.Content: Two weeks of phased return in a physical job is no time at all Tiggy62. My return took 4 months!  dont feel useless as you are far far from it but also don't put yourself into the position where you will be run ragged. I'm familiar with the environment you work in and it might be worth specifically saying you can't take charge at the moment. Build up to that. Go back to your GP to talk about another 'fit for work with adjustments' Note and speak to your employer and be honest about what you feel your capabilities are for the next few weeks.  please put yourself first. My return went so well. I've been back 13 months now and pride myself on having not one day off sick! If you burn yourself out now you will put your ' moving on' back.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Not coping now back at work .

Posts.Content: Hi bobins  I'm only 4 months post treatment so can't advise on the time frame but if this is a new symptom rather than it still being healing pains from surgery I would get it checked before September. Is it swollen at all? If you had lymph node removal there's a chance it could be lymphoedema in the breast but only a professional will diagnose that. All the best xx
Posts.Title: new breast pain

Posts.Content: Fantastic news Liz, many congratulations. What a great feeling it is to reach the end and to have good results. I too had a pathological complete response (I had TNBC) to neoadjuvant chemo, although my nutrition (which day to day is normally very good) went to the wall during chemo so it wasn't that. I had a WLE but then questioned why I needed RT after it was known I had had a PCR. Due to the TNBC diagnosis my oncologist would not recommend not having RT. He said they didn't know enough to be sure that by not having RT it wouldn't put me at anymore risk. You being HER2 + you may get the same response. As you say, you don't have to go with the advice of the oncologist but be prepared for them to say they recommend it. I didn't think twice about not having it because of the TN diagnosis.  All the best with the decision making x
Posts.Title: Mastectomy 3 weeks ago & now Cancer Free! Yipee!!

Posts.Content: Hi Chrisb.84  Good on you for being a caring partner and wanting to find out more about this. Was there a reason why your girlfriend saw a nurse and not the GP? Did the nurse do a full breast examination as well as seeing the visual symptoms? I  would suggest that your girlfriend makes an appointment with the GP and gets the GP to make a opinion on if that lump needs further investigation. To be honest there are only two weeks left of January so visiting the GP next week is only a week earlier than advised. All the best. We are always here should you or your partner have more questions. Julia
Posts.Title: Worried partner :( Mastitis or worse?

Posts.Content: For anyone getting their heads around Triple negative breast cancer, I found Patricia Prijatel's Surviving triple negative breast cancer a lifeline when I was diagnosis. A book which will make you laugh and cry tears is 'The C word' by the brilliant Lisa Lynch.  I also follow Kris Hallenga, founder of Coppafeel. Kris has had secondary BC for over 7 years and continues to do so much in raising awareness in younger girls
Posts.Title: Books you recommend

Posts.Content: Hi TootsBess  I would wait another couple of weeks. Your immune system will take months to get back on track. Chlorine may aggravate chemo skin. My skin was very sensitive for some months. I also wouldn't have been comfy using a pool without hair. walking is just as good for keeping you ticking over In the fitness department.  Don't dispare about the numbness. I had it for over 12 months but it's now much better. you do get use to it. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Getting back to exercise. And underarm sensitivity.

Posts.Content: Hi Cycling girl  I had TNBC, invasive lobular grade 2 diagnosed at 41years. It does happen after 40 years but when diagnosed under 40 there is more risk at having the faulty BRCA genes. Being TN was the biggest shock for me to start with but I did lots of research and asked many questions from oncologist. The unfortunate thing is that there some very negative words used when describing TNbC and that in itself is shocking if you have it.  Ask to see the scores of the oestrogen progesterone and her2 tests. I had a 3 out of 8 score for progesterone but they still take that as negative. But I believe this can help. I have read that TNBC is attracting much research and there is  signs of movement on terms of finding a preventative drug. I pray this happens. It is not known what makes TNBC grow, that's the problem.  I pushed for the BRCA testing as my great aunt had ovarian cancer and her daughter breast. It's a long process and I'm awaiting results.  As you say TNBC responds well to chemo, I had neo adjuvant chemo. I had a 25mm tumour and one node effected and come surgery there were no cancer cells to be found. The risk of reoccurrence however is slightly higher within two years. However if after 5 years you have no reoccurrence then the reoccurrence rates after that time are far less than other BCs, if that makes sense. My oncologist described TNBC that responds well to chemo as being on a level playing field with BC that can be controlled by hormonal/biological therapies.  I have a daughter and panicked when I was tested until the genetic counsellor pointed out, testing is not permitted on under 18s. My daughter is 10. When she becomes an adult I can only hope there is so much more prevention/cure for TNBC. I have taken part in two studies and given permission for my tissue to be sampled. I did have RT after a WLE and if I were u I would question this again. As I had no cancer cells after chemo I questioned why I needed RT and my oncologist could not say it was safe not to have it as a preventative measure. With TNBC you need all the ammunition you can get I feel.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Isingbass  One more positive on your list would have tipped the balance in positives favour. It's a good start However. In another 12 months I guarentee your positive list will far outweigh your negatives list.  It's true in that time is a great healer. Take that from the posts from ladies on here further down the moving on line. You are doing great. There are no expectations that you are a positive Polly 100% of the time. I don't think I could say I was even before BC affected me. Fatpuffin i was saddened to read your post especially when you say you almost look back on chemo fondly. It sounds as though there are many things making you feel down. Your stuck in a rut and don't feel your husband gets you and how you feel. It will be a viscious circle. Do you talk openly with your husband about how you feel?  i completely understand how you feel about this forum. I felt the same whilst I was going through treatment then I was asked to support others which gives me great happiness. But I am able to do this without my emotional state being affected because I feel in a good mental state. I lived for 6 months in a bad state and new I couldn't carry on so I sought help. I was on self destruct. have you thought about talking about how you feel to a counsellor? I think you would find it very beneficial. They say post treatment can bring on symptoms like PTSD.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: 12 months ago today since my mastectomy...

Posts.Content: Here's me all poised for a reply to Bev and I get to George's post and it all goes Pete Tong! As I recompose myself and wipe the tears from my cheeks.................... Bev... All I would say is that I would be mindful that as time goes on it will be less and less realistic that you have the time, motivation and stamina to stick to a diet plan. When you hit docetaxol you will lose all taste buds and at best your mouth will feel like the bottom of a bird cage. This will play a very important part in what and when you eat. Dieting now may set yourself up for a fall and psychologically that may hit you hard, especially if in the past WW has been successful for you. Julia x
Posts.Title: Slimming world/ weightwatchers while on Chemo??

Posts.Content: I think we have to be mindful that in professionals eyes there is some information that is considered unnecessary for the patient to see. It's also something that that trusts will not budget for, giving out copies of everything. Also whilst going through treatment we may not have asked for information or copies of things yet in hindsight we should have. It would surprise me if your requests for such info was denied however. I was shown the MRI scan of my Breast and I may have been looking at coronation street..... it didn't show anything to me. There is a fine line between being given too much Information that people won't understand or being treated like you will only be given info on a 'need to know basis'.
Posts.Title: How do I get copy of pathology report?

Posts.Content: Thank you for the compliment Monika. I'm not in the medical profession, I guess Ive learnt an awful lot over the last 12 months.  I work for a Fire and Rescue service so am use to the public sector. I have found that from being triple negative I have wanted to find out more and more information as there seems to be very little good advice for triple negative ladies/gents out there.
Posts.Title: How do I get copy of pathology report?

Posts.Content: Hello Devon Dweller I am so sorry to read this outcome concerning your wife. Here we are a year on and its looking like treatment will start up again. Reading a diagnosis in black and white is truly shocking. I too am in Devon. I was treated at Torbay but I know the RD & E well and I do know the team are very good. It maybe that you need extra support during this time. The Macmillan helpline would be able to signpost you. Keep posting for support from us. I wish you and your wife all the best and hope that treatment will commence soon and be a benefit. Julia
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: Dear Devon Dweller  Now I know why the stars shine bright in Devon at the moment.  I am so sad and sorry to read your wife has passed. May she rest in peace.  I do hope you are receiving all the support you need.  From another Devon girl.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: Hi Lacomtekp  I really can't recommend the Priticia Prijatel book enough. Please don't go into full panic mode with TNBC.  I see a consultant alternatively every three months (as you describe). I'm now into year two post diagnosis so this will change to six months soon. if you were to ask your oncologist, would your after care be any different if you had any other type of BC and the same treatment you would probably find it exactly the same. recurrence risk is higher for us within the first 5 years but get to that and your risk is way below ER+ BC. Recurrence of ER+ will continue post 10 years but it's not like that with TNBC. There are so many differt subtypes of TNBC that one size does not fit all and that's why we all respond so differently to neo adjuvant chemo. I like to view the positives of TNBC. Would I be wanting to take hormone therapies at 41 Years, no not really. I'm happy that if I can get through another three years my risk of recurrence is very low. Do speak to your Onco and let him give some confidence. Mine was terrific. Julia X
Posts.Title: Books you recommend

Posts.Content: WHOOP WHOOP Thanks Dreamthief  for the TNBC info. I confess it's made my week already. I follow the research into TNBC therapies and it's looked promising for awhile now.  Happy happy happy . Julia X
Posts.Title: Books you recommend

Posts.Content: A lovely post Zanib. Your Mamma sounds like my Mum. My mum tells me often.... Ill always be her little baby. What would we do without them.
Posts.Title: please explain

Posts.Content: Hi Ronstar Has lymphoedema in the breast been suggested to you? It can happen after RT so the timings are right. Mine was diagnosed a couple of months post RT.  Surgery was too far away for a seroma to happen to you now. See what Monday brings Love Julia xx ronstar
Posts.Title: Firm swelling of 'breast'

Posts.Content: Hi silkpainter31  You are amongst friends here. We will always be on red alert when it comes to lumps bumps and aches and pains. Consultants should always be thorough because if they don't things get missed.  When is a good time to be told you have a lump that needs investigating? Never. The consultant could've withheld the information from you until after Christmas but that's not Eithical either. This isn't the fault of your consultant so get angry at cancer and what it does to us moving forward.  I had a lump in my good breast that needed checking out I've also had a lymph node in my neck checked out all with a normal result. It's constant checks and balances but that's all part of being vigilant to avoid what's happened before. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Ever so slightly stunned ! Please not again.

Posts.Content: Hi Fatpuffin  I had counseling over a 5 month period. It ended up being very little about the cancer but more about the way I was looking at my life because of the experience I had just had. My relationship, my job, my relationship with my family was all part of it and finding a counselor that I connected with meant I processed all the negative thoughts I had. You cant move on when you are carrying so much baggage. Off load. It sounds to me that your relationship with your husband isn't what it could be. Cancer aside, were you happy in your life before the diagnosis? You sound like you have very little self esteem. Why do you feel like your 'cocking up'. Have you considered that your husband may just not be sympathetic to where you are at and that is his issue not yours. For me cancer was life changing and it meant I looked at my life at the end of treatment and made a conscious decision that I was going to live how I wanted to live in order to keep happy and content. My relationship was the first to go. make a list of what you want to do and plan how you can achieve that. Be realistic about your goals and timeframes. Where do you want to start? Is getting a job your priority at this moment in time?  If you want to climb Kilimanjaro, make plans to do so. Take back some control. Cancer has controlled you for some time now, its time to get back on top. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: 12 months ago today since my mastectomy...

Posts.Content: Hi millie63  im sorry to read this.  Did the nodes not get removed? Was it just the sentinel node? I had one node positive but 11 removed and no RT. I would have only been comfortable with the cancer cells being removed.  Love julia x
Posts.Title: double rads?

Posts.Content: You don't sound at all stupid millie63.  I was wondering why with a positive node they didn't remove it when the tumour was removed? Or was it removed and they are offering Rt on top of that?
Posts.Title: double rads?

Posts.Content: Hi Katie  you are having a tough time of it. It must seem endless at the moment.  I don't have a similar experience in terms of clear margins but did have an MRI scan due to having lobular BC. MRI is the gold standard so with regard to misdiagnosis, with three scans it's highly unlikely they will miss anything. You have had all the scans you can have.  Your surgeon will have the results of the MRI before surgery today. Ask him about them to set your mind at rest before you go for surgery.  Treatment comes with set backs. I had a fair few. That's where the analogy of a roller coaster comes in. It's up and down. You do think the worse because that's what are brains do until we teach it to stop. It will get better. All the best for today and a speedy recovery x
Posts.Title: Treatment and Diagnosis constantly changing

Posts.Content: So happy to read you are getting support from home Zanib.  I think your appointment will give you the low down on chemotherapy and what to expect. They will tell you what you should be doing whilst on chemo and what to avoid. You will be given info on getting a wig. You are right about your hair being thick and therefore losing it slowly. Mine was very thick and it took weeks to fall out until it looked silly.  Take someone with you tomorrow. You will be given lots of information and they may also give you lots of drugs to combat side effects. It can be very confusing.  The blood test will be just to check you are in good health ready for your first chemo. It's standard procedure. You will have blood taken before every chemo session.  Take some pain killers before your picc line on Wednesday.  It's not painful just un comfy.  All the very best for Thursday. It's a worrying time because it's unknown. This time next week you will have an idea on what to expect from chemo.  Julia X
Posts.Title: please explain

Posts.Content: Hi Pixidust  You can ask to see any information about you regarding your diagnosis that's held on your file. Just be mindful that a pathology report is very 'medical' and you will most certainly need a consultant to talk through all the letters and numbers. The risk is you Otherwise google what it means and that is scary! Was there a reason why you wanted a second opionion? It's common practice for consultants to keep your GP informed of all your treatment and progress. I asked to be copied in on all correspondence and found these letters much more informative than what the consultant verbally said to me x
Posts.Title: How do I get copy of pathology report?

Posts.Content: Hi Haysie  The reason why you are feeling low will be a lot to do with the anesthetic you had for surgery. I felt the same after. It affects hormones and we all know that affecting hormones in us ladies will affect our mood. It will wear off. You are right, folk are hoping to celebrate good news with you when get your results. Don't feel pressured to reply during this time to them seeking information. In hindsight, it was the compassion of friends and family that got me through. We all thrive when we feel loved. Imagine no enquiries to how you are feeling :( Sending hugs ... it does get better after surgery. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Struggling today

Posts.Content: Morning Katie What a rubbish way to start the week. I would imagine you are still in shock and still in hospital? I am sorry to read this. This is a crap time but it will help to look at the positives. The MX was going to happen whatever happened. Whatever nasty's were in your breast are now gone. I assume the other breast was healthy, which is good news. Try not to think of it as back to square one when the nasty's have been removed. You are still ahead of the game. The tissue removed will be sent to the pathologist where it will be tested for grade and receptor status. That will indicate what adjuvant treatment you will have and would have been done regardless of the MRI results you had yesterday. Everything is being done that can be done. When the shock of the MRI calms down you will start to feel better. Honestly. It takes time to get use to the news. Be mindful post surgery can make you feel down. This being the result of surgery and anesthetics. If you feel like this in a couple of days it will be the after effects of surgery. I hope you have a speedy recovery. Julia xx
Posts.Title: Treatment and Diagnosis constantly changing

Posts.Content: Hi Mazza2016  im sorry to read about your diagnosis but am glad you have found the Mac community. I'm hoping you find us a big help during a bad situation. Many many women on diagnosis automatically think to cure anxiety and recurrence a bilateral mx is the way to go. I was triple negative, lobular, 41 years old, lymph node involvement and grade 2 and convinced the bilateral MX was the only way to go. I had numerous appointments with my surgeon and was finally Convinced weeks later a WLE was the way forward. I'm so glad I went with that. I'm assuming a WLE has been suggested so far? being grade 1 and a small tumour  I think you will struggle getting a surgeon to say a single MX is the best way forward let alone a bilateral. Many surgeons won't remove a healthy breast.  My surgeon was very frank with me. He told me removing both my breasts and possibly being very unhappy about my appearance even with implants, it was no guarantee to 'solve' my anxiety. I had major anxiety being Triple negative. He also said having both breasts removed had no bearing on whether I would die of cancer nor would it stop a recurrence. It was harsh but I got what he was saying. He was saying it was over treating.  I had a very successful WLE but months of counselling after to help with the anxiety. To be honest many of us here have counselling regardless of what surgery we have as the fear is still real with a  MX.  You should be able to talk to your surgeon about what and why he is recommending. You should be able to see photos of MX's and reconstruction your surgeon has done so you can be fully informed.  it doesn't seem your BC team are trying hard enough to inform you about what and why. Has your surgeon agreed to the bilateral? That's the first hurdle. If he's in agreement then aslong as your signing the consent form you are good to go. My only advice is to take time to consider this carefully.  All the best  Julia X
Posts.Title: New Diagnosis and I want a bilateral mastectomy

Posts.Content: Fantastic news.  Do hold that swimming thought until you see how you go over the next few weeks. I finished RT as you are describing but got very sore over the two weeks after finishing treatment. I think if I had swam during that time the chlorine would have been far too harsh. There is always a risk the skin may break too.  But you never know you could be ready to hit the water next week.   Julia xx ps we are never 'the same' after cancer but new. Don't be put off as it can be a good 'new'
Posts.Title: Finished Radiotherapy !

Posts.Content: Hello karen  its a scary time. Not only have you just had surgery but you have found out more about your BC and each stage/new thing learnt takes time to process. The nodes that were affected have been removed. The Cancer has been taken out of you. That's the crucial thing here. I had 11 nodes removed even though only one had been affected.  Waiting for scan results is torture, I won't lie, but they need to be done even if it's just to confirm its only the BC you need chemo and Rt for. After my diagnosis I had a CT, MRI, and bone scan as I was triple neg and lobular. All this sent me into a right spin and I started to shut down. I quickly realised I couldn't focus on treatment if I was so negative. Scans do Give peace of mind . Not everyone does get scanned on diagnosis. Try not to worry about what you don't yet know. It's hard I know but you need to recover from surgery. There will be many blows along the way but there will be peaks too. This is all still very new to you.  Friends can become detached as they don't know how to be.  They will need time just like you.  It's a long journey but it will be done. We are proof of that.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Removed lump and had axeually clearance on Friday

Posts.Content: Ouch Jojo4  We protect our children but we also don't realise how resilient children are and how they dislike being kept in the dark. He may respond best to you if you are honest. You can't avoid the conversation for ever. He will understand if you are honest and say you were getting information from the internet so you can be prepared.  My daughter was 9  years old when I told her and I thought carefully about what I would say Or more importantly what I wouldn't say. It was hard when I lost my hair but apart from that she kept me going throughout treatment.  J xx
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Hi Katee if you are saying the swelling has got worse recently I would get it checked out. Have you had RT since surgery as this can cause swelling too? There's always a possibility of Lymphoedema. With numerous possible causes, if you think it's getting worse not better you need to get a professional to take a look x
Posts.Title: Swollen arm/breast is it normal?

Posts.Content: As they all vary so much depending upon your own circumstances my advice is go to a price comparison site (money supermarket/go compare etc) and state you need to declare a medical condition. I've used CoverForYou before but there are loads out there.
Posts.Title: Travel insurance recommendations for Europe

Posts.Content: I live within 30 miles of three major hospitals and have always been given a choice of where I wanted to be treated.  Bath and Bristol hospitals are about 10 miles apart. I am sure if you can't make Bath and patient transport cannot be provided for you then you will get your choice of having everything in Bristol.  Good luck with it.
Posts.Title: Changing hospital appointment

Posts.Content: Hello ladies  chemotherapy can cause changes to the heart. After my first FEC I had immediate palpitations and they are still with me. I'm 13 months post chemo. I've had an ECG and heart tape monitor on for 24 hours and it was all 'normal' palpitations. Palpitations aren't always a danger.  Strangely enough I never have problems when I'm exercising hard. My heart rate is what is was in that respect. its worth a mention. They will follow up with a 24 hour tape if necessary.
Posts.Title: Letrozole and increased heart rate

Posts.Content: Hi Had enough   I don't think you can afford to not get this checked out now. When your doctor said it was normal what did he base this comment on. Were other tests/examinations done At that time? i had this on docetaxol and the reason for it was amaemia but that wasn't confirmed until I had blood tests.  Are you able to get medical attention now? Blood loss and breathing difficulties are reasons to go to A & E.  please let us know how you get on. love Julia xX
Posts.Title: Breathlessness

Posts.Content: Hello JJsailor  i think with fatigue after cancer treatment (not just chemo), anything goes. The Macmillan fact sheet on fatigue is really good at explaining. if you think your not long from recovering from a major op and being quite poorly, it all adds up. do you also know what state your periods are in? have you gone through the menopause? Lower levels of oestrogen in our bodies cause problems with bones and joints. do you take supplements like omega3? As you are sailing and no doubt active with this you may just find you need to adjust to take into account your not up to speed. Happy sailing. julia xx
Posts.Title: 1 yr post chemo is this normal?

Posts.Content: Hi Daisy  Firstly, sorry to hear about you mum. Your support will be meaning the world to her during this time.  I can tell you about my situation which is similar to your mums and you can compare to others. I've just finished 6 cycles of chemo. Chemo was my first treatment. I was scanned after chemo 2 and after chemo 6. Luckily the tumour has responded to chemo and done one! Phew.  I found that whilst having chemo you have lots of contact with your oncologist but I didn't meet with my breast consultant At all. I was lucky in that the consultant that did the ultrasound half way through chemo told me what she was seeing. That's obviously what your mum needs, information on the chemos progress as you go on.  now I've finished chemo I am now due back to see my breast consultant next week where we will talk sugery. At this stage they have indicated a lumpectomy.  i too had queries with with my lymph nodes. I asked my oncologist how do they know what lymph nodes have been effected by cancer cells if after chemo the cells are no longer there. He told me scar/tissue damage will indicate how many nodes were previously effected. As I am lead to believe, it's not until surgery that they will know about the damage to the lymph nodes and will take out what they need too.  Hone this helps and all the best julia x
Posts.Title: Ladies with lymph node positive result at initial diagnosis

Posts.Content: That is good news Pinksparkle. Not that I wish lymphoedema on anyone but its a better outcome than others. I was diagnosed with lymphoedema  5 months from surgery but didn't get antibiotics and cream. What I would say is that when you go back in two weeks ask that you are referred to a specialist clinic. Lymphoedema needs help in reducing the swelling and getting the lymph fluid draining away from the breast again. Lymphatic drainage massage is one good way and I found the thing that worked the best for me was kinesio taping. The cream may help the itchiness and soreness but ultimately may do nothing to reduce swelling. The feelings you are having concerning mistrusting the consultant are all normal and part of 'moving on'. Once you start trusting your body again you won't take every pain and symptom as a sign of a recurrence. It takes time but it will happen. I had 5 months of counseling to get me into a good headspace but it was worth it. I also found in hindsight worrying is exhausting so its so good not to be in that zone. It will get better. Trust me. Julia x
Posts.Title: Going crazy - inflammatory breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi strong96  its not unusual to learn more about your diagnosis in this fashion. It was the same for me. I had to wait quite awhile for my Her2 result. That's the reason why chemo is still a question mark for you at the moment. You can also get a score for progesterone too.  The size of the tumour is a rough size. If you have an MRI they are more reliable but not everyone will have an MRI.
Posts.Title: understanding letter received by GP

Posts.Content: Another birthday....... Definitely time to celebrate Sister Snail and JJ.  Love  Julia xx
Posts.Title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY !!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Pinksparkle  We can only try and help with suggestions but from past experience it's very difficult once you are in that mindset. You've looked on google and self diagnosed. You and I both know that is  not how BC is diagnosed. As you have a tendency towards anxiety try and avoid situations that make it worse.... Googling is one. Hide the computer Along with the eggs in the garden.  My mantra after I had my initial biopsy was that I wouldn't allow myself to worry unNecessarily. It was almost a defence mechanism. If I didn't think it, it wasn't going to happen. If after 5th you are told it's nothing sinister you will look back and think why did you get yourself into such a stew. You have been through enough already.  However, I say all this and know it's easier said than done.  I still get an itchy boob 14 months after surgery. If I scratch it for long periods I make it red and sore. My skin is very sensitive now especially after RT. It's probably just protesting about being itched. Are you using any different skin products?  You know your anxiety triggers better than any. For the time being stay away from the research.  sending hugs to you.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Going crazy - inflammatory breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Jen never ignore the advice given. It's given for a very good reason. the sickness and headache is all very normal as side effects but the temp drop isn't. You don't need our permission lovely. You will be talked through things on the phone it doesn't mean you automatically have to go into hospital. Have a bag packed incase though. hugs  Julia X
Posts.Title: Temperature range

Posts.Content: Another birthday....... Definitely time to celebrate Sister Snail and JJ.  Love  Julia xx
Posts.Title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY !!!!!

Posts.Content: It does annoy me when professionals think because you dont fit within the general risk age They can put up last on the list. For me young people should be seen quicker because quite often tumours are more developed when they are found. im keeping my fingers crossed for you xx
Posts.Title: Lump on Rib after Double Mastectomy

Posts.Content: Morning taylor0428  That's a hell of a lot to take in. No wonder you have questions. I really am sorry to read that this is the outcome. Cancer is a sneaky bugger. Scientists are still working on why it reappears in some cases and some not. It can never be guaranteed despite surgery that a cell hasn't sneaked off and lies dormant for it then to start overcoming your body again. Because of the area you are finding cells present it is likely its from the original diagnosis. What the scans will confirm is that it hasn't reached other parts of your body. Then you can get the best treatment plan set up and most suitable chemotherapy drug. I can understand your need to know what is what. When I was first diagnosed as I had a particular nasty type of BC and it was already in my lymph nodes I had three other full body scans. That was the hardest time and I dipped very low. However, you will find the strength to fight this again with your husband and family around you and us supporting virtually. Hugs back at you. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Lump on Rib after Double Mastectomy

Posts.Content: Morning Jen  its always advisable to phone the emergency number when your temp goes above or below critical points. temperature is a big indicator of our bodies being in trouble. As this is your first chemo session, its wise not to take chances.  Sepsis risk is between day 5 post chemo and 15 But again as this was your first session it was wise to keep an eye out on how your body was reacting.  You will probably feel rubbish for a 2/3 more days then start to pick up but remember that's when you are in the sepsis risk range so monitor temperature and act on anything above or below critical points.  next time round it will be less scary as you'll have an idea of what to expect. take it very very easy over the next few days. julia X
Posts.Title: Temperature range

Posts.Content: A lovely encouraging first of December chemo post JMC04.  To all of you ladies embarking on or still having chemo, there will be bad days but please remember there are so many of us here that have walked that path and can give help advice and support.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly  You can make the decision to stop chemo now but I'm guessing it would be against the advice of your oncologist. All the chemo therapies you are having do different things.  As JJ has said, if you are waiting for SE then see what FEC brings as that made me very sick however that may be a reason to avoid it!  You say your tumour has shrunk quite a bit. I had neo adjuvant chemo and had a pathological complete response by the end of 6 sessions (FEC t). Imagine what your response could be like after 3 FEC, you could have no tumour or any cancer cells left.  It's a conversation you need to have with your oncologist and a decision you can live with.
Posts.Title: Can I speed up treatment

Posts.Content: Hi taylor0428  Understdably you are anxious and are looking for any reason why it isn't cancer. There are many reasons why it won't be cancer but your mind is drawing to one conclusion. Every day is precious, you'll appreciate that. I waited for many many test results to see if my BC was metastic before treatment began and my mantra was to not ruin days/weeks of worrying over something that Id made up in my head. until you know for sure you may find you've been stressing for no reason and that's days/weeks you don't get back.  We can't speculate about what is going on only a serious of tests will get to the bottom of this. In the meantime do try and life a life that's precious. Distractions are always good and even positive thinking. i hope the Macmillan helpline helped too. love julia x
Posts.Title: Lump on Rib after Double Mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Scotland That's good news on the healing front.  When you say normal chemo do you mean Fec-t? I think Herceptin is mostly given after chemo and over a period of time as injections but it can also be given at the same time so do check.  I had a Picc line so dont know what it would have been like without it. For me it was well worth it. Bit uncomfortable going in but not painful. Takes around 24 hours to get use to it. Bear in mind it needs flushing and the dressing changed every week. Some chemo units say go in for that others can arrange home visits.  Be guided by your oncologist. My chemo unit didn't give me an option, it was picc or nothing.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Having chemo and herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi taylor0428  Gosh what am age to lose your Mum. Im very sorry to read that. i can appreciate how much of a worry this is for you. Im not sure how helpful information will be at this stage. it could be the original bc thats come back in the rib cage. Did the GP also check your collar bone and neck for swollen lymph nodes? It could equally be nothing cancer related at all.  You are obviously very much on the ball keeping an eye on your body and hopefully that clinic appointment will come soon. Early detection is key.  Meanwhile i know your nerves will be wracking.  Did the Gp offer any other explanation that you can keep in mind? let us know when that appointment comes in and we can continue to support.  Sending hugs  Julia x
Posts.Title: Lump on Rib after Double Mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Sophie A warm welcome to the forum. We have all been through what you are going though so we understand the feelings you are having. In hindsight I would have taken some pain releif such as paracetomol before having my PICC inserted. Its not painful as such just uncomfy. Do remember to breath deep breaths when its going in or you will end up light headed like me. When Im stressed I seem to hold my breath. Not condusive to pain control. The line takes a couple of days to get use to. The chemo nurse may suggest a warm compress should it get sore. Mine behaved lovely so didnt give any problems. I cut up old coloured/patterend tights and used then as covers. The MRI is more detailed so will hopefully confirm what is going on with your liver. I would imagine the results will need to be back before you start chemo but it may not happen like that. I was warned that CT scans can pick up areas on organs that could have been there for a long time it doesnt mean that they are cancer. If the suspicious areas are found to be secondary breast cancer (cells which have originated in the breast but have moved to the liver and started forming) it is as you have been told, incurable. That means that they cant remove it completely but they can stop and slow the growth of the cancer using specific types of drugs and chemotherapy. It will depend upon what receptor status your breast cancer has been defined as. (Oestrogen, progesterone, HER2). There is a secondary breast cancer forum which I know has active ladies on. I hope the MRI happens soon and its just the primary breast cancer that needs dealing with. All the very best.
Posts.Title: Possible secondary breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Cath When you say results are you meaning, whether clear margins have been achieved? As cancer cells were found in the nodes I am assuming you are heading into chemo soon anyway? I guess the path lab have taken longer than expected or is the delay with your MDT? It might help you to find out where the delay is.I had clear margins so I didn't have further surgery but I am sure the extra 7 days of waiting for results won't have any detrimental affect. I know you are eager to get on with things but the majority of operations achieve clear margins so the reality is that your plan wont change. Its just playing on your anxiety. As soon as you get the results, the length of time you have waited disappears from your mind completely and you move into the next treatment. All the best for the 18th. Julia x
Posts.Title: Waiting for results a nightmare

Posts.Content: I found that really helpful George thank you. I like too know how things work and this gives a good picture to Tilly.
Posts.Title: Can I speed up treatment

Posts.Content: Maybe make an official complaint via PALS and request the missing letter.  If you are serious about taking this forward and you have legal advice with home and contents insurance then give them a buzz. Its a hard case to argue because you need to prove that it being undiagnosed for sometime has had a detrimental affect on treatment.  xx
Posts.Title: Copy of notes

Posts.Content: I can understand why you have these thoughts. That's a sizeable tumour to be slow growing in 18 months . Not a grade 3? The mammogram pre 18 months really might not have picked it up but proving it did will be hard. On the basis it took five mammo to be seen inducates it was a tricky one for something so big.  Guilt comes with the package unfortunately. I had it too. My tumour was detected by me when it was big enough to be felt. I was nowhere near screening age. It was 25mm and felt huge to me.  Did you ever feel the tumour?  moving on support is just as important as the treatment itself. You may find if you do get help  you can explore your feelings of guilt. Those feelings won't help you move on. You can take control of your health now but eating well and getting lots of exercise and being vigilant about ailments that linger. It all takes time though. i had 5 months of counselling so I know it's not an easy thing to fix xx
Posts.Title: Copy of notes

Posts.Content: Hi Ange  Good on you for getting involved in the trial. It's very important we do get involved Where we can. I entered a RT trial.  As a younger women diagnosed well before screening age I wonder if things will ever change regarding earlier screening. I doubt it as they will argue our breasts are harder to screen and we are in the minority age bracket for getting BC. We know however the younger you get it the more advanced it is on diagnosis.   The NHS in my opinion dropped a massive clanger last year when they sent out footnotes with mammogram appointments saying there was a risk that early detection could lead to over treatment. Big big mistake. I know lots of ladies that I've had to beg to go to to that screening as they considered the over treatment risk to much.  FB is a good way to get your message across but then you would have to look at your security settings to be able to reach as many folk as you can. A blog on this community is another idea Or just blog in general. I follow Kris Hallenga who founded Coppafeel after she was diagnosed at 23years with metastic BC. She is now 30 years old. I watched her documentary years ago before I was diagnosed and was drawn to her. She won a woman of the year award. julia X
Posts.Title: How to make others aware

Posts.Content: Yes yes yes. I am loving all this positivity. WORRIED2016 i am delighted at your results and reading your post I would say you have got it girl. Make EVERY day count. We know how shite life can be... that makes us appreciate how bloody good it can be doesn't it. loving all this talk of running. I hold you in high esteem. As a half girl myself I've never quite got my head around a full marathon. I'll never give my running up it's my saviour. If anyone is in south Devon I'm always happy to have a running partner. I'm starting of 2017 with a 10k race on the first Sunday. I run because it makes me feel alive.  We worry and we worry. Which can never change the outcome. I look back on my treatment phase and think what a waste. I worried a lot.  someone mentioned Baileys too yum yum : )  Partial to Ameretto myself but would never say no to Baileys. i feel immensely proud of you ladies right now.  love Julia x
Posts.Title: Two thanks and a Wish...

Posts.Content: Hi LittleWren  I can understand why you might be feeling all over the place. What I've learnt is that consultants  always err on the side of caution. On diagnosis I was told I had a 3cm tumour that actually went down to 2.5cm When I had an MRI. (More precise than mammo) The problem being it's difficult to be 100% accurate Even on scans.  It is weird that your oncologist moved you off of EC after only one dose. Was he going by how he thought the tumour felt with examination? They normally only make decisions like that after scans to back up what they might/might not be feeling.  Just because it feels big to you doesn't mean it has got bigger. To be honest chemo affected both my breasts and all my body so nothing felt normal to me. Some days it felt small, others big and it was very sore. Touching it regularly also doesn't help. Come the end of chemo however I had no cancer left. Chemo had done its job to the max.  Go with what the scanographer is telling you. She's the one reading the screen.  Speak to the oncologist and say what you have been told after the scan And ask why you weren't given the opportunity to carry on with EC.  julia X
Posts.Title: Relieved but confused

Posts.Content: In my experience Londonfornow, no. I go for waxing regularly but never touch my affected side. I do however shave with a normal razor but I react less to that than waxing. I have been made to bleed through waxing and get very sore so I won't take the risk. I'm sure there will be people out there that will do it for you but I wouldn't personally take the risk. Julia X
Posts.Title: Underarm Waxing

Posts.Content: I don't think so Ali. I just got confused reading the above too.  I had a grade 2 yet chemo first on the basis a Successful WLE could be done. The smaller the tumour size, the better the Breast will look after the WLE.
Posts.Title: puzzled! !!

Posts.Content: Hi Elaine  If anything the 'botanical' aspect of these may be questioned. Many will say to avoid soya but there is no firm evidence to support this. Most of the ingredients mirror that of a multi vitamin. As you will do on Tuesday though , check it out. Be prepared for them to say no but do ask why they say no if that's the answer.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Menopause Support vitamins (boots own)

Posts.Content: Hi mamasatch  I feel for you especially as you can't share this with your family And hubby is away.  im like Chloecat in that I refuse to worry until I'm told results. I've wasted so much time worrying and hated that time. We know worry can't change what's coming our way. with a previous cancer diagnosus however we will also live on a knives edge.  You could ask the scanographers explicit questions like do they think it looks like a cancer DX but if you are like me I was to scared. Again I wanted to wait until the results were given formally. You could speak to your BC unit and get the results of the ultrasound before waiting for the CT scan. That's not an unreasonable request. sending hugs  love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Ultrasound. ...it might be back !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Janey Welcome to the site and congratulations for getting through chemo without us :) That's a major positive in itself. We have all been there. Its like our minds develop a persona of their own. Its like the devil sitting on our shoulders bellowing in our ears that we are going to be one of the unlucky ones and we cant reason with that devil. We always default to the worst case scenario. Our minds run away with us. The trick is reining it back in again and that takes time and a lot of practice. Think of a balance of scales. In one hand list all the positives : Chemo will have done its job, surgery will remove all of what is left, you are having reconstruction so will have a breast shape, you get to take hormonal therapies to help prevent recurrence?? and you haven't been told its incurable (a major positive). The opposite side of the scale is your mums diagnosis but is there any connection between your mums cancer and yours? You have to always find more positives than negatives and at this stage you can do that. I only stopped fretting a good six months after treatment ended which would have been 18 months post diagnosis. BUT it does fade with time. Your life is on hold at the moment but the good news is that a new life happens and as you get stuck into that new life the old life does become a thing of the past. You may feel after all your treatment has ended you need help 'moving on' and that support is out there if you ask your BC unit. Mindfulness is a great place to be in and I highly recommend it. Stress and worry wont help you in staying fit and healthy so you may need to learn new techniques. This is such a common issue - you aren't alone in your thinking. Julia x
Posts.Title: Worried!

Posts.Content: Hello strong96  Sorry to read your are having problems with this. I had critical illness and it paid out within 6 weeks but I went straight into invasive. Im guessing the terms and conditions will confirm what should have been disclosed. How the leg swelling is relevant I don't know! I have heard that BC is going to be down graded on critical illness cover as it's no longer considered 'critical'. More like the insurance companies aren't making enough money!  Insurance companies are buggers. I would have a look at the small print just to be sure x
Posts.Title: critical illness insurance

Posts.Content: Hi Von What has caused you to be a bit wary? There is evidence that it may interfer with a chemo given for myeloma. I drank green tea, pre, during and post BC. I learnt the hard way tthrough chemo.......... I stopped drinking enough fluid and ended up in hospital. My advice (and that given by the chemo ward) drink fluid in whatever form (obviously not alcohol for at least 3 days post chemo lol) There are many benefits to consuming green tea. Obviously if you havent been used to it then it would be hard to 'aquire' the taste now especially as your taste buds will be all over the place. I would give it a try however.  I found sucking on ice lollies helped but aim for at LEAST 2 litres of liquid per day.
Posts.Title: Green tea and antioxidants help please

Posts.Content: You are very welcome. All part of the service. xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah I would take that as good news. I was just about to say about our MDT meetings but Carolyn already beat me too it. So I don't think that's a 'France' thing. Not sure what you mean about the ganglion thing. Does it mean lymph node? That may change your stage but you may not have been given that to start with? I had one effected node. Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Me too.  The days getting better and better. Xx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Hi carol PICCS are definitely to make your life easier, not theirs. I had one and it was a godsend. They are slightly uncomfortable going in (take pain relief before it happens) and then you will have an x-ray to make sure its on the correct place. You also need to consider that it needs a weekly clean/flush. You may get the choice of a home visit or visiting the chemo unit weekly. I choose the chemo unit which in hindsight was good as it meant on the 5 day after every chemo session I was forced to get out and about, for which I also felt better for after. The risks if you don't have a PICC are that the chemo damages/destroys your veins which is very painful and very problematic for future sessions and time consuming. Some ladies are allergic to the dressings they use and some have had infections in their lines but on the whole I think there are mainly positives to getting a line. All the best. Julia x
Posts.Title: JANUARY CHEMO CLUB

Posts.Content: I love your attitude towards RT Carolyn. That's exactly how I viewed it. x

I found those letters very informative.  This link should help .... http://www.nhs.uk/chq/pages/1309.aspx?categoryid=68 With regard to digital images I don't know how feasible this is. They are probably wary about the reasons you ask. they do have a duty to share certain info with you should you want it but it's a long winded process. Good luck with it love Julia x
Posts.Title: Copy of notes

Posts.Content: Hi Soups Please don't be stressing over this now, it really is the last thing you need. The oncologist has just put a ball point figure on when he will assess you again.  This really shouldn't be an indicator that you can return to work. Its jumping the gun. The oncologists assessment wont take into consideration your mental well being all it is will be a look at your breast. To be honest I would have approached your GP and discussed the back to work plans with him/her but not until RADS finish. You should be covered by a sick note now anyway?  GP's can tailor a fit note to your needs. I didn't even consider going back to work until after I had finished RADS. In the end I went back 6 weeks after under the fit note my GP gave.

Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Hello Ladies French - As already said the negative HER result and low  Ki67 % is very encouraging. Ki 67 is  a marker than can indicate prognosis and a low score is better than a high score. This all links back to you being diagnosed at Grade 1. I am use to seeing the ER and PR scores out of 8. I'm not sure what 'marking 2' means ( I think its to do with tumor markers)  but 90% of cells with ER indicates it likes ER very much and again the PR score is high. This is good indicating that hormonal therapies will be very good for you. I expect the predict tool will support that statement. Sounds like it does if you are up in the 90's without chemo. Please bear in mind though I am not medical trained. Julia x
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: All the best.  Do let us know how you get on xx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

It may be that they just go with RT to your axilla area as well as the breast. RT really is ok just uncomfortable and a pain going daily for weeks, xx

Posts.Content: Say hello to April  ... the month of Chocolate Easter Eggs and Chocolate and More chocolate Four months into the 2017 already. Anyone starting chemo this month, we wish you all the best. If you are having or about to embark on chemotherapy as treatment for breast cancer please feel free to use and abuse this club to share your experiences, ask questions, support others or just get it off your chest (no pun intended!!) Carolyn28 and Crystaljuju are two community champs who have previously had chemo and who can answer questions as well as Mistymoley and Dreamthief.
