Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: I'm definitely with you girls........... don't deny that treat as it wont help that psychological state. Also, don't be in any rush to lose the chemo pounds. It took me a good 6 months post treatment to shift my stone. Its incredibly frustrating but it takes time. As has been said before, any weight that has been put on can come of just as it went on. I'm so glad you find the site amazing Wendy. Its been part of my life for 18 months or so and it feels very comfortable here. Have a good day xxx
Posts.Title: MacDonalds milkshake?

Posts.Content: Hi SpicedTea  We all have different tolerance levels so I can't say if you are being overly sensitive. It's obviously made you uncomfortable so that's enough in itself. Before you do broach the subject with your friend ( who actually sounds a very decent friend) ask why she told this guy. It may have been the guy asked outright what surgery/treatment you had. She probably felt obliged to say. No one would have known he would express such an opinion on it all however after being told the facts! If he had kept quiet no doubt you'd be none the wiser. Your friend is giving you a heads up with this guys opinion so you aren't caught in the headlights should he mention it face to face.  im the only woman in my office and the guys  knew I had breast surgery. Like most guys they were/are curious to know if I still have my own boobs. It's a man thing! when they have asked I've been candid in my reply And it's left at that.  For me, it's  something that happened. I'm not uncomfortable talking about it and I'm still happy with my body.   We are all different though. Your friend will no doubt feel mortified if you get heavy with her for telling the guy. im sure she didn't feel the information was confidential and I'm sure she never meant to cause you hurt. If it's one guy then it's not an indication she's blabbed to every man and his dog.  love and hugs Julia xx
Posts.Title: Am I being Oversensitive?

Posts.Content: Just popped by to Say hello French. What a whirlwind for you. If France always deals with diagnosis's that speedily then you are in the right place. You are right, and its good you have realized  that this is more tricky than you first realized. It doesn't help when celebs document how easy surgery for BC is etc because you get the impression it can be done without any fall out. Your BC sounds very early stage which is a very big positive but its still cancer and as already said so well, the psychological affects of a diagnosis can be far reaching long after the conventional treatment stops. Don't write the holiday off yet as you have every chance of being well recovered from the WLE then.  You haven't said if you need radio therapy though? that will need to be considered if you do. Try not to overload your mind with the future at the moment. Take it literally one day at a time and be comfortable doing that. These things have a horrible way of biting you on the behind when you least expect it. Consider it a temporary set back. My BC journey lasted 11 months and it took me a long while to get back into life. Julia x
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: ha, no worries. I answer to both.  There is a slight risk that your diagnosis can change after surgery but it's not common. Everything about your diagnosis suggests early stage so I wouldn't expect it to go from that to grade 3 or stage 2. The tumour size suggests it hasn't reached anywhere near the lymph nOdes. However I do remember how anxious I was until I hasten to add I was told it was still grade 2 stage 2 and nothing had changed. My tumour was actually smaller than first predicted.  Go onto Pinterest on your phone and have a browse. Theses always something interesting to look at and it keeps you distracted. Maybe find a book that you've always wanted to read but never got round to it. one sure thing is that daylight always follows a night and therefore that will lift you out of the worrying time xx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Loving all this running chat.  Never ever underestimate what you are achieving. Some have never run 3 miles let alone run it in 36 minutes. As they say, you are over taking those sat on the sofa.  it's proven that excercising  reduces the risk of recurrence.  Slowly slowly does it to reduce the risk of injury.  Im running a half marathon in 4 weks. My first since being diagnosed nearly two years ago. I'm not expecting a PB but I'm so happy I am back to running 13 miles! Would never have thought it.  happy running ladies  xx
Posts.Title: Anyone enjoy running post mastectomy?!

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy  i don't think there's any ingredients in either of these products that you should be avoiding? in your blue book given by the chemo nurses it will say what to avoid but I think you are safe with these.  Julia
Posts.Title: MacDonalds milkshake?

Posts.Content: CARDBOND I see alot of people say their lump felt pea size. I'm wondering if anyone felt a larger lump. And am curious to know how big their lump actually was in reality..... In comparison to pea size, mine felt like pebble size!! I stumbled  across it. In hindsight I was bad at checking my breasts or rather I wasn't thorough enough.  On diagnosis it was sized at 35mm but was actually 25mm. Id never had a mammogram before diagnosis as hadn't reached that age. However.... after chemo there was nothing left :)  Julia x
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Hello G and J What a fab eye catching way to get your attention. A clever marketing campaign.  Ive done the self assessment sheet (forgetting for a moment that I had Breast cancer!) and apparently I am at average risk. Maybe it is more 'bad luck' than we are lead to believe, especially with non-hormonal breast cancers.  Have a good day everyone.I'm down in Devon and it's not looking like the English Riviera today
Posts.Title: Know Your Lemons

Posts.Content: I'm still seen every three months by oncologist and surgeon alternatively up until recently. I'm now two years post chemo/surgery. Oncology wanted to leave me for 12 months but as I went on the Import High trial for RT I am still seen every 6 month now. Julia x
Posts.Title: Whats the normal follow up after treatment finishes.

Posts.Content: I so totally agree Pinkus88 and I think your approach is very sensible. Your comment about romping in the hay makes me smile. Sexuality post cancer is massively important. I'm over two years post diagnosis and would say it gets more important as time goes on. I still like my body and I'm not afraid to share it (with the right people of course!!)  and a healthy sex life is worth its weight in gold so you must do all you can to keep it so. Being able to have uncomplacated and fun sex is a big part of moving on.  Let me know how you get on with your oncologist on Monday.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Sterilisation to save reoccurance

Posts.Content: The F is fluorouracil or 5FU. It can affect the way the heart works. I had FEC (3 years ago now) and I've had palpitations since although they are not suspicious ones, apparently. Take it as a good thing you get the taxol every weeks and not every three weeks. I think the side effects are more manageable. It has been proven in studies that the frequency in which you have the drug doesn't affect its effectiveness. Loads to learn huh and not necessarily what you want to learn about :( Hang on in there. It does become clearer. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: It's a bit like the national retirement age..... keeps getting higher.  i swear it will be post 70 years by the time I get near :(
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Hi Pinkus88  I do get where you are coming from except I was triple negative but still advised not to take any forms of birth control Involving hormones. going back to condoms is hideous.  I was 41 during chemo and I'm back to a normal menstrual cycle and no proper method of birth control. I'm also not in a proper relationship so it makes things even more complicated. I would have a serious chat with your oncologist (you still see him?). Mine is very good with these issues. I think there is a good case for sterilisation. It's definately worth exploring. I would but just can't face another op just yet but then I think it's quite a uncomplicated procedure?  Hugs  Julia X
Posts.Title: Sterilisation to save reoccurance

Posts.Content: It's a bit like the national retirement age..... keeps getting higher.  i swear it will be post 70 years by the time I get near :(
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Definitely a myth Maggs, do not fear.    My hair started re growing after my second cycle of docetaxel. The difference being your mum has started chemo with docetaxel first. Not to panic you but wait until she has FEC, the epirubicin (E) causes hair loss so you may find all body hair is lost again. Such a shame when you are starting to see some lovely sprouting. Hope your mum is doing ok and you are ok too xx
Posts.Title: Hair regrowth during chemo!?!

Posts.Content: Hellooo  i definately compute! Good on you for getting back out there. I ran pre during and post cancer. I hope you are finding the mental health benefits too.  I had a WLE but still get uncomfortable 14 months on To be honest though I always did suffer from soreness due to the mileage I do. The zip up sports bras (m and s) are suppose to be the best. I need a crossback wired sports bra at 34dd . I also find Royce bras very good as they give support higher up than just the cup. To be honest no bra will stop you from moving completely but too be honest the benefits of exercise outweigh the soreness. You may find in time it does settle.  Lovely post!  Julia
Posts.Title: Anyone enjoy running post mastectomy?!

Posts.Content: Time to move over to MAY ladies MAY chemo club
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: The blue book is a patient held record book. I guess not all trusts give them out but I'd like to think they are giving this info out in your pre chemo assessment.  The foods to avoid are  un-pasteurised milk/milk products soft mould ripen cheese pate and fish paste raw or undercooked meat and shellfish  unwashed fruit and veg live/bio yoghurt  raw or uncooked eggs  eg mayonnaise (homemade) so imagine foods that you were too avoid if/ when pregnant.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: MacDonalds milkshake?

Posts.Content: Hi Smoothie Hold out until the appointment with the oncologist. I say that as I have found and still find anything non surgery related , that the BC team are useless. My oncologist is my hero and one of very few that makes sense. Sounds like you need much more evidence about why you are needing chemo. The oncotype DX test would be great here. As others have said you dont want belt and braces - chemo is too harsh for that. You only need to take it if there is a clear cut benefit. I cant believe they said to you because you are young you can withstand more treatment. What rubbish. Probably one of the worse things I have heard!  You should be offered chemo purely if there is a benefit that it will prevent reoccurence or secondary. You have had a very bad experience with this Junior doctor ( i am angry just reading the post). I only hope your oncologist is the complete opposite. Julia x
Posts.Title: Post op appointment yesterday

Posts.Content: Hello Powderpuff (the name made me smile) You are feeling like we have all felt and continue to feel sometimes. Survival will kick in, trust me. Everything is still unkown and new for you you. Its a steep learning curve, ontop of everyhting else. I am 12 months post diagnosis and treatment went very well for me. I had one node involvevment but 11 removed when I had a wide local excision. I knew from the original biopsie that nodes were affected. I also had lobular invasive cancer which was triple negative. A terrifiying combo! Iso I did have a CT, MRI and bone scan before treatment started. Luckjily I was only being treated for the tumour in one breast. I had neo adjuvant chemo (chemo before surgery). As Della has said, shuting the family out may end up biting you on the bottom. I like you, did that initially but then quickly found without them I could not have survived. They became my strength and courage.The support I have received from friends and family have caccooned me and gave me strength to go through treatment. Its true what they say............... You never know how strong you can be until you have no choice. You will surprise yourself. Al the best xx
Posts.Title: Feeling Lost

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass  I am sorry that the tears are still here, overshadowing the outcome of yesterday. Whilst the comments of your BCN might seem harsh today, on the basis she doesn't seem to be able to provide you with enough support I'm wondering if you can get the support you need from her signposting you on. It really is worth considering if at not least to give it a shot. In my experience most 'clinical' staff don't have the time for the touchy feely stuff even though I know most would like to. You do deserve to get FULL emotional support but that may not be from clinical staff. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: More unnecessary tears...

Posts.Content: Hi Ali It may seem that they are in denial but it can be a whole host of other reasons why they appear dismissive. Close family may be struggling to cope with what is going on and dont want to show their fear for fear of making you feel worse. To hear you talk about the SE of chemo can be shocking especially if they have no expereince of chemotherapy. Lets face it the biggest risk of chemo is sepsis and I signed to say that I knew it was a risk that could kill me. Your family may also feel by allowing you to go into the doom and gloom of chemo that they are accepting of it and actually they may not wnat to accept that there is a risk. They will also be worried and dare I say it even feel sorry for you having to lose hair etc. You do need one or two people whether its family or a friend who you can turn to and who will allow you to say and do whatever helps you get through treatment. Not everybody needs to know everything. Only my partner and a close friend really knew what was what, warts and all! My Mum didnt see me at all through chemo through her choice. I would never hold this against her as my dad had just died and she just couldnt cope with any more. Nearly all of us on here have shared your worry over hair. It was the first hing I thought of when I was told I had BC. Shit what about my hair. I am 11 months post chemo and Ive coped. We all cope. The only guarrenteed way not too lose hair is by not having chemo and that's not an option for all of us. Please remember hair loss is temporary. Ok, it may take years to grow back if you have hair as long as mine was but I only wore wigs for 5 months. My short hair is so worth me being successfully treated for BC. I have a good prognosis and thats what matters. All the best with chemo - join the Chemo club to talk with other ladies going through it. Julia x
Posts.Title: Family in denial

Posts.Content: Hi Iona my daughter was 9 years when I told her. It was around 2 weeks after I was diagnosed.  I managed to get hold of a super book from one of the breast cancer charities with super heroes in it (I'll let u know more later as I will dig it out and tell you more) . It was the only book I thought age appropriate. The others I thought were cringeworthy.  My daughty Daisy knew I had had something done to my boob (the biopsie) as I was in bed with the pain after it so I followed it on from there. I explained the biopsie was to test a lump I had found. I told her it was BC and I needed to have chemo which would make me look different and make be poorly. I also explained about surgery. She then had the book to read through in her Own time. She asked lots of questions which I always answered. She initially worried she would get BC too.  I never said to her that cancer was life threatening which in hindsight I could have done. A few weeks into treatment Daisy came home from school saying a friend had told her you die from cancer which upset her so I had a conversation with her about how well mums treatment had gone etc and I would recover.  I did tell the school I had BC and Daisy received a lot of emotional support  through thrive.  Daisy never ceased to amaze me at how well she coped. She inspired me. Kids are very in the moment so whatever you tell them one day they will have moved on by the next.  Julia
Posts.Title: advice on telling my children

Posts.Content: Hello Purplejan  I was all for a bilateral MX but was persuaded kicking and screaming a wle was enough. I had ILC but dont give it a second thought as my main concern was being triple negative. As Carolyn says, you need to find a surgeon that will remove it first. Being a grade 2 with no node involvememt and low oncotype score doesnt put you at high risk of recurrence. Recurrence in the breast isnt the biggest problem for us its metastic breast cancer. My surgeon was very blunt with me and said removing your breasts would not mean i didnt die from bc. From then i decided to keep my breasts and deal with recurrence in the breast but to do my upmost to stear clear of secondarys. Your family have a point. Major surgery for how much benefit? I thought removing my breasts would stop my anxiety. Now i know it wouldnt have. Fear of recurrence is a seperate issue to whether you have or don't have your own breasts. An issue that should be dealt with via psychological help not a surgeons knife. As i understood with ILC the risk is at first diagnosis when you are more than likely to see it in both breasts at the same time. ILc's prognosis is actually slighlty better than Idc and is inown to be the 'lazier' of the two. Yes detection is harder but you will have robust aftercare. My ilc did present as a lump. Its not always a hardening only.  Im nearly two years post surgery and very happy i still have my own breasts. The best i can hope for is for this to remain the case. Do have a word with your surgeon as he will be the voice to listen to also. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Removing a healthy breast vs the risk of recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi Rosalyn  That all sounds rough. You would definitely have hoped this was all behind you now chemo has finished.  I haven't any experience of tamoxifen but I hadn't realised or know if it does cause neutrophenic sepsis. Thats implying it is affecting your white cell count. Have you looked on the patient info leaflet to see if it's a documented side effect? Your oncologist will ultimately advise you. Did the hospital give any indication why your white cell count could be low or did the blood tests reveal and type of infection? I'm guessing you have been taking tamoxifen awhile so it's not a reaction to it. Worth seeing your oncologist I would say. Julia xx
Posts.Title: tamoxifen and neutropenic sepsis

Posts.Content: Mummy's lump is the booklet that made me cringe. There is a picture of a woman staring into a mirror without hair and for me just not right. It's very old fashioned but agree more suitable for younger children.
Posts.Title: advice on telling my children

Posts.Content: This is the book. Its by Roche and endorsed by Breast Cancer care. We no longer need it so if you would find it useful I would be more than happy to post it to you. Private message me contact details if you would like it. Julia
Posts.Title: advice on telling my children

Posts.Content: Very true Zanib but also believe and take comfort in this being temporary. There is life after Breast cancer and I have found it a much more rewarding one.  Keep your faith and remember this will pass and you will smile again. You have to go through the rough (and it will be rough at times) to get to the smooth.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Nasty disease

Posts.Content: Brilliant  news that clear margins were achieved. Bad news however if the chemo mallet has just been mentioned. I am wondering why if you had clear nodes and you are ER+ the oncotype test is being done. It may be routine for your hospital to oncotype test all tumours removed? It may also be because you had vascular invasion? Was your tumour particularly large?  It's really worth checking it out with your oncologist especially as you say it hasn't been mentioned until now. Check it out to put your mind at ease. julia X
Posts.Title: Possible chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I had surgery in January and was advised to wear the stockings for 2 weeks. Cant say I felt very sexy during that time!!! A man hoovering is worth its weight in gold let alone in surgical stockings :)
Posts.Title: Quadrantectomy plus LD Flap

Posts.Content: I had an appointment a few weeks ago and didn't end up seeing my normal consultant and it really threw me. We get use to the security of the same consultant. Having had lymphoedema  I know it can cause symptoms similar to recurrence symptoms. Do get the scan done though Ali and make sure you get a referral to manage the lymphedema because it can get worse if left. xxx
Posts.Title: bloody insensitive doctors !!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Mira The advice I would give is stick with it.(haha... can you see the joke there!!!) I had oedema in my affected breast and the only thing that worked for me was the kinesio taping. I actually preferred the tape to compression bras which made me feel so bloody frumpy. I saw results after 6 weeks but after 3 months I stopped using it as the oedema went. That was two years ago and I’ve not had it come back. If you learn how the tape goes on yourself you can change it with help every three days or so. Give your skin a breather in between as you can develop a rash from the tape. Rock tape worked best for me. Cheaper tapes aggregated me. You can get some funky patterned tapes or nude so the choice is yours I can’t recommend the tape enough . Good luck with it Love Julia
Posts.Title: Kinesio Taping - request for information

Posts.Content: Hi JJ I was TN too but had only a WLE. I knew from early on in my diagnosis I was TN so knew I had to have chemo and RT. I must be hard to preocess all this info all at once. I was adamant I wanted a MX and my sugeon said I didnt need it. I fought against his advice for two months before finally opting for a WLE. If I had been told after surgery that clear margins weren't achieved I would have definitely said the next op would have been a MX. Its a tough decision but with TN and the results you have had after the lumpectomy it may be pointing that way to you. I had CT/Bone scan and MRI before chemo - they told me it was normal with TN and invasive lobular. Its a blow to be told now you will  head into chemo. Its tough but the support on here is great. You will find strength and courage you never knew you were capable of. All the best  and hope the chest infection clears soon x
Posts.Title: Gutted bad news

Posts.Content: Hi Puzzle  I was diagnosed with lymphoedema in the breast 6 months after surgery. Surgeons normally like to give it at least 6 months post surgery to see if it is something you need to go to an odema clinic for. I was referred to a clinic locally and to be honest they were a waste of time. I was told to wear a compression bra (which I wear daily for running anyway) and they gave me a bit of bobbly material to wear inside my bra which did nothing but irritate me. In the end I found a lady who does kinesio taping and I had this done. Within 3 months the odema had gone.  I massage my breast with moisturiser (ok I know this sounds kinky!!) every night and you massage away from the Axilla site, so towards the good side.  Your lymphatic system takes time to learn to function without those nodes that have been removed. Don't give up hope as it's still very very early days for you.  To be honest I was glad it wasn't my arm as with breast odema you can hide but I'm so pleased mine was treated successfully.  Breast odema is becoming more common due to the different techniques used in surgery.  All the best with it. Julia xx  PS Compression sleeves for the arm aren't recommended 'just in case'. Just because you have odema In the breast doesn't mean you will get it on the arm.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Lymphoedema in breast - need advice

Posts.Content: Fantastic outcome Caroline. I am glad you can consider more surgery after the WLE. I was told if I wasn't happy with the ways things shaped up then I could consider it to. Its nice to know that they will spent more time with you to get the results you are happy with. I had my first mammo in January. Know how you feel. It will be good to get it out of the way. It also brings back some weird feelings but nothing beats getting that letter saying no worrying signs. Julia x
Posts.Title: Guilty meltdown.

Posts.Content: Hi Scotland If it's going to happen to you, it's 4/5 months away. Ask your chemo nurses what they suggest when you get to docetaxel. Take one step at a time. To be honest by the time you get to the end of chemo you will take on anything because of what you have been through. I was without fingernails for a shorter period of time than being without hair. All the best for Tuesday. Julia X
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy on Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi Scotland If it's going to happen to you, it's 4/5 months away. Ask your chemo nurses what they suggest when you get to docetaxel. Take one step at a time. To be honest by the time you get to the end of chemo you will take on anything because of what you have been through. I was without fingernails for a shorter period of time than being without hair. Posts.Title: Chemotherapy on Tuesday

Posts.Content: FEC will more than likely make you feel sick. Put the nail hardener on the back burner until docetaxol.  things you might need: A thermometer to take your temp Bottled water if you don't do tap. Aim for over 2 litres per day ice lollies helps with nausea  crackers/ginger biscuits for nausea Take the anti sickness regularly don't wait until you feel sick. Eat little and often. I was in bed for three days after each Fec but then recovered. Sleeping it off is the best way if you can.  Your chemo unit should be helpful too so don't hold back with the questions.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy on Tuesday

Posts.Content: One of the best lip balms out there is Carmex. it really works wonders as has petroluem and camphor in it. julia x
Posts.Title: Preparing for chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Annie H  At the moment the only test that's available to check if you have a gene mutation which is proven to cause BC is the BRCA 1 and 2 mutation test.  I would suspect because you have all been older than 40 years old on diagnosis Your consultants haven't thought it worth following up.  Have a look at the OPERA tool on the Macmillan site. It's off line at the moment but should be back. You can also view information at  https://www.nice.org.uk/Guidance/CG164 If when you input all the details you have explained above into the tool and it suggests you are tested, take this to your consultant whilst you are being treated. They can then take it forward. i have to say though it's normally for those diagnosed around or under 40 years of age.  I had the test and was negative but the letter I got said my BC still could be hereditary it's just that scientists haven't worked out what other genes apart from BRCA is responsible. I was however 41 on diagnosis. The younger the diagnosis, the more it indicates a gene fault.  it would be easiest if you or your sister take this forward rather than it coming from your children/nieces.  All the best for your radiotherapy. I'm sure you and your sister have helped each other through this rubbish time no end. Julia X
Posts.Title: Hereditary breast cancer

Posts.Content: Have a super day Jackie xx
Posts.Title: Something good for a change

Posts.Content: Hi bougiecat  I didn't see the news report. There are 100's of chemotherapy drugs and not all need to be put in via the bloodstream. A friend of mine who had leukaemia took alot of his chemo orally and this was at home.  Some chemo drugs will lend themselves to self administration no doubt... abit like us self administering the GCSF drugs. Those that come with risks of anaphylactic shock or heart problems i would imagine aren't the ones for self administration. Our experience of chemo is unique to BC and there are many other regimes.  I personally have/would have no problem with self administration as the gscf at home was very convenient. Each injection alone cost over £300 so I understand why the NHS won't want to incur on costs ontop of that making me come in again just for something that I could do at home.  I fear for the NHS. I think it's an amazing thing about the uk but quite obviously it cannot go on functioning at breaking point. What would happen if we didn't have an NHS.  I read somewhere the average cost of cancer treatment per patient is £30,000. Mind boogling love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Concerned about recent news

Posts.Content: My diet was awful during chemo but I got through. It's a time when you don't need to be too strict with yourself . One more to go though is fab. The relief when I finished chemo was immense. Almost there ..... The finish post is within sight and you can be proud of getting through xx
Posts.Title: Barleygrass

Posts.Content: FEC will more than likely make you feel sick. Put the nail hardener on the back burner until docetaxol.  things you might need: A thermometer to take your temp Bottled water if you don't do tap. Aim for over 2 litres per day ice lollies helps with nausea  crackers/ginger biscuits for nausea Take the anti sickness regularly don't wait until you feel sick. Eat little and often. I was in bed for three days after each Fec but then recovered. Sleeping it off is the best way if you can.  Your chemo unit should be helpful too so don't hold back with the questions.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy on Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi silvercloud  It does seem that the complete results of the patholgy tests are needed first before you decide. If you are her 2 positive then you know chemo is the way forward. If your not her2 + then could you not ask that you get the Oncotype dx test? That will give you less of a human opinion and is based on your tumour. However due to the mix you had going on in there I won't say chemo was unusual.  Its not a good idea going into chemo putting that pressure on your hair to stay put because your daughter won't be able to cope. You need to be reassuring her and talking to her. My daughter wouldn't allow me to take her anywhere when my hair first fell out as it was a big thing for her And she was so embassies. She was 9 years old. However in time when she got use to it and her friends and the school were so very supportive towards her she was very accepting. It was her who encouraged me to be brave and ditch the wig and she was the one who said when I showed my 'crew cut' to the world. It was great. The cold cap is no guarantee you will keep your hair.  its worth asking if chemo (if that's the route you go) can start after your hols.  Apart from that, the oncologist will tell you what drugs he wants you to have and how often. It's Normally 6 sessions in total every three weeks. Ask how it will affect your fertility if you are considering more children.  Chemo is the most scary of treatments but it's very doable. I got through it 17 months ago and I am fit and well. This site is full of people that got through chemo. It really is a means to an end of cancer but you need to be convinced that you do need it. Good luck with the appointment. julia X
Posts.Title: Oncologist appointment questions to ask

Posts.Content: Live life for each day. valuable days are bypassing you whilst you just wait for the results. Which by all accounts will show things are still stable. The here and now is what matters the most. i made a vow to myself that because I literally made myself mentally ill after treatment I would never go back there. I didn't go through treatment because I was desperate to live only to go onto worry about how long I have left on the planet. No one knows that.  How you get your head in that mindfulness state is down to you.  As we all say on here.... where does worry get you apart from feeling bloody crap. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi Baxter  I became angry during chemo (fECT) and jammyfiona and I had a similar conversation yesterday. To be honest it may not be an affect of any of the medication just a emotion being realised due to this crap treatment. I became very short with my 9 year old and very withdrawn and would pick fights with my partner. I think mainly to try and have some control in a time when everything is out of control. I was feeling awful in myself and I had physical pain.  As George says though, if it's severe enough for physical anger do mention it to your oncologist.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Angry!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Judith  regardless of the reason you have raised cholesterol I would recommend the statins. I do know how you feel though about a gut reaction being to say no. I've known for 20 years I have familial hypercholesterolaemia. At the time of diagnosis (my 20s) I was considered too young for statins. Since then I've managed to lower it slightly but after treatment for BC it was raised again and my GP suggested it time to start statins. I was 41 and hated the idea initially but thinking about it I realised a lower cholesterol meant less risk of stroke and heart disease etc. I did insist on a 10mg dose though which is the lowest dose.  I've never been over weight, eat healthily, am a runner and have a BMI of 21 yet always had a high cholesterol which wasn't through anything I had done. I think we tend to associate cholesterol with bad lifestyle choices but it's not always like that.  The statins don't give me any side effects and your liver function is monitored on them.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/ Arimidex: SE: Raised Blood Cholesterol ?

Posts.Content: Mmmmm "A large ship with a small hole" that's got to be the best yet. Did you laugh as much as I just did when he said that????
Posts.Title: Could we give some hope to people like me please?

Posts.Content: Hi amy66  I havent used this statistic in the past but I am sorry that it's caused enough angst for you to raise it. That's definitely not in keeping with the supportive nature of why we are here. To be honest I use to get very hot under the collar about people describing triple negative BC as highly aggressive because when you have TNBC you think you have no hope. ive learnt however It's not the case. Statistics can be used either way. We never know which category we sit in until 5 and 10 years time. i don't have a 90% prognosis of surviving 5 years but I don't like to think I'll be in the 15% that doesn't make 5 years in my category of diagnosis.   Your oncologist can give you a statistic based upon your specific BC without having chemo or he might have already done that? As Carolyn says, it doesn't mean you will be in the 10%. Even having had all treatment methods you can you will never be 100% protected and our 'predict' scores can give an indication of how likely we will survive.  Have you been able to consider hormonal therapies? I know in previous posts this has been uncertain. love  Julia X
Posts.Title: Could we give some hope to people like me please?

Posts.Content: Oh my Skye01, Yup youve had a pathological complete response (pCr). Sooo happy for you. Take this golden nugget with you moving forward.  Happy happy weekend. You've made me smile. love Julia xx ps... it means your chances of recurrence are very much reduced and the prognosis good :)
Posts.Title: Happy news....

Posts.Content: Wonderful news. Congratulations xx
Posts.Title: survivor

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline Never think you are wasting a consultants time. As the cancelled appointment had that initial affect on you can clearly see that you need to have that appointment. What would be the alternative? You could be waiting another few weeks and in the meantime you have to cope with that mental anxiety making you suffer. Maybe the other women he is seeing too are in similar situations, you just don't know. There are times to be selfish. Look after you. The end of treatment is a very emotive time. For me it was when I developed a mental illness. Protect yourself and I guess your consultant may never know that the cancelled appointment upset you. It might also help to think that the cancelled appointment has nothing to do with you - someone somewhere has over booked. Why should yours be the one that drops off the table. In time when you go for longer periods imbetween seeing your surgeon you will find it does get easier so any future rearrangements wont affect you so badly. All the best for Thursday. Julia x
Posts.Title: Guilty meltdown.

Posts.Content: Hello Scotland  If you think back to where you were before the infection reared it's ugly head, you were still very anxious about starting chemo. The added emotional turmoil of  postponing the start is catching up with you, along with antibiotics you have been taking. Weekends always seem worse for periods of Worry. i don't think anyone of us here didn't go into chemo without fear and sadness. So it's not just you. As you are her2+ you need to think of chemo as a necessity. It's a very small bite size chunk out of what will be a long life. It will be worth it.  Tomorrow is Monday, the start of new beginings. Grab it and do something memorable to set you in good stead for Tuesday.   Julia X
Posts.Title: Having a wobble

Posts.Content: Hello Yvonne  I think each different type of BC brings its own challenges. You, like me have the rarer type of BC. i was triple negative and it can be very tough living without taking a preventative drug unlike her2 and Er+. On the other hand I don't think I would want the SE hormonal drugs bring. You will become more at ease with the type And keep in your mind that herceptin was expecially made for your type of BC. It works.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Got myself worked up about HER2 + status

Posts.Content: A lovely post to read Kate. Counselling is a good way forward and you will get a lot from the moving forward group, I did. I had 4 months of counselling after treatment finished. It's hard to learn to live with the fear but you will. Life has a knack of over taking. It won't feel like it now but trust me it does. I view me in remission/no evidence of disease/ whatever you want to call it as a second chance. Second chances aren't to be sniffed at. julia X X
Posts.Title: Got myself worked up about HER2 + status

Posts.Content: Hi amy66  I havent used this statistic in the past but I am sorry that it's caused enough angst for you to raise it. That's definitely not in keeping with the supportive nature of why we are here. To be honest I use to get very hot under the collar about people describing triple negative BC as highly aggressive because when you have TNBC you think you have no hope. ive learnt however It's not the case. Statistics can be used either way. We never know which category we sit in until 5 and 10 years time. i don't have a 90% prognosis of surviving 5 years but I don't like to think I'll be in the 15% that doesn't make 5 years in my category of diagnosis.   Your oncologist can give you a statistic based upon your specific BC without having chemo or he might have already done that? As Carolyn says, it doesn't mean you will be in the 10%. Even having had all treatment methods you can you will never be 100% protected and our 'predict' scores can give an indication of how likely we will survive.  Have you been able to consider hormonal therapies? I know in previous posts this has been uncertain. love  Julia X
Posts.Title: Could we give some hope to people like me please?

Posts.Content: Hello adassarose  in terms of worry and anxiety this is definitely the worse time because you are always thinking the worse. It happens at night because you have no distractions and your mind wonders. I was very close to slipping into depression on diagnosis until I realised I could not function if that happened. Then treatment commenced and it was head down and get stuck in. At least when you start treatment you know all is being done to get rid of the cancer and it helps. When you aren't you feel it's taking over your body by the minute . It's not the case. i can say sleep will happen as time moves on. In the meantime I can recommend herbal remedies, sleeping in the day if you need to and keep as  distracted as you can. Go to bed when you are really ready to sleep. Read before you try and get off. To be honest my treatent started with chemo so I seemed to spend nearly all my time asleep whilst going through that I needed to.  Mindspace apps are good but it takes awhile to be able to be mindful. It helped me though. When are you commmencing treatment? if you have any more questions we can always help answer them. Julia X
Posts.Title: Sleepness nights

Posts.Content: Hi mags  I'm sure the oncology department will say it's ok to have the marker so soon to chemo. Think of it like a picc line insertion. I had my line inserted two days before chemo started.  The marker insertion is quite minor and done under a local. I think these procedures done under hospital condition have little risk of infection. i can't remember seeing any major 'wound' after my clip was inserted.  As for eating before chemo (I think your mum will start with docetaxel you said?) I would suggest light meals, nothing too heavy and sweet. I started with FEC and made the big mistake of eating heavily beforehand then was as sick as a dog! Docetaxel didn't make me nauseous at all. too be honest it's a bit boring having doc as it takes an hour and I found it boring. They will monitor your mum very closely whilst she has her first session. Take in water and a healthy snack as she might feel peckish During treatment. Beware with doc as side effects can kick in late... 2 or 3 days after having it. Co codamol helped me. The foods to avoid whilst on chemo are similar to those to avoid during pregnancy. Don't stress over food too much, the most important thing is to drink drink drink.  I hope all goes well. I found my day care unit fantastic and so so caring. I actually miss them if that doesn't sound too weird! Xx
Posts.Title: Marker clip and chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi karen  I can share my experience of my pre chemo meeting if it helps.  I knew I would have a picc line fitted as that was explained to me when the chemo ward rang me and told me when my first session would be. My line was fitted around 3 days before I was due to start.  The pre chemo chat is all about what you expect from the chemo as in side effects. You get vouchers for a NHS wig. You get loads of gumpf on neutrophenic sepsis and what to do if you think you have it. They go through foods to avoid whilst on chemo similar to if you were pregnant. They take bloods. Your height and weight are taken if not already done as this will determine how much chemo they give you.  Alk the chemo appointments may be made for you in one go so you may have a say in what time of day you have it.  If you go with a picc line then you have to arrange weekly cleaning and flush appointments.  Be warned, you do get bombarded with info. My partner came with me as I knew I wouldn't take it all in.  If you want to know about the drugs you are having ask as each one will give different side effects eg the red colour one (I hated this colour and could never watch it going into my body) is the one that makes your hair fall out.  All the best with it. There will be other ladies going through it simultaneously so join the chemo chat thread. I'm almost a year post chemo now. It's becoming a distant memory even through at the time I thought it would never end.  Julia x
Posts.Title: Still in discomfort

Posts.Content: Barley grass, wheatgrass, spiralina or any 'clean green' claim to give antioxidant benefits. I take a powder in smoothies. I started taking it during treatment. As to what effects it has on cancer treatment you will probably never find out conclusively. Check the CRUk site out as they have an excellent site for checking the claims of certain products/foods against cancer. For me it's more about personal choice. You can never be certain that alternative remedies help but if you feel you are helping your body then it helps mentally. Some will argue you should get all you need from a healthy diet. X
Posts.Title: Barleygrass

Posts.Content: I had one node involved on diagnosis. Chemo killed all the cancer cells in it but I went on to have 11 nodes taken away. I also had vascular invasion.  Im 2.5 years on from diagnosis. I live a very happy contented life but Ibe learnt how to do this.  My consultatants said my treatment was a success and I was a no evidence of disease (NED) thats as good as it gets in terms of end of treatment. you will learn to trust your body again when you return to life. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Worrying again

Posts.Content: Hi Loolyboo  It's difficult to argue against a 'guideline' unfortunately but I am sure your oncologist will provide the reassurance. Both my consultants did.  I had chemo first but then waited over 10 weeks for surgery then 8 weeks between surgery and RT. George is so right, use the extra time to build your strength up. I had an easier time for it.  The extra two weeks you will be waiting won't mean your cancer has grown back even though that's what your mind is telling you.  I know it's hard as I have been through the extra wait but it made no difference to the outcome only meant I was very well recovered moving on to the next treatment.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Waiting forever!

Posts.Content: TootsBess Good afternoon. Hope we're all warm and keeping well.  Three weeks post chemo and just wondering when this insipid fatigue will start to clear and I'll start feeling like my old self again. What are your experiences please?  Also, I had the cold cap treatment but obviously still lost a bit of hair and still am losing a bit each day but now post chemo I'm wondering when the hair will stop coming out and start growing back?  Thanks all.  Xx Hi TootsBess  Sorry, but 3 weeks is no time at all in being back to normal. Not what you want to hear I know but  not putting a time frame on it will help not being disappointed, I was back running 6 weeks post chemo but the fatigue took much longer. When I say fatigue, I didn't need to sleep in the day but was just shattered come the evening. When you say fatigued how do you mean? A common SE of docetaxol is anemia. It happened to me and I ended up having a blood transfusion. I was so tired that walking up the stairs was hard without stopping and having a rest. I didn't cold cap but had hair regrowth 6-8 weeks post chemo. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Post Chemo Fatigue and Hair!

Posts.Content: Hello Eleanor  I remember the discomfort after I first drove after WLE and Axilla clearance. You have been doing something you haven't done since surgery. Your body will let you know it. It doesn't mean it's a bad thing. Moving your arm more normally needs to happen. I drove after three weeks and kept going until it no longer felt strange.  Mention your feeling unwell to the chemo unit when you have your pre chemo chat. Bloods will be taken pre chemo and chemo is normally only delayed if your blood counts aren't in healthy ranges.  Watch out for any swelling or hotness/pinkness in the breast  in the meantime if you do drive. There are no hard and fast rules when it comes to holding back especially as you are 4 weeks post surgery just bear in mind you have had two bouts of surgery.
Posts.Title: Still in discomfort

Posts.Content: Morning ladies  At the moment you are sensitive to such adverts. As already said, the adverts have been around for a long time but you didn't have a connection to them previously, now you do. There are also lots of adverts about dementia, heart disease, diabetes but the sad thing is that we tend not to take notice because we don't think it will ever happen to us.  When your treatment has finished and all has gone well you will be able to look at these adverts again not with fear and panic but an understanding and a felling of proudness for what you have gone through. You might also feel grateful for the money that is raised to have found preventative drugs such as tamoxifen etc. that's how I found I coped with the media coverage.  At the end of the day and selfishly I cannot wait until breast cancer no longer kills people and the only way this will happen will be by raising enough money for this to happen. I was triple negative so a preventative drug is all I want.  One big learning curve from all of this is how people judge others and they think its the right to be able to do that. The comment about using social media is a horrible example. I agree so much with you Grogg.  I don't have a large group of friends on FB but I have chosen carefully. They are friends not just people I know. My BC was put on FB by my partner who gave updates and messages of encouragement and love. The support I received from friends was immeasurable. When you are feeling loved you can get through even the toughest of times.  Have a good day ladies xx
Posts.Title: Adverts!!

Posts.Content: Thank you. Holiday is going fab. Mostly on a sunbed ha ha.  I had my hair cut by a friend a couple of weeks pre chemo. She came to my house for fear of me having a melt down! I had it cut shoulder length just to soften the blow. I kept a lock of the hair weirdly enough!  I went wig shopping whilst I had hair so the assistants could get a feel for what would suit. I went to house of Fraser. I kept as near to my normal style at first then swapped to a red head near the end of chemo as I started to feel rebellious!  I held out for as long as I could whilst my hair fell out. It happened over weeks. In the end I went so thin ontop my partner politely said I should sort it out! That's when I started with the wig. I favoured scarves most of the time as they were more comfy.  FEC t is a common combo but not a given. It normally means 3 cycles of FEC (three different drugs) which made me feel like I had morning (all day) sickness but only for around 5 days after I had it. Then it's 3 cycles of a taxol. I had docetaxel and no nausea hurray. But it did affect my mouth and joints. You will learn so much as you go along.  Chemo for me was literally about surviving and getting to the end. Never had I wished time away before then. It will test everything you have but you will find it in you to get through, Without sounding too phylisophical. Xx
Posts.Title: Still in discomfort

Posts.Content: This is one area that is very well researched and proven. There is a link between if you drink more you are at more risk. CRUK and breast cancer now sites are sites to start with.  The jury is still out however on the effect alcohol consumption has on TNBC. If you have oestrogen positive BC the more you drink the more you are at risk.  It leads you to believe that you should have less than the recommended number of units per week.  I was TN and still drink around 10 units per week. It's a personal thing. Reducing alcohol intake should be part of a healthy diet and exercise. One with out the other cancels each other out.  It's Christmas. Crack open those bubbles.  Cheers xx
Posts.Title: Alcohol ??? yes, no, some ?

Posts.Content: Mmmmm "A large ship with a small hole" that's got to be the best yet. Did you laugh as much as I just did when he said that????
Posts.Title: Could we give some hope to people like me please?

Posts.Content: I too have my first mammogram in January, one year after surgery. For me the screening does help with anxiety. I am assured that if anything does happen now it will be picked up very quickly and that's the best you can hope for. I was under the age for screening pre diagnosis so in a way its good that I am now being looked at regularly. We are closely monitored. In my eyes that is a positive thing. All the best for the upcoming appointments x
Posts.Title: 2 Year Check Up

Posts.Content: Hi CEC  im sorry you too have had this diagnosis.  Being brave: ready to face and endure danger or pain. We may seem like that too you now but believe me we all remember those few weeks after diagnosis when we thought we were dying.  If your not brave what happens? You accept cancer will get the better of you and that's not what you want. It will take awhile for your survival to kick in but it will.  Give your daughter time just as you need time but please ask her or others for help with the fur babies and horses because you will need it and appreciate it.  use this forum to open up to or seek confidence in a close friend. Your daughter may struggle hearing about your fears but a close friend will be all ears.  feel free to ask questions but only as and when you feel strong enough for us to bombard you.  It will be ok. I am approaching two years post diagnosis after ing diagnosed at 41years.  All the best julia X
Posts.Title: How are you all so brave, I've just been diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi Islanikita  What is "normal"? Don't think you are a freak as you are no more different then the next big breasted, small breasted, short or tall woman with or without breasts or with scarred breasts. I'm just under 6ft and I could guarentee there was always a remark getting me into a scanner or being assessed. My surgeon wrote on my assessment I was 'unusually tall'.  We were made this way. Don't feel freaky And don't be afraid to ask for more to be done so you are happy with the results.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Made to feel like a freak because I am larger breasted

Posts.Content: As you have great tits now then this will be hard for you! (Your words ha ha) Generally women would change something about their boobs which helps when deciding on surgery but you are happy with what you have.  I can't remember but I think you are being Brca tested later on? If the consultants think it's highly likely that you have the Brca gene mutation then it really is worth having a bilateral mx now.  I was all set for a mx but ended with a WLE as I had a complete response to neoadjuvant chemo.  I am 20 years younger and the surgeon would only do a bilateral because he wanted and I wanted very much to have a matching pair. I wouldn't have coped with different shaped/sized breasts and didn't fancy any more than one lot of surgery.  My surgeon suggested implants due to my frame and bust size  (34d). like you though I knew I was not going to have a diep/tram etc.  If you need RT then that's not recommended after implants unless you have expanders. (Pumped up over time to achieve a good shape).  I have seen implants and in clothes the results are amazing.  the cleavage can be different. Even with push-up bras it's hard to create cleavage due to there being more of a gap between the breasts. However the shape is fab. They are also more noticeable when you lie down as they don't droop like natural breasts.  Your surgeon has seen your body, what does he suggest would look right on your frame? Be guided. As I say it's hard for you as you have breasts you love already.  By the way when i had to decide on the type of surgery it totally messed my head up especially as I'd had 4 months of chemo first.  It feels like a life and death decision at the time but in hindsight it wasn't.  Hope the decision gets easier for you.  Julia
Posts.Title: How do I choose, one mastectomy or two, immediate or delayed reconstruction...

Posts.Content: Hi Smiffy  As the girls have said, I feel it's a personal choice about who you tell. You don't have to tell everyone. The most important thing is you getting your head around this diagnosis and you may find that's by just you and a few close ones knowing or a wider circle.  With regard to your biopsy I would say the pain is normal. I was in agony after my biopsy and was so bruised. I also swelled quite a bit. Any invasive procedure is going to have side effects.  Hopefully by now it's easing for you.  i was on pain relief for some days after.  I went to Glastonbury festival a few weeks after my diagnosis. I wasn't me and very anxious and thoughtful but I wanted distractions. My friend found this hard as she wanted to party. The holiday maybe a good thing for you but explain to your friend that you may not be 'you'.  julia X
Posts.Title: Newbie with core biopsy question

Posts.Content: Hi Yogijo   im sure the consultants won't be assessing your grooming skills :) If you are still numb in the armpit you need to take care. An electric razor is your best bet if you do want start shaving now. Hair remover too but only if youve used that before and are ok with it.  I carried on with a normal razor even after axilla clearance. I've never cut my armpit in the years I've been shaving so guessed my risk was pretty low! While it's numb however it's a weird sensation. Julia x
Posts.Title: Armpit shaving!

Posts.Content: Hi shades of dawn  your consultants reply to your question may have been off the cuff and not thought through due to the infrequency of this question being asked. To be honest I never considered wanting the marks to removed as they aren't noticeable amongst the freckles. I never give them a thought. If they are affecting you psychologically then do Persue their removal but otherwise do see if they fade in time. From what I gather tattoo removal isn't pain free and would you really want to put your body through that after the BC treatment,  Take more comfort in a 4% recurrence rate than a dislike over the RT tattoos x
Posts.Title: Radiation tattoo shock!

Posts.Content: Hello Broken-Emi  Welcome to the Mac community. We will have to work on you to become 'unbroken'. Although it seems your world and life has ended at the moment I can tell you that it hasn't by a long way. I too was 41 years old on diagnosis with a 9 year old and had the rarer triple negative type BC like her2+.  You know exactly what the plan is as you have listed it in point form. That's your adVantage. You are already taking control. Some time very soon your survival instinct will kick in. Trust me.  I had neoadjuvant chemo. I can tell you that her2+ tumours can respond very well to chemo, as early as after the first session. We have a fantastic monthly chemo chat thread where you can go into chemo at the same time as others and support each other. It's not pleasant nor is it pretty but it's a means to an end of cancer.  You will lots more questions so fire away when you need too. There's always a virtual ear on here for you.  BC is so very treatable with high success rates. Allow a year out of your life to do this very important job.  Call on your friends and family for support, don't be afraid of asking for help with the kids during this time. You could do with it.  Hugs  Julia
Posts.Title: Just been diagnosed with HRE2+ AND ER+ breast cancer

Posts.Content: Just to pick up on your question about the tumour feeling bigger. Don't fret. This is more than likely due to the biopsy you had. It's an invasive procedure so quite often your poor boob will react and get swollen and feel different. Mine did.  The grade of your BC will determine the aggresiveness, although I don't like that word. The grade means how different the cells are from normal cells. Grade 3 being the most different, grade 2 intermediate and grade 1 slow growing.  There is unfortunately lots more to learn. Not at all what you expected for yourself but a curve ball huh.  I can't help with the SNB as I had Axilla clearance automatically as I knew on diagnosis one node was affected. Xx
Posts.Title: Just been diagnosed with HRE2+ AND ER+ breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Cuckoo  theres no reason why it shouldn't heal as per normal unless you have it infected. I'm sure you cleaned it and put antiseptic on it to help it heal. If it starts getting red and angry or your fingers and/or hands start swelling its time to get antibiotics from your GP.  Julia
Posts.Title: cut on my hand after lymph node removal

Posts.Content: Hi modestmouse  many congrats on reaching five years post diagnosis.  I don't have the option of taking tamoxifen so can't give any advice on that. It sounds like you would like to discuss the pros/cons of staying on them for another five years, in which case your oncologist should make themselves available to discuss this with you before you make a final decision. Have you tried to make an appointment through oncology reception?  Im surprised you weren't given an option over chemo as I had to sign an agreement before I entered Into the treatment and part of this was discussing the reasons for having the chemo.  Try your GP for the lymphoedema as they can give antibiotics and make a referral to a lymphoedema clinic. I always find my breast care unit is stretched to the limits.
Posts.Title: time to stop tamoxifen

Posts.Content: No problem. It's been a bit quiet the last few days which you could say is a good thing :)  https://community.macmillan.org.uk/cancer_types/breast-cancer/f/38/t/107282 Most chemo regimes are FEC-t. 3 sessions of FEC (3 different drugs) then you switch to a taxane, often docetaxol. Again 3 cycles given every three weeks. Sometimes it's given weekly if you have a pre existing medical condition. Neoadjuvant is when you have chemo first. It worked well for me. I had a complete response so keep that in mind. it does happen.  As your having herceptin (for the her2 status) you start that with the T and then carry on after every month. Up to a year I think it is?  Xx
Posts.Title: Just been diagnosed with HRE2+ AND ER+ breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Cocopops1  All my very best wishes for the funeral tomorrow. I hope the sun shines and you can remember your Nan in a special way. Let us know how the tests go in the afternoon.  Keep your pecker up lovely. Julia x
Posts.Title: Scary times ahead

Posts.Content: KiwiCardi I've suspected for a little while that I've started developing lymphodema in my affected arm and my side just below the armpit - I had a mastectomy and lymph node clearance. It's just been feeling a bit weird, sort of tight and tired, so I went to the lymphodema nurse and she did the measurements. Sure enough, my right arm is slightly bigger than my left - not a huge amount, but too much to be just normal variation due to my being right-handed. She told me to increase my lymphodema exercises to twice a day, and to add in activation of the lymph nodes in my groin, stroking from my armpit down towards the groin. She also ordered me a compression sleeve, but said I don't need to wear it all the time - just to put it on when I'm doing physical work like housework or gardening. So my question is, has anyone actually been able to improve their lymphodema and reduce the feeling of puffiness? I've been doing the exercises twice daily for about a fortnight now and I think I can see some improvement, but it might be just wishful thinking! i had lymphoedema in the breast but it didn't affect my arm. the only treatment that worked was kinesio taping. You can have this on your arm. It's becoming very common now but odema clinics are still slow to use the technique I suspect due to training.  I would recommend it, it solved my odema after around 4 months. love julia xx
Posts.Title: Possible to reduce lymphodema in arm?

Posts.Content: Yeah to you both Matt. What fantastic news and thank you for being such a big support to your wife through this flippin awful time. Her mojo will return with your help but bear in mind sometimes folk need a little extra help 'moving on' as its very hard to leave a cancer diagnosis in the past. Sounds like your wife could deal with anything whilst she has you. Keep well, both of you and go and live life. Julia x
Posts.Title: All over, thank you x

Posts.Content: If you aren't feeling unwell then I'm guessing a high temp may be normal for you? If you are functioning with it then carry on lovely xxx
Posts.Title: Unwell and unsure

Posts.Content: Hi Cocopops1  Welcome to our community. You will find help and support here. You ask many questions already. This in turn will be making you feel manic. One step at a time. I felt a lump which was already big and it tuned out to be BC but that was 2.5 years ago and I'm now cancer free. Dont get hung up chastising yourself on not going to the GP sooner. You can't change the past. You can influence your future. its normal to get fast tracked to the BC unit when the GP feels a lump. My lump felt huge but in fact it was 25mm. That's not big in the grand scheme of things.  A diagnosis will take time. The core biopsy isn't pleasant and I would adivse taking pain relief Before you go. If you dont like needles look away. You will have a local  anasthetic so won't feel it at all and it's very quick. I waited a week for results, some are given the same day. The ultrasound will give a good picture of the lump and they will look at lymph nodes under the arm too. You might like to ask the scanographer what he/she is seeing. I couldn't as was was silent due to shock.  If it is BC then more scans may be needed such as bone and MRI. This is normal But means more waiting of test Results. Results are not given out on the telephone So don't let this worry you on the day of your Nans funeral. It's sad you are having this loss to deal with also. I found my lump 2 days after my dads funeral.  90% of people undergoing treatment for BC will end up successfully treated. That's a good percentage. Please keep that in mind. So The odds are heavily in your favour that you don't die from this. It won't feel like it though if you do get a diagnosis Because your mind plays cruel tricks on you. Take this one step at a time because it's very overwhelming. keep preoccupied with anything you can.  Was the GP concerned over the result blood test results? What action was taken? Keep posting and we will help you.  Sending love and best wishes and remember there is a chance this may not be cancer but a benign cyst. It happens in younger ladies. i was 41 years old on diagnosis.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Scary times ahead

Posts.Content: Hello Siarry and welcome to the breast cancer forum. There are no hard and fast examples of how quickly letrozole can work. Have scans shown there Is no change in the tumour? Is your oncologist implying three months should have already given some result? Heather77 is one lady who persevered with letrozole for sometime but with a good end result. She is knowledgable on this and will be very supportive.  Love  Julia X
Posts.Title: Advice please.

Posts.Content: Hi Mojo723  After care varies massively with each trust. Mammograms are normally given 12 months post surgery. Our trust only does mammos every two years from then on although I disputed this and got it changed for me As I had TNBC. I wasn't prepared to be left for two years.  Do ask what follow up appointments you will get though. I'm still seen every three months and I'm 2.5 years away from diagnosis and tbh now I find it too much.  You also need to be told that you are a NED (no evidence of disease) so don't be afraid to ask otherwise you may find that the consultants won't say anything and that's not helpful.  On the basis your tumour was removed with clear margins and you had chemo and/or RT you are deemed as a NED.  This is an axious time though, learning to life with a risk and learning to live life again.  One thing I've learnt though.. if you don't ask you don't get so speak out and ask the questions.  Love julia x
Posts.Title: Mammograms after treatment

Posts.Content: Hello Suzeanna  I too am sorry to read you are facing more surgery. At times like these we dwell on the horror stories. Its not a bad thing but only if it hinders us making an informed decision. I had node clearance (11 nodes in total) two years ago. I have no mobility issues and not had lymphedema. I am 41 years and very physically active so to compare our circumstances isn't ideal. Clearance doesn't automatically mean ALL nodes are taken just those around any that are obviously affected. I only had one node affected and in hindsight am thinking why was it necessary to remove 11. I did have lymphoedema in the breast which was cured after 4 months. Its never come back. Be clear from your consultant what the best case scenario could be in terms of the amount of nodes they remove and the worse case. Would you consider alternatives to clearance now such as hormonal treatments? Do you now what score the ER+ is at this time around? Node clearance brings a risk of lymphedema but you need help from your consultaint to ascertain if the risk of the cancer being left in situ will cause a bigger risk than the  lymphedema risk. What grade of cancer do you have?  That will help make your decision. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Terrified at the thought of axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Peace  Are you new too the forum? If so, a warm Christmas welcome.  Your mind galloping away from you will ruin your Christmas if you let it. Would you have preferred the results before Christmas? I think that would equally have been hard.  You don't know what the results are and you can't let your mind diagnose yourself with breast cancer. To be honest most diagnosis are only given after a biopsy has been taken so your consultant may not even have conclusive results yet.  I waited two weeks for a breast cancer diagnosis. That was 18 months ago. I could tell you BC doesn't mean the end but that won't mean much to you at the moment. During the time I waited for results however I was adamant until I knew exactly what was what I wasn't going to waste time worrying and making myself ill. I've done enough worrying since diagnosis. It's hard but you need to put it to the back of your mind. I think you will have more tests before things are confirmed either way.  Happy Christmas. Julia
Posts.Title: Petrified waiting for results

Posts.Content: Emily how flipping awful. Not only for you but your Mum, husband and family.  Sounds like a joint approach with this is the best way forward. I'm assuming your oncologist is still thinking tax is the way forward and not to continue with EC?  Is there any medication you can take to counter balance the mental issues? Could you be admitted into hospital when you have tax so any issues can be dealt with quickly? Would having weekly doses of tax help instead of three larger doses? Are there no other taxanes you can have without steroids? I do know they play an awful big part in docetaxel. I was told if I didn't take steroids then I could not have docetaxel.  I can imagine you are fraught with decision making. Let's hope between your mental health worker and oncologist they can come up with a way forward.  All the very best. Julia X  Ps steroids taken with docetaxel are more for preventing anaphylactic shock (so I was told) more so than controlling sickness.
Posts.Title: Psychotic reaction to chemo steroids

Posts.Content: Hello again Emily  Another lady has just posted and in she talks about a psychotic episode she had after FEC. Her's was down to anti depressants that were taken at the same time as chemo. Is your oncologist 100% sure yours was the steroids?
Posts.Title: Psychotic reaction to chemo steroids

Posts.Content: HI Positive1968  ive never rated semi permanent colours. I went straight into permanent colour around 5 months post chemo. I couldn't hold out any longer but I went with a brown.  if you want to go lighter (the pink) and need to use peroxide/bleach you need to be more cautious. All you need to know is on this website. I found it fab: http://www.mynewhair.org/ Do go to a hairdresser who has been trained In 'my new hair' .Those are featured in this guide. Julia X
Posts.Title: Colouring Hair

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn28  I can follow email links ok but I frequently encounter other technical issues with the site. I use an iPhone 6 And it's very tempramental.  Lets hope the techies can fix us soon.  J xx
Posts.Title: Email links not working

Posts.Content: Hi helsbels18  Do ask your consultants that you are considered for a US based upon your previous experience. In my experience.. if you don't ask you don't get. I queried another aspect of screening and was successful in getting the outcome I wanted.  Love julia x
Posts.Title: Screening after bresst cancer

Posts.Content: Think of this phase as you being an animal being let back into the wild. You must be a tortoise though and do this very slowly. Don't be in any rush to get back into old life because a new life is better. I needed five months of counselling after treatment as I fell apart. I did know I needed help though and was lucky I had quick access to it.  I'll always maintain the end of treatment was the hardest but as I feel better than ever now I feel it was worth hitting rock bottom to get back ontop.  reach out for counselling if it's stopping you living JJ.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Falling apart now it's over

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4  You may not be offered chemo first so we are discussing something that may not happen however if you are, I can give you my opinion. I am very biased as I had such a great result from having chemo first. I would recommend it.  Chemo for me obliterated all the cancer so that when surgery happened there was nothing left to remove apart from clear margins. The result was minimal tissue being removed and minimal scarring. Having neo adjuvant  chemo can be a double edged sword. On the plus side you will get to see the tumor getting smaller and smaller hopefully to the point where nothing is left. If you have a pathological complete response to chemo then your prognosis is very good. I cling to this nugget which controls my fear of recurrence. The downside is if the chemo doesn't have much affect on the tumor. You then need to switch drugs to try another or accept that no response to chemo has a poorer outlook. If you have surgery first to remove the cancer then have chemo after you have no way of telling what the chemo is doing for you. For some people, that doesn't sit well. They like to see results. We say this based upon you needing chemo and you might not need it. It wont be clear if you need chemo if you are ER +  as that's only normally known after surgery using the oncotype DX test. Julia x
Posts.Title: Large lumps

Posts.Content: I knew from the fist chemo Jojo4. it was around week three of the first chemo it felt smaller. I had discomfort in the breast which was a sign things were working. I saw my oncologist regularly through chemo and he would confirm it felt smaller on palpitation. Half way through chemo I had a scan which showed it had shrunk. Come the end of chemo and an ultrasound the scanographer couldn't find anything.
Posts.Title: Large lumps

Posts.Content: My comment was in relation to Denzils earlier comment about tumour size. My comment was reinforcing that tumours over 20mm (2cm) are treatable/curable so would still be considered early stage.
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: Hi Helen  If it helps you to take back control and help anxiety over recurrence then maybe it's a way forward for you.  For me a healthy all round diet and lots of exercise is the key. If you want to take the pills as part of a healthy diet then it's a plan.  For me personally, I don't trust claims like these. The only possibility for me would be a low dose aspirin but even then there is no conclusive evidence.  If you are seriously considering them then take into consideration hormonal therapies you may already take?  Julia X
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: You can on the 25th George.  Let us know what you find He he
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: It's not being a drama Queen, it's being scared. On this forum we all get what you are saying And have felt the same. Take the positives, it hadn't reached your lymph nodes. As I say, I know women with hormonal BC that have had vascular invasion. That's the role of the chemo To kill those nasties.  I finished my treatment last Friday. 6 cycles of chemo, WLE and 15 sessions of RT. That's me well and truely cooked! Ive  just seen you too use to put your mobile next to your breast, I did too when running as did others as you will read. It's such a dodgy area and like has been said before, maybe some years before evidence proves there is a link between mobiles and cancers. You just never know.  There is a triple negative forum but it's not very active so you may like to keep with this forum as it's very active xx ps the roller coaster will keep you on for a while longer. I'm now having to learn to come off Of it!
Posts.Title: Triple negative ductal carcinoma

Posts.Content: My comment was in relation to Denzils earlier comment about tumour size. My comment was reinforcing that tumours over 20mm (2cm) are treatable/curable so would still be considered early stage.
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: Hello Debbie Indeed your 1st birthday is tomorrow. So you mark it how you feel fit. The survival stats are based from when you are diagnosed. I am heading towards two years. I make a point of celebrating. Its great having two birthdays a year. The Queen shouldn't be the only one to benefit! It will be poignant too for you but look how far a year has taken you. I am glad you find the site helpful. I always recommend it to the ladies I meet with BC and other cancers. Many Happy returns for tomorrow lovely. Julia xx
Posts.Title: 1 year on...

Posts.Content: Welcome back Frances, its good to hear from you. I would say that there are other reasons for not offering a CT and they have used the 'radiation' one as you are less likely to challenge it. To be fair a mammogram also gives radiation but its a lower does than a CT scan. There are protocols which dictate what follow up scans we get. These only stretch to physical examinations and mammograms. Lets face it, given the chance we would all like to know the full picture in terms of what are bodies are looking like inside but the dear NHS wont and can't fund that.  A CT scan/bone scan/x-ray  would be offered if you had pain that was lasting and unexplained but they don't offer routine CT scans after BC. You could go back and really challenge the real reasons for not having the CT as the radiation one is lame but equally its hard to accept that due to cost we aren't worth more scans than the mammo. I am not sure if there is enough evidence to suggest that routine CT scans are of benefit? Julia
Posts.Title: Post-surgery follow-up... concerns

Posts.Content: Hi Shellie I would be asking for a second opinion, not because I think you have BC but because you need peace of mind.  I had lobular BC that was picked up on a mammo and ultrasound. But by then it was big enough to be seen.  If the consultant had ANY doubt he/she would have done a biopsy. This implies the consultant is in no doubt that taking into consideration your family history and your symptoms you don't have BC. You need a second opinion.  Whilst I was going through treatment I had a scare in the good boob. I have calcifications in both breasts and pre mensturally they become very lumpy. I had the lumps checked out with fine needle aspiration and they are benign. I have learnt what lumps are normal at what time in my menstrual cycle. Did calcifications get mentioned to you and do the lumps get prominent pre menstrually?  I hope, for your own sanity and safety you get a second opinion.  All the best  Julia
