Posts.Title: Invisible lumps??

Posts.Content: Hello Syers As you say, there is no nice Bresat Cancer to have. Each one has its own positives and negatives and you need to be positive about triple neg.  i had a lobular triple neg BC. A double whammy of cancer types in the minority! My TNBC was a grade 2. You mention TNBC is more aggressive, do you know if you are a grade 3? Any BC has the potential to invade the blood. Mine had and had affected one lymph node. Have you been told that TNBC respond better to chemo (especially a taxol) than hormonal types? I had chemo and had a complete pathological response. By the time I had surgery (I had neoadjuvant chemo) there were no Cancer cells left in the breast or in the lymph nodes. Chemo had got it all so I take comfort in the fact that hopefully the chemo destroyed any cells in my blood stream too or any elsewhere! Reoccurrence stats are slightly higher with TNBC in the first 2 years. But drop after 5 years to a better place than hormonal cancers where the risk of occurrence can remain for many years.  I didn't consider the cold cap as I took the opinion that I didn't want to try and stop the chemo from doing its job. I wanted it all around my body and didn't consider having no hair a reason to try a cold cap. I do appreciate that not all people want to lose their hair. The other good news is that mine started regrowing during DocetaXol.  A book that helped me was 'surviving  triple negative breast cancer' by Patricia prijatel.  You have been shocked today (i continue to get shocked when I learn something new!) but you will feel better as time goes on and you learn more. all the best  julia xx
Posts.Title: Triple negative ductal carcinoma

Posts.Content: I've just recently noticed that the stats have changed from 1 in 3 to 1 in 2 of us getting a cancer diagnosis. Half of us. The good news as reported, more of us are living after a diagmosis. I find I smile more now and I smile at least once to some random person a day. It's a lovely feeling to make someone smile. Helping on here makes me smile too.  Have a good day ladies xx
Posts.Title: How many do you know?

Posts.Content: The best route maybe through your BC unit. I had a similar experience whilst going through rads. They got me in within 48 hours and had a fine needle biopsy there and then and turned out it was nothing.  Never good to hesitate over these things.  All the best. Julia X
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: lemons really are the tip of the cancer myth ice burg.  There are so many claims of Anti-cancer foods, and my favourite, cannibis oil.  Do people really think that the medical professionals would still be treating with chemotherapy when lemon juice would do the same thing!  You can't beat a healthy diet and exercise. But we all know that when you have a cancer diagnosis you grab onto areas which we can control.  We are adults and we make choices on what's best for us.
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4  After biopsy the area will be very swollen this is normal with an invasive proedure. It's not the lump growing.  I can guarantee that there is treatment for you. The lump isnt too big. If after biopsy results you need chemo then having chemo first would be a good option in hope of shrinking it down so that breast conservation surgery can be done (WLE).  Your feeling aches and pains because your stressed and tuning in on things you would otherwise ignore.  You need to stop blaming yourself. That's in the past and you can't change that. You can affect what happens from now on. believe me when I say, when you get your treatment plan it will be such a whirlwind you will get stuck in. hugs lovely  Julia x
Posts.Title: Large lumps

Posts.Content: You can either become that self fulfilling prophecy in that people treat me like I'm on my way out so I'll act like I'm on my way out or as Steve says, you can get on with living. We have all been touched with a disease that has the potential to kill. Today we are still alive and are either going through treatment or have successfully gone through it. I couldn't bear being treated with kid gloves but appreciate I'm nearly two years post diagnosis so my 'panic' really has worn off. However I am not complacent.  Cancer may in reality not be the thing that we should most fear. Someone close to some of us on this community who was a huge character got through a battle with cancer. He very sadly recently passed due to a heart attack.  As Carolyn says, you could deny yourself that wine or that bit of cheese to later die of say dementia. boy if that were me I'd be pretty pi&&ed at denying myself those treats in life If that happened.  We have been given the insight into being close to death which makes us (or should) appreciate how flippin good life is. I sit and watch those crossing the finish line at the LVM and listen to the stories on how they got there. (I've been in tears for most of it!) People with a history of cancer and other diseases and I feel totally inspired and proud. The only person stopping us from living is often ourselves.  Take comfort in the fact that you all matter to alot of people who are trying to say they couldn't live without you. Julia xx
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: Judith I am so sorry to read this. How very sad. I'm sending you a hug lovely lady xx
Posts.Title: Falling apart now it's over

Posts.Content: I too am glad you are home JJ.  What an awful experience you have had. How on earth have you stayed sane in 7 weeks. 7 weeks in hospital is enough to tip anyone over the edge.  I think we are all aware of risks but at the time of consent we don't consider them for long enough to make them alter our decisions. I remember signing the chemotherapy consent form and the oncologist had written under 'risks' that I could die if I could an infection during chemo. I didn't give it a second thought then but since I've known of people who have sadly died from infections during chemo it seems real. In hindsight however would  it have changed my decision to accept chemo, no I don't think so.  Take it easy and I hope you are back at your friends where you can be taken good care Of.  Much love andI hope you continue to heal well.  Julia
Posts.Title: Back from hospital after DIEP

Posts.Content: Advice is to wait 6 months post chemo for permanent colour however I did mine after 5 months. As long as you do a skin test at least 24 hours before hand and it's ok then you are good to go. Going lighter however should be avoided until 6 months if you are using peroxides. Always seek a hairdresser who has experience of post chemo hair. My new hair by Trevor Sorbie is the site to visit on the net. Loads of helpful info here. Julia X
Posts.Title: 1st haircut after vhemo

Posts.Content: Hi Pat This radiographers question has led you to believe there is an alternative to a MX. The woman does need a talking too about her people skills but foremost she will not be any way qualified to suggest what surgery is appropriate or offer alternatives to you. I wonder what would have happened if you had asked what the alternatives would be For your diagnosis! I dread to think. I am guessing she is either not experienced at biopsies and was feeling under pressure or she just was having a bad day! If she was qualified to give diagnosis' and suggest surgical procedures then she would be a doctor/consultant not a radiographer. Mention this to your BCN as you say and find out if there is any validity at all in what the radiographer was saying...., I doubt it.  You can complain to PALS but who needs the stress and upset during this time???! I saved up all my complaining until the end of treatment then submitted a complaint at a time when I was able to deal with it. Park it aside until that time. I found documenting each situation cathartic too after it happened.  There are generally some caring professionals out there but we all have come across one that wouldn't win any care award anytime soon!  All the best  Julia x
Posts.Title: Confused and upset

Posts.Content: Hi loolou  This is such a brain scrambler of a decision. One only you can make, as hard as it is.  I was triple negative so chemo and radiotherapy were a given or my chances of survival were slim. Going through chemo was testing and the hardest thing I've done to date BUT I am 10 months post chemo and have no lasting affects. My chemo brain wore off after about 7 months but all it was was me being more forgetful and my concentration was bad. I exercised throughout chemo as have other ladies on here which helped a great deal. I was 41 years on diagnosis and had a complete response to chemo so it was worth every single dark moment. I don't have the option of taking any preventative therapies now but I would take them should they be a benefit to me.  You need positive experiences of her2 ladies and George's Jackie is one so he will be a massive help to you. He will be along soon.  All the best Julia
Posts.Title: help needed re chemo or not

Posts.Content: Just wanted to say congratulations Maggie. A major step. I quit smoking 7 years ago and became a runner. I could never exercise properly when smoking. I'm so glad I did as I do think good health is a major factor in coping with treatment. Good on you Maggie x
Posts.Title: smoking! !

Posts.Content: Hello iwannaliveforever  I was sorry to read that the site makes you worry. That's never our intention, we always hope we have the opposite affect. Ive looked into this topic quite a lot. There is no hard evidence that parabens are a causal factor of BC but I don't blame you for looking at it. I too have made changes with hair skin and make up. its much easier nowadays to find paraben/sls/aluminium free products. some brands are: missy deodrant innecto hair products Waitrose do a fab "pure" range sanex for deodorant and shower gel say "yes" products from boots palmers body butters/cocoa butters You will find make up harder. Boots are rubbish for displaying their ingredients within their make up and are one of the worse offenders with nasties. Bourjois are good. Bare minerals are good. A large M and S has a very good range of more " up market" brands which are kinder to skin. if it's not got parabens in the list of ingredients then it's a start.   Parabens give a longer shelf life in a product so if it's got a long shelf life the reality is it's got nasties in it. Also anything that claims to last 24 hours or you need a blow torch to remove it means it's got nasties in it!    Go spoil yourself.... your worth it xx
Posts.Title: Parabens, etc

Posts.Content: The only time I was told not to have alcohol was the first 48 hours after chemo. To be fair I never fancied it until around day 10/11 anyway. Even a lot of meds don't carry the warning to avoid alcohol. The key is moderation. I think we all get that though. Im also a big advocate of not  depriving yourself of those finer things that make you feel good.  Pre BC I did drink more than the suggested units per week but not now.I would never give up completely though.
Posts.Title: Red wine

Posts.Content: I would agree. Surely it's anything up to having metastasized to different organs and becomes incurable. If it's curable (whether that's permanantly or temporary who knows) then it must have been caught early enough To respond to Treatment.  BC tumours larger than 20mm are still curable.  We live in hope x
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: I would agree. Surely it's anything up to having metastasized to different organs and becomes incurable. If it's curable (whether that's permanantly or temporary who knows) then it must have been caught early enough To respond to Treatment.  BC tumours larger than 20mm are still curable.  We live in hope x
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: As you have said you have a family history of BC and OC I would say it's not ideal you having an implant or using anything that affects hormones. Speak to your GP about this.  Julia X
Posts.Title: Invisible lumps??

Posts.Content: Hi Leona  A CT scan is normally To check on vital organs, liver lungs etc. The gold standard for picking out lumps would be an MRI for the Breast. Ultrasounds I have found to be better than mammos and pretty accurate.  The best thing to do is really keep a check on it. When are you due a mammogram after treatment? Keep mentioning symptoms to oncology and breast care so they have to take notice.  You are like a packet of Revels in that you don't know what you are gonna get. In a nice way of course.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Invisible lumps??

Posts.Content: Hi Alice I can feel your frustration. Hopefully that will pass. You say that the operation has been moved. Do you have another date? There will been hundreds and hundreds of people affected by industrial action taken by the NHS and rest easy that this isn't a personal attack at you or anyone else waiting for surgery. Surgery will happen on a critical basis only until full service is resumed. A WLE wont be classed as critical. For one reason or another I waited over ten weeks for surgery. It made no difference to the positive outcome. I know you are ready and psyched up for this but we also have to be positive about our precious NHS staff fighting for something they feel very strongly for and actually I support, as I also work for an emergency service. We are slowing losing our NHS. I underwent 9 months of treatment that cost the NHS thousands and thousands of pounds. I have no complaints. The complete opposite. I bet that telephonist  has gone home ranting and raving tonight. Tomorrow is another day. Hang on in there.
Posts.Title: strike action REALLY

Posts.Content: Hi Maria 712  I did keep a diary and would highly recommend it to anyone. My diary was given to me along with a basket of 'spiritual' gifts. The cover was lovely embossed picture of a wizard and it inspired me. I wrote notes in it to my dad too as he died a month before I was diagnosed. Writing your feelings down is very cathartic just like being on here.  I still have the diary and I can't read it now as it's a chapter best left on the page. What I would say however is that you will be proud. Bearing in mind I'm now 2.5 years from diagnosis I am very proud of myself and think I was brave. At the time I didn't and I see lots of ladies on here who don't like the term brave but believe me, as time goes on you will congratulate yourself and give credit where it's due. You are doing great Maria. love julia x
Posts.Title: Keep a diary

Posts.Content: Life post cancer Maria 712 is a different life. Different doesnt mean worse or better but for me my life is much better and It has more meaning to me. For that I am glad. You make an interesting point about in the future when you are having a bad day you can reflect. In my experience I no longer get bad days, not like the bad days I did get, stressing over work or my daughter not doing as I asked. Those things don't bother me any longer. Cancer will always be our comparison and that puts perspective on life in general.  i had 11 months away from work, 9 months of treatment and 4 months of counselling. It had to be done. I needed that time to feel 'right' again.  I had triple negative bc and know the next three years are key in terms of keeping cancer free. But I don't think about it much. It doesn't stop me living. I'm a big believer in positivity and at the moment I am cancer free and intend to stay that way. I look after myself and keep happy. It's better for me than living a life in fear. Saying that I had a lot of help to get my mind where it is now. Start the diary, I think it will help.  Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Keep a diary

Posts.Content: You can either become that self fulfilling prophecy in that people treat me like I'm on my way out so I'll act like I'm on my way out or as Steve says, you can get on with living. We have all been touched with a disease that has the potential to kill. Today we are still alive and are either going through treatment or have successfully gone through it. I couldn't bear being treated with kid gloves but appreciate I'm nearly two years post diagnosis so my 'panic' really has worn off. However I am not complacent.  Cancer may in reality not be the thing that we should most fear. Someone close to some of us on this community who was a huge character got through a battle with cancer. He very sadly recently passed due to a heart attack.  As Carolyn says, you could deny yourself that wine or that bit of cheese to later die of say dementia. boy if that were me I'd be pretty pi&&ed at denying myself those treats in life If that happened.  We have been given the insight into being close to death which makes us (or should) appreciate how flippin good life is. I sit and watch those crossing the finish line at the LVM and listen to the stories on how they got there. (I've been in tears for most of it!) People with a history of cancer and other diseases and I feel totally inspired and proud. The only person stopping us from living is often ourselves.  Take comfort in the fact that you all matter to alot of people who are trying to say they couldn't live without you. Julia xx
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: A lovely post Wendy. I do find we can be quite critical of others whilst we go through treatment but I totally agree with you. i would not have got through without my friends. The support was over whelming and I felt wrapped up in a cocoon of love. im almost two years on and find I have a better understanding of relationships and treasure those dear people close to me. id like to think I would be able to do the same if a friend of mine went through a tough time.
Posts.Title: Aren't friends wonderful?

Posts.Content: Hi jules66  All my nails lifted off after I had had chemo (Docetaxol). But from 6 weeks onwards. This is a common side effect of this drug. Since you finished your chemo 7 months ago I doubt it's the chemo. It could be the after effects of anastrozole But I haven't seen this as a se described on this forum.  Maybe others may be along soon to confirm nail loss can be a se of anastrozole or even tamoxifen but to ease your mind you could visit your GP unless you have a follow up oncology appointment soon? Julia X
Posts.Title: Nails breaking and coming away from Nail bed

Posts.Content: Hi Phaedra  This is common on a taxane. I had docetaxol.  I had it. Couldn't get up the stairs without getting out of breath. if it's that serious they will give you a blood transfusion. I had two bags of blood and felt much better after. It's a simple procedure.  love julia xx
Posts.Title: Anyone become anaemic on chemo?

Posts.Content: Hello Helen You are being so critical of yourself and that's hard and will make it worse for you. Cancer is cancer and it is happening to you. You are petrified (I know the feeling very well). Who doesn't get scared after a diagnosis? So please don't beat yourself up over being pathetic(not that I think you are ). We don't have to cope with these awful situations. Allow yourself to just 'be'.  I truly believe you cannot go through cancer without a mental wellbeing unbalance at some stage. Mine happened after treatment. When everyone said great your cured lets all move on. I would have done and did do anything to help my mental state get back on an even keel, whether that's medication or therapy. Sometimes things do change as treatment progresses but it is uncommon for diagnosis's to change. You brain has a good knack of telling you the worse. You need to tell it politely to shut up. Friday will be here in no time.  I was Grade 2 on diagnosis. Was convinced they must have got it wrong as I was TN. But it stayed at Grade 2. If your diagnosis has been written as ER+ then the score would suggest it wasn't weak enough to be classed as negative. Hugs Julia
Posts.Title: bit of a ramble starting to wobble!

Posts.Content: Hi violet sky  The swelling does sound like lymphoedema especially as it lessens overnight. This is due to gravity. Whilst lying down it does relieve some what. Do you find the swelling worse later in the day? Just because it's feeling better come the morning doesn't mean you don't need to get checked out. Lymphoedema can just happen so don't think because you haven't lifted anything heavy etc it can't be that.  Hopefully you will get a diagnosis and treatment soon. Julia X
Posts.Title: Intense Pain in Back, Arm & Hand

Posts.Content: That sounds good. Lymphoedema in the arm often presents in the fingers/hand first x
Posts.Title: Intense Pain in Back, Arm & Hand

Posts.Content: I was very sleep deprived when first diagnosed but when I started chemo  I slept. After each session I would sleep pretty much for three days. It helped get me through. Sleep will come back into your life soon. You might find after the first chemo you relax a bit more as you know wha it's all about. The biggest fear of chemo is fear of the unknown. After one session it's no longer unknown.  Chemo brought in hot flushes for me so yiu may find the flushes hang around whilst on chemo. You never know though. Take care Julia xx
Posts.Title: so scared new to this

Posts.Content: A lovely post Melanie.  Thinkingbof you tomorrow heather. Check in with us to say hello when you can x
Posts.Title: Quadrantectomy and LD flap

Posts.Content: Hi TootsBess  Aaah shame you miss out on the party Amanda.  Could you manage an hour just to say hello? It will lift your spirits. Sounds all very normal and common SE of docetaxol. I got by on cocodamol but anything similar should work. Tramodol can make your mood feel worse.  I felt crap from around day three post tax until 7-9 days. To be honest you may find you don't fully recover in the three weeks like you did on FEC. are you good with keeping fluid intake to over 2 litres per day? this should help with the liver. No doubt it's working hard at the mo. You wouldn't feel up to it but I can recommend walking daily. Muscles and joints hurt when they aren't doing what they are designed to do.  just a spin round the block would help. Hope you feel better soon. love Julia x
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Hi Scotland  it is docetaxel that affects the finger and toe nails. You will know you are having this at the start  Of chemo when you are given the exact regime. To be honest it freaked me out too even though I was warned. As it happened so long after chemo had finished I wasn't prepared for anymore side effects. I hasten to add it doesn't take long for them too grow back but they look awful once fallen off And they are sore. Ouchy.  You can paint them a dark colour whilst going through docetaxel to prevent it. It didn't know this when I was going through it. In France I've read there are specific products you can use on the nails to prevent them lifting but it's not used in the uK.  I wish I could be more positive but it was quite a harrowing experience for me.  ask your oncologist what he suggests. Julia X
Posts.Title: Toes!

Posts.Content: Hi ladies  if you finished chemo with docetaxol there is a risk you will lose finger and toe nails. My finger nails came off around 6/7weeks post chemo. the process started with them being very sore.  Julia
Posts.Title: Toes!

Posts.Content: Hi franm_1962  Im sorry to read that these are your symptoms. I don't take hormonal therapies but I do know that changes in hormones (a bit like the menopause) will cause problem with memory. Is it short term memory you are having problems with? I have problems with names but found I remember things about my work Despite chemo and 11 months off.  Anxiety Could be a separate issue. When did you finish treatment? I suffered with anxiety (not depression) for around 3/4 months after treatment of which I needed counselling for to move on from it. You may find the anxiety is the primary condition and the memory loss is stemming from that. Our brains do funny things when out of balance. Explain all this to your GP and they can make a diagnosis. Medication can help anxiety but you can't beat counselling especially when trying to move on from a cancer diagnosis. Love  Julia X
Posts.Title: Urgent ****Memory loss and anxiety - Breast cancer and diabetes

Posts.Content: Hi Mr T I am sorry this is now part of your lives. Regardless, of how long the tumour may have been growing, when the word Cancer is said to you immediately think you are dying. That was me over a year ago. Now I know I am not dying.... not for a long time yet anyway! I have re-read your post a couple of times. Has cancer been confirmed via a biopise or is that the results you are getting on Thursday? The beginning is information and shock overload. You dont know what you need to know or where to begin. My tumour was 25mm (you will be given a rough size of the mass) and I was also told it would have been growing for sometime. It was only picked up because I felt it. There is no screening when you are 41 years old. Just because its been in there a while doesnt mean its bad news. You will get to know : the Grade of cancer. This tells you how fast its growing. You will also find out if it has receptors to eostrogen, progesterone and HER2. The results of these tests will dictate the specific treatment. You may also get to know if an uultrasound was done if it looks like there is lymph node involvement. Even with lymph node envolvement its not necessarily bad news either. I appreciate I am speaking a foreign language at the momemt as there are test results yet to come. Each result will bring more panic and fear but in time that will give way to getting onto treatment. You assume most people would be positive?........ I never felt postive until I saw chemo working 4 months into diagnosis and then it was haphazard. Explain your partners existing depression to the consultant. They should take that into consideration. My thoughts are with you for Thursday. Julia
Posts.Title: Partner has just been diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hello again Mr t  Body scans are common with lymph node involvement. I had one node affected but scans revealed it was only primary BC. I too had neo adjuvant chemo and had a complete response to it. Even with grade 3 BC (I'm assuming it is grade 3 as the consultant said it was fast growing) treatment can be very successful.  The wait until Tuesday will be awful for you both. The scan itself isn't nice . I wish you all the best that it's only primary BC and treatment can begin. There is always hope x
Posts.Title: Partner has just been diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Morning Maria 712  Im glad hubby came to the rescue and was able to comfort you.  He sounds like a good man. We are so volnurable going through treatment. We don't know what will happen to us and we take risks. Whilst feeling like that we can't handle being faced with cancer on the telly. It feels like its all around. It isn't it just feels like it at the time. We can't escape it. Mainly because it's on our minds 24/7.  i was off work for 11 months but read emails. I work for quite a large organisation and we have regular emails informing us employees/ex employees have passed With funeral arrangements. We were receiving them weekly to the point that it was upsetting me whilst on treatment so much I wrote to HR and said could they stop it, I found it to morbid. I was told politely no. 2.5 years on those emails don't bother me Because I no longer feel volnurable. I also feel embarrassed now for asking for them to be stopped. My dads funeral was two days before I discovered my lump. I know where you are coming from with your dad. ❤️ Cancer is all around us. 1 in 3 people and 1 in 8 people will get BC. With such a wide effect, the soaps will use it as a storyline and when we see it we do question our mortality. One thing we can't do though is compare diagnosis. We are all different.  Losing hair Is a biggie. In fact it's huge. my confidence left when my hair did . however you need a little mantra..  .... hair loss is temporary not permanant. in 2 years time, trust me, it will be a distant memory, your hair will be long again and you won't feel as volnurable. Sending hugs Julia x
Posts.Title: I think the poop has hit the fan

Posts.Content: Hi heather  I can only speak from my experience of a WLE and Axilla clearance but I definitely still had pain two weeks after surgery. In fact I'm 7 months post surgery and still get discomfort. Maybe your expectations of how quickly you would recover are a little high. Your surgeon will take a look at you Tuesday and let you know how well you are healing. It can take up to 12 months for our bodies to settle after treatment.  It can be a vicious cycle in that you get frustrated about not being able to wash your hair etc and still feel pain which affects your emotional state and vice versa. Your hormones will be all over the place which doesn't help and having a general anasthetic will also affect your mood. You also have to deal with the changes that have taken place to your body.  It sounds as though your 'friend' is feeling that you haven't supported her enough over the years and now she's making it known. Why she should make it known now when you are feeling very vulnerable is more the question. These situations bring out the best and the worsT in folk. You have to be selfish and decide who you need around you to get you through this. This friend may not be someone you should keep close at the moment. I found my best friend was the worst friend to have during treatment. She couldn't deal with any of it so kept away. That's changed the way I feel about her. We never fell out but I don't give her my all like I did before BC.  Self preservation is what it is about for you at the moment until you feel stronger again.  All the best for Tuesday. Julia x
Posts.Title: Quadrantectomy and LD flap

Posts.Content: Great stuff WORRIED2016. You got to start treatment. The finishing line is well and truely in sight xxx
Posts.Title: Starting radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Lollywg1965  Welcome the the community. i was only allowed to be discharged from hospital after they made sure I could put my bra on. They recommend you wear them 24/7 for sometime post surgery. Did you not get any assistance from nurses and is there assistance at home You can call on? post surgery I went a cup size bigger and band size bigger to take on the dressings too. Can you swap the new bras  for a bigger band size if it's too tight?  You do need to be back in the bras to help with seroma And lymphoedema risks. How are you coping with the arm/shoulder exercises? love  julia x
Posts.Title: scared to put a bra on after surger for lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Lorylinge Definitely ask about it on Wednesday. I had a definite 'hardening' of the skin next to my WLE scar but no 'lumps'. Its more than likely an effect of surgery but always worth getting a professionals opinion. As you say, you had surgery less than two weeks ago so there will still be loads of changes going on with your boob.
Posts.Title: A question for my friends

Posts.Content: Hi sister snail, if you are taking medication now (hormonal or biological therapies) it means you were oestrogen positive or Her2 positive. The treatment you have received would have all been determined on your receptor status.
Posts.Title: Cold milled flaxseeda-can you help

Posts.Content: Hi candytop  Everything happens at once huh. What bad timing for you. I would say which is the most time critical treatment? Can your teeth not wait until you have had treatment for your BC. Surely this takes priority? I had neoadjuvantt chemo and am a big advocate of having chemo first for many reasons. It's not advisable to have such major dental treatment before chemo Or as you suggest you run the risk of delay and you need to start chemo soon if you go with that first. if you have the tumour removed first you will still be looking at chemo 6-8 weeks post surgery so you then have a window for dental work but bear in mind you will be recovering from surgery and you don't want dental work to delay the commencement of chemo. do the teeth need to come out now? was your dentist able to advise when you said you were about to start treatment for bc? love Julia x
Posts.Title: Dental verses chemo before lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hello and welcome to the community Bjez. Youve joined us at a good time and I know you will find lots of support. We are all strong ladies pre cancer, i sometimes wonder if that's why we fall harder. Many of us come out the wringer the other end stronger than before. Chemo is scary, no doubt. I'm a big advocate of having chemo first. I had it first and had a complete response. I wasn't her+ though but one of our Champs Carolyn28 was. Chemo does have SE but not everyone gets them all. It really is a case of wait and see. i actually found the first session of chemo an anti climax as It was so uneventful yet had built up a horrific picture. Chemo units are so very good a putting you at ease. They look after you. Do you have a pic line in? We have a fantastic chemo club with some great information to help you plan.  https://community.macmillan.org.uk/cancer_types/breast-cancer/f/38/t/120536 With regard to anti anxiety meds I'm sure there is someone suitable but all I would say is , you will be having no end of drugs soon so you may not feel like popping more pills.  Drink lots and lots of water before the session on Friday and over 2 litres for the preceding few days.  Youll get through. You won't feel like you will but before you know it it's halfway then done. think of it as an inconvenient phase to getting your life back. love Julia x
Posts.Title: so scared new to this

Posts.Content: Hi Denise  ive just seen this video too and had to hide it from my Facebook feed. I can't describe how I felt about it but I just didn't want to have that in my face. I also had a photo of a women's torso showing MX scars and her story about how using your boobs to hold drinks cans for breast cancer awareness wasn't appropriate. Not quite sure how either of theses posts were showing how people should be more breast cancer aware!  I guess for me it's hard to see people being so blatantly open (for the whole wide world) about their situation.  I'm only three months post treatment and I'm very conscious that it's still early days in terms of staying cancer free. Maybe our sensitivity will get better in time? Julia xx
Posts.Title: Is it just me ...

Posts.Content: Jojo4 Morning.  It's natural to be terrified.  I was a wreck before my first chemo and they had to give me medication to calm me down.  I'm going for number 3 this morning and not worried at all.  Everyone is different with side effects but your doctor will do everything possible to minimise them and you will be reviewed each time.  It is definitely doable and it doesn't last forever, just a few days.  You will get through it and your inner strength will come through.  Jo xx Hope it goes well Jojo4  hugs  julia xx
Posts.Title: so scared new to this

Posts.Content: Heather you have a beautiful smiley face and I totally empathise with you feeling so low. It happened to me at the weirdest of times, when I had finished treatment. I held it together for so long it all came out in the end. I started counselling back in May and still have it and it's been so helpful for me. Originally the counselling was about my fear of dying due to the cancer but it quickly moved on to all sorts of day to day issues I have. Like you I didn't want any more drugs in my system so didn't go down the anti d route.  We are all strong ladies but that strength can wain and it's perfectly normal for that to happen. The holiday from letrozole sounds great. Sometimes you need to make those decisions just to feel better for a while.  Julia xx
Posts.Title: Quadrantectomy and LD flap

Posts.Content: Hi Lollywg1965  Welcome the the community. i was only allowed to be discharged from hospital after they made sure I could put my bra on. They recommend you wear them 24/7 for sometime post surgery. Did you not get any assistance from nurses and is there assistance at home You can call on? post surgery I went a cup size bigger and band size bigger to take on the dressings too. Can you swap the new bras  for a bigger band size if it's too tight?  You do need to be back in the bras to help with seroma And lymphoedema risks. How are you coping with the arm/shoulder exercises? love  julia x
Posts.Title: scared to put a bra on after surger for lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I too counted my blessings yesterday through sadness. A friend who was diagnosed with bowl cancer shortly after me having a bc diagnosis has had a recurrence and it's not looking favourable. She was successfully treated first time round. Nobody is immortal but having had cancer we have empathy which you can only really show through experience. make every day count. we don't need to be told. Love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Feeling sad but lucky!

Posts.Content: Unfortunately the steroids you have to take increases with taxol as you have to take them days before. I did always take mine as early as possible so they didn't affect my sleep.  I had docetaxel every three weeks. I was very nauseous with FEC which I struggled with so it was a relief when I never once felt sick with docetaxel. I also slept for a good three days post FEC even with steroids. I did find docetaxel made me ache and the worse thing was the mouth soreness, loss of taste and generally a birdcage of a mouth. FEC side effects would kick in around 8 hours post chemo but with tax I had a good three days post administration before I startzed to feeling pants.  Well done for getting your first one ticked off. X
Posts.Title: Re: Steroids

Posts.Content: Hi Audrey  i would really recommend checking with your oncologist that this was ok.  I know when I started docetaxel after FEC I was told If I hadn't taken my steroids before hand then they wouldn't administer the docetaxel. Steroids with docetaxel are for more than reducing sickness. I think docetaxel comes with more risk than AC but still I would check.  Was there a reason you didn't want to take the steroids?  Julia x
Posts.Title: Re: Steroids

Posts.Content: This happened to me on docetaxol which was caused by anemia. I was only slightly anemic but it made a big difference to me getting up the stairs. I had to stop halfway to rest!!!
Posts.Title: Taxol side effects

Posts.Content: To be honest, if you have chemo first there are no guarantees you will be able to enjoy a Christmas dinner anyway. Chemo can make you feel very sick and it alters your taste buds big time so what you once enjoyed won't taste the same. there is a risk chemo first will accelerate gum disease and cause issues but you may form the opinion due to what's happened already the dental work can wait. sounds to me the lumpectomy then teeth out is the best way to go In the hope you recover enough to have chemo within a good timeframe. Do discuss with your oncologist. Xx
Posts.Title: Dental verses chemo before lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I cringe at anything "reported" in the Daily Mail". isnt it an oncologist that suggests hormonal therapies as adjuvant treatment for BC. This implies it's not GPs who are the ones who would initially prescribe the drug. No doubt done GPs don't know what hormonal therapies are but is that stopping patients getting the treatment they need???  Food for thought. love Julia xx
Posts.Title: Interesting article in paper today

Posts.Content: Hi Always Baking   If you werent offered scans before treatment commenced your consultants didn't think there was a chance it had spread and so scans we're not required. I can't see any info on your profile page and can't remember if you had lymph node involvement? The MRI was for a specific  area wasn't iT yesterday? To do with your lower back pain? They normally only concentrate on one area. A CT scan Is used for internal organs and bone scan for bone mets obviously so when they said your MRI scan was normal, it hasn't highlighted any area of concern In the area they looked at. I had an MRI but only to the breasts specifically because I had lobular BC. If you get ongoing issues that need checking out you will be referred for the most appropriate scan. The bigger question is, how long would a all clear scan appease your anxiety? A day, a week, a month? It could turn into a vicious cycle. Trusting your body and trusting yourself to notice any changes is key and hard to do but it will happen in time. Take yesterday's scan as positive as before you went in I expect there was an element of you thinking it would be the worse outcome. The scan has reassured you there's nothing to be concerned about?  Im about to spend the afternoon in the kitchen baking, Carrot and apple cake with a cinnamon cream cheese frosting nom nom. I'm happy in my very new kitchen that has taken me over 6 months to decorate. Ho hum. Julia X
Posts.Title: Is An MRI Scan The Best Scan To check If The B.C. Has Spread ?

Posts.Content: All done.  Have a great Ride. julia xx
Posts.Title: Raising money for Macmillan - New Forest Cycletta - 20 September ...

Posts.Content: If your deemed to be at risk of developing BC how is it known that tamoxifen would do any good? Not every BC is hormonal so you could end up depleting oestrgen for no reason at all. J xx
Posts.Title: Interesting article in paper today

Posts.Content: Hi Joyce It really depends upon individual factors. People with multiple sites of tumours or very large tumours in the breast or extensive DCIS may be offered a MX as breast conservation surgery (WLE etc) wouldnt give good results. Chemo is a minefield and really is very individual. BC that are triple negative will have to have chemo regardless as at present there are no targeted therapies for it. Her2 positive BC normally means that chemo is needed to accompany herceptin. Without knowing the exact diagnosis of other peoples BC then yoiu cant really compare what treatment you are having. Saying that, I guarantee that there are contradictions between consultants across the country.
Posts.Title: Grade 2

Posts.Content: Hi Pmamummy  A bitter/metallic taste is common but I haven't heard of the salty taste or excessive thirst. I had the opposite in that I literally had to force water down.  The head in the vice sounds very familiar! After day 3 post chemo you should find you pick up and start to feel brighter. Love Julia x
Posts.Title: Side effects of EC chemotherapy?

Posts.Content: I can totally understand your disappointment Ali. We all know this to be a risk. I was told it could happen. I too wanted a mastectomy to start with but was persuaded otherwise. In my case it worked out for the best having a WLE. The thing is no one can be absolutely sure what is going on inside until the surgeon takes a look. The positive outcome is that there is another plan. They can remove your breast and remove the rest of the nasty. As they say, hind site is a great thing but we go into these battles by being 'guided' and making choice After choice. You will find strength, the same as you previously found it. This news takes time to absorb. xx
Posts.Title: Disappointment

Posts.Content: Hi Justmai  I'm sorry to read your sister is now having to deal with a secondary diagnosis. It's obviously a very rough time for you all. You are very right, none of us deserve cancer. i can't really comment on the prognosis of your sister. The information you have, is it first or second hand? The specialists may be offering words of encouragement  because they feel it can be treated again. If they thought it was untreatable that's the time to worry. We need encouragement when faced with news we don't want.  Breast cancer can reappear anywhere in the body after a primary tumour has been treated. It doesn't have to be back in the breast. Places it is sneaky in returning to are lungs, bones, head and liver. It's more than likely the affected Lymph node in her head/neck can be removed to stop cancer cells circulating around the body. I had 11 nodes removed from my Axilla as part of my original surgery. The nodes catch the cancer cells like sieves to stop them moving on.  As your sister has already had chemo they will be probably offering her a different drug than what she orinigally had. All drugs are different and she probably will keep well enough to work.... If she wished. A consultant rarely advises you can't work during chemo but it's left to the individual to see how they cope. Some folk aren't in a position to quit work Or it's important to them to continue as best they can.  the PET scan would have identified  any suspicious areas that's why the whole body gets scanned.  Telling a person to rest whilst going through cancer treatment can be counter productive to someone who is dealing with the diagnosis and doesn't want to rest and let it slow them down. It's all part of wanting to try and keep some sort of control on their lives and normality. Only your sister will know what her capabilities are during treatment. You can be there for support.  Although you need you sister, she also needs you at this time. be there to listen to her as its a very scary time. Offer help where you can and just let her know you are there for and love her. Ask her what you can do to help practically.  All the very best Julia X
Posts.Title: What to do what to say how can I help

Posts.Content: My dear zanib  all that you describe is the fault of Mr T. He packs a punch huh. When you are feeling physically unwell your mood lowers.  Use a warm salt solution and rinse your mouth regularly. Use a soft bristle brush as those gums will be very sore.  You aren't evil. Cancer isnt selective. Don't be blaming yourself. You will love and live life again. I wish I could show you in a crystal ball. I'm heading for two years post diagnosis and my life is the best it's ever been.  T makes you nails fall off. It's another side affect but normally happens after the last dose. It's very sore and unsightly. Keep them clean to avoid infections in he nail bed. Julia X
Posts.Title: when it will finish

Posts.Content: Hi moonshine  if you are questioning why you aren't having the F, your chemo nurse or onc will explain. There are a few combinations of chemo for BC. I had FEC-T which is quite common but there will be a reason why you are having only EC.  All the best for chemo. julia
Posts.Title: Post Breast Cancer operation Chemo type

Posts.Content: Hi Hawkster  its ok to feel sorry for yourself. Who hasn't felt sorry for themselves during this awful journey of ups downs, and treatment after treatment. When going through it it seems never ending.  You do need to be able to confide in someone to get this out. To tell them those real fears. You say you can't tell them how terrified you are? I had amazing support too but one special close friend who allowed me to say anything. I used that to full advantage. My BC unit had a specific surgery nurse who I met and she went through everything including many photos of surgery. I wasn't shocked just surprised at how good the results were.  I've met many people affected by cancer lately and they all say 'people say I look so well or I am so brave but inside I'm a wreck'. To most people that's how we would want to be portraied because we don't want to have a deep discussion with them about our inner feelings and thoughts. I take comments like these as compliments, like in the spirit they are given. However you will need at least one person who sees you 'and allows you to be 'warts and all'. I've had 3 months of counselling and I can't tell you enough how good it feels to talk about what I've been through. It's like I'm being given permission to let it all go.  Think of surgery as another sh&?& box ticked. A step closer to the finish line. I found surgery so much more manageable than I had expected, but I can't compare my surgery to a MX. Some of my worry was over how would I look after. I am 7 months post surgery and Im dusting off my bikinis for a holiday next month. Whilst having treatment I could not envisage a holiday ever again.  You will get through surgery but you need to talk about your fears now. There is three more weeks to go and that's a long time of anxiety and worry which as you are saying, is having a knock on effect with sleep etc.  julia x
Posts.Title: Struggling on the inside

Posts.Content: Hello loupielou  I know how you feel about the camping out bit. Not only did I have a new kitchen but an extension to put the new kitchen in and for months I didn't even have a cooker And a postage stamp size work top. It's my pride and joy and a something that was only able to happen as I got breast cancer! Sounds weird but I had an insurance policy and was able to get my dream kitchen.  Every cloud huh...  The first holiday I had abroad after treatment had me really nervous but it ended up being just perfect and what I needed. I took emergency antibiotics with me as I've had Axilla clearance but had no problems at all. My skin was also well behaved in the sun but I did use a factor 50 on the affected boob.  Im off to Menorca Friday with my family.... The first family Holiday since I was diagnosed ❤️. A new kitchen and a holiday ..... Perfect . Julia xx
Posts.Title: Is An MRI Scan The Best Scan To check If The B.C. Has Spread ?

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies I wasn't aware that there are 4 grades of BC. I thought there were only 3. The stages of cancer are different however. I am a grade 2. The grades indicate how different the cells are from normal cells and gives and indication of how fast they will multiply. Grade 2 cells are not as fast growing as grade 3 cells. Stages of BC are measured on tumour size and how far the BC has travelled (lymph nodes, other organs etc)
Posts.Title: Grade 2

Posts.Content: I can totally understand your disappointment Ali. We all know this to be a risk. I was told it could happen. I too wanted a mastectomy to start with but was persuaded otherwise. In my case it worked out for the best having a WLE. The thing is no one can be absolutely sure what is going on inside until the surgeon takes a look. The positive outcome is that there is another plan. They can remove your breast and remove the rest of the nasty. As they say, hind site is a great thing but we go into these battles by being 'guided' and making choice After choice. You will find strength, the same as you previously found it. This news takes time to absorb. xx
Posts.Title: Disappointment

Posts.Content: Hi dl99  Picc lines can be uncomfortable for the first 24 hours or so as you get use to them but being sore enough for pain relief sounds a bit severe. I was advised to have a warm hot water bottle put on it to help. i found it a pain at night but only for the first two nights. If the picc hole looks inflammed and/or red or your arm feels warm to touch or swollen you may have a problem So seek advice.  I don't think anyone of us could say we looked forward to chemo. It's a means to an end of BC and takes 4 months out of your life but you can make up for that lost time when you finish treatment. join in with the monthly chemo chat room where you can share your chemo journey. All the best. Julia X
Posts.Title: Pick line
